fields.headline: Such Keane value
fields.standfirst: Gordon Strachan sold Robbie Keane yesterday. What price the rest?
fields.trailText: Figo's transfer was more to do with politics than football. But what has it done to the value of the Premiership's top performers now?
fields.body:
It's frightening how much the transfer market has evolved since I've been in management. Fees and salaries have gone absolutely crazy. If you'd have asked any manager three years ago if they would have considered today's figures they would have said you were absolutely off your head.

Figo's transfer was more to do with politics than football. But what has it done to the value of the Premiership's top performers now? My post-Figo estimates of the most valuable player for each Premiership club ignores Overmars, as I think £25 million is a vastly inflated deal. When you're assessing a player all you think about is whether he's hungry and if he wants to get better. Settling on a price depends upon how much your team needs a player. When I had Robbie Keane, if I was interested in another striker I wouldn't have spent too much because I had Robbie. If I'm desperate for someone - and that club know you are - then the price goes up. (By the way, my £20 million Keane valuation may be in my imagination!)

Losing him was the biggest disappointment since I came to the club. The decision was outside my jurisdiction. It's part of a manager's remit to know the market for when these things happen, to have a number of targets ready just in case. This is the worst possible timing for us. It's a disappointment because if I'm going to be a good manager I need good players.

At Coventry we've not got the history to attract top players to come here so we have to pay them a lot of money. It's very hard for us.

ARSENAL

Patrick Vieira £25m

He can do everything - tackle, run forward, head, score goals. He's the best all-round player in the country.

ASTON VILLA

Ugo Ehiogu £8m

He gives Villa the ability to commit more players to attack because he defends so brilliantly.

BRADFORD CITY

Dave Wetherall £5m

He scores very important goals from set pieces, as was seen last season when his goal against Liverpool kept them up.

CHARLTON ATHLETIC

John Robinson £8m

He can play anywhere in the midfield and he'll score a goal.

CHELSEA

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink £15m

He's what they have been look ing for, somebody who is going to score them 25 goals a season.

COVENTRY CITY

Robbie Keane £20m

The club already missed him in training the day he went to Milan for talks. I have got to try to replace him with players who will make the squad feel a bit better.

DERBY COUNTY

Rory Delap £5m

Can play right back, right side of midfield, they can stick him up front. Fantastic attitude.

EVERTON

Kevin Campbell £7m

Made a big difference, saving Everton from relegation.

IPSWICH TOWN

Richard Wright £6m

We'll find out how good he is now he's getting his chance in the Premiership.

LEEDS UNITED

Harry Kewell £20-25m

He's a top player, one of the players of last season without a doubt. If Leeds get to a European final he could become established as a world-class player.

LEICESTER CITY

Neil Lennon £10m

He wins the ball, doesn't give it away, possesses great enthusiasm and he's cunning.

LIVERPOOL

Steven Gerrard £15m

I was surprised he didn't play more for England in the European Championship. He's got everything: energy, bravery and passing ability.

MANCHESTER CITY

Nicky Weaver £5m

Doesn't lack confidence. A young goalkeeper making his Premiership debut, I think he'll be looking forward to it.

MANCHESTER UNITED

David Beckham £35-40m

Creates more chances than anybody else in the British league. The number of crosses, and goals he makes from crosses, make frightening statistics.

MIDDLESBROUGH

Mark Schwarzer £8m

Abig presence for them. When he's playing well the confidence spreads though the team and they are a different side.

NEWCASTLE UNITED

Alan Shearer £15m

Last year when Robson came along he found his legs again and he's stretching people. I think he'll benefit from retiring from the England scene.

SOUTHAMPTON

Marian Pahars £5m

When you play against him you take notice of him. He can beat people, has a good turn of pace and can score outstanding goals.

SUNDERLAND

Kevin Phillips £20m

Goalscorer plus attitude equals top player. They trailed 3-0 against us last year but he and Niall Quinn kept fighting and it ended 3-2.

TOTTENHAM HOTSPUR

Sol Campbell £10m

Great passer of the ball but most importantly does what every manager, especially George Graham, likes: enjoys defending.

WEST HAM UNITED

Paolo Di Canio £?

I love watching him, but there's more to it than that. There are entertainers and there are players, and he's a player. I've not a clue what price to put on him because of his age and the baggage he brings along. His price depends on how daft the manager who is buying him is.

webTitle: Forget those crazy fees, it's the cast list that matters

fields.headline: Forget those crazy fees, it's the cast list that matters
fields.standfirst: Will Buckley says fans need not fret about transfer dramas
fields.trailText: Fans should cease fretting about transfer dramas and start treating star players like members of a soap opera.
fields.body:
There was a moment last season when Chelsea supporters wondered if the game had gone not mad but... a bit odd.

The club had bought an unfeasibly starry array of strikers (Gianfranco Zola, Mark Hughes, Gianluca Vialli, Tore Andre Flo, Pierlugi Casiraghi) and Chris Sutton, yet not one of them had managed, or even looked like threatning, to score 20 League goals in a season. It was then that Colin Hutchinson presumably thought 'bollocks to all that' and telephoned AC Milan to see if George Weah was available to help out.

The George Weah - sometime World Footballer of the Year. Six years previously, the crowd had been singing 'Steino, There's Only One Steino' (repeat for as long as appropriate), now they were pondering over their pints whether the gaffer should pick Weah. A quite spectacular change in circumstances.

George came. George did some pretty clever things with a football. George pocketed his 40 grand a week. And George went. It was as if Sydney Poitier had turned up for a guest spell on EastEnders. An analogy that is near perfect for now more than ever football resembles a soap opera.

As with Coronation Street , the major players have moved effortlessly from the back of the paper to the front, taking in 12-page spreads in Hello! along the way. Bet Lynch leaves The Street - hold the front page: Overmars leaves The Arse - that's one helluva news story. As with Emmerdale, Arsenal have suffered from their own version of the airplane wipe-out. In the time it takes to read a fanzine, Marc Overmars, Manu Petit, Davor Suker and, stalwart of the Highbury Arms, Nigel Winterburn have all been written out of the script.

And this is where football could run into problems. Forget the wage packets involved for they are irrelevant. Did any fan of EastEnders ever care what Angie and Den were paid? Of course not - they weren't doing the paying. The only people who gave a jot were Angie and Den, their agents and the person at the BBC responsible for writing the cheque. Same with football. Marcel Desailly is paid 40 grand a week and Ken Bates has to pick up the tab. The heart bleeds.

Forget, also, the size of the fees for they too are irrelevant. Football is simply going through the kind of crazy inflationary period that often afflicts the property market. What is important is the difference between what you receive and what you pay. Getting £15 million (or whatever) for Overmars makes little difference if you have to shell out £15 million for Wiltord.

Worry instead about the cast list. The Emmerdale disaster allowed them to clear out the old hams and bring in some lively talent. It worked. As it has on occasions for football clubs. But there is a limit to how often you can pull off this trick without leaving your audience bewildered. Do it too often and the season-ticket holder will start to resemble the fairweather fan staring at the pitch and having to ask, 'Who's the big lad up front?'

And once he is reduced to that state it might cross his mind that the game is no longer worth the candle.

fields.headline: Second rate
fields.standfirst: Perhaps now we can see the true, lowly worth of the Premiership
fields.trailText: With all this money sloshing around Europe, perhaps now we can see the true, lowly worth of the Premiership.
fields.body:
The best thing about the world transfer record being smashed to smithereens, apart from the sheer sanity of being able to read about football again and stop having to pretend an interest in the eccentricities of golfers or athletes, is that someone always wheels out a list of the most expensive players in history.

Looking at the current top 20, the under-representation of English football, fond of imagining it has one of the most exciting and prosperous leagues in the world, is startlingly obvious. Only one English player figures, Alan Shearer in joint sixteenth place, and his £15m move was between two Premiership clubs. Just one other English club gets a mention, Chelsea having just equalled Newcastle United's 1996 splash on Shearer to pick up Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, which is not something anyone would have predicted four years ago.

The picture changed slightly when Barcelona handed over some of their Luis Figo millions for Arsenal's Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit, but even then it was not the English players in the big-money charts or an English club doing the buying. The conspiracy theory currently doing the rounds about Sir Alex Ferguson preparing the ground for selling David Beckham by unnecessarily raking over last season's controversy, when he was dropped for missing training, values the player at around £40m of Barcelona's or Milan's money, but at this stage is somewhat fanciful.

Ferguson appears to have made an uncharacteristic blunder by reopening a matter he promised would stay closed, but is unlikely to have an ulterior motive, much less a machiavellian masterplan. If Manchester United (and their new chief executive, Peter Kenyon) wanted to sell Beckham, they would do so without worrying too much about the player's feelings or their supporters' opinions.

Any footballer, and Figo's new fencing price of £110m proves he is no exception, is always on the market. It just depends on the size of the offer, and if United receive a satisfactory one for Beckham it is hard to imagine their decisive manager or their frugal plc doing anything other than conducting the business first and saving the explanations for later.

If sending Beckham to Italy or Michael Owen to Spain is the only way England can make an impression on the international transfer market it makes claims that the Premiership is in any way superior to other European leagues look even more ridiculous. How come English clubs never splash the cash like their continental rivals? We are constantly being told Manchester United are the most profitable football club on earth, yet when they inquired after Figo they quickly decided they couldn't afford him. Real Madrid, protected from bankruptcy by a long list of wealthy and powerful individuals, are unworried by debts of over £100m and not in the habit of living within their means.

Yet even if Real's audacious capture (moved by their president Florentino Perez) of their main rivals' best player is regarded as a one-off, that still leaves a lot of big-money deals around Europe that have passed the Premiership by. English clubs have talked about the Batistutas, the Verons, the Rivaldos and the Trezeguets, but apart from Arsène Wenger's astute purchase of a young Nicolas Anelka, Hasselbaink is the only overseas player in the top 20 to have been landed by a Premiership team.

It all seemed so different four years ago, when Newcastle's splurge on Shearer not only shocked English football but set a world transfer record. Back then, the Premiership was only four years old and growing in confidence with every passing season. English football fans observed the arrival of players such as Fabrizio Ravanelli and Roberto di Matteo on absurdly inflated salaries and wondered whether the old order was changing and the Premiership was at last about to challenge the financial might of Serie A .

The first Match of the Day of the new season featured a Ravanelli hat-trick against Liverpool and a goal from the halfway line against Wimbledon by Beckham, a young player who had not even figured in Euro 96. There seemed no end to the promise or ambition of the Premiership, which is why Shearer's solitary slide down the table of top deals over the last four years strikes an accusatory note. For new dawn read false dawn.

Italian and Spanish clubs always used to monopolise the major signings, with England looking on with a mixture of envy and incredulity, and nothing much has changed. Now, more than ever, the Premiership appears just a new way to dress up leftovers.

Maybe English supporters do not want to see their underachieving heroes rewarded any more lavishly than they already are. It is just possible that Premiership clubs have struck the right balance between realism and irresponsibility and should continue cutting their cloth sensibly and leaving the fancy window-dressing to the continentals. All these arguments have merit, but are undermined by the fact that leading Premiership clubs are making more money than ever before, without spending it.

The question supporters should be asking is the same one people now ask of the boom years between the wars, when stadiums were filled to watch players whose wages were capped at a pitiful level. What happens to all the surplus income? There is precious little surplus in Italy or Spain, since it all goes to servicing the debt or buying the next superstar. This may make accountants blanche, but the whole point of football clubs is to exist outside the workaday world and you don't find many fans complaining.

English clubs, on the other hand, have turned themselves into mini industries where accountants have the upper hand. 'To say Manchester United and other leading British clubs cannot compete with Europe is wrong, because they can,' said Jason Zillwood, of the financial advisers Deloitte & Touche. 'But generally they choose not to, because they have more responsibilities. There are plcs with stock market valuations to consider. A lot more business acumen is involved.'

Responsibilities? Stock market valuations? When did it become a virtue for clubs to have an invisible corporate tier between the players and the fans, binding the manager's hands in the transfer market and creaming off a proportion of the profits? When people used to say football needed to be run more like a business, what they meant was that they deserved to be run less like Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory. They did not mean football should be turned into business, which is what seems to have happened. For all the grandiose claims advanced on its behalf there is not much bravery any more in the plc-led Premiership. If the knock-on effect of Figo's move produces anything like the predicted player drain, there will shortly be little glamour left either.

fields.headline: What is unfair sacking worth?
fields.standfirst: I was fired three months ago by the bank I worked for after a gross misconduct hearing. My trade union made an unfair dismissal claim on my behalf and we might be able to reach a settlement. But how much should I ask for?
fields.trailText: I was fired three months ago by the bank I worked for after a gross misconduct hearing. My trade union made an unfair dismissal claim on my behalf and we might be able to reach a settlement. But how much should I ask for?
fields.body:
The cap on an unfair dismissal claim is £50,000. You need to present a coherent and apparently objective argument which shows how long you might be out of work and, therefore, your likely loss of earnings. You need to take into account your age, status, location and the availability of other jobs.

If you are 57, for instance, you will find it much harder to get another job in the ageist world of banking than if you are 23.

Ideally, you would be able to say that you have already applied for jobs and been turned down. A solicitor doing a thorough job on your case might ask you to be assessed by a local recruitment agency who could produce an objective, written report saying how long they think it would take you to find work again.

If you conclude that it will take you a year to get a new job at the same level, then you could ask for one year's salary.

 Legal advice from Pinsent Curtis.

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: Taking the magic out of options

fields.headline: Taking the magic out of options
fields.standfirst:
The profits masseur of the new economy is out of control, says Simon Caulkin 
                            Taking the magic out of options
fields.trailText: A discussion paper by the Accounting Standards Board on 'share-based payment' may not sound like the stuff of high corporate drama. But make no mistake: in its excruciating prose, the ASB document lays out the script for one of capitalism's first big battles of this millennium.
fields.body:
A discussion paper by the Accounting Standards Board on 'share-based payment' may not sound like the stuff of high corporate drama. But make no mistake: in its excruciating prose, the ASB document lays out the script for one of capitalism's first big battles of this millennium.

The issue is that totem of the new economy, stock options. Stock options, conferring the right to buy a company's shares some time in the future at today's prices, have become an article of faith for the remuneration and payment policies of technology companies. 'If Silicon Valley is the economic engine of the world, options are the fuel,' the new conventional wisdom has it.

There's no mystery, of course, as to why options should appeal to employees: as investors of human capital in today's knowledge-driven companies, they have as much claim to corporate equity as investors of financial capital. Internet guru Manuel Castells calls options 'the currency of the new economy'. The Government seems to agree, making it progressively easier for small and medium-sized companies to give out options and shares.

But altruism is not why companies too are hooked on options. No, the main reason they make hard-hearted finance directors drool is that in accounting terms they have a truly magical property: they don't exist. The legerdemain works like this. Because options typically don't have a cash value when they're granted, they appear to be free of cost. So no charge is recorded in the accounts. Of course, when employees exercise their options at some time in the future, even this non-existent instrument turns out to have a cost - but it is hidden away in the balance sheet. In the United States, it even rates as an expense that can be charged against tax.

The practical result of all this is that, far from options causing companies a financial hit, they can be used as a sort of financial supercharger. First, by loading employees up with 'free' options, firms keep salaries down and thus reported profits up. Then, the reduced tax charge triggered by the option exercise provides a useful secondary thrust. Finally, the circle is completed by regular share buy-backs to cancel out the dilution (from the new shares in circulation) that would otherwise result in tell-tale lower earnings per share. Buy-backs do not affect the profit and loss account, of course, but they do boost the share price and the value of the options and the spiral starts all over again.

This is what a past treasurer of Microsoft, an inveterate options user, approvingly termed the 'virtuous cycle' of stock options. For Microsoft and its imitators, options do not just keep employees happy; they are at the very core of their financial systems. As the stock-option phenomenon has snowballed, however, others reckon that the cycle is not so much virtuous as artificial and dan gerously self-serving. Critics - including investment expert Warren Buffett - claim an out-of-control stock-option tail is now wagging the corporate dog off the ground.

It's not just the gross amounts of money that have been handed out to undeserving executives. Stock option windfalls have been the unspoken agenda behind many a megamerger, and the not-so-hidden motive behind dotcoms whose business plan starts and ends with a 'liquidity event' (that is, an initial public offering). In this way stock options have contributed generously to the swelling stock market bubble. All this can be traced back to a hole in company accounts where options should be.

It is now so large as to cause many annual reports to give investors a false impression of companies' real financial condition. London investment adviser Andrew Smithers estimates that restating the net profits of the largest US companies to take full account of their options would reduce their 1998 figures by more than half. Bear Stearns, a US investment bank, found that operating profits for computer networking companies would be reduced by 26 per cent under a different form of option accounting.

This is the muddle of silence, obfuscation and near-deceit that the ASB is trying to unravel - without destroying the device's legitimate uses. In the circumstances, any solution will be controversial. Colin Paterson, a partner at specialist adviser RM2, complains that under the ASB's chosen formula, valuations of quoted companies could suffer from a double hit to earnings per share (since reported profits would fall, while the number of shares in circulation went up).

Nonetheless, most investors will strongly favour the initiative. It's 'on the side of the angels,' says Smithers. Alan MacDougall of Pensions and Investment Research Consultants agrees. Both see the proposal as a firm signal of support for a UK investing culture that has so far averted the worst scandals and abuses that have disfigured the US scene. Smithers gives short shrift to the despicable argument that telling the truth about options will mean the end of the entrepreneurial economy as we know it - in other words, that it is better to keep investors in the dark.

Rarely has the battle so clearly been between what's right and what's convenient, he believes. In any case, the expedient is a mirage: 'Belief in miracles leads to pain and perdition,' he says. 'In due course people will realise it hasn't led to wealth creation but to wealth stealing.' While there will now be a consultation period for reactions to the ASB draft, the chances of getting something on the regulatory books in the UK seem fairly good.

This would then be a precedent to take the battle to other territories where the ASB has a remit, including Australia, New Zealand, and the US. The latter, of course, will be a much harder nut to crack. Bob Monks, the doyen of American activist investors, says baldly that while the ASB draft ought to have an effect in the US, 'under the prevailing "corporate hegemony" it will not have an impact'.

webTitle: Don't give way to the summertime blues

fields.headline: Don't give way to the summertime blues
fields.standfirst: No sobbing out, get off the couch and put your career on the road
fields.trailText: No sobbing out, get off the couch and put your career on the road
fields.body:
University is over, exams are over and it may well seem that the good times are over too and that summer is a time to get tanked up because nothing will ever be the same again. If you've got a job lined up for September or even if you haven't, putting your life on hold for six weeks to bum around might seem like a good thing to do.

But take a reality check. That autumn deadline looms and your bank balance is a debt mountain, so there may be other options for the summer months. Everyone in the careers advice field says enjoy yourself but put the fun time to good use as well.

Irene Krechowieka, author of Net that Job, says have fun while you job hunt but add to your skills base and don't despair if you don't have a job.

The summer can provide excellent opportunities. Obviously unpaid work experience can be an excellent route into the job of your dreams, or you can go out temping and get the experience of working in different places.

Krechowieka also believes that many smaller and medium-sized companies aren't fully geared into the graduate recruitment cycle or they may have sudden unexpected vacancies to fill. "Look wider than the big employers and investigate. Don't feel you have missed the boat," she says.

Andrea Shavick, author of Landing your First Job, agrees. "Some of the advantages of working for small to medium employers are more responsibility earlier on, a chance to work directly with directors, opportunities to learn all aspects of how a business works, reasonable starting salaries and a chance to be a big fish in a small pond.

"It is also much easier to land a job with an SME because their recruitment processes are usually simpler. Most rely on a couple of interviews and that's it."

Small and medium-sized companies can be a business of up to 50 people or with a turnover of £20m so some are quite sizeable.

SME recruitment fairs are also growing in popularity, says Shavick, so be on the lookout for these and trawl the ads in the national, regional and specialist press.

And, of course, there is the net. Irene Krechowieka says be cautious about some of the sassy new employment sites on the web - they promise to deliver, but do they have the goods?

She recommends the BBC's Job Jungle and also thinks you should do some company research by visiting their sites to find out more about them.

"Employers' websites can be a rich source of jobs," she says. "And employers will be impressed by people who are motivated enough to go looking for them."

Some can let you apply on-line. Hewlett Packard, for example has an application form on its site which is speculative and will be held by them for six months. "Work is not the only option, " she says. "There's volunteering, a year out or further study."

Summer is a good time to review your skills, says Paul Redmond of ADCAS and head of careers at Liverpool Hope University. And keep in touch with careers services - you can use your local university's advice centre - and check out the website.

"Take small risks," advises Redmond. "Step outside your comfort zone and do something different during the summer which will make you stand out from other candidates. And network - everybody who is in a job, knows about a job vacancy"

And finally ... don't become a slacker. Don't go home and spend the next eight weeks chilling out in front of the TV.

Enjoy yourself, yes, says the Graduate Recruiters' Association's Carl Gilleard, but it's a balancing act. "Keep active and productive," he advises. "Home is not the real world and there can be a sense of disconnectedness."

You have been a part of a community ever since you started school and now you're on your own, so don't isolate yourself.

Gilleard points to the danger of a rapid loss of confidence if you hang about at home, undecided about your future. "You lose your sense of perspective," he says" and decisions which should be simple to make become big issues. You have just graduated and your brain is toned up, keep it that way."

And don't spend all day in bed - remember the world of work is during daylight hours, so you'd better start getting used to it.

webTitle: Put yourself in the frame for that job abroad

fields.headline: Put yourself in the frame for that job abroad
fields.standfirst: How CV styles vary around the world
fields.trailText: How CV styles vary around the world
fields.body:
Two weeks in Tuscany might persuade you to ditch life in the UK and go European in search of a job; a weekend in the Big Apple could lure you Stateside for employment. That's fine, but don't fall at the first fence by making a mess of your application.

You may know everything there is to know about German beer fests, but do you know what sort of CV to submit to a banker in Frankfurt? And what would the French or Americans expect from you? We may live in a global village, but subtle cultural differences still apply, says the European Business School's Simon Hamm.

And although Britain is part of Europe, it takes its business philosophy from America - the "can do" marketing mindset which does not always go down too well with our continental partners.

And another big problem for us Brits is our ineptitude with other people's languages. Catherine Gilbert of careers advisers Drake Beam Marin says European employers have a less good perception of UK graduates because of this.

So, if you do have language skills you must highlight them as well as any foreign experience, travel or multicultural experience.

"Your CV should show that you are someone who is open to new cultures and to new ideas," she says. "Highlight any work you have done abroad, even a summer holiday job and also highlight any valid experience which has a multicultural aspect, whether it's work or voluntary activity."

Elizabeth Marx, from headhunters Norman Broadbent and author of Breaking Through Culture Shock advises plenty of preparation if you are looking for an international career.

"If you decide to apply for a job in a different country it is advisable to adapt your application to the style of the country," she says.

Even in Europe there are enormous differences. French companies will expect you to send a hand-written cover letter. They are very keen on graphology. Gilbert says as a general rule requests for handwritten cover letters usually indicate that graphology will be one of the tests applied by an employer.

French companies also expect you to list personal interests and any languages you speak. You would do a standard CV layout and might be asked to include a photograph.

German companies on the other hand, expect you to include a photograph with your CV. German CVs differ a lot from British versions, because applicants are have to include other information.

"You present your CV in a binder," says Catherine Gilbert, "and include copies of all your education certificates and any references from former employers. "German applicants include things which in Britain would not be considered appropriate until the offer stage."

German companies will not want to know about your personal interests, says Elisabeth Marx, "but German applicants often include their parents' details and occupations."

But despite all this rigour, German CVs are less likely to follow a clear structure and format. Italy and Spain are strong on networking, says Simon Hamm, and much of Italy's economy is built on the small to medium family-owned company. So if you are looking for a career in these countries one of the best moves is actually to go there and meet people.

"If you don't know the language but are willing to learn, Italians can accept that," he adds. Italy has a paternalistic culture and trust is very important, so is dressing well and having good manners at the interview.

Scandinavian cultures, especially Norwegians, would frown on a self-centred CV which seeks to sell the individual with all those marketing buzzwords like "passionate", "committed" and so on. "Norwegians expect you to be more reticent and not to overplay your achievements," says Hamm.

Although US marketing mindset dominates British business culture, there are still some very important differences when you put together a CV for an American company.

Much of what Brits bung in CVs would be illegal in the States. The rule of thumb is to exclude anything which might give prospective employers a chance to discriminate against you, warns Marie Finrite from Drake Beam Marin.

This means you exclude personal details such as age, sex or marital status. Nor do you mention your driving licence if you have one. And never, ever include a photograph -more grounds for potential discrimination.

The aim of an American CV - known as a resumé - is to show you can do the job. Including personal interests is a matter of debate, says Finrite, but she recommends including them if they are relevant.

"Make your CV extremely skills focussed," she says. "Your resumé is a marketing tool and not an historical perspective."

Stick to one or two pages and use bullet points. Usually education comes at the end, but if you are a recent graduate that is a strength so put that at the top. "An American resumé is very impersonal, " says Finrite, "you are being hired on the basis of your skills."

If your CV hits the job spot then don't be surprised to get a phone call from the company, often in the evening, as part of a screening process.

Interviews are when you will be judged as a person and Finrite recommends you research the company and its culture. One big plus with American companies is that they generally don't use psychometric testing - the discrimination thing again - but expect to be taken round on a beauty parade and introduced to the team.

Finrite warns that British reticence can work against you. "It can be interpreted as lacking initiative or aggression," she says. "So bear this in mind at an interview. Lean forward, make eye contact and be a little assertive."

Her final advice ? "If you are thinking of working in the States talk to an American first."

fields.headline: Cool Companies
fields.standfirst: No 38 Aston Martin Lagonda
fields.trailText: No 38 Aston Martin Lagonda
fields.body:
Automation, robotics may be the buzzwords in the 21st century's volume car production - but when it comes to Aston Martin every car is hand built by highly skilled people who care. Their dedication is in the detail, and their very senses that craft and hone every Aston Martin - sight, feel and touch - live on in the finished car, as an enduring reminder of rare skills.

This does not mean that Aston Martin does not keep abreast of the development in motor engineering. Take its latest and best selling model the DB7 Volante, a convertible, with a steel underframe, body panels and bonnet. Composite front wings, sills, boot lid and front and rear bumper/aprons and side impact protection in doors. Fully-lined electrically operated hood with heated glass rear screen.

Under the bonnet is an all alloy twin overhead cam 24 valve in-line 6 cylinder 3.2 litre engine delivering a compression ratio of 8.3:1 moving from 0 to 100mph in 6 seconds, complete with a fully catalysed exhaust system. And inside the car it comes with CFC-free automatic climate control system the state-of-the-art six speaker audio facility with multi-disc CD autochanger.

Unlike a conventional car plant, time isn't an enemy, at Aston Martin it is a friend. There's time enough, to produce a perfect motor to maintain its legendary standards.

It is doubtful if any car maker has drawn as much strength from its employees and customers as Aston Martin. Owners, employees and admirers are enthusiasts to the core, an extended family that stretches around the globe.The sense of family is strong at Aston Martin with a number of father/son teams employed in its workshops.

Aston Martin buyers' children have grown up alongside their parent's prized motor and later become owners themselves. In more than 80 years a little over 14,000 cars have been made.

Such has been the success and popularity of the Aston Martin DB7 Volante, with customers in 31 countries, it is now the most successful and popular Aston Martin of all time exceeding the combined production of the famous DB5 as driven by James Bond and the DB6 models.

Founded in 1914 by Lionel Martin and Robert Bamford in a small West London workshop, Aston Martin has since grown to become a world renowned manufacturer of exclusive, luxury sports cars. From its manufacturing base in Newport Pagnell and the new DB7 facility in Bloxham, Aston Martin continues to produce only to individual order.

If you have got an outstanding engineering, science or technology degree and have built up a track record in car production watch out for its recruitment adverts or write to Les Kelland, the human resource director at Aston Martin Lagonda Ltd, Tickford Street, Newport Pagnell, Milton Keynes, MK16 9 AN.

From its manufacturing base in Newport Pagnell and the new DB7 facility in Bloxham, Aston Martin continues to produce only to individual order. If you have got an outstanding engineering, science or technology degree and have built up a track record in car production watch out for its recruitment adverts or write to Les Kelland, the human resource director at Aston Martin Lagonda Ltd, Tickford Street, Newport Pagnell, Milton Keynes, MK16 9 AN.

webTitle: How to ... act the part to perfection

fields.headline: How to ... act the part to perfection
fields.standfirst: Promotion or new job - we all stage a big production number to show we can do the biz
fields.trailText: Promotion or new job - we all stage a big production number to show we can do the biz Promotion or new job - we all stage a big production number to show we can do the biz
fields.body:
Having a new job is great, says Kate Carolson, recently promoted to account director for a big PR company. "The only problem is that half of me constantly thinks that one day someone's going to come up to me, say its all been a mistake and ask me to leave. I have a real fear of being found out as a fraud - logically I know that I've got the experience and the know-how to do the job, but I still can't quite believe I can pull it off."

Most of us have, at some time or another, felt exactly the same way - the heady feeling of excitement at being awarded a promotion or new responsibility, mixed with a slight edge of disbelief and a - usually totally ungrounded - fear that you don't actually deserve it. "It's all about confidence," believes psychologist Ben Williamson. "It's natural to worry a little how you're going to manage a new set of responsibilities - but it's important to have enough confidence to be able to reassure yourself that you'll cope."

Gaining confidence can be tricky, but it's not just about standing in front of the mirror and repeatedly telling yourself that you're great. Confidence comes from a variety of sources - how you dress, how you communicate and how you present yourself - as well as how you feel inside. Fortunately, the first three are far easier to do something about.

"For the first couple of weeks I felt completely like a fish out of water," says Carolson, "and I also felt that everyone looked smarter and more together than me. With my first pay cheque I went out and bought two new suits, had an expensive haircut and bought some decent make-up. It might sound superficial, but it really helped - suddenly I felt confident about how I looked - and that helped lift my self-esteem in other areas."

According to Laurel Herman, whose company Positive Presence deals with how to put your best image across, gaining confidence in the workplace is all about how you appear. "It's not just about how you look - although obviously an immaculate appearance is going to contribute to an air of professionalism," she says. "It's also about how you come across - and that's a mix between being positive and in-control, and not being too over-confident. If you swagger in being too cocksure one of two things will happen - people will either see through it and realise it's an act, or they will simply think you're arrogant."

In theory, it all sounds like common sense, but in reality it can be a hard balancing act to pull off - particularly if you're trying to learn new skills or areas of responsibility at the same time. "When I got promoted I was the youngest spokesperson working for our organisation," says Charles Jordan, who works for a large business institute.

"I was determined to seem up to the job, so I was always the first to volunteer for anything, to offer an opinion in a meeting, to come up with new ideas. I was worried that if I didn't look like I was firing on all cylinders all the time, people would think I couldn't do it. In the end no-one thought that, but they did all think I was the most annoying person in the office."

Jordan has a point - no-one is more annoying in office life than the person who constantly tries too hard, and no-one is more consistently perceived as insecure about their position.

"The simplest way of overcoming anxiety is simply to look at the facts," believes Ben Williamson. "No-one is promoted, or given more responsibility because they are bad at their job, or unprofessional. Neither does it happen through luck. If you accept the fact that you have been rewarded for working competently and confidently, then your faith in your own abilities will soon rise."

If you truly believe that you can't change the way you feel inside, then concentrate on the differences you can make. Buy an expensive new suit, get a haircut, have some new business cards printed. Concentrate on your body language - if you fidget, try and stop it, if you feel you talk too much, try and be more concise and think what you want to put across. "Getting the right image is like doing a jigsaw puzzle," says Laurel Herman, "all the different pieces need to fit together. It can take time but, what is certain, is that once you get one thing right, the others come more easily. If you feel confident in how you look, you will communicate better, others will respond better, and so it goes on."

If you don't remember anything else...

There is a great saying; Be brave. If you can't be brave, pretend. Most people don't know the difference. Look smart, be positive and remind yourself that no-one needs convincing of anything. Except you.

fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.trailText: Whale watching | Angel Falls and Orinoco | Egypt
fields.body:
Europe

Britain: a whale-watching trip with a difference. This eight-day break enables guests to join a research vessel to study a resident population of minke whales, which return to the Hebridean Sea each summer to feed and raise their calves. The price is £498pp (based on two sharing) and includes seven nights' B&B, Oban-Mull ferry, four days' whale-watching and full-day land safari. Departure August 12 or September 9. Discover The World (01737 218800)

France: Provençal farmhouse, sleeps eight, on the outskirts of Courthezon, close to Avignon. Departs August 5. Price is £1,875 including ferry or Eurotunnel. Vacances in Campagne (0870 0771771).

A 12-night holiday on a permanent camp-site on the Côte D'Azur with supervised games for children. Between August 12-17 cost for a family - up to six - is £914, inc car ferry. Canvas Holidays (0870 9022022)

Spain: a three-night break in Seville at the three-star Hotel America & Derby costs £282pp in August (must travel Friday - Sunday and stay Sunday night). Travelscene (0870 7774445).

Turkey: two weeks' holiday staying at the Alinda Hotel, Dalyan, B&B, departing August 4 from Gatwick or Manchester, Price is £399pp. Jewel in the Crown Holidays (01293 533338).

Cephalonia: two weeks, departing August 27, staying in self-catering apartments with pools in quiet villages. Price is £299pp. Details Direct Line Holidays (020-8239 3399)

Middle East

Egypt: a 14-day Nile and Beyond tour taking in all the must-see sights of Egypt. Departing August 31, September 21 and later dates, the cost is £710pp. Guerba (0870 0549199).

South America

Angel Falls and Orinoco: Explore Worldwide offers a 15-day non-trekking adventure in the more remote regions of Venezuela. First, the group explores the maze of channels and creeks that form the Orinoco Delta, before travelling by river on a four-day boat-trip to skirt the table-top mountain of Auyan-Tepui and marvel at the world's highest waterfall - the Salto Angel (Angel Falls). In addition, there is an opportunity to relax on the idyllic Caribbean beaches of Chichirivichi. Availability on September 2 departure for £1,550pp. Explore Worldwide (01252 760100).

Cruise

Mediterranean: a 14-night trip on P&O's Victoria, including visits to Mykonos, Bodrum, Heraklion, Corfu, Dubrovnik, Venice, Rome, Villefranche and Barcelona. Prices from £2,075 with flights departing Manchester or Gatwick on August 11. P&O Cruises (020-7800 2222).

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Malta

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Malta
fields.standfirst: Lionel Blue
fields.trailText: Lionel Blue
fields.body:
Why: I went there in the 1960s with a friend who was convalescing, and I fell in love with the place because Malta is a world in miniature. It has everything - its own government, its own language, its own roccoco architecture and even a place where you can get away from everything in Goza, the next island along. Malta is only about 15 miles by about five or six, but if you get into the locals' way of thinking, going a couple of miles up the road into town is a bit of an event, and going to Valletta - a 15-minute drive away - needs careful consideration. Malta has a tremendous history and the prehistoric temples are still pretty much intact. There are churches everywhere and Maltese religion is pretty gentle. There is one church with a postbox by the altar, where you send your letters to the Almighty. I often wondered where they ended up.

What's the best thing? Maltese bread. It's round and flat. You should eat it fresh with their big mishapen tomatoes, fresh garlic and olive oil, washed down with a bottle of altar wine. I was introduced to altar wine by a priest. It's excellent.

My advice: Get there fast before all the countryside disappears, and make time to go in the winter when it is quite cheap. You might be unlucky with the weather at that time of year, but there are fewer tourists then. You should sit in a café in Valletta at midday with a glass of wine, a little curried- pea Maltese pastie and watch the world go by. Then come back in the evening and watch the boys and girls.

How do I get there? Seven nights' B&B accommodation in the three-star Carolina Hotel in Bugibba costs £271pp with Cadogan Holidays (0238 0828306). Price includes return scheduled flights from Gatwick.

 Sun Sand And Soul, by Lionel Blue and Jonathan Magonet, is published by Hodder & Stoughton at £6.99.

fields.headline: Basic instincts
fields.standfirst: It's brash, flash - and sexist.  Jonathan Glancey  offers an up-to-the-minute guide to nightlife in the Russian capital
fields.trailText: It's brash, flash - and sexist. Jonathan Glancey offers an up-to-the-minute guide to nightlife in the Russian capital.
fields.body:
You would think me drunk if I sat down and told you what Moscow nightlife is like today. It is, in a word, delirious. And, in other words, it's sexist, chauvinistic, painfully loud, flashy, wasteful, boastful, swaggering, libidinous, overpriced, decadent, sometimes dangerous.

It's dangerously hormonal, too - as highly charged as a Vostok rocket about to lift off, and as far in spirit from life in the former Soviet Union as a weekend in Las Vegas.

Things have settled down a bit since the New Russian heyday - or, more accurately, wild night - of the first five years following the collapse of the Red empire. I had last been in Moscow in 1994, when the first generation of late-night bars, clubs and casinos really were stuffed, wall-to-wall, with low-cut Versace, black Armani suits, fistfuls of dollars, champagne by the bucketful, and protected by the meanest- looking hoods this side of Ronnie and Reggie Kray.

My friends took me to eat - the men packing pistols - at the Up & Down Club. It is still there, at Zubovosky Bulvar 4 (Metro: Park Cultury), if you want to experience the fag end of New Russian excess - real gangsters and molls. But as they charge $70 to get into the restaurant and bar before you eat, you might decide that trying to relive the early days of nighttime glasnost and perestroika is best left to the smoke-windowed BMW set.

Versace might have given way to DKNY and Prada in the minds of wealthy young former comrades yet, although less frontier-town in spirit than it was in 1994, Moscow after dark remains a riotous if far from revolutionary place. This is, says the cosmopolitan staff of listings magazine The Exile (TE), "no place for Dutch tourists" or "sexless, progressive Canadian couples".

Nor for those with socialist sympathies, weak livers or high moral standards, either. Feminists, save for those seeking to be offended, should never step across the threshold of these testosterone-, vodka-, cocaine- and E-fuelled meat markets. Bars and clubs in Berlin, London and New York might be infinitely more sophisticated, but if you want to get drunk, laid and ripped-off in equal measure, dive in.

If you want to begin to understand Moscow today - a city through which 80% of Russia's GDP passes - you ought to give yourself a wild weekend out on the town.

There are a few things you should bear in mind, though, before you head off into the wild yonder. There is zero tolerance for drinking and driving. The Moscow Metro runs like clockwork - trains every one-to-two minutes on all 10 lines on weekdays from 5.30am to 1.15am. Not late enough for those heading home around 2am, but early enough for those leaving all-night bars and clubs.

There is never a problem with transport. When the Metro, trams, trolleybuses and diesel buses have packed up for the night, flag down almost any private car - more often than not a jacked-up Lada driven by an Ali G wannabe with a Mother Russia of a sound system - and negotiate your way home.

Expect to pay between 50 and 100 roubles (£1.25 and £2.50) to get to most places in the city limits. Women best travel in pairs or packs, but this holds true for most big cities. Moscow isn't particularly dangerous unless you're involved in big business deals, drugs or want to pick a fight. Just don't, even if you think you are tough. Older men in bars, despite a lack of wedding rings are mostly married; many younger women are on the game. There are very few gay bars and only one for women only.

Opening hours vary, with some serving 24 hours a day. Bars and clubs come and go: the latest travel guide will be out of date by the time it reaches the shelves.

There may or may not be cover charges; women are nearly always admitted free. Weekdays can be quiet, while Fridays and Saturdays are crowded. Drinks are generally more expensive than in Britain, and pushing and shoving is regarded as something of a local custom.

The mwaa, mwaa, twittering boho-chic of London's Clerkenwell, Hoxton and Shoreditch has yet to invade Moscow. In fact, it's as likely to get to Red Square as Napoleon or Hitler were. TE has definite, although realistic views, about the bars designed for refined British tourists (sorry, travellers) with history-of-art degrees keen on scented candles and difficult ethnic recipes.

Doug and Marty's Boar House
Address: Zemlyanoi Val 26.
Hours: 24 hours.
Cover charge: 60 roubles for women, 100R for men.
Metro: Kurskaya.

What TE says: "Weekend packed with liquored-up clientele working their mojo, sweaty prole chicks doing their best to look sexy, commercial DJs playing Ricky Martin, and loose young prey." The Boar House boasts $50 hookers, "aggressively quasi-latino men".

What you get: A heaving bar set up by Doug Steel, a big, shaven-headed Canadian best known for his former Hungry Duck bar, where hundreds of girls were admitted for a single greenback, fuelled on free liquor for a couple of hours before the local lads and ex-pats were let in. Result: bedlam and what Time Out's unsexist and considered guide to Moscow described thus: "The stench of Slavic pheromones burns your nose, sweat drips from the ceiling, the floor is slip pery with spilled beer and vomit, and the toilets are awash with puke."

Cabana
Address: Raushkaya Nab 4.
Hours: 6pm-6am.
Cover charge: None.
Metro: Tretyakovskaya.

What TE says: "Strippers and hookers go here on nights off."

What you get: Colourful interior; two bars serving the kind of fancy blue or red cocktails of the plastic-monkey-climbing-up-a-plastic-swivel-stick variety that were popular in London in the early 1980s. Live music, good deli restaurant, TV monitors (Beavis and Butthead are very popular among sandpaper-headed young Moscovite men.) Affordable. Be warned: the place is empty on weekdays.

The Embassy Club
Address: 8/10 Bryusov Per.
Hours: Variable.
Cover charge: None.
Metro: Pushkinskaya.

What TE says: "Walk-in humidor should impress upwardly-mobile dyevs [babes] and Cuban bar tenders are said to make some wicked cocktails. Appropriately impressive toilets. Live jazz that doesn't suck... but do you really like cigars? How about the people that smoke them?"

What you get: Upmarket cigar lounge and bar. Bit like Che's in London's St James's. Late flowering yuppy hangout comes with hangover.

Taxman
Address: Krymsky Val 6.
Hours: Midday-6am.
Cover charge: 80R on live music nights.
Metro: Park Kultury.

What TE says: "When we say skanky teens, we mean really skanky."

What you get: Really tacky club for the former proletariat (sorry, heroic sons and daughters of the Revolution). Clientele like to strip. Young men are big and scary.

Gallereya
Address: Corner of Petrova and Strastnoy Bulvar.
Hours: Variable.
Cover charge: None.
Metro: Pushkinskaya.

What TE says: "Tasteful minimalist interior, with a nod to Egon Schiele, designed as an ironic low-key gallery for the Merc-Jeep set. Babes de Milio on every square inch of floor - touch a chick, though, and your body won't float to the top of the Moskva River until mid-spring."

What you get: Designer chic bar; there are a few of these in Moscow. Drinks are mega-expensive. Not for Brits on average salaries.

Night Flight
Address: Nochnoi Polyot, Tverskaya Ultisa 17.
Hours: Variable.
Cover charge: None.
Metro: Tverskaya.

What TE says: "Features a 'Business Class' section for married men with hastily removed wedding rings... The place is packed with drop-dead gorgeous women, practically every one of whom is for sale; a place for corporate entertainment where you can run into your boss or Russian girlfriend."

What you get: Night Flight is a Swedish-run club that, while down at heel a few years ago, is back on hideous form. Meat market for ex-pats. Food is said to be great.

Sirius
Address: Strasnoi Bulvar 10, Str 2.
Hours: 6pm-6am.
Cover charge: None.
Metro: Chekhovskaya.

What you get: If you thought any of the above were beyond the pale, Sirius boasts a "Monica Lewinsky Cigar Room". Don't even ask. The "Crazy Menu" allows you to choose anything, from the songs the working girls sing to the girls themselves.

Golden Palace
Address: 3rd Yamskogo Polya, 15.
Hours: 8pm-8am.
Cover charge: 250,000 roubles for men (ie to stop outsiders getting in); women admitted for free.
Metro: Belorusskaya.

What you get: A taste of 1920s Chicago, Moscow-style. This is the place for those (stupidly) in love with gangster chic, except the gangsters are for real and the guards tote pump-action shotguns. Forget it; Brits just don't have this sort of money.

Buchenwald Club

Unless you are mad, leave this one well alone. This is a skinhead/grunge/techno club. Can be a touch violent. Don't ask if they do kosher food. Mind you, that's pretty good advice for all too many places in Moscow, which has Viennese tendencies.

Krai
Address: Spartakovskaya 14.
Hours: "Hell if we know" (TE).
Metro: Baumanskaya.

What TE says: "Boho-arty club, said to have a cool crowd. This place was as dead as William Burroughs the last time we were here."

Krisis Zhanra
Address: Bolshoi Vlasyevsky Per, Dom 4.
Hours: 11am-midnight.
Metro: Kropotinskaya.

What TE says: "Come here and mellow out with the rest of Moscow Boho-intelli crowd. Good place to sit and act alienated, waiting to be discovered by someone... Too many quirky, horn-rimmed glasses types."

What you get: A safe place to sport your goatee and combat trousers and talk intensely, or not at all. Few Muscovites.

OGI Club
Address: 8/12 Potopovsky Pereulo Str 2.
Metro: Chistiye Prudi.

What TE says: "Good place to take Dutch tourists."

What you get: Poetry and book readings for those of a literary disposition.

The Horse and Hounds
Address: Malaya Kommunisticheskaya Ulitsa 16/27.
Metro: Marksistskaya.

What you get: Same as in any of chain of John Bull pubs.

Rosie O'Grady's
Address: Znamenka 9/12.
Metro: Borovitskaya.

What you get: By the Kremlin; "Irish" staff hail from the Caucasus, but what the hell?

Shamrock Irish Bar
Address: Arbat Irish House Novy Arbat 11.
Metro: Arbatskaya.

What you get: The first foreign-owned pub to open after "perestroika". Closes, like Rosie's, when the last punter wobbles out.

The practicals

British Airways (0845 7733377) flies direct from Heathrow for £357 including tax; Scandinavian Airlines (0845 6072772) for £306.20 inc tax from Heathrow/Stansted via Stockholm. Tourist visas for the Russian Federation (£25) are valid for 30 days and available through travel agents or the Russian National Tourist Office in London (020-7937 7217); Moscow City Tourist Office: www.moscowcity.com

But as they charge $70 to get into the restaurant and bar before you eat, you might decide that trying to relive the early days of nighttime glasnost and perestroika is best left to the smoke-windowed BMW set. Versace might have given way to DKNY and Prada in the minds of wealthy young former comrades yet, although less frontier-town in spirit than it was in 1994, Moscow after dark remains a riotous if far from revolutionary place. This is, says the cosmopolitan staff of listings magazine The Exile (TE), "no place for Dutch tourists" or "sexless, progressive Canadian couples". Nor for those with socialist sympathies, weak livers or high moral standards, either. Feminists, save for those seeking to be offended, should never step across the threshold of these testosterone-, vodka-, cocaine- and E-fuelled meat markets. Bars and clubs in Berlin, London and New York might be infinitely more sophisticated, but if you want to get drunk, laid and ripped-off in equal measure, dive in. If you want to begin to understand Moscow today - a city through which 80% of Russia's GDP passes - you ought to give yourself a wild weekend out on the town. There are a few things you should bear in mind, though, before you head off into the wild yonder. There is zero tolerance for drinking and driving. The Moscow Metro runs like clockwork - trains every one-to-two minutes on all 10 lines on weekdays from 5.30am to 1.15am. Not late enough for those heading home around 2am, but early enough for those leaving all-night bars and clubs. There is never a problem with transport. When the Metro, trams, trolleybuses and diesel buses have packed up for the night, flag down almost any private car - more often than not a jacked-up Lada driven by an Ali G wannabe with a Mother Russia of a sound system - and negotiate your way home. Expect to pay between 50 and 100 roubles (£1.25 and £2.50) to get to most places in the city limits. Women best travel in pairs or packs, but this holds true for most big cities. Moscow isn't particularly dangerous unless you're involved in big business deals, drugs or want to pick a fight. Just don't, even if you think you are tough. Older men in bars, despite a lack of wedding rings are mostly married; many younger women are on the game. There are very few gay bars and only one for women only. Opening hours vary, with some serving 24 hours a day. Bars and clubs come and go: the latest travel guide will be out of date by the time it reaches the shelves. There may or may not be cover charges; women are nearly always admitted free. Weekdays can be quiet, while Fridays and Saturdays are crowded. Drinks are generally more expensive than in Britain, and pushing and shoving is regarded as something of a local custom. The mwaa, mwaa, twittering boho-chic of London's Clerkenwell, Hoxton and Shoreditch has yet to invade Moscow. In fact, it's as likely to get to Red Square as Napoleon or Hitler were. TE has definite, although realistic views, about the bars designed for refined British tourists (sorry, travellers) with history-of-art degrees keen on scented candles and difficult ethnic recipes. Doug and Marty's Boar House Address: Zemlyanoi Val 26. Hours: 24 hours. Cover charge: 60 roubles for women, 100R for men. Metro: Kurskaya. What TE says: "Weekend packed with liquored-up clientele working their mojo, sweaty prole chicks doing their best to look sexy, commercial DJs playing Ricky Martin, and loose young prey." The Boar House boasts $50 hookers, "aggressively quasi-latino men". What you get: A heaving bar set up by Doug Steel, a big, shaven-headed Canadian best known for his former Hungry Duck bar, where hundreds of girls were admitted for a single greenback, fuelled on free liquor for a couple of hours before the local lads and ex-pats were let in. Result: bedlam and what Time Out's unsexist and considered guide to Moscow described thus: "The stench of Slavic pheromones burns your nose, sweat drips from the ceiling, the floor is slip pery with spilled beer and vomit, and the toilets are awash with puke." Cabana Address: Raushkaya Nab 4. Hours: 6pm-6am. Cover charge: None. Metro: Tretyakovskaya. What TE says: "Strippers and hookers go here on nights off." What you get: Colourful interior; two bars serving the kind of fancy blue or red cocktails of the plastic-monkey-climbing-up-a-plastic-swivel-stick variety that were popular in London in the early 1980s. Live music, good deli restaurant, TV monitors (Beavis and Butthead are very popular among sandpaper-headed young Moscovite men.) Affordable. Be warned: the place is empty on weekdays. The Embassy Club Address: 8/10 Bryusov Per. Hours: Variable. Cover charge: None. Metro: Pushkinskaya. What TE says: "Walk-in humidor should impress upwardly-mobile dyevs [babes] and Cuban bar tenders are said to make some wicked cocktails. Appropriately impressive toilets. Live jazz that doesn't suck... but do you really like cigars? How about the people that smoke them?" What you get: Upmarket cigar lounge and bar. Bit like Che's in London's St James's. Late flowering yuppy hangout comes with hangover. Taxman Address: Krymsky Val 6. Hours: Midday-6am. Cover charge: 80R on live music nights. Metro: Park Kultury. What TE says: "When we say skanky teens, we mean really skanky." What you get: Really tacky club for the former proletariat (sorry, heroic sons and daughters of the Revolution). Clientele like to strip. Young men are big and scary. Gallereya Address: Corner of Petrova and Strastnoy Bulvar. Hours: Variable. Cover charge: None. Metro: Pushkinskaya. What TE says: "Tasteful minimalist interior, with a nod to Egon Schiele, designed as an ironic low-key gallery for the Merc-Jeep set. Babes de Milio on every square inch of floor - touch a chick, though, and your body won't float to the top of the Moskva River until mid-spring." What you get: Designer chic bar; there are a few of these in Moscow. Drinks are mega-expensive. Not for Brits on average salaries. Night Flight Address: Nochnoi Polyot, Tverskaya Ultisa 17. Hours: Variable. Cover charge: None. Metro: Tverskaya. What TE says: "Features a 'Business Class' section for married men with hastily removed wedding rings... The place is packed with drop-dead gorgeous women, practically every one of whom is for sale; a place for corporate entertainment where you can run into your boss or Russian girlfriend." What you get: Night Flight is a Swedish-run club that, while down at heel a few years ago, is back on hideous form. Meat market for ex-pats. Food is said to be great. Sirius Address: Strasnoi Bulvar 10, Str 2. Hours: 6pm-6am. Cover charge: None. Metro: Chekhovskaya. What you get: If you thought any of the above were beyond the pale, Sirius boasts a "Monica Lewinsky Cigar Room". Don't even ask. The "Crazy Menu" allows you to choose anything, from the songs the working girls sing to the girls themselves. Golden Palace Address: 3rd Yamskogo Polya, 15. Hours: 8pm-8am. Cover charge: 250,000 roubles for men (ie to stop outsiders getting in); women admitted for free. Metro: Belorusskaya. What you get: A taste of 1920s Chicago, Moscow-style. This is the place for those (stupidly) in love with gangster chic, except the gangsters are for real and the guards tote pump-action shotguns. Forget it; Brits just don't have this sort of money. Buchenwald Club Unless you are mad, leave this one well alone. This is a skinhead/grunge/techno club. Can be a touch violent. Don't ask if they do kosher food. Mind you, that's pretty good advice for all too many places in Moscow, which has Viennese tendencies. Krai Address: Spartakovskaya 14. Hours: "Hell if we know" (TE). Metro: Baumanskaya. What TE says: "Boho-arty club, said to have a cool crowd. This place was as dead as William Burroughs the last time we were here." Krisis Zhanra Address: Bolshoi Vlasyevsky Per, Dom 4. Hours: 11am-midnight. Metro: Kropotinskaya. What TE says: "Come here and mellow out with the rest of Moscow Boho-intelli crowd. Good place to sit and act alienated, waiting to be discovered by someone... Too many quirky, horn-rimmed glasses types." What you get: A safe place to sport your goatee and combat trousers and talk intensely, or not at all. Few Muscovites. OGI Club Address: 8/12 Potopovsky Pereulo Str 2. Metro: Chistiye Prudi. What TE says: "Good place to take Dutch tourists." What you get: Poetry and book readings for those of a literary disposition. The Horse and Hounds Address: Malaya Kommunisticheskaya Ulitsa 16/27. Metro: Marksistskaya. What you get: Same as in any of chain of John Bull pubs. Rosie O'Grady's Address: Znamenka 9/12. Metro: Borovitskaya. What you get: By the Kremlin; "Irish" staff hail from the Caucasus, but what the hell? Shamrock Irish Bar Address: Arbat Irish House Novy Arbat 11. Metro: Arbatskaya. What you get: The first foreign-owned pub to open after "perestroika". Closes, like Rosie's, when the last punter wobbles out. The practicals British Airways (0845 7733377) flies direct from Heathrow for £357 including tax; Scandinavian Airlines (0845 6072772) for £306.20 inc tax from Heathrow/Stansted via Stockholm. Tourist visas for the Russian Federation (£25) are valid for 30 days and available through travel agents or the Russian National Tourist Office in London (020-7937 7217); Moscow City Tourist Office: www.moscowcity.com

fields.headline: Beyond the pail
fields.standfirst: www.cheapflights.com
fields.trailText: www.cheapflights.com
fields.body:
How cheap?
Very cheap. Dubai - normally a very expensive destination - for £249. The choice of cities is vast. But it's no use trying to book here.

It's an online bucket-shop?
Dozens of bucket shops. Every Rite Flites and Discount Deals agency in outer London seems to have signed up to join Cheapflights, which publishes a long list of phone numbers you print off and mark up.

Rather old media...
Yes, but lots of people still use their phone line to access the Internet, and a typical destination search will return a long list of agencies with flight offers. The quickest solution is to ring all the numbers to see if they have flights on the days you want.

Worth a try then?
Definitely - just remember it's not the most sophisticated of websites (although a redesign is apparently imminent).

fields.headline: On the road with Che
fields.standfirst: Che Guevara rode 7,000 miles on a motorcycle on his way to planning a revolution.  Ben Lawrie and  Karl Rees relive his incredible journey
fields.trailText: Che Guevara rode 7,000 miles on a motorcycle on his way to planning a revolution. Ben Lawrie and Karl Rees relive his incredible journey.
fields.body:
We had both always dreamed of going to South America; reading Che Guevara's The Motorcycle Diaries, the classic account of his 7,000-mile journey through the deserts and mountains of South America was exactly the kind of inspiration we needed. We were both 23, the same age as Che had been at the time, and had time on our hands after finishing university. The fact that we had never ridden motorcycles before didn't seem important, and we began planning and publicising in earnest.

Since Che was so moved by meeting the patients in Peruvian leprosy colonies en route, we decided our journey would mark the 75th anniversary of LEPRA, the British Leprosy Relief Association.

One year later, we found ourselves in Buenos Aires with motorbikes we were barely able to ride. We loaded up and headed for the town of Alta Gracia, where Che was brought up. Our arrival caused quite a stir, attracting local television and radio coverage. We interviewed Che's ageing yet sprightly primary school teacher, Elba Rossi, who gave us sweet cherry liquor and recounted tales of the future revolutionary. A surprisingly normal boy it seemed, with a penchant for stealing peaches from other people's gardens.

Back in the capital, we felt ready to follow the trail blazed by Che, leaving 47 years and five months to the day that both he and his friend Alberto set off in January 1952, heading down the flat Atlantic coast. At the town of Bahiá Blanca, we turned inland and rode into the heart of the vast Pampas. Still on good roads, we made rapid progress through the wastes of thorny scrub until the increasing cold and the short daylight hours of the southern hemisphere winter began to limit our riding time. By the time San Martin de los Andes and the epony mous foothills which surround it loomed large in front of our eyes, we had been frozen to the core on more than one occasion.

As the cold nights intensified, our five-litre water sack would freeze - a fate that also befell the contents of the Thermos flask and, to our annoyance, the washing up liquid bottle. The clarity of the stars in the clear, dry air would have been a consolation had we been warm enough to stay out for any length of time to appreciate them in all their beauty.

Our decision to travel light meant we had denied ourselves the luxury of a tent, instead packing two khaki German army ponchos that we clipped together and slung between the bikes to make a rudimentary shelter. This proved far from satisfactory, and we'd spend the long frozen nights buried at the bottom of our sleeping bags, still wearing all our clothes, boots and riding gear.

The Southern Argentine Andes in June are somewhat reminiscent of the English Lake District in winter - great barren, snow-clad mountains, expanses of rock interspersed with glacial lakes. It was only when both ourselves and the road became snow clad that we realised how bitter the conditions could be.

Fortunately, however, we soon left behind Argentina's bleak wastes and crossed the border into Chile, where the lush dank vegetation was a welcome relief. However this proved to be short-lived, it quickly becoming apparent that the reason for Southern Chile's verdancy was a ridiculous amount of rain. Our first stop, the town of Osorno, has an average of 200 days rain a year, typically concentrated at the time we were there.

We spent two days sheltering in a barn with a bronchial and homeless ex-trucker named Gonzalez. Heartily sharing our suppers of pasta and beer, he explained how most people in Chile hated General Pinochet and why Rolls-Royce represented everything that was good about Britain.

After 48 hours we realised the chances of a break in the downpour were remote and headed off to Puerto Montt, Chile's most southerly town with road access to the north. We were still 2,000 miles south of the border crossing into tropical Peru and it felt like it.

The murky clouds which obscured the classically beautiful pyramid peak of Volcan Osorno set the scene for the next two weeks. Progress was always slow, with frequent stops needed in order to warm our bones.

In such conditions, the disadvantages of our ponchos really became apparent. The moisture content of our sleeping area was little helped by the hoods each poncho sported in the middle, and come morning we rarely awoke dry and warm. Our appearance went steadily down hill: more than once a friendly stranger took pity and offered us the use of their washing facilities.

Then one of the bikes gave up the ghost and left us stranded in the grey town of Los Angeles. Our mechanical ineptitude ensured that not only did we not know what caused the problem but that even when we had located a worn out spark plug with the help of a friendly mechanic, we found that we had brought the wrong spares.

We must have looked pretty sorry for ourselves since the mechanic, Francisco, lit a charcoal brazier to dry our sodden clothes and, having offered us accommodation on the workshop floor, proceeded to bedeck the fire with the beginnings of surely the greatest barbecue in the history of mankind. Soon the heady gin-like Chilean national drink of Pisco made an appearance, and the rest of the evening is a blur.

Los Angeles marked a change of fortune, and on the road to the capital, Santiago, we received just one more severe drenching. Indeed, from Santiago onwards we experienced only five minutes of light drizzle in the next 3,500 miles.

After a short spell in the dull Europeanised capital it was a relief to head up the rugged winding Pacific coast Easy Rider-style in bright sunshine. Soon, the scenery metamorphosed from grassland to scrub, from scrub to cactus and from cactus to sand, and we found ourselves on the edge of the driest desert in the world.

The Atacama desert is not to be taken lightly, and certainly not on motorbikes with a meagre 100-mile range, so we acquired spare jerry cans and extra water bottles in the picturesque colonial centre of La Serena. The town was founded in 1544 by the Spanish conquistador Juan Buhon following his hellish crossing of the Atacama, in which more than half the conquistadors and their native slaves died. It was with some trepidation that we headed for the desert.

In the bleak wastes of the Atacama, the shimmering road ahead was our only link with civilisation. Throughout the day we passed ghost towns, roofless houses alone in the desolate haze. In the breathless midday heat we stopped at one of these old nitrate mining settlements, Officina Edwards. Searching for shade in one of its crumbling buildings, the interior walls still painted a faded yellow and maroon, we found an immaculate 1920s child's leather shoe, delicately stitched and nailed, perfectly preserved in the dry air. Through a paneless, shutterless window, out across the hot sand, a solitary cross marked a forgotten grave. We sat listlessly in the relentless heat, sipping our precious water and tried to imagine the harsh life of the mining families that the dusty remains once housed.

It was in the desert wastes that Che, (like any a good prophet should) had one of the revelations that shaped his life. One bitterly cold night spent sharing a "miserable blanket" with a persecuted communist miner and his wife was an experience that made Che feel closer, really for the first time, to the marginalised people he would later come to fight for: those he then termed this "strange, for me at least, human species".

Back on the road, we pushed on across a barren expanse of flat, grey desert bounded by the spectacular volcanoes that mark Chile's border with Bolivia; at the oasis village of San Pedro de Atacama we left the road behind. We felt truly free bumping along the rutted gravely tracks. The dust billowed out behind us and there was nothing in sight except parched bare-backed mountains that rose up from the plain.

That night, we had no need to erect our ponchos as we found our way into the Valley of the Moon, a fantastic selection of wind sculpted rocks and dunes.

Nevertheless, real adventure beckoned, and we set course for the El Tatio geyser field on the side of one of the distant volcanoes that mark the border with Bolivia. The road was terrible, and we bounced and shook our way upwards throughout the day, the air becoming thinner and colder by the minute. It proved to be the most spec tacular period of riding we had experienced.

When we reached the geysers in the late afternoon we were exhausted but elated. We had made it to 15,000 feet on our struggling bikes, vicuñas (wild relations of the llama) running out in front of us from frozen lakes, the dust from their hooves hanging ghostlike in the cold dry air long after our passing.

The geysers turned out to be gently bubbling steaming pools in which we boiled eggs for breakfast, frozen and feeling like death because of altitude sickness. Much as we would have liked to stay to appreciate the stunning scenery, we feared for our health and hastily descended.

Back on the main roads we made speedy progress towards mountainous Peru. The sun shone brightly everyday, and although the desert nights were bitterly cold, we could sleep without shelter by the side of our bikes.

Peru proved completely different to anything we had expected. Within 60 miles of the border we were ascending steadily on ancient roads, little more than donkey tracks, through a land that time had forgotten, epitomised by the ruins of the Inca citadel of Machu Picchu.

Three months after setting out, we made it into the polluted heart of Lima, our faces looking like chimney sweeps from all the soot we had accumulated in our helmets along the way.

In Lima, Che stayed with a famous leprologist, Dr Hugo Pesce and was greatly moved by the patients he met there. He later headed north into the jungle, where he spent his 24th birthday with the leprosy patients of the San Pablo colony on the Amazon; Che was on the cusp of his true vocation.

BBC Radio 4 will broadcast the story of Ben and Karl's journey on Tuesday at 11am as part of its six-part series of travellers' stories, Tales from the Back of Beyond. The Motorcycle Diaries, by Che Guevara, is published by Fourth Estate, 1996, price £5.99 (ISBN 185702 399 4).

webTitle: Organising a round the trip world trip with children

fields.headline: Organising a round the trip world trip with children
fields.standfirst:
I am thinking of taking my two children, aged 10 and eight, on a six-month world trip from March to September. We will be travelling on our own most of the time, my husband joining us for two fortnight periods. Have any readers done this, and, if so, have they any advice on places to go, accommodation etc?
Janet Morris
fields.trailText: I am thinking of taking my two children, aged 10 and eight, on a six-month world trip from March to September. We will be travelling on our own most of the time, my husband joining us for two fortnight periods. Have any readers done this, and, if so, have they any advice on places to go, accommodation etc?
fields.body:
 I travelled recently to New Zealand and organised the trip through Bridge the World (0207 911 0900). All their consultants are well travelled and can give you expert advice. Round the world airfares are up to one-third cheaper for children under 12, and some tickets allow you to change dates as you travel around.

South East Asia is a great place to take children as the culture is very geared up to mothers and their kids. Thailand is also incredibly cheap at the moment and there is good quality basic accommodation, especially on the beaches and islands of the south. In Singapore, a day trip to Sentosa Island's theme park with its "underwater world" and "volcano land" is a must.
