webTitle: Are MI5 and MI6 a waste of time and money?

fields.headline: Are MI5 and MI6 a waste of time and money?
fields.standfirst: For peace studies lecturer Michael Randle, the British security services cost taxpayers a fortune and may even have engaged in illegal activities for which they remain unaccountable. But author Nigel West says there is no evidence that MI5 or MI6 have abused their powers and that the actions they do undertake are in the interests of national security. Have your say here
fields.trailText: For peace studies lecturer Michael Randle, the British security services cost taxpayers a fortune and may even have engaged in illegal activities for which they remain unaccountable. But author Nigel West says there is no evidence that MI5 or MI6 have abused their powers and that the actions they do undertake are in the interests of national security. Have your say here
fields.body:
Dear Nigel,
Last year, the running costs of the British security services, together with that of GCHQ, rose by 17% to £1bn. These costs can be expected to rise further in the coming years. The services would be cheap at the price if they really were accountable and their activities confined to protecting the population from foreign subversion and terrorism. But we know that this has not been the case. Prior to 1989 neither service had any standing in law and there is compelling evidence that both engaged in unlawful activities, from MI6's collaboration with the CIA in 1953 in the coup against Mossadeq in Iran, to the MI5 plot against Harold Wilson in the 1970s and its targeting of trade unions, civil liberties groups and peace organisations. Has this changed? Two acts of parliament have established a degree of parliamentary and ministerial supervision of the services. But the amended Official Secrets Act (OSA) of 1989 imposed on their members a lifetime obligation of confidentiality, and the Shayler case shows the lengths to which the authorities are prepared to go to prevent the publication of evidence of criminal abuses. At present, then, the problem with the security services is not so much their cost as the threat they pose to individual and collective freedom.

Yours sincerely,
Michael Randle,
Lecturer in peace studies,
University of Bradford

Dear Michael,
Whether MI5 [the domestic branch of the intelligence services] and SIS [the international branch, also known as MI6] are worth £1bn a year is moot, but to propose that greater accountability will ensure value for money is a non-sequitur. Both have always been accountable to ministers, and now MI5 is accountable to an independent tribunal, a commissioner, a staff counsellor, an interception of communications commissioner and a parliamentary committee. As for the past, there is no evidence that MI5 abused its powers, and its surveillance of organisations penetrated by Soviet-funded communists merely monitored hostile foreign intelligence activity, but took no direct steps to disrupt it. To use the coup against Mossadeq as an example of SIS misconduct is absurd. Blame the politicians who ordered the operation, but it was not illegal for SIS to undertake it. Furthermore, it was in Britain's interests. What about SIS's telephone tapping in Athens that enabled weapons destined for EOKA terrorists to be intercepted? It was illegal under Greek law, but the operation saved British lives. It would be absurd to allow disaffected MI5 employees the freedom to betray the confidences of people who have volunteered information to the security service. If a genuine whistleblower has a grievance, there are plenty of safety valves available.

Yours sincerely,
Nigel West,
Authority on national security

Dear Nigel,
There is no non-sequitur. If the security services have been doing those things they ought not to have done, and leaving undone those things they ought to have done, openness and accountability serve to minimise the abuse of power and ensure better value for money. Clearly there is more accountability now than before 1989 when the services had no statutory existence. But the list of watchdogs you mention all have rubber teeth. The parliamentary intelligence and security committee is appointed by the prime minister, chaired by former defence minister Tom King, meets in secret, is bound by the OSA, and never makes any fundamental criticisms of the services. It refused to allow David Shayler to appear before it even when he had evidence that, at the very least, MI6 knew of the existence of a plot to kill or depose Colonel Gadafy. Its reports are vetted by the prime minister, and he and other ministers, or the head of an agency, can prevent the committee getting information they deem "sensitive". The tribunal is equally ineffective, and during its existence has not upheld a single complaint. Moreover, if a member of the services informs someone that they are being targeted, they render themselves liable to prosecution. Most crucial of all there is no public-interest defence in the 1989 OSA. So if a member of the services informs anyone, even their MP, of criminal activities by any of the services, they are liable to prosecution. You say there is no evidence that MI5 abused its powers. But first, it had no legal powers other than those enjoyed by any private body. Second, it was a ruling by the European commission on human rights that MI5 surveillance of Harriet Harman and Patricia Hewitt was in breach of the European Convention that forced the government to introduce the Security Service Act in 1989. As an advocate and occasional practitioner of civil disobedience, I agree that it can sometimes be right to break certain laws to prevent a greater evil. But criminal actions that breach the rights of people are another matter and cannot be justified in law or morality. You approve of the coup that overthrew the elected government of Mossadeq because it was "in Britain's interest". The claim is disputable, the act indefensible. About 100 people are estimated to have lost their lives in the coup, and Mossadeq's foreign minister was executed. The defence of "only obeying orders" should be ruled out once and for all.

Yours sincerely,
Michael

Dear Michael,
Tom King's committee is not the toothless pussycat you portray it to be. I can't see any of the ministers being cowed by the threat of an OSA prosecution if they seek to make a disclosure outside the protection of the Palace of Westminster. True, the committee declined to see Shayler, taking the view that he was a disgruntled ex-employee and not a whistle-blower, and that his complaints were best handled internally. His allegation regarding Gadafy is especially galling because, while he has asserted that SIS was in touch with a Libyan opposition group, he was wrong to say that SIS paid for, masterminded or even knew of an assassination. As you rightly say, the Harman/ Hewitt case proved the catalyst for the introduction of MI5's complaints tribunal and the commissioner, but you are mistaken if you interpret that event to mean that hitherto all the intercept warrants signed by many ministers of many different governments were illegal. SIS has always been an instrument of political power, collecting intelligence for ministers and undertaking clandestine operations on their authority. MI5 happily takes no such political direction but operates within the limits of the 1989 Act. To open either to public scrutiny would negate their effectiveness, place the public in danger and waste the taxpayer's money.

Yours sincerely,
Nigel

Dear Nigel,
Your letter confirms the fact that control exercised by the parliamentary intelligence and security committee is weak. You are confident that their members would be prepared to risk prosecution under the OSA if they felt it necessary to make disclosures outside the protection of the Palace of Westminster, but the question is whether they should have to act within that kind of restraint. Regarding Gadafy, the MI6 report posted on the internet shows that an MI6 officer was informed in advance of the plot to kill the Libyan leader in 1996 and that this report was circulated round Whitehall. According to Shayler, the informant was paid £100,000. As Lord Justice Judge said last Friday when he found in favour of the Guardian and Observer: "If true, it was difficult to overestimate its enormity. If false, the allegations were inevitably damaging. Yet their refutation was also a matter of public importance." Yet the committee was not even prepared to hear what Shayler had to say. This was an acid test of its independence and competence - one that it failed. The problem with the tribunal is that it was set up to hear complaints from individuals who believe their privacy has been abused by the services. Since such individuals have no means of knowing whether or not they are being targeted, this safeguard is illusory. Whether or not the operations against Harman and Hewitt - and other innocent people - were strictly illegal is beside the point. They represented a gross abuse of executive power, as the European Commission judgment implies. Regarding SIS, you state that it has always been an instrument of political power, collecting secret intelligence for ministers and undertaking clandestine operations on their authority, and you accept that it was involved in the overthrow of a democratically elected government in Iran in 1953. No further comment is needed. The proposed new anti-terrorist legislation defines terrorism so broadly that MI5 will be able to target a still wider range of activists. This is the context in which its operations, and the lack of accountability, needs to be viewed.

Yours sincerely,
Michael

Dear Michael,
Actually Tom King's committee has taken evidence very widely, and not just in the UK. Nevertheless, I concur that it is a less than perfect watchdog unless it has an experienced staff. However, the proposition that because there is room to improve current systems of parliamentary oversight we should scrap the country's security and intelligence agencies is plain daft. There is a vast difference between ministers being advised of anti-Gadafy plotters and SIS paying for his assassination. The security service does not randomly target or disadvantage innocent people, and undercover police enquiries do not conclude with the suspects being invited to review the evidence accumulated. The coup in Iran had full cabinet approval, and although you may not like either that, the Suez operation or a dozen other manifestations of past policy, SIS never acted independently. Criticise the politicians, but not the services that do their legal bidding.

Nigel

webTitle: Last chapter in Sylvia Plath's tragic love story

fields.headline: Last chapter in Sylvia Plath's tragic love story
fields.trailText: They still hear wolves at night in Chalcot Square, though in the 37 years since Sylvia Plath took her life there has been plenty heard from jackals too.
fields.body:
Nightly now I flog apes owls bears sheep
Over the iron stile. And still don't sleep

- from Zoo Keeper's Wife by Sylvia Plath

Wolves consoled us.
Two or three times each night
For minutes on end
They sang

- from Life After Death by Ted Hughes

They still hear wolves at night in Chalcot Square, though in the 37 years since Sylvia Plath took her life there has been plenty heard from jackals too.

Yesterday, in a quiet ceremony just beyond Regent's Park Zoo, a final chapter in the tragic literary love story was played out.

Plath and Ted Hughes lived intensely but mostly happily in a second floor flat at Number 3 for almost two years, and their daughter Frieda Hughes (who was born there) unveiled a blue plaque to her mother on its gaily painted facade. The house in north London has long been a place of pilgrimage. Many have never forgiven Hughes, who died in 1998, for "abandoning" his American-born wife and two small children during the long, cruel winter of 1963. His defenders counter that it was she that left him, after he had affairs. Plath, aged 30 and with a history of mental illness, killed herself shortly afterwards.

Literary lights were notably thin on the ground as Frieda, herself a poet and who has inherited her mother's striking looks, admitted she found the experience very emotional.

"I haven't been back here since we left," she said. Now 40, she was a toddler when her mother gassed herself in the kitchen of a flat round the corner in Fitzroy Road, in a house once owned by the Irish poet WB Yeats. There had been grumblings that the plaque should have been on that house, where she wrote much of her final, visceral collection of poems, Ariel.

Plath's son Nick Hughes, who was barely one when his mother killed herself in the next room, and who now lives in Alaska, hung back from proceedings, preferring to keep out of view of cameras.

The philosopher Jonathan Glover, who now lives in the Chalcot Square house, said the square had changed hugely since the penniless Hughes left. "The type of people have changed a lot too, though we can still hear the animals in the zoo at night." Pop star Neneh Cherry, broadcaster Joan Bakewell, comedian Les Dennis, and film star Ewen McGregor have houses in and around the square, and Harry Enfield and Ben Elton live nearby. But, Mr Glover said, the flat was unchanged. "It's had a few coats of paint, but basically it's as it was when they lived there." His wife, Yvette, had no objections to the plaque. "They were happy when they lived here. It was the flat round the corner where... well, I think you know..."

Questions have been asked about why it took English Heritage 36 years to erect a plaque to an outstanding poet and a feminist icon; usually it takes 20 years. Francis Carnwath, who chairs the blue plaque panel, said there was no dark conspiracy, it was merely there had been a backlog to clear.

fields.headline: Crab Manor, Yorkshire
fields.trailText: What looks at first like a cluttered Georgian country house is actually an endearingly weird upmarket theme hotel where the theme is - hotels.
fields.body:
Address: Crab Manor, Asenby, Thirsk, North Yorkshire YO7 3QL.
Tel: 01845 577286.
Web address: www.crabandlobster.co.uk

First impressions: Rare combination of friendliness, luxury and eccentricity. What looks at first like a cluttered Georgian country house is actually an endearingly weird upmarket theme hotel where the theme is - hotels.

What are the rooms like? Each is decorated and furnished in the style of one of the world's great hotels: the Cape Town Mount Nelson, Marrakesh's La Mamounia, the Cipriani Palace in Venice, Raffles in Singapore and five more.

The bed test: Four-poster perfection, complete with drapes, teddy bears and the ubiquitous cherubs.

The bathroom test: A vast free-standing tub, marble tiles, authentic Cumbrian wallpaper.

The restaurant: The Crab and Lobster is an esteemed seafood restaurant in its own right, serving, among many other options, a delectable mixed fish grill. Meals with a starter weigh in at around £22 a head, not including wine.

The lounge: Unsurprisingly bizarre, with several garages-full of random objects suspended from the ceiling.

What is there to see within walking distance? Seven acres of Alice-in-Wonderland grounds should keep you busy: a golf hole with practice tee, a hot tub and sauna, numerous romantic bowers.

What is there to see within a 20-minute drive? Thirsk, with its racecourse, James Herriot heritage, vaguely twee shops and branch of the world-famous Yorkshire tea rooms Betty's.

How much a night? Rooms start at £100 a night, including breakfast, and go up to £120.

Would you go back? Absolutely - and then try to impress my friends by reeling off the great world hotels I've stayed in (without mentioning that they were all outside Thirsk).

Web address: www.crabandlobster.co.uk First impressions: Rare combination of friendliness, luxury and eccentricity. What looks at first like a cluttered Georgian country house is actually an endearingly weird upmarket theme hotel where the theme is - hotels. What are the rooms like? Each is decorated and furnished in the style of one of the world's great hotels: the Cape Town Mount Nelson, Marrakesh's La Mamounia, the Cipriani Palace in Venice, Raffles in Singapore and five more. The bed test: Four-poster perfection, complete with drapes, teddy bears and the ubiquitous cherubs. The bathroom test: A vast free-standing tub, marble tiles, authentic Cumbrian wallpaper. The restaurant: The Crab and Lobster is an esteemed seafood restaurant in its own right, serving, among many other options, a delectable mixed fish grill. Meals with a starter weigh in at around £22 a head, not including wine. The lounge: Unsurprisingly bizarre, with several garages-full of random objects suspended from the ceiling. What is there to see within walking distance? Seven acres of Alice-in-Wonderland grounds should keep you busy: a golf hole with practice tee, a hot tub and sauna, numerous romantic bowers. What is there to see within a 20-minute drive? Thirsk, with its racecourse, James Herriot heritage, vaguely twee shops and branch of the world-famous Yorkshire tea rooms Betty's. How much a night? Absolutely - and then try to impress my friends by reeling off the great world hotels I've stayed in (without mentioning that they were all outside Thirsk).

webTitle: The power of cheap music - but Napster is not run by philanthropists

fields.headline: The power of cheap music
fields.standfirst:
But Napster is not run by philanthropists
Net news
fields.trailText: The uproar over Napster - the internet service which enables users around the world to exchange copyrighted music from their computers with each other through a central directory - is a modern morality tale.
fields.body:
The uproar over Napster - the internet service which enables users around the world to exchange copyrighted music from their computers with each other through a central directory - is a modern morality tale.

A US federal judge has granted an injunction to prevent the company from copying and distributing music. It will not work. It is the modern equivalent of putting a digit into the dyke to prevent the dam (in this case containing trillions of 1s and 0s rather than water) from bursting. It will not work because there are already other so-called "peer to peer" alternatives (like Gnutella, FreeNet and many more in the pipeline) which cannot be brought to court since, unlike Napster, they have no central place where the music files are collated.

This case has no heroes. The record companies that brought the case have been making too much money out of their music rights and do not seem to realise that it cannot be maintained in the "free-for-everyone" ethos of the internet.

Napster, the brilliant creation of a couple of entrepreneurial students, tries to pretend it is upholding the mutual principles of the internet by facilitating the free exchange of music files from one hard disk to another. It is doing nothing of the sort, since (unlike the alternatives) it has formed itself into a company to make money out of it.

We are witnessing here the latest confrontation between the founding centrifugal forces of the internet (pushing information downward and outward at no cost to users) and the centripetal forces as corporations and governments try to recapture the centre (where the profits and power reside).

The power to digitise everything from books to Hollywood films could lead to all of these being freely exchangeable on the web just as share prices and news are now. That could happen unless film and music makers get a grip on what is happening and cooperate to produce a solution recognising the deflationary forces of the web. That means making recordings available on the web at prices reflecting the fact that distribution is free and that it costs no more to make a million copies than it does to make one. Consumers should pay something to reflect the intellectual property rights of what they are buying - especially if quality is guaranteed - but they will not be duped into paying monopoly prices.

If the record companies do not accept that, they will contribute to their own destruction. And it will not be a long-playing record.

webTitle: EMI and MP3.com reach copyright accord

fields.headline: EMI and MP3.com reach copyright accord
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: EMI yesterday became the third big record company to settle a copyright infringement suit against music website MP3.com.
fields.body:
EMI yesterday became the third big record company to settle a copyright infringement suit against music website MP3.com.

Under their agreement the online company will be able to stream music for which EMI holds rights. The financial terms of the settlement were not disclosed, but sources said MP3.com was expected to pay EMI about $20m in damages and royalty-type fees based on usage of tracks owned by the British company.

In April, a district court in New York ruled that MP3.com violated copyright law via My.MP3.com, a database which could be used to store music digitally for later access from any computer.

Warner and BMG settled similar actions against MP3 last month.

Jay Samit, senior vice-president of new media at EMI, said: "This settlement ensures that copyright owners and creators are compensated fairly."

MP3.com portrayed the outcome as part of the emerging compact between technology and the music industry.

"A business model where artists, copyright holders and record companies can potentially monetise [bring into legal tender] their music digitally and in an accretive manner is finally emerging," said Michael Robertson, chairman and chief executive of MP3.

MP3 is still in talks with Sony Music and Universal, which is being acquired by Vivendi. Should it fail to settle with either company, MP3 could face court-imposed damages totalling billions of dollars.

On Monday, MP3.com said it took a $150m charge against its second quarter earnings for the estimated legal costs. There is also a pending copyright infringement case filed by song publishers.

 Download site Napster yesterday lodged an appeal against the preliminary injunction which requires it to cease operations by the weekend.

webTitle: When Lola the dog met Kafka

fields.headline: When Lola the dog met Kafka
fields.trailText:
With which organ does a dog sense its surroundings? a: nose; b: eyes; c: touch. 
That, according to the newspaper Berliner Zeitung, is one of 30 questions I shall face in a multiple choice test set by the Berlin authorities to determine whether I am fit to own my pet.
fields.body:
With which organ does a dog sense its surroundings? a: nose; b: eyes; c: touch.

That, according to the newspaper Berliner Zeitung, is one of 30 questions I shall face in a multiple choice test set by the Berlin authorities to determine whether I am fit to own my pet. If I fail, my pet will be taken away and kept in a cage for the rest of its life.

As you may sense, this is only partly a story about animals. It is mostly about how I brought a dog to Berlin and ended up meeting Franz Kafka.

Last month, an appalling incident took place. Two dogs kept for fighting escaped into a school playground in Hamburg and attacked and killed a six-year-old child.

It was the almost inevitable outcome of a situation to which most German politicians had been turning a blind eye for years. As I remarked in an earlier edition of this column, as a newcomer to Berlin I found the number of pit bull terriers roaming off the lead here one of the more alarming aspects of life in the city.

But nothing had prepared me for the speed at which things swung from one extreme to the other, or how quickly the authorities put together a towering paper edifice of regulation.

Within six days of the tragedy, and with no evidence of consultation, the regional administration for Berlin had tacked up a decree proclaiming 12 breeds of dog to be inherently dangerous. They included such questionable choices as the Pyrenean mountain dog.

The rearing of dogs from these breeds is now banned in Berlin, and those already here - some 20,000, according to police estimates - must be kept on a lead, except in special dog running zones, and muzzled even in the designated areas.

What is more, they are to be confiscated and put in the equivalent of Battersea dogs' home if their owners are unable to produce a certificate, the Berlin dog licence known for short as the Amtliche Bescheinigung .

We have just eight weeks in which to get hold of one, and to secure an Amtliche Bescheinigung we need to assemble six other pieces of paper.

My quest began at the borough veterinary office where two officials registered our harmless Staffordshire bull terrier and noted down her precise date of birth - 23.01.93 - before granting her a temporary certificate and photographing her for an album of known suspects. Since the dogs in the album are wearing muzzles, they all look alike.

Next stop was the local police station to get another certificate to say that I had no previous convictions. After that, a phone call to make an appointment to visit an officially approved examination centre to pick up the forms to apply for my test and for the two tests - for aggression and harmlessness - which Lola must take.

I am looking at one of these forms as I write. One of the questions relates to "known vices". I presume this applies to Lola.

But before we take our tests I have to get insurance for Lola in case she takes a strong dislike to the examiner. Since most insurance companies have decided not to cover any of the banned breeds, this is not as easy as it sounds. To make things worse, the veterinary office orchestrating this whole extraordinary paper chase refuses to divulge the names of firms which can help us.

If we get through all three tests, our prize is the certificate and a medallion for Lola's collar which will be "green, circular and with a diameter of 4cm". At which point, she will be allowed out - still on a lead, but freed from the muzzle. Or so you might think.

Remember I met Kafka - or should it be Joseph Heller? Despite everything done to ensure that the dog - and I - are harmless, Lola will continue to be imprisoned in a face mask which ensures that she can no longer be properly exercised: try throwing a ball for a dog which cannot pick it up.

The woman at the examination centre said several owners had already reported that their previously docile pets had shown signs of aggression since the new regulations were introduced.

fields.headline: Sommerset House, London
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort salutes Oliver Peyton's new baby
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort salutes Oliver Peyton's new baby
fields.body:
There is something about the great courtyard of Somerset House that imposes a certain stateliness of step. Hurrying doesn't seem consistent with the 18th century, frock-coated, silk-stockinged, tricorn-hatted classical magnificence of the space. Out there, in the Strand, all is hustle and bustle, fume and fuss. In here is a different world which keeps to a steadier time. At least, that's what I thought as, late for lunch, I hurtled across the paving like a greyhound from the trap. I had heard spectacular things about the food at The Admiralty, Oliver Peyton's new venture at Somerset House, and I wanted to marvel - or not- for myself.

Oliver Peyton is not a chef, but a restaurateur. Actually, he is more of a restaurant impresario, a Phineas T Barnum of restaurants. He has a penchant for the spectacular and the idiosyncratic, and I was curious to see if the restrictions imposed by Wren's grand design and the quangos who guard the spirit of the place, had restrained his visionary energy.

The answer is yes and, alternatively, no. The restaurant runs through three linked rooms in the right-hand wing at the far end of the great courtyard if you enter from the Strand. Notionally, the rooms overlook the River Terrace and the river itself, but the windows are set so high that you can only see out when standing up. But they are handsome rooms, with the characteristic high ceilings, and a curious, rather clubbish, feel to them. This may have been due in part to the dominant kind of sub-fusc green colouring, or to the stuffed sailfish and head of ibis leaping off the walls.

But you can't keep the fun out of a Peyton restaurant. Beneath the marlin there was a little case of dried sea horses and some of the chandeliers take the form of little galleons under sail. Then there was the curious decking attached to each table, adding another level on which you could put bottles of wine, dinky bread baskets or, as most people did, a left or right arm.

And there was the food, and such food it was, too. It's described as cuisine du terroir ; a curious notion, you might think, to serve quintessential French grub in this most English of buildings, but there you are. I am not sure what part of France chef Eric Guilbert calls home, or which restaurants he has cooked in on his way here, and neither do I care. On the evidence of lunch, he is one of the most talented and original chefs working in London at the moment.

By original, I don't mean he is ostentatiously inventive, or theatrically demonstrative. I mean simply that he produces food unlike anyone else around, food of profound deliciousness, balanced, perfectly integrated, with flavours sounding off like a chime of bells all over your mouth. There is nothing crude or obvious about each dish, nothing out of place or out of key. The plating arrangements are handsome, but not distractingly artful. Instead, there is a deceptive, artless directness.

The fair Melisande ate scallops on a bed of cabbage and pork belly with a warm balsamic dressing, and then roasted rabbit in a lavender sauce with carrots and sautéed new potatoes. I ate chilled beef pot au feu with vegetables in its jelly, then roasted freshwater eel, with leek and a Sechuan pepper sauce, finishing with and a mousse au chocolat with pistachio madeleines.

These dishes may seem a little prosaic in English, but space prevents from giving the more euphonious French menu poetry, or from enumerating all the many qualities of each dish, but here are a few to be getting on with . . .

The belly pork with scallops was crisp, fat and scorched by the touch of a grill. This served to heighten the sweetness of the scallop and cut the vegetal squelch of the cabbage.

The rabbit had been roasted to a perfect savoury sweetness, the lightly caramelised exterior breaking on to a tender, dewy interior. The sweetness was picked out by the carrots, too, with the lavender sauce rolling delicately perfumed luxuriance around them.

The earthy sweetness of the eel was cut by an unadvertised bed of braised, crushed tomatoes of fruity intensity and a dribble of herbal sauce verte as well as the exotic fragrance of the Sechuan pepper.

The chocolate mousse was a great cloud of soft richness, with tiny shards of chocolate nipping between the teeth. It comes in a bowl from which you eat as much as you can, wish or dare. My only complaint was that the bowl was stainless steel. In terms of honouring this splendid pudding, it should at least have been china.

The wine list is as individual as the cooking, and you may need to be guided through unfamiliar terrain of exclusively French vin du pays. We ended up with a bottle of Comte Peraldi from Corsica, completely unknown to me or to the fair Melisande, who is pretty expert in these matters. It completely vindicated its high price of £39.50. In fact, the whole bill came to £106.35, of which the food element was £55,50. This is a ridiculously small sum of money to spend on food which matches the magnificence of its setting

fields.headline: A leaf less ordinary
fields.standfirst: Don't despair of that gloomy corner - glossy leaves reflect the light and will cheer up the murkiest space. Shine on, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Don't despair of that gloomy corner - glossy leaves reflect the light and will cheer up the murkiest space. Shine on, says Christopher Lloyd.
fields.body:
There are various ways in which a plant can draw attention to itself, either for its own good, to attract or repel; or, fortuitously, by pleasing us for some extraneous reason. The shiny leaf is one of these.

A shiny leaf reflects the light and, on the whole, this is a cheerful property. If, for instance, we are growing a plant in rather heavy shade, gloss on the leaf will reflect any light that's around, and we shall appreciate its brightening of the gloom.

Asarum europeum is a favourite of mine in this respect. It is a low-growing perennial, making clumps of dark green, orbicular leaves that are highly reflective. I particularly noticed this property when I saw it in the wild, in the Carpathians, where it made clumps (which I prefer to a uniform ground-covering carpet) beneath a canopy of mixed woodland. Being deciduous, the foliage is entirely fresh each spring and advantage can be taken of its winter dormancy by allowing aconites to thrive among a colony.

The evergreen Daphne laureola (whose attractive name gave its title to a play in which Edith Evans starred) is equally at home in the shade of trees, and this again has glossy leaves. It makes a fair-sized shrub in time, of moderately sprawling habit 1.5m high, and it has rather insignificant green flowers in spring. However, it is worth picking some flowering branches for the house, as they are heavily fragrant at night.

A sub-species of this daphne is called philippi , and this is almost ground-hugging. It has a mildly suckering habit and is quite a handsome plant in some gardens. I can hardly claim that it is that in mine, where it is (only) slightly scruffy.

Another plant with which I have yet to be successful, though I am still trying, is Mahonia nervosa, from Oregon. This, again, is quite low-growing and suckering. It likes leafy woodland soil. Mine doesn't seem to be that sort of garden. When suited, this is an extremely handsome shrub, wholly for its foliage, which is bronze when young, then deep, lustrous green, and the svelte leaflets are smartly angled forwards along their central axis.

The foliage of most camellias is glossy enough, but seems to me to draw attention to the worst attributes of the man-made cultivars. The leaves have become too large and coarse (keeping pace with the flowers). I should prefer them to be less obtrusive. An exception is a Camellia japonica cultivar called 'Lady Vansittart'. This has abundant, neat, pointed foliage with a twist on the leaves. The flowers take you by surprise by varying their colouring, sometimes white, sometimes pale pink, sometimes red, or partially red. They die brown on the shrub, as with so many camellias. Still, I grow it.

Glossy leaves are best appreciated on shade-loving plants. Another such is the rather tender Farfugium japonicum (0.3m), with large and substantial orbicular leaves. In Japan, it flowers handsomely with rich yellow daisies in October, but in our climate it does not reach that stage. Still, it is a splendid foliage plant and I have a very soft spot for the hecticly yellow-spotted cultivar, 'Aureomaculatum'. The white-variegated 'Argenteum' is also offered and is a good plant, though leaf gloss is less evident in this case.

Hart's-tongue ferns, Asplenium scolopendrium, have an excellent shiny front surface, the texture and shaping of which varies considerably among the many cultivars. These fronds are more or less evergreen, but the old crop is best removed in early spring, so as not to interfere with its pristine new sheaves.

The cherry laurel, Prunus laurocerasus, is apt to be demeaned simply because it is both vigorous and undemanding, flourishing in sunlight and shade. If not heavily pruned, it can make a delightful display in spring, with candles of white blossom. Here, again, there are many cultivars. If you have the space, I can recommend the large-leaved 'Latifolia' (also known as 'Magnoliifolia'), which is handsome at all times of the year. 'Otto Luyken' is a deservedly popular smaller cultivar, with a sharply pointed leaf and a neat habit. Its dark, lustrous green contrasts well with a golden conifer-like Thuja occidentalis 'Rheingold'.

I usually prune my 'Otto Luyken' a little after its spring flowering, removing the weakened shoots that flowered most. A heavier pruning, to prevent the shrub becoming over-bulky, is done perhaps once in eight years. In some years, there is an autumn crop of its white blossom.

Eucalyptus niphophila is a very different animal from any so far mentioned. A usually rather slender tree with a pale trunk, its pendant scimitar leaves catch sunlight, especially from a low sun, and perform a winking act that seems to make them dance. Being evergreen, the performance is year-round and this species is pretty hardy. It is reckoned to be a sub-species of E. pauciflora.

The shiny leaf is one of these. A shiny leaf reflects the light and, on the whole, this is a cheerful property. If, for instance, we are growing a plant in rather heavy shade, gloss on the leaf will reflect any light that's around, and we shall appreciate its brightening of the gloom. Asarum europeum is a favourite of mine in this respect. It is a low-growing perennial, making clumps of dark green, orbicular leaves that are highly reflective. I particularly noticed this property when I saw it in the wild, in the Carpathians, where it made clumps (which I prefer to a uniform ground-covering carpet) beneath a canopy of mixed woodland. Being deciduous, the foliage is entirely fresh each spring and advantage can be taken of its winter dormancy by allowing aconites to thrive among a colony. The evergreen Daphne laureola (whose attractive name gave its title to a play in which Edith Evans starred) is equally at home in the shade of trees, and this again has glossy leaves. It makes a fair-sized shrub in time, of moderately sprawling habit 1.5m high, and it has rather insignificant green flowers in spring. However, it is worth picking some flowering branches for the house, as they are heavily fragrant at night. A sub-species of this daphne is called philippi , and this is almost ground-hugging. It has a mildly suckering habit and is quite a handsome plant in some gardens. I can hardly claim that it is that in mine, where it is (only) slightly scruffy. Another plant with which I have yet to be successful, though I am still trying, is Mahonia nervosa, from Oregon. This, again, is quite low-growing and suckering. It likes leafy woodland soil. Mine doesn't seem to be that sort of garden. When suited, this is an extremely handsome shrub, wholly for its foliage, which is bronze when young, then deep, lustrous green, and the svelte leaflets are smartly angled forwards along their central axis. This has abundant, neat, pointed foliage with a twist on the leaves. The flowers take you by surprise by varying their colouring, sometimes white, sometimes pale pink, sometimes red, or partially red. They die brown on the shrub, as with so many camellias. In Japan, it flowers handsomely with rich yellow daisies in October, but in our climate it does not reach that stage. Still, it is a splendid foliage plant and I have a very soft spot for the hecticly yellow-spotted cultivar, 'Aureomaculatum'. webTitle: Top designer spruces up staff at Tate galleries

fields.headline: Uniform look
fields.standfirst: Top designer spruces up staff at Tate galleries
fields.trailText: The British fashion designer Sir Paul Smith has designed a new uniform for wardens, restaurant staff and shop assistants at Tate Modern and Tate Britain.
fields.body:
The British fashion designer Sir Paul Smith has designed a new uniform for wardens, restaurant staff and shop assistants at Tate Modern and Tate Britain.

The look, modelled here by staff at Tate Britain's exhibition, Intelligence: New British Art 2000, debuts today. The style is described by Damien Whitmore, communications director of the Tate, as "more informal" than the previous uniform.

Gone are the traditional sombre suits and traffic warden style caps favoured by most galleries and museums; instead, the uniform is made up of a wardrobe of garments, including flat-front trousers, black V-neck sweaters, and bright orange polo shirts, from which staff can choose their own outfits.

Sir Paul, a longtime supporter of the gallery, was "the perfect partner" for the project, because, said Mr Whitmore, his designs were "traditional yet witty".

Sir Paul joins a long line of catwalk designers who have turned their hand to the less glamorous world of uniforms. Paul Costelloe recently designed new uniforms, including orange fleeces and baseball caps, for the shop floor staff of Sainsbury's.

Earlier this year, Barclays Bank paid £3m for a new staff uniform designed by Jeff Banks.

fields.headline: Granada's £1.75bn ITV deal
fields.trailText: Granada Media yesterday won the struggle to become the dominant player in the ITV network when it agreed to pay £1.75bn for the Meridian, Anglia and HTV franchises.
fields.body:
Granada Media yesterday won the struggle to become the dominant player in the ITV network when it agreed to pay £1.75bn for the Meridian, Anglia and HTV franchises.

The agreement puts Granada in pole position to take full control of the network when legislation allows.

ITV has been whittled down from 15 firms to just two of any size, with Carlton remaining as Granada's only real rival.

Granada is buying the ITV licences from Lord Hollick's United News & Media. Talks between the two opened last week after United's plan to merge with Carlton was ruled out by competition authorities.

"This is a transforming deal for Granada and for ITV, which moves from a federal structure to a partnership between us and Carlton," said Charles Allen, the Granada chief executive. "We will be better able to make big decisions and continue to lobby for rules allowing a single ITV company."

The deal adds Meridian and Anglia to Granada's portfolio, joining Yorkshire, Tyne-Tees and LWT. It will broadcast to 15m homes and command advertising sales of £1bn.

Granada will have to sell HTV to meet rules limiting any firm from covering more than 15% of the UK audience.

Lord Hollick, a Labour peer, yesterday described the decision by Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, two weeks ago, which ended his ambitions in ITV, as "perverse". Mr Byers insisted on the sale of the Meridian licence on the south coast as a condition of United's merger with Carlton. This proved too much for Carlton.

Lord Hollick yesterday played down speculation that United's other assets including the Daily and Sunday Express were for sale but added that he would always listen to offers.

webTitle: MPs in 'Punch and Judy' euro row

fields.headline: MPs in 'Punch and Judy' euro row
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union


Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The Westminster launch of a Commons report on the euro yesterday descended into a bitter personal spat between furious Labour and Tory MPs, in what one onlooker described as a "Punch and Judy show".
fields.body:
The Westminster launch of a Commons report on the euro yesterday descended into a bitter personal spat between furious Labour and Tory MPs, in what one onlooker described as a "Punch and Judy show".

The publication of the Treasury select committee's report on the Maastricht criteria for joining the single currency was overshadowed by a bout of public squabbling between members of the committee.

The press conference to launch the report swiftly descended into acrimony as Labour and Tory MPs angrily traded insults in front of journalists and television cameras. The spat marked a sharp breach of the parliamentary convention that select committees try to avoid partisan politics.

The report was cautiously worded and did not come down on either side of the argument regarding British membership.

Nevertheless, the four Conservative MPs on the committee refused to endorse it and backed a minority report which accused the chancellor, Gordon Brown, of being "economical with the truth" regarding the government's intentions.

At the launch, held in a Commons committee room, Labour MP Brian Sedgemore angrily accused the Tories of breaking a "gentlemen's agreement". "They have said between now and the next election it's war and I can tell you that I won't be as well behaved in future. It's a bad, bad, show," he said.

Tory MP Sir Michael Spicer retorted sarcastically that it was "a great honour" to have Mr Sedgemore at the launch "because he very rarely shows up except for public occasions".

The dispute grew even more personal when another Tory, the Eurosceptic Sir Teddy Taylor, complained about the cost of the "top-class" hotels used by the committee when they travelled to Germany to see how the euro was working.

At this the Labour committee chairman Giles Radice sniped: "I notice Teddy Taylor came with us and didn't seem to mind staying in them."

As the proceedings degenerated into what one MP on the committee described as a "Punch and Judy show", an other Labour MP, James Plaskitt, was derided by Tory David Ruffley for "typical Gordon Brown glove-puppet spin".

After the meeting, Sir Michael admitted: "The climate was hotter than usual but the committee on the whole gets on pretty well together. This was really a straightforward party political divide."

The committee's report did not take a view on whether the chancellor's five tests for euro membership have been met, although it noted that Britain had met all the original conditions laid down for membership in the Maastricht treaty, except exchange rate stability.

It also warned that British influence in shaping EU economic policy could be weakened if the meetings of the eurozone finance minister were to "usurp" the role of the full council of ministers (Ecofin).

"The British government will need to ensure that, while the UK remains outside Emu, the euro-area group does not usurp the role of Ecofin in shaping economic policy," it said.

While City firms are already using the euro, the committee said the majority of British businesses were waiting for a lead from government before making expensive preparations to switch to the euro.

fields.headline: Coventry sell £13m Keane to Inter
fields.trailText: Coventry City will today clinch a £13m deal to sell Robbie Keane to Internazionale.
fields.body:
Coventry City will today clinch a £13m deal to sell Robbie Keane to Internazionale.

The Highfield Road chairman Bryan Richardson was due to fly to Italy from holiday in the US last night to conclude the deal for the 20-year-old striker.

He said: "We have basically agreed a deal and I hope to tie up the details when I fly to Milan. Robbie Keane is discussing the matter with his agent at the moment. The fee is £13 m - dropping to £12.5m when my phone bill is taken into account."

Keane, who became English football's most expensive teenager when he joined the Sky Blues from Wolves for £6m last August, has been top of the Milanese club's list since bids to sign Lazio's Marcelo Salas and Bordeaux's Sylvain Wiltord fell through.

Earlier the Coventry manager, Gordon Strachan, had insisted he would do all he could to keep hold of the Republic of Ireland international, who scored 12 goals last season despite missing much of it with a knee injury.

Strachan said: "Obviously we are doing all we can to keep hold of him. Robbie is very special to us." And he joked: "I'm just hoping Robbie doesn't like the San Siro, doesn't like the wages - and wants to come back here."

Keane's rapid rise to prominence comes despite the less-than-enthusiastic assessment of the Manchester United manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, just under a year ago, as Middlesbrough, Coventry and Aston Villa were bidding to sign the Dubliner from Wolves.

Ferguson claimed Keane, who has 16 caps, was only worth around £500,000 when Villa were ready to shell out £5.5m for him. Strachan admitted he was surprised when his chairman told him the Sky Blues were ready to pay £6m for Keane last August.

There will be red faces at Molineux, however, if the move to Internazionale goes through as the First Division side neglected to include a sell-on fee when negotiating Keane's move to Coventry.

He scored the only goal - after a typical twisting, jinking run - on his return to the Black Country club in a pre-season friendly this week.

The Argentine international Fernando Redondo needed a police escort to shield him from angry Real Madrid fans who had gathered at the city's airport yesterday.

Redondo, 31, moved from Real Madrid to Milan on Thursday for £11m. Although the demonstration remained relatively peaceful, police intervened to protect Redondo from discontented fans who had been jostling with waiting reporters.

He had left Real Madrid's training camp in Switzerland yesterday morning, returning to the Spanish capital to resolve a number of personal and family issues before his move to Italy.

His status as a hero to the Real fans - after two Spanish league and two Champions League triumphs during his six years at the club - has quickly disappeared and has had to suffer public vilification during the last 24 hours.

A Real Madrid source leaked a copy of the transfer contract to the Spanish sports daily Marca, which published it on its front page yesterday. "Redondo signed first. Madrid want to demonstrate that the Argentine wanted to go," Marca commented.

Ironically Redondo could make his debut for Milan against Real Madrid on Tuesday when the two teams meet in the San Siro to celebrate the Italian club's centenary.

webTitle: Why money is killing the game I still love

fields.headline: Why money is killing the game I still love
fields.standfirst: Tony Cottee says that football will pay for having too many rich kids and too many foreigners
fields.trailText: July 2000, a month I have been building up to for a very long time. In fact, I have been waiting 18 years since my Dad told me at the age of 17 to invest in a pension that I would not receive until the next century. I immediately started putting aside the princely sum of £10 a month and have been waiting ever since.
fields.body:
July 2000, a month I have been building up to for a very long time. In fact, I have been waiting 18 years since my Dad told me at the age of 17 to invest in a pension that I would not receive until the next century. I immediately started putting aside the princely sum of £10 a month and have been waiting ever since.

Now that time has arrived a thought has occurred to me. How many of today's Premiership players will need a pension when they reach the age of 35? The answer, probably, is none because football has changed so remarkably since 1982. But has it changed for the better? I don't think so.

Who would have believed back then that on my pension date half the Premiership - or First Division as it was in those days - would be made up of foreigners?

I am not anti-foreign and the likes of Cantona, Zola, Gullit, Bergkamp, Schmeichel and Ginola have been good for our game and have helped the Premiership to become one of the most exciting leagues in the world. They have in many aspects helped the development and attitudes of British players and I can say through experience that it's a much harder league to play in now than 10 or even five years ago.

But I do think the time has come for us and all the other European countries to bring in rules restricting the number of foreign players. There have been many overrated and overpaid foreigners who have come to England and not been as good as the British players they have replaced. They have earned thousands of pounds without deserving it.

Lennart Johansson, president of Uefa, said recently that we have too many foreign players and he is right, because people don't realise the domino effect that they cause. Every not-so-good one forces a Premiership player into the First Division, and then more Englishmen into the Second and Third. In the end you may have around 300 professional-quality players with no club to play for.

I would like a ruling where 10 of a chosen squad must be British, and the other six from anywhere else. This will encourage clubs to develop home-grown talent mixed with only the cream from abroad. A club can have 15 foreigners if they like but on match days only six should be chosen.

I think the number of foreign imports would soon drop if they weren't more or less assured of first-team football.

Clubs need to take more responsibility as well. Appointing foreign managers is a guarantee that loads of foreign players will be coming in, as managers quite understandably like to have players they can converse with in their mother tongue. As good as the coach may be, it is not always a good thing for English football.

Clubs are too easily being persuaded to try the quick fix nowadays by splashing millions on foreigners instead of investing in the future. Arsenal have just bought two more foreigners yet their youth team have just won the FA Youth Cup. One of the cup-final goalscorers, Jay Bothroyd, has already been sold to Coventry.

Surely there must be a Tony Adams or Paul Merson waiting to come through? I just wonder if we will ever get the chance to see them.

Chelsea announced at the start of the summer that they would buy British, and have since bought three foreigners, reducing the chances of the Brits next season. Though, to be fair to both clubs, had they inquired about a British player - say in the First Division - they may have been quoted an exhorbitant figure, say £5m, for someone who has yet to appear at the highest level.

That can't be right. Transfer fees and the whole foreign problem have to be looked at so we can protect and improve the future of our game.

Our Euro 2000 performance doesn't bode well for the future but I believe we have an exciting crop of youngsters coming through who could be on top of the world in 2006. The next World Cup will come too quickly for them, and Euro 2004 should be used as a launch pad for the German World Cup. But if we can play as a team rather than as 11 talented individuals we might just have a chance with the likes of Beckham, Scholes, Cole and Ferdinand in our side.

Perhaps by then the government will have realised the shameful scenes in Charleroi and Brussels were not caused by true football fans but by thugs looking for the nearest punch-up. We don't get trouble inside grounds any more but the hooligans are still there and they certainly did everything possible to wreck our World Cup bid.

The government needs to act and perhaps now, in Adam Crozier, the Football Association's chief executive, we've at least got someone in the FA under the age of 70 who is willing to take some hard decisions.

We need to restructure our youth football before it is too late. The government keeps building houses on the playing fields and the kids now seem more interested in Gameboys than kicking a football around.

We need to get back to basics and teach kids of eight and nine to pass, control and shoot properly rather than to win every game and kick the ball as far as possible.

Better coaching and less of the "win at all costs" mentality has to be good for football. Parents should stop shouting and hollering, and encourage their children to play the game properly and practise their skills.

Perhaps then we might find among our population of 50 million someone who can play for England and actually kick the ball with his left foot.

Another thing we need to look at is the wage spiral which is getting worse and worse. It is only a question of time before a player is earning £100,000 a week - in some countries they already do - and clubs will go to the wall if they continue to pay players a weekly wage of even £20,000 - the exact sum it took me a year to earn in 1983.

Paying young players these vast amounts of money is not a good idea because being a millionaire by the age of 20 is not likely to keep you motivated for another 10 years or so.

Players will very soon start retiring at 27 or 28 with a swollen bank balance but fed up of the hassle and aggravation that comes with being a professional footballer, and with no desire to play any more.

The only connection between the points I've raised is the word "money" - the love of which is frequently seen as the root of all evil. I wouldn't go that far but it's fair to say that in 1983 football was a sport, now it's just a massive business empire.

I really do fear for the future and if I sound like a moaning old professional it's only because I care.

Still, I've had my time in the game and I wouldn't change a minute. I would just like to see the powers that be do what's right for the game and its future and sacrifice short-term gain for long-term planning.

I will take my pension and enjoy it, happy that we are not hosting the World Cup in 2006. My two-year-old twin boys will be 28 and in their prime when England hopefully hold the tournament in 2026 and I might see them help recapture the cup 60 years after the last time. And, by the way, one of them is left footed.

As good as the coach may be, it is not always a good thing for English football. Clubs are too easily being persuaded to try the quick fix nowadays by splashing millions on foreigners instead of investing in the future. Arsenal have just bought two more foreigners yet their youth team have just won the FA Youth Cup. One of the cup-final goalscorers, Jay Bothroyd, has already been sold to Coventry. Surely there must be a Tony Adams or Paul Merson waiting to come through? I just wonder if we will ever get the chance to see them. Chelsea announced at the start of the summer that they would buy British, and have since bought three foreigners, reducing the chances of the Brits next season. Though, to be fair to both clubs, had they inquired about a British player - say in the First Division - they may have been quoted an exhorbitant figure, say £5m, for someone who has yet to appear at the highest level. That can't be right. Transfer fees and the whole foreign problem have to be looked at so we can protect and improve the future of our game. Our Euro 2000 performance doesn't bode well for the future but I believe we have an exciting crop of youngsters coming through who could be on top of the world in 2006. The next World Cup will come too quickly for them, and Euro 2004 should be used as a launch pad for the German World Cup. But if we can play as a team rather than as 11 talented individuals we might just have a chance with the likes of Beckham, Scholes, Cole and Ferdinand in our side. Perhaps by then the government will have realised the shameful scenes in Charleroi and Brussels were not caused by true football fans but by thugs looking for the nearest punch-up. We don't get trouble inside grounds any more but the hooligans are still there and they certainly did everything possible to wreck our World Cup bid. The government needs to act and perhaps now, in Adam Crozier, the Football Association's chief executive, we've at least got someone in the FA under the age of 70 who is willing to take some hard decisions. We need to restructure our youth football before it is too late. The government keeps building houses on the playing fields and the kids now seem more interested in Gameboys than kicking a football around. We need to get back to basics and teach kids of eight and nine to pass, control and shoot properly rather than to win every game and kick the ball as far as possible. Better coaching and less of the "win at all costs" mentality has to be good for football. Parents should stop shouting and hollering, and encourage their children to play the game properly and practise their skills. Perhaps then we might find among our population of 50 million someone who can play for England and actually kick the ball with his left foot. Another thing we need to look at is the wage spiral which is getting worse and worse. It is only a question of time before a player is earning £100,000 a week - in some countries they already do - and clubs will go to the wall if they continue to pay players a weekly wage of even £20,000 - the exact sum it took me a year to earn in 1983. Paying young players these vast amounts of money is not a good idea because being a millionaire by the age of 20 is not likely to keep you motivated for another 10 years or so. Players will very soon start retiring at 27 or 28 with a swollen bank balance but fed up of the hassle and aggravation that comes with being a professional footballer, and with no desire to play any more. The only connection between the points I've raised is the word "money" - the love of which is frequently seen as the root of all evil. I wouldn't go that far but it's fair to say that in 1983 football was a sport, now it's just a massive business empire. I really do fear for the future and if I sound like a moaning old professional it's only because I care. Still, I've had my time in the game and I wouldn't change a minute. I would just like to see the powers that be do what's right for the game and its future and sacrifice short-term gain for long-term planning. I will take my pension and enjoy it, happy that we are not hosting the World Cup in 2006. My two-year-old twin boys will be 28 and in their prime when England hopefully hold the tournament in 2026 and I might see them help recapture the cup 60 years after the last time. And, by the way, one of them is left footed.

fields.headline: Team by team
fields.trailText: Aberdeen
fields.body:
Aberdeen

Manager

Ebbe Skovdahl

League position last season 10th (of 10)

Relieved of their toaster and a PA announcer - the consequence of drastic cost-cutting measures - sustenance in the form of league points may also be at a premium. Final appearances in both domestic cups did not mask shocking form that would have cost them their Premier place but for First Division runners-up Falkirk failing to meet the stadiums criteria. Monetary constraints have prevented Skovdahl adding to his squad during the summer.

Hibernian

Manager Alex McLeish

Position 6th

Another of the plethora of betwixt-and-between clubs with empty pockets. The £2m brought in by Kenny Miller's move to Rangers will have to be reinvested in fresh talent to prevent Hibs going backwards. A clutch of free transfers of varying reputations has allowed McLeish to contemplate a top-six finish but the loss of Miller leaves him dreadfully short on attacking options.

Celtic

Manager

Martin O'Neill

Position 2nd

Come what may, O'Neill is surely destined to be the first of four Celtic managers in as many years to remain in the post longer than the gestation period of a hump-backed whale.

Assuming he finds several more acquisitions, following Chris Sutton and Joos Valgaeren, Celtic should run Rangers closer than last season. Though not very close. But anything fewer than 21 points will be claimed as progress, and the presence of Henrik Larsson ensures Celtic will be a more cohesive force.

Kilmarnock

Manager Bobby Williamson

Position 9th

Flirted with relegation - when it existed - last season and the Scottish trio of Andy McLaren, Craig Dargo and Neil McFarlan signed during the summer may not be capable of pushing them further up the table. Ally McCoist has wangled a pay-as-you-play one-year contract but the fact that Williamson gave him a run-out says a great deal about the lack of confidence he has that his forward line can produce goals. An outside bet for the drop, but this should ultimately be avoided.

Dundee

Manager

Ivano Bonetti

Position 7th

Outrageous claims have been made for the Dens Park side in the wake of the Bonetti brothers taking over the reins from Jocky Scott, mainly based on the raft of foreign talent attracted to Tayside. Whether unknowns with sexy names such as Marco di Marchi, Fabian Caballero and Juan Saracan help Dundee scale the heights better that the home-grown journeymen that Scott had punching above their weight remains to be seen.

Motherwell

Manager Billy Davies

Position 4th

Narrowly missed out on Europe and the progress under Davies these past two years has been steady, if not spectacular. No significant additions to the squad in the close season, but the Fir Park players proved during the last campaign that when they discover the winning groove they are capable of taking points off any side.

Dundee United

Manager

Paul Sturrock

Position 8th

The bottom fell out of the Tannadice club's season when Billy Dodds was sold to Rangers in December. Third in the table at the time, they won only three of their last 21 league games. Sturrock insists everyone at United is refreshed and ready to improve. He said the same last year. His major buys, Danny Griffin from St Johnstone and Hansey Aljofree from Bolton, should not be enough to prevent them from scratching around the lower reaches.

Rangers

Manager Dick Advocaat

Position 1st

A place in the last 16 of the Champions League will be the ultimate aim for the Ibrox club. Their stranglehold on the Scottish game is unassailable and with a 31-man squad, boosted by seven acquisitions, the concept of having a team for the home front and one for continental competition moves closer. Advocaat has given Rangers greater credibility abroad. Now he will be intent on delivering the promise they demonstrated in the Champions League last year.

Dunfermline Athletic

Manager

Jimmy Calderwood

Position promoted

Calderwood has enjoyed a more fruitful close season than most of his new rivals, recruiting five players, all of whom have some form of Dutch connection.

The Fife club may have won promotion as bridesmaids to the First Division champions St Mirren but could be in the top six when the league splits after 33 matches. Calderwood is a curious mix, a Dutch footballing philosophy bolted on to an abrasive Scottish psyche after nearly three decades in Holland as player and coach.

St Mirren

Manager

Tom Hendrie

Position promoted

Trepidation must be the overriding feeling around Love Street this week, for with the loss of Junior Mendez to their fellow Premier new boys Dunfermline, St Mirren appear to have too young and inexperienced a squad to survive in the top flight. Hendrie certainly had his youngsters playing with a pluck and an aggressive streak that was instrumental in clinching the First Division title, but they could be about to yo-yo.

Heart of Midlothian

Manager

Jim Jefferies

Position 3rd

Penury has prompted a "mystery" consortium to launch a bid to buy into the club, which followed chief executive Chris Robinson ordering Jefferies to draw up a list of players that could be moved on to reduce the wage bill. Reputedly losing £250,000 a month less than a year after media group SNG bought an £8m stake, the club denied Jefferies a summer transfer pot. Moves behind the scenes could undo Jefferies's work in re-establishing his team as Scotland's third force.

St Johnstone

Manager

Sandy Clark

Position 5th

Clark appears determined to shake off the Perth club's tag as marginally less enjoyable to watch than recently emulsioned walls. He has signed Paul Hartley from Hibs and Tommy Lovenkrands from AB Copenhagen and is suggesting that St Johnstone may be prepared to pay a more expansive game. Another team who will will count themselves successful if grouped with the old firm for the last five games of the 38-match season. Such an ambition should be attainable.

webTitle: Wenger will spend to save Arsenal's season

fields.headline: Wenger will spend to save Arsenal's season
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger has been guaranteed more than £50m to prevent Arsenal's season from coming apart at the seams after reluctantly agreeing to sell Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit to Barcelona for an estimated £32m yesterday.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger has been guaranteed more than £50m to prevent Arsenal's season from coming apart at the seams after reluctantly agreeing to sell Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit to Barcelona for an estimated £32m yesterday.

Wenger will respond to the demoralising loss of two of his most influential players three weeks before the start of the new season by resurrecting a deal for the French striker Sylvain Wiltord and attempting to salvage something from the highly embarrassing transfer fiasco involving the Brazilian midfielder Edu.

However, even with his undoubted knack of discovering high-calibre players at relatively low cost, Wenger is acutely aware that time is running out if the London club are to mount a more sustained challenge to Manchester United.

Arsenal finished 18 points adrift of Sir Alex Ferguson's team last season and, unless Wenger acts swiftly by bringing in at least two or three top-quality signings, their transfer dealings this summer have done little to suggest the gulf will be reduced over the next 10 months.

As well as losing Petit and Overmars, they have also allowed Nigel Winterburn and Davor Suker to join West Ham United on free transfers, meaning the loss of four influential players this summer, with only the French midfielder Robert Pires and the Cameroon playmaker Bisan Etame Mayer, known as Lauren, being added to the payroll.

Wenger is now under intense pressure to bolster his increasingly fragile-looking squad although money should be no object in his pursuit for new players, especially as a good percentage of Nicolas Anelka's £23m sale to Real Madrid remains untouched.

The Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein confirmed last night that Barca's £32m cheque had gone straight into the club's transfer budget and Wenger will have carte blanche to sign some of the world's leading players.

His first task will be lodging an improved offer for Wiltord after balking at Bordeaux's £15m asking price for the player who scored France's injury-time equaliser against Italy in the Euro 2000 final.

However, Dein also confirmed that the club had not, contrary to reports, abandoned all hope of sorting out Edu's passport problems and resurrecting a £6m deal for the Corinthians midfielder that most observers believed had been brought to its knees.

"We are still actively trying to get Edu as well as a couple of others," said Dein. "The fans simply have to trust Arsène's judgment - and I don't believe anyone could have any questions about it since he joined the club.

"Admittedly the timing of this deal perhaps does not work in our favour but it's all about whether players are available at a given time."

Although it will be of little consolation to Arsenal's fans, the departure of Overmars and Petit represents a massive financial success for the club.

Overmars cost £5.5m from Ajax three years ago and Arsenal recruited the versatile Gilles Grimandi as part of the deal when Petit arrived from Monaco in a £3.5m deal.

Both played a pivotal part in the club's 1998 double but Overmars suffered from a loss of form and recurrent ankle injuries last season while Petit repeatedly threatened to quit the English game because of his disciplinary problems during a disappointing campaign for the club.

When Barcelona contacted the players' advisers at the start of summer they immediately let it be known they would relish the move and, no matter how reluctant Wenger was to accept the inevitable, he was realistic enough to accept there was no way financially that Arsenal could compete.

Although Arsenal rarely reveal the prices they pay, their 25 signings under Wenger are believed to have been made for a total of around £58m, while more than 30 players have been shipped out for a combined income of approximately £77m.

But the problem Wenger is likely to encounter is coming across any club willing to part with key players so close to the new season.

The left-sided Pires may be seen as a ready-made replacement for Overmars but he did not play as an out-and-out winger for Marseille, while much will depend on how quickly Lauren, a £7m arrival from Real Mallorca, acclimatises to the English game.

Wenger will renew his acquaintance with Overmars and Petit when Arsenal meet Barcelona in a pre-season tournament hosted by Ajax next week.

The Dutch international winger Boudewijn Zenden's £7.6m transfer from Barcelona to Lazio has fallen through.

webTitle: Deschamps off to Valencia but Petrescu sale collapses

fields.headline: Deschamps off to Valencia but Petrescu sale collapses
fields.trailText: Didier Deschamps will complete a £2.3m move to Valencia next week after Chelsea agreed the switch with the Spanish club. The French midfielder , who led his country to Euro 2000 triumph, asked for a move after to failing to settle in English football.
fields.body:
Didier Deschamps will complete a £2.3m move to Valencia next week after Chelsea agreed the switch with the Spanish club. The French midfielder , who led his country to Euro 2000 triumph, asked for a move after to failing to settle in English football.

Chelsea also agreed the £800,000 sale of Dan Petrescu to Southampton but the deal collapsed when the Romanian wing-back failed to agree personal terms.

Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchison said he sanctioned the sale of Deschamps, 32, with regret because he believed the Frenchman still had plenty to offer the club as a player or, in future, as a coach.

Hutchinson said: "Didier is a great professional and still a very good player, as he proved in Euro 2000.

"Perhaps because the length of time he spent in Italy, he didn't adapt to the English game as well as he would have liked last season but I still believe, if he had stayed at Chelsea, he would have done better in the coming season.

"He sat down with me three months before the end of the season and explained his reasons, which were personal. It certainly wasn't that he didn't like Chelsea or that he didn't like English football.

"But he said, if the right opportunity came, would we allow him to go? Reluctantly, I agreed to that."

Valencia swooped for Deschamps, the first Frenchman past 100 caps, whom Gianluca Vialli bought from Juventus for £3.5m last summer.

The Spaniards were runners-up in last season's Champions' League and finished third in the La Liga.

Deschamps will fly to Spain on Monday to complete the deal. He will link up with the Slovenia midfielder Zlatko Zahovic, who has joined Valencia from Olympiakos.

Petrescu, meanwhile, seems surplus to requirements at Stamford Bridge. He fell out of favour at the end of last season after a row with Vialli during a match at Manchester United.

There was no place in the FA Cup final for the Romanian who insists he wants to stay, but Hutchinson emphasised Chelsea's willingness to sell.

Hutchinson said: "He's a Chelsea player and under contract to Chelsea but we've made it clear by accepting an offer from Southampton that, provided we can do a deal with the club, we are prepared to let Dan go."

Glenn Hoddle brought Petrescu to Stamford Bridge for £2.3m from Sheffield Wednesday in 1995 but his attempt to sign the 32-year-old for the Saints was thwarted.

The Fifa president Sepp Blatter will instigate a wide-ranging discussion into the World Cup bidding process at the executive meeting of the world governing body in Zurich on Thursday.

The South Africans have requested that Germany's victory in the race to host the 2006 event should be examined by an arbitration panel.

However, the debate will have no bearing on the investigation into the South African claims by the Fifa general secretary Michael Zen-Ruffinen.

webTitle: New bhoy Valgaeren thrown straight in as Rangers recall Amoruso

fields.headline: New bhoy Valgaeren thrown straight in as Rangers recall Amoruso
fields.trailText: The Belgium international Joos Valgaeren looks set to move straight into heart of the Celtic defence tomorrow against Dundee United after Martin O'Neill's second signing - a £3.8m buy from the Dutch club Roda JC Kerkrade - was rubber-stamped yesterday.
fields.body:
The Belgium international Joos Valgaeren looks set to move straight into heart of the Celtic defence tomorrow against Dundee United after Martin O'Neill's second signing - a £3.8m buy from the Dutch club Roda JC Kerkrade - was rubber-stamped yesterday.

The 24-year-old former Mechelen defender came through a medical without a hitch and signed a five-year contract before training with his new team-mates.

"Celtic is a club which has fantastic support and the ambition and potential to become a force in Europe once again," said Valgaeren, who has six caps and will increase competition for places as Alan Stubbs and Tom Boyd are also vying to be part of O'Neill's first-team plans.

"I am delighted that we have signed Joos, a quality international defender," O'Neill said. "He is a strong, talented player and I have no doubt he will be a valuable addition to our playing squad. He performed very well for Belgium at Euro 2000 and I am looking forward to him repeating this level of performance for Celtic as we challenge for domestic and European honours."

The Rangers manager Dick Advocaat sprang a surprise by recalling Lorenzo Amoruso for today's visit of St Johnstone, and even handed back the captain's armband to the Italian defender.

Amoruso, who had to have surgery on an ankle injury late last season, was on the verge of joining Sunderland during the close season but is back in favour at Ibrox as a replacement for the Australian international Craig Moore, whose knee problem aggravated against Zalgiris Kaunas in midweek may require an operation.

"I was close to signing for Sunderland but I couldn't agree to something," said Amoruso. "Although I almost signed nothing has changed. I am still captain of this club, captain of this team."

Bert Konterman, Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Andrei Kanchelskis are also back in action with Paul Ritchie, Allan Johnston, Dariusz Adamczuk and Jonatan Johansson pushed to the sidelines.

The Aberdeen manager Ebbe Skovdahl's most pressing selection problem before taking on promoted Dunfermline at East End Park today is choosing the replacement in goal for the retired Jim Leighton.

"Ryan Esson and David Preece have both shown tremendous attitude. You will find out tomorrow at 2.15pm who is playing," he said.

"It is a long season ahead and it is inevitable that we will use all the players. It is important that the players who do not start do not get disappointed but have the mental courage to prove me wrong."

The Kilmarnock manager Bobby Williamson admits to some relief that his team selection has not been badly affected by injuries for today's match against St Mirren. He was consistently denied a full squad last season, which cost the club dear as they struggled near the foot of the table.
