webTitle: O'Neill goes naked into the arena

fields.headline: O'Neill goes naked into the arena
fields.standfirst: Celtic's new manager kicks off the season with some trepidation, says  Thomas Kerr
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill might be under the impression that he has joined a new football club. The problem is that he has not. He has joined Celtic, an emotional, social and religious institution, numbering millions of devotees around the world, for whom the words "football club" seem laughably insufficient.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill might be under the impression that he has joined a new football club. The problem is that he has not. He has joined Celtic, an emotional, social and religious institution, numbering millions of devotees around the world, for whom the words "football club" seem laughably insufficient.

Celtic, with thousands of shareholders, are owned not by any one property magnate or a plethora of business tycoons, but by their own in-fighting fans. They were owned until recently by a bald, little Scots-Canadian, Fergus McCann, who rode into town, built the biggest club stadium in Britain and promptly cleared out.

The club has had five managers in five years - a Scotsman, a Dutchman, a Slovak, an Englishman and now an Ulsterman - and last year descended into holding press conferences in pubs. In a huddle, the players kiss and cuddle before kick-off while their supporters, like a gospel choir, sing a hymn about lovelorn Irish peasantry.

O'Neill kicks off his Celtic coaching career in earnest tomorrow night with the club's opening fixture of the new Scottish Premier League season at Dundee United. In the canon of Celtic fiascos and dramas, this is entirely fitting.

Down the years Tannadice has been the scene of some calamitous Celtic misfortune. It was there that Mick McCarthy, their centre-back, once managed to score at both ends. It was there, too, in Liam Brady's first match in charge, that his team managed to score three goals while conceding four. The black crepe around the Tannadice memories for Celtic fans is that at least twice in the 90s, Rangers have clinched the championship title in that same stadium.

After his first game Brady appeared frazzled and left Glasgow two years later like a wounded animal. By 8pm tomorrow O'Neill could well have a fevered brow.

"It was the toughest decision of my life coming here but it was still a job I had to take," O'Neill still insists. "I think you only need to look at this club, the ground and the supporters to appreciate that managing Celtic is a challenge to be relished."

He has arrived at a club in ferment, stirred by years of unfulfilled promise and expectation, whose fans bowl along regardless to Parkhead in throngs. The overflowing of the hot-blooded passion and faith of Celtic's fans has been questioned down the years but their willingness to take emotional punishment and still come back for more is beyond doubt.

Parkhead has 60,000 seats and most Saturdays they are filled. There is talk of an extension to 70,000 in the near future and this is not an over-reaching ambition. The man who sets Celtic alight, and navigates them successfully in Europe, will be laughing all the way to the bank.

O'Neill, though, has inherited a squad with glaring weaknesses. If some of his players are not well endowed technically, others seem to have been in psychological disarray. Eyal Berkovic, for one, did not play for a quarter of last season because, it was claimed, his mind was not right. Olivier Tebily, a defender from the Ivory Coast, was claimed to have been held hostage for two days during a trip home. Bought by John Barnes, he is one of the doziest defenders ever seen in the Scottish game, which has had more than its fair share of somnambulists.

With the Brazilian defender Rafael Schiedt included in his catalogue of woes, O'Neill must have an even greater sense of Rangers' superiority. Like Tebily, he was signed by Barnes, and at the insistence of the club Schiedt is commonly referred to by his christian name for obvious reasons.

O'Neill at least seems to be a realist. He has some gouging and surgery to perform quite unlike any he has experienced at Wycombe or Leicester.

"In terms of the number of players at their disposal and their quality, Dick Advocaat and Rangers are far ahead of us," said O'Neill. "If I can, though, I'd like at least to get off to the best possible start to keep up the pressure on our rivals. In our pre-season games we've shown great determination, which has been a bonus. The players are at least trying to come round to my philosophy."

Pre-season, though, has not boded well for Celtic. A tour took them to Ireland, Scandinavia and, unfathomably for one day, to Germany. On their travels Celtic's world famous green and white hoops were stopped in their tracks by various teams of little renown. Back in Glasgow last weekend they took a hammering from a Bordeaux side that admittedly was highly talented, before regrouping in time to beat West Ham on Tuesday.

Perhaps none of this matters a great deal. By definition, pre-season is about conditioning and not conclusions. The hunch already, though, is that Celtic are on the threshold of another nerve-shredding campaign.

As if these omens were not enough, the £6m Chris Sutton has arrived from Chelsea. While Advocaat has bought seven new players, Sutton and the Belgium centre-back Joos Valgaeren are O'Neill's only summer signings. Yesterday Celtic completed the £3.8m deal for Valgaeren from Roda JC Kerkrade, though for an anaemic team it all seems an insufficient transfusion of new blood.

Sutton, inured surely to his own unflattering headlines at Chelsea, still popped up like a rabbit in headlights when he was ambushed by the media on his first day in Glasgow. This is another aspect to which even established names from England like O'Neill and Sutton must adapt. As Walter Smith has admitted since moving from Ibrox to Everton, the gang of pressmen who are interested in all things Rangers and Celtic is like no other in British football. It is this pressure from the media, and how O'Neill handles it, which will be a determining feature of his success or failure in Scotland.

For two years , though, there has been one shining light at Parkhead, and O'Neill can at least be grateful that it is back on full beam. Henrik Larsson is this team's heart and soul, the imaginative catalyst forever dragging Celtic out of a hole. After 10 months out with a broken leg, the Swede appears back to his ferreting, mischievous best. "You can see just by looking at him what a special talent he is," says O'Neill. "I'd heard a lot about Henrik in England but it is still wonderful to work with his talent and attitude."

The green half of Glasgow awaits to see if Larsson and Sutton can work in harness. An emotional football city is also braced to judge whether a charming Irishman can restore Celtic once the blarney has ceased.

fields.headline: Hillsborough retrial 'would be unfair'
fields.trailText: A judge explained yesterday why a senior police officer would not face a retrial in connection with the Hillsborough disaster, saying he could not get a fair trial if the case returned to court.
fields.body:
A judge explained yesterday why a senior police officer would not face a retrial in connection with the Hillsborough disaster, saying he could not get a fair trial if the case returned to court.

On Monday, Mr Justice Hooper ended the trial of former chief superintendent David Duckenfield when the jury failed to reach a verdict after more than four days of deliberations at the end of a six-week trial.

Mr Duckenfield, 55, of Bournemouth in Dorset, was match commander at Sheffield Wednesday's ground in April 1989 when 96 Liverpool fans were crushed to death during an FA Cup semi final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest

He faced two sample charges of manslaughter in a private prosecution brought by the Hillsborough Family Support Group.

The judge said Mr Duckenfield had endured a public trial and the "very public humiliation that accompanied it".

"I have no doubt that to require him to undergo a further trial would, in the very unusual circumstances of this case, constitute clear oppression," said the judge.

"In saying that, I do not in any way underestimate the suffering of those who lost their loved ones at Hillsborough, and the many others whose lives were so deeply affected by the events of that day. I have an overriding duty to ensure a fair trial for the defendant. That, I am firmly convinced, is no longer possible."

Mr Duckenfield's deputy, ex-superintendent Bernard Murray, 58, of Pontefract in West Yorkshire, was cleared of the same charges last week.

The prosecution had alleged that the two former South Yorkshire police officers were responsible for the deaths.

More than 50 of the victims' families, who had attended court every day, had wanted a re-trial and said they were "bitterly disappointed" by the judge's decision. Mr Justice Hooper said of the families: "Notwithstanding that much of the evidence was inevitably very emotional, their behaviour was impeccable."

The families have made it clear they will not take their legal action any further.

Ian Daines, South Yorkshire's assistant chief constable, said at a press conference yesterday: "The lessons have been learned and the blame has been distributed.

"Some of that blame has been laid quite properly at the foot of South Yorkshire police. Nothing more can be gained about the disaster. We heard all there is to hear about the tragedy."

He described allegations of a cover-up of evidence as "frankly nonsensical".

fields.headline: Divided house a happier home
fields.standfirst: With a third of the season to go,  Rob Steen weighs up the pros and cons
fields.trailText: Bleedin' typical, innit? Though Alf Garnett's passion lay with the 'Ammers rather than yer actual Essex CCC, his catchphrase remains no less apt. Here we are, two-thirds of the way through the inaugural two-divisional championship, and the weather has been as compassionate as a vulture at a funeral.
fields.body:
Bleedin' typical, innit? Though Alf Garnett's passion lay with the 'Ammers rather than yer actual Essex CCC, his catchphrase remains no less apt. Here we are, two-thirds of the way through the inaugural two-divisional championship, and the weather has been as compassionate as a vulture at a funeral.

Throw in iffy pitches and balls that could teach tungsten a thing or two about durability, and power resides ever more firmly with the seamer.

Up to yesterday, 43 bowlers had taken nine or more wickets at 25 or less, whereas only 12 batsmen had made 350 runs at 50. Moreover, while 42 bowlers boast a strike rate of under 50 balls a wicket, only nine First Division batsmen averaging 30 are scoring at more than 50 per 100 balls.

On the eve of the Old Trafford Test 10 Augusts ago, the number of bowlers paying fewer than 25 runs a victim was five. Admittedly the sun kept his hat on, pitches were slower than a sloth, Cruella de Vil would have had trouble picking the seam and a record 428 centuries ensued.

Yet the comparison is instructive. It emphasises how far the pendulum has swung, and how far we still are from anything remotely resembling an even contest.

Discussing the introduction of pitch liaison officers and a graded fine system back in April, Alan Fordham, the former Northamptonshire opener who is now the England and Wales Cricket Board's cricket operations manager, noted: "We played three-day games on four-day pitches, and now it's four-day games on two-day pitches."

This season 47% of games have been drawn, compared with last term's 32%, but this is more down to the elements than any marked improvement in those dying squares. Centralised groundsmen, accountable to board rather than county, grow ever more imperative.

The belated arrival of promotion and relegation, nevertheless, has found favour with the players. "Like four-day cricket, it'll take time to make an impact," says Surrey's Martin Bicknell, whose "opinions" entry in the Cricketers' Who's Who is invariably the most extensive, not to say heartfelt.

"There's no easy games now. Either you're battling for promotion or you're playing top sides all the time, which is great. Because we play everyone twice we have more scope to analyse opponents. From year to year a batsman's technique changes, but in the space of three weeks nothing alters much."

Surrey of course are the First Division leaders, but the keener edge is even more apparent in the Second Division, where only 33 points cover the nine sides and all are busting a gut to claim one of three promotion spots (which ought to settle at two to discourage meaningless fluidity).

As early as mid-June Ronnie Irani, the Essex captain, admitted that a draw in Cardiff would do nicely, the priority to put Glamorgan out of the running. He batted accordingly and the plan worked - with one minor glitch: the Welshmen are now top of the table.

"We recently sent a questionnaire to our members and not one in over 500 complained about being in the Second Division," says Steve Coverdale, chief executive of Northamptonshire. "We also asked non-renewals their reasons, and only two in 60 cited that.

"What members do miss is playing all the counties. At Cheltenham I was surprised at the number of spectators with no allegiance. One prominent figure at another Second Division club complained to me that his team were the best in the country but couldn't prove it. Four or five in our league could do just as well as four or five in the first."

The change in bonus points, designed to encourage the batsmen, has also been beneficial. The leading four in the First Division have gleaned 22% fewer bowling points than the bottom five (105 to 135) but 33% more batting points (88 to 66); in the lower tier, the top quartet have combined for almost 30% fewer bowling points (92 to 130). "We pushed for that change for a long time," enthuses Coverdale, "so we're delighted."

Coverdale's stance on the more vexing matter of imports highlights a rising trend. "In 1991, two of the game's biggest names were willing to come here and divide the work. They wouldn't have cost us much more than our then-overseas player was getting.

"Given the volume of international cricket my view has hardened: we should be able to sign two. It would also make it more attractive for the best, improve standards, raise interest and restore standards at second-XI level."

The most encouraging statistic emanates from a wholly unexpected quarter. Up to yesterday morning, Messrs Warne, Saqlain and Kumble had taken 119 wickets at 19.73, the leading homegrown twirlers, Giles, Salisbury and Patel, 102 at 22.17.

Whether this says more about batting techniques than any renaissance of English artful dodgery is open to conjecture.

webTitle: Yorkshire cry foul as Gough is kept in mothballs

fields.headline: Yorkshire cry foul as Gough is kept in mothballs
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 267
Yorkshire 4-0
fields.trailText:
Lancashire 267
Yorkshire 4-0
fields.body:
Yorkshire's growing disaffection with the central contracts system became more poignant yesterday when it was revealed that Darren Gough, withdrawn from this Roses match, will today play in a one-day match in Barnsley.

Gough, who has not played first-class cricket since he bowled 29 overs in the Test win at Lord's a month ago, will turn out for the Yorkshire Academy in a league match. He had contacted the England coach Duncan Fletcher and requested some cricket before next week's third Test in Manchester.

Yorkshire are already angry that the England and Wales Cricket Board has decided that players involved in both the Test and one-day squads this winter will play no more first-class cricket after September 5.

That means Gough and Craig White, and possibly Michael Vaughan, will miss the climax to the season when Yorkshire might be in a position to push for their first championship in 32 years.

Chris Hassell, the club's chief executive, said yesterday: "They have changed the goal-posts. When we entered into this agreement we were not told it would be like this. It is something I intend to bring up at the next ECB meeting.

"I would hope that the players concerned will be seething to miss the climax of the season and I know that our members will be. It is all very disappointing and in my view unnecessary."

Hassell was more philosophical about Gough's appearance in Barnsley this afternoon. "I would much prefer him to play here. But there is a difference between a one-day game and a four-day game, and we know what the situation is."

On another poor Headingley pitch Lancashire were happy to make 267 after being 128 for six and they were grateful to their wicketkeeper Warren Hegg for a spirited and characterful 75.

The pitch was green and again did too much, while the Lancashire batsmen were disappointed by the dampness. How will players ever develop on bogs like this? But duff pitches are such an established norm these days, and particularly at this ground, that the watching pitches liaison officer, AC Smith, is unlikely to report it unless he discovers something even nastier in the next few days. This is Yorkshire's last match at Headingley this summer.

This brought in the in-form Andrew Flintoff, fresh from his thumping century at the Oval.

Flintoff not only hit the ball hard but timed it well too. When he plays like this he looks out of scale with those around him. He resembles an Action Man amid small toy soldiers in a boy's playroom; a Dinky in the middle of a Matchbox collection.

He looked ready to play another major innings. But after striking five fours in a 24-ball 28 he was leg before to Elstub's third ball. Elstub had also surprised Flintoff with his first two deliveries.

In the next over Atherton was caught behind off one from Matthew Hoggard that moved away. fields.headline: Ramprakash cracks enigma code
fields.standfirst:
Middlesex 227
Sussex 84-2
fields.trailText:
Middlesex 227
Sussex 84-2
fields.body:
Mark Ramprakash looked anything but a rejected Test player yesterday. He scored a beautifully controlled, attractively fashioned hundred. And all the riddles about his temperament resurfaced. The boundary, not for the first time, rumbled with "Ramp" polemics.

He clearly likes the sylvan ambience at Southgate. Already this season he has composed a century against Worcestershire here and totted up the runs against Glamorgan. Yesterday, without ever giving the appearance of indecent haste, his hundred came in three hours of technical efficiency - while at the other end too many of his Middlesex team-mates sustained the unenviable habits of a summer which has seen them on the bottom of the Second Division.

Ramprakash is an infuriating enigma. When he bats like this, his strokes come straight from the manual of theoretical purity. His footwork was a treat. His confidence, which can be fatally elusive, grew as the murmurs of approval multiplied. He was making one of his elegant statements.

He sent a sharp, well pitched-up delivery from James Kirtley skimming through the covers in a style for doting north London schoolboys to savour. Into the 90s, he effortlessly picked up Robin Martin-Jenkins for a six over square-leg and into the tennis courts. Soon after, with the unconcern that characterised his innings, he steered Michael Bevan through the off side for his 49th century.

It is hard to tell what the Middlesex players make of their temporary departures from Lord's. They must miss the grandeur and history: walking through the Grace Gates and the Long Room, Father Time and those wondrous, familiar names on the stands.

But dare one suggest Southgate is really nearer the true, romantic spirit of county cricket? This could be a secluded village ground, defying as it does the proximity of London's traffic and concrete. The steepled church chimes the hour; just one house peeps through the trees.

The only disturbance to the pastoral scene came from the early rumbles of thunder and distant forked lightening. But these stayed away and there were only brief breaks for rain.

It was certainly no excuse for Middlesex's batting. Owais Shah unwisely played across the line to be bowled, Mike Roseberry edged outside the off-stump and Keith Dutch was a shade too tardy trying to withdraw his bat.

Kirtley was patently the best of the bowlers, taking five for 50 in just under 16 overs. He has a rhythmic run-up, deceptive pace and is now coming purposefully into form. By the sixth over Middlesex had lost both Roseberry and Justin Langer, both to Kirtley.

Chris Adams made a timely entry to account for David Nash in the slips, the captain's first wicket of the season. Sussex had shrewdly included an additional slow bowler in anticipation of turning times but it was another seamer, Martin-Jenkins, who checked Andrew Strauss when he seemed to be building a significant stand with Ramprakash.

Middlesex were all out for 227, almost half of them made by the undefeated Ramprakash. Then they brought on Phil Tufnell after only 12 overs and, from the late-evening evidence, he is going to be busy.

Sussex ended on 84 for two. Middlesex's obligatory task today will be to dislodge Bevan, who has ominously just completed three hundreds in a row.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: While Surrey, Lancashire and Yorkshire compete for the title, the main priority for the rest in the First Division is to avoid relegation.
fields.body:
While Surrey, Lancashire and Yorkshire compete for the title, the main priority for the rest in the First Division is to avoid relegation.

It is not surprising then that counties are beginning to fret about the absence of their England players. The result is they are beginning to suffer from the practicalities of central contracts.

In Dominic Cork's absence at Canterbury, Tim Munton took over as captain of Derbyshire and watched his openers, Steve Tichard and Steve Stubbings, reach 75 for 0 by lunch. Stubbings benefited from Kent's generosity. He was dropped twice in a morning session interrupted by showers.

More rain wiped out the afternoon's play and the break seemed to galvanise Kent. They took four wickets in eight overs after the resumption. David Fulton made amends for dropping Stubbings on 32 by holding a slip catch off Martin Saggers.

The pace bowler then knocked back Michael de Venuto's off-stump. David Masters continued the mini-collapse, having Titchard leg-before and running out James Pyemont.

Kent, who have lifted themselves off the bottom of the table with successive championship victories, confirmed their fightback when their captain Matthew Fleming took out Luke Sutton's middle stump.

Somerset's bowling attack at the Riverside was not only shorn of Andy Caddick but also Peter Trego. The teenage pace bowler, who has made a favourable impression in the absence of several injured colleagues, was required at Cardiff for England Under-19s' game with Sri Lanka.

The 35-year-old Paul Jarvis was called up for his first championship match of the season and disappeared for six an over as Durham's opener Jonathan Lewis at last discovered some form. Before yesterday, 17 championship innings had brought him only 326 runs. His first century of the season, between the showers, helped his side recover from 17 for two.

It has seldom been dull when Worcestershire have played Gloucestershire this season and it was no different on the first day of their Second Division match at New Road.

The England and Wales Cricket Board's pitch liaison officer, Phil Sharpe, watched as 15 wickets fell. It could have been worse. Rain restricted play to 73 overs.

After Worcestershire had decided to bat after winning the toss, Ben Gannon reduced them to 13 for three on a low, slow pitch which produced variable bounce. Ian Harvey took the next three before Mike Smith received some reward for his miserly swing bowling. He mopped up the tail to finish with four for 16.

Gloucestershire's brittle batting line-up must have known what was coming, however. Defending a total of 98, Glen McGrath bowled Worcestershire back into the game with four wickets of his own and Gloucestershire might now be hard-pressed to achieve a desired first innings lead.

England's under-19 side drew first blood in the three-match NatWest one-day international series against Sri Lanka with a tight 15-run victory in Cardiff yesterday.

After England made 238 for six in a match reduced to 42 overs, Sri Lanka were bowled out for 223 in 41 overs, their last six wickets falling for 37.

England's total owed much to an authoritative second-wicket partnership of 108 in 20 overs between Durham's Nicky Peng (89) and the captain Ian Bell (62) of Warwickshire.

fields.headline: Selvey
fields.standfirst: Fun days and run days out in the sticks
fields.trailText: Glance at any of the questionnaires in cricket magazines and there is usually a section to do with favourite grounds. Lord's is the invariably the response from players, followed by those on which they have been personally successful. Few place Derby, Ahmedabad or the Courtaulds ground at Coventry high on the agenda.
fields.body:
Glance at any of the questionnaires in cricket magazines and there is usually a section to do with favourite grounds. Lord's is the invariably the response from players, followed by those on which they have been personally successful. Few place Derby, Ahmedabad or the Courtaulds ground at Coventry high on the agenda.

My own first choice was also Lord's, but only when it was full for a final - I never played a Test match there. The rest of the time, when it was echoingly empty, it was the most dismal place to play. For that reason I was fond of playing on the out grounds, where a modest crowd of a couple of thousand was sufficient to surround the boundary two or three deep and lend atmosphere, where such numbers are lost on the big arenas.

Southend was always great fun - well, all Essex games were, to be honest - and so was Scarborough, either during the festival or for an ordinary championship match. Cheltenham, Bath and the Kent grounds, too.

Now the counties are cutting back. Lancashire, for instance, had a tradition of sharing matches around - to Blackpool and Lytham, Liverpool and Southport. But financial considerations, they say, have led to cutbacks. So apart from a tourist match and one championship game at Liverpool, it is Old Trafford or bust this season. All of which is a shame, not least because the out grounds, as seen at Oakham school this season, can provide enthralling cricket in a conducive atmosphere.

Only twice in my time at Middlesex did we get out into Lancashire. The last match of the 1977 season was at Blackpool with the pokiest dressing rooms ever, and as it transpired, no stumps for the start either. Best, though, was a match in late July 1981 when on a blistering hot Chas 'n' Di wedding day the queue at Southport stretched a quarter of a mile down the road.

I remember that match for two reasons. First, Wayne Daniel took a hat-trick in the second Lancashire innings, a fact that seems to have eluded the Wisden correspondent of the time. Secondly, Lancashire had hired a local authority road roller, a huge yellow job that the groundsman would set off on its very slow path down the pitch and then leave for another job, returning only to reverse it back up the pitch. The discovery that it had a vibration mode like an earthquake, surreptitiously engaged by the pull of a lever, came in handy for fragmenting the pitch when the second innings was looming.

But it was at the same venue 18 years ago this very weekend that Lancashire and Warwickshire contested perhaps the most remarkable game in County Championship history.

It had modest beginnings with Warwickshire winning the toss, batting and stumbling to 53 for three. Then ... well, let Foxy Fowler, the Lancashire opener, tell it.

"At a quarter past 12," he vividly recalls, "I pulled a muscle and left the field. And so I sat and watched as Alvin Kallicharran made 230 not out and Geoff Humpage 254, with a record fourth-wicket stand of 470; 523 they reached on the first day before they declared.

"I opened the batting with a runner and by the close I was 26 not out, and Bumble was out to Gladstone Small in the last over. They had a great tub of champagne outside their dressing room to celebrate, but we dragged it into ours instead and drank it. Bumble was fuming at getting out and on the way home he said: 'We'll win this.'

"Next day he ran for me, and I made 100 more before lunch and got out. Gladstone, meanwhile, had been called into the Test side and the Warwickshire manager David Brown became the first person to take a wicket as a substitute.

"We declared at 414 for six and, on the last day, the ball swung everywhere and Les McFarlane bowled them out for 111, including Gladstone, who had rejoined the match. I still hadn't fielded a ball but I opened again with Ian Foley as my runner, and when I reached 48 he suddenly told me to get my head down: he'd never made a fifty, he said.

"Anyway, I went on to get another hundred and when I got there, Foley, at square leg, waved his arms aloft, raised his bat to the crowd, took his hat off and shook hands with the opposition.

"Bumble and I put on 226 and we won by 10 wickets. No one else has scored two hundreds in a match batting entirely with a runner, and they changed the rules after that so it can't be done as an opener.

"Oh, yes, 1,274 runs for 20 wickets in the match, and Robin Dyer, with all his initials, bagged a pair."

webTitle: Lara injury gives Windies a fright

fields.headline: Lara injury gives Windies a fright
fields.trailText: West Indies officials insisted last night that Brian Lara - the man for whom they moved mountains to entice him to England - would definitely be fit for next week's third Test despite pulling out of their final warm-up match with a hamstring strain.
fields.body:
West Indies officials insisted last night that Brian Lara - the man for whom they moved mountains to entice him to England - would definitely be fit for next week's third Test despite pulling out of their final warm-up match with a hamstring strain.

The champion left-hander was named in the XI to play Leicestershire at Grace Road yesterday only to be withdrawn by team management at the last minute.

But the manager Ricky Skerritt said Lara was a definite starter for Old Trafford, where he hit 87 and 145 the last time West Indies visited these shores. "We didn't want Brian to aggravate the injury," Skerritt explained. "He was complaining of some tightness in his right hamstring. It was only a precaution."

Franklyn Rose and the leg-spinner Mahendra Nagamootoo both staked claims for the contentious fourth bowler's slot with two wickets apiece as Leicestershire were restricted to 210 for five on the first day.

Mohammad Azharuddin's nightmare week ended in further embarrassment yesterday when income tax officials seized "incriminating documents" from the house of his wife, the Bollywood actor Sangeeta Bijlani.

Only days after Australian television claimed the former Indian captain had made $50m (£33m) from fixing matches, officials raided the flat that Bijlani had apparently sold two years ago to a man called Suresh Jain.

"We were surprised that the flat still had her name written outside," a tax department spokesman said. "Incriminating documents relating to property and income tax evasion were recovered."

Detectives would no doubt love to be a fly on the wall at the Oval today when Azharuddin takes the field against the Rest of the World for an Asian XI managed by Kapil Dev and including Wasim Akram and Ajay Jadeja - all of whom have been linked with alleged corruption.

Azharuddin could be forgiven for being a little distracted at the crease although, with Indian detectives waiting to question him upon his return from London, he would be well advised to stay out in the middle as long as possible.

fields.headline: Bell tolls for Giddins as Warwickshire suffer death in the afternoon
fields.standfirst: Northamptonshire 296-7 v Warwickshire
fields.trailText: Northamptonshire 296-7 v Warwickshire
fields.body:
Ed Giddins has about as great a yen for the quiet life as Ernest Hemingway. The latest twist in a career that has seen Warwickshire's maverick banned for testing positive for cocaine, accused of throwing, voted one of the country's most eligible bachelors and get up more noses than is good for him, saw him "rested" here.

This euphemistic slap in the face comes just a couple of months after he was named man-of-the-match in England's test win over Zimbabwe at Lord's: the greasy pole has rarely been slicker.

Giddins has only taken 11 championship wickets at 31.63 apiece this term but that, one strongly suspects, was not the principal reason.

At Cheltenham last week he was spotted lounging in the outfield while colleagues were pressing for victory; not exactly the canniest ruse with a new contract in the balance.

Perhaps this was Warwickshire's way of tempering financial expectations. Not that they missed him yesterday. For that matter, Allan Donald might just as well have put his feet up, so negligible was his threat.

In fact, one needed a quite a deal of convincing that this was the opening day of a match at Edgbaston; the new ball proved innocuous, five of the first six wickets fell to spin - the exception a breathtaking run-out by Nick Knight - and Trevor Penney misfielded.

"Take away the Australian imports and you don't have much," asserted Steve Coverdale, Northamptonshire's chief executive, bemoaning the state of county batsmanship.

As if to ram home the point, Matthew Hayden, who is arguably his country's fourth-choice opener, sustained the visitors through thick and thin with a bruising 122. However, the crux of the day was the tussle between the hulking Hayden and Ashley Giles, one the Northamptonshire captain, aided by his left-handedness and an invitingly short boundary on the Pershore Road side, took by a technical knockout.

Four times he propelled the country's leading slow left-armer for six, one an immense straight blow that drew more than the odd gasp.

To his credit, Giles kept tossing the ball up, a far cry from those not-so-long-off days when, as befits an erstwhile fast bowler, he would go round the wicket, flatten his arc and fire it in. His rewards had come earlier, when he claimed the first four wickets - abetted by smart takes at slip from Dominic Ostler.

Only Jeff Cook could count himself unfortunate. While waiting for the Sydneysider to complete his seven-year residential qualification, there were doubtless a few mischievous cynics who felt that Northamptonshire's faith owed more to a desire to continue a virtually uninterrupted sequence of Cooks on the books spanning nigh-on three decades.

They know better now. Notwithstanding Hayden and Graeme Swann, for once leavening audacity with a dash of responsibility, this James Cook high school graduate (where else?) progressed as serenely as any until, attempting to glide Giles, he looked aghast as Ostler swooped low and two-handed.

Buoyed by his artful contribution to the NatWest quarter-final victory over Glamorgan, Neil Smith finally outsmarted Hayden, inducing a mis-drive to mid-off.

"I tell you what gets me," harrumphed one long-toothed Warwickshire member shortly before play. "It's having to pay extra for all those one-day Cup games." There's gratitude for you.

fields.headline: Two dead in Peru riots
fields.trailText: At least two people died and dozens were injured in pitched street battles between police and protesters in Lima yesterday, as President Alberto Fujimori was sworn in for a third term. Chanting "the dictator will fall", some of the tens of thousands of demonstrators set government buildings ablaze and threw rocks at windows.
fields.body:
At least two people died and dozens were injured in pitched street battles between police and protesters in Lima yesterday, as President Alberto Fujimori was sworn in for a third term. Chanting "the dictator will fall", some of the tens of thousands of demonstrators set government buildings ablaze and threw rocks at windows.

Inside the heavily guarded congress building, a beaming Mr Fujimori ignored the unrest sparked by a May 28 re-election many said was rigged and celebrated the beginning of an unprecedented third five-year term. It was also his 62nd birthday.

Mr Fujimori, wearing the red-and-white presidential sash, raised his arms in a victory sign as opposition congressmen shouted insults and waved signs that read "New Elections Now". As the president began his inaugural address, they walked out in protest.

At least 80 people - police and demonstrators - were injured in the protests, four of them by bullets, hospital officials said. The bodies of two men, apparently security guards, were later found in the ashes of a state bank that was set ablaze, said Fire commander Victor Podesta.

"While removing the debris we found one person dead in the first floor and the other on the second floor; apparently guards. We haven't identified them yet," said Cmdr Podesta.

Smaller protests erupted in Arequipa, Peru's second-largest city, some 465 miles southeast of Lima.

The office of the human rights ombudsman said 80 people were detained in Lima. Some 40,000 police had been called out.

As Fujimori swore to respect the country's constitution, riot police outside fired bullets in the air and tear gas into the crowds. A fire burned out of control in the lobby of the former education ministry, one of the tallest office towers in downtown Lima. Later, protesters' fires gutted the state bank building where the two dead were found, and the building housing the national elections board.

Chanting "the dictator will fall", some of the tens of thousands of demonstrators set government buildings ablaze and threw rocks at windows. Inside the heavily guarded congress building, a beaming Mr Fujimori ignored the unrest sparked by a May 28 re-election many said was rigged and celebrated the beginning of an unprecedented third five-year term. It was also his 62nd birthday. Mr Fujimori, wearing the red-and-white presidential sash, raised his arms in a victory sign as opposition congressmen shouted insults and waved signs that read "New Elections Now". As the president began his inaugural address, they walked out in protest. At least 80 people - police and demonstrators - were injured in the protests, four of them by bullets, hospital officials said. The bodies of two men, apparently security guards, were later found in the ashes of a state bank that was set ablaze, said Fire commander Victor Podesta. "While removing the debris we found one person dead in the first floor and the other on the second floor; apparently guards. We haven't identified them yet," said Cmdr Podesta. Smaller protests erupted in Arequipa, Peru's second-largest city, some 465 miles southeast of Lima. The office of the human rights ombudsman said 80 people were detained in Lima. Some 40,000 police had been called out. As Fujimori swore to respect the country's constitution, riot police outside fired bullets in the air and tear gas into the crowds. A fire burned out of control in the lobby of the former education ministry, one of the tallest office towers in downtown Lima. Later, protesters' fires gutted the state bank building where the two dead were found, and the building housing the national elections board. AP

webTitle: MoD drops £100m project to build anti-tank weapon

fields.headline: MoD drops £100m project to build anti-tank weapon
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence has scrapped plans to develop a European anti-tank weapon after spending more than £100m on the project, it announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence has scrapped plans to develop a European anti-tank weapon after spending more than £100m on the project, it announced yesterday.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said Britain will abandon the production of the medium-range Trigat weapon which is already 10 years late.

The decision was announced a day after Britain and seven other European countries pledged to strengthen cooperation on defence projects.

The national audit office revealed earlier this month that Trigat had been delayed for so long that it would have been ineffective by the time it was brought into service.

In a written Commons answer before the summer break, Mr Hoon said Britain had not been able to reach agreement with the other nations - France, Germany, the Netherlands and Belgium - developing the weapon.

The project began in the mid-1970s and the weapon was due to enter into service in 1996. The main British contractor to build the weapon was Matra BAe Dynamics.

The MoD will now look for an "off-the-shelf" anti-tank weapon which could be carried by light infantry forces. It will also review the weapons needed by heavier mechanised units.

The MoD yesterday also confirmed it is refusing to accept delivery of a new version of the US Chinook helicopter designed for special operations.

fields.headline: A step change
fields.trailText: Philological filibustering and two posthumous apologies
fields.body:
You may perhaps notice a step change in my column this week. While it is true that in former times...

Curious (Nuneaton) writes: What is a step change, exactly?

Smallweed remarks in tones of rampant exasperation: I'm not sure myself, and none of the madly rivalrous dictionaries which destroy the piece of my home with their constant shrieks of "me, me, me" has anything useful to say on the subject. Yet they seem to be everywhere nowadays. For instance, the arts council supremo/ guru/tsar Gerry Robinson hailed this week's government statement on spending on sport and arts as "a step change in support for the arts". Gordon Brown in his statement on the spending review promised a step change in investment in public transport, and when John Prescott, following behind, outlined his plans for investment, what did he call it? A step change.

A philologist writes: I suspect a step change is taking place here. People in search of a suitable cliche used to talk of a "sea change". Now the sea is replaced by a step. I find this deeply indicative, though of what I am not quite sure.

Smallweed rebarbatively snorts: Typical.

 Moreover, answer me this: why are so many people in government so apparently obsessed with rocket scientists? Even Tony Blair's public opinion guru/supremo/ tsar Philip Gould - soon to be appointed, I'm told*, to the office of Colander-Royal - is into this kind of talk. "We need one word," he writes in one of his famous memos, "to sum up each policy area and the government also. But we need also to hold to message, and keep it simple. For example, nobody in Britain (or perhaps a very few people) know we are preparing a plan for the NHS. This just needs the discipline of telling Britain repeatedly that we are producing a plan. This is not a rocket science ." (My bolding; whose else could it possibly be?)

Jack Straw, too, seems particularly fond of this conceit, and is given to saying: "We can solve this problem. It is not rocket science." Rocket science, in other words, can be taken to mean, in the context of government, "something we cannot see how to cope with". Which tellingly indicates, you may think, just how badly stumped Straw must be over asylum. The Home Office Immigration and Nationality Directorate, which superintends these matters, is run by a man called Chris Mace - a former rocket scientist with the MoD.

 To continue: While it is true that in former times, great swathes of the countryside...

We interrupt these proceedings for an urgent apology.

GK Chesterton (1874-1936): an apology. At some time in the eight long years since Smallweed was first foisted on a reluctant public, this column has quoted Chesterton as saying: "One sun is sublime. Two would be merely vulgar." While sorting through books at the weekend, I came across the original statement and found that what he actually said was that while one sun was splendid, six (not two) would be merely vulgar. This, I have to admit, is a very different kettle of fish. The word "sublime" occurs in his following sentence. I apologise to the late essayist for any inconvenience caused.

 Oxford scientists, the Guardian reports, have shown how a parasite can take control of the mind of its host. A tiny microbe that also infests humans can, they maintain, persuade a rat into a suicidal attraction to cats. Is there not a poignant parable here for the way that some special advisers/spin doctors imperil the very ministers whom they serve? Some special advisers are sage and dignified people who add to the public weal, but others are clever young microbes straight out of college with a taste for mischief, the conducting of inter-ministerial feuds, and getting people to notice them. Ministers so parasited may embark on a course of action which results, if not in a tendency to offer themselves up to cats, then at least in a tendency to offer themselves up to catastrophe. This is why Tony Blair was right to accept the wise advice of Lord Neill to cut down their numbers - even if he's not doing so yet. There are quite a few of these people whom this government would be better without.

 To continue: While it is true that in former times, great swathes of the countryside, particularly in north Cumbria...

We interrupt these proceedings for another apology.

James, Duke of Monmouth (1649-1685): an apology. It has come to my notice that in a former column I alleged that the Duke's supporters charged up the beach at Lyme Regis during his doomed rebellion howling out the unwieldy slogan: "No prelacy, no Erastianism." While sorting old notebooks this weekend, I found to my horror that in my original note of these words, they were said** to have been employed by supporters not of Monmouth but of the Earl of Argyll.

But which earl was that? Could it be Archibald Campbell (1598-1661), eighth earl, rebel and trouble maker, whose last words, at the end of a half hour speech on the scaffold, are said to have been: "I die not only a protestant, but with a heart-hatred of Popery, Prelacy, and all superstitions whatever"? Or his son, also Archibald (1629-1685), ninth duke, rebel and troublemaker, whose last words before execution reportedly were: " Lord Jesus receive me into Thy glory"? The latter I guess, since he was a co-conspirator of Monmouth. At any rate, I suppose I had better apologise to Monmouth, to both earls of Argyll, and to their various henchmen, kinsmen in perpetuity, castellans, baronial sheriffs, vavasours, personal trainers enfeoffed and disenfeoffed, understrappers, whipper- snappers, stewards within or without the wardrobe, victuallers, ostlers, resident gerontologists, dapifers, horse thegns, step-changers and special advisers howsomever and wheretofore, for any distress my reference may have caused.

I shall not be here next week, so my apology to the people of Hounslow will appear in a fortnight's time.

* Source: Smallweed's fevered imagination.

** Source: illegible after so many years. Sorry.

fields.headline: Jacob's Drum
fields.trailText:
This is Jacob's drum

how he beats on it how he fights on it

how he splits every crack of the house...
fields.body:
This is Jacob's drum

how he beats on it how he fights on it

how he splits every crack of the house
how he booms
how he slams
hair wet-feathered sweat gathering
red-face Jacob throwing his money down
all on the drum his one number
beating repeating

O Jacob

don't let go of it
don't let anyone take your drum
don't let anyone of all of them
who want you to be drumless
beating your song on nothing
Jacob they'd do it
believe them

it's time they say

to put your drum away

do you remember the glow-worm Jacob?

how we looked and nearly touched it
but you didn't want to hurt it?
I thought it was electric

some trash a child dropped
some flake of neon
stuck to a rock

don't put your finger on the light

you said and I stood still then
glow-worm Jacob remember it
I had the word but it was you
who told me it was living

and now I say to anyone

don't touch Jacob's drum

I thought it was electric some trash a child dropped some flake of neon stuck to a rock don't put your finger on the light you said and I stood still then glow-worm Jacob remember it I had the word but it was you who told me it was living and now I say to anyone don't touch Jacob's drum

webTitle: Novel damned by Captain Corelli's model

fields.headline: Novel damned by Captain Corelli's model
fields.trailText: A former Italian soldier regarded as the model for the hero of Captain Corelli's Mandolin - Louis de Bernières's bestselling novel set on the Greek island of Cephalonia during the second world war - has launched a fierce attack on the book as an unacceptable smear against Greek resistance to the Nazis.
fields.body:
A former Italian soldier regarded as the model for the hero of Captain Corelli's Mandolin - Louis de Bernières's bestselling novel set on the Greek island of Cephalonia during the second world war - has launched a fierce attack on the book as an unacceptable smear against Greek resistance to the Nazis.

In an interview with the Guardian, Captain Amos Pampaloni, 89, a Florentine whose experiences almost exactly reflect those of the fictional Corelli, accuses the British author of rewriting the story of Cephalonia's war and "pandering to racism" by portraying Greek partisans as "barbarians".

Mr Pampaloni's onslaught is likely to fuel controversy about de Bernières's story on the island, where a US-backed film, starring Nicolas Cage as Captain Corelli, is being shot.

Under a barrage of complaints from Cephalonian resistance veterans and politicians the film-makers have given undertakings that the movie will be a straightforward love story and will not repeat de Bernières's most controversial claims.

The author was persuaded to cut inflammatory passages from the Greek edition of his book, which has sold 1.5m copies worldwide, and recently conceded that he "might be wrong" about the communist-led Greek resistance.

But the campaign in Cephalonia against the book appears to be growing, despite the boost to its tourist industry. Last week the Greek government was criticised for providing soldiers and ships for the film's battle scenes.

The novel tells the story of a love affair between the daughter of a Cephalonian doctor and a captain in Mussolini's army of occupation, who helps turn Italian troops against the Germans and survives the subsequent massacre of more than 9,000 of them.

Woven into the drama is an unremittingly hostile account of the role of the Greek resistance, who are portrayed as torturers, rapists and cowards who refuse to fight the Germans. In particular, de Bernières claims the partisans refused to support the Italians in their confrontation with Hitler's troops in September 1943.

Speaking for the first time about the book at his home in Florence, Mr Pampaloni said Cephalonian guerrillas did fight alongside the Italians.

"The picture painted of the Greek partisans is unacceptable," the Italian veteran said. "To speak of the Greeks as barbarians, who killed for the sake of it, is pandering to racism."

Like de Bernières's hero, Mr Pampaloni was a captain in an artillery regiment on Cephalonia and like Corelli, he had an affair with a local girl. Like Corelli, he played a central role in the decision to attack German troops and like Corelli, he was shot and left for dead after the Italian defeat.

But, whereas Corelli returned to Italy to be a fireman, Mr Pampaloni fought for a year with the partisans and helped lead the liberation of Cephalonia in 1944.

In an email to the Guardian Bernières denied that Corelli was inspired by Mr Pampaloni.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Invention Of Jane Harrison by Mary Beard

fields.headline: Secret history
fields.standfirst: That elusive heroine of classics, Jane Harrison, has met her match in her biographer, Mary Beard
fields.trailText: That elusive heroine of classics, Jane Harrison, has met her match in her biographer, Mary Beard
fields.body:
The Invention Of Jane Harrison
Mary Beard
Harvard, £23.50
Buy it at BOL

Someone was running across the gardens of "Fernham College" at a terrific pace. Her features were indistinct; the half-light made phantoms of everyone. But there was something familiar about her. "Could it be J- H- herself?"

Jane Harrison, who had died a few months before, would have enjoyed her cameo role in Virginia Woolf's A Room of One's Own as a fleeting, unstoppable ghost. Born bang in the middle of the 19th century and passing into the Land of the Shades only in 1928, Harrison remains one of the most important and influential women in the field of classical studies.

Almost a century after they were written, her books - Themis, Prolegomena to the Study of Greek Religion - are still in print. She is famous for being among the first to dig through the sublime surfaces of Greek civilisation to expose the stranger and more primitive culture lurking underneath.

Prime ministers knew her, as did Eliots TS and George. André Gide wrote a poem, "Persephone", based on her ideas about the vegetation cycle, while Virginia Woolf was on hand to observe her "billing and cooing" with Hope Mirlees, the woman with whom she shared her later years and who became her devoted but reticent archivist.

As well as being clever and important she was also, of course, a Character, full of self-belief. Indeed, she was several Characters, depending on the audience and the mood - a professionally bluff Yorkshirewoman when it suited her, at other times the chain-smoking Sappho of Colville Gardens, whose intimate seminars were the subject of an admiring article in the Pall Mall Gazette.

Her lectures were full-scale theatrical events that she toured around the country. She dressed for the occasion, most famously in a shimmering beetle green, talking emphatically and always down to her audience, casting shadows over the hand-painted images of bearded serpents, sacrificial oxen and key words projected onto the screen behind her. There were sound effects, too. On one memorable occasion she had two friends whirl bull-roarers at the back of the hall to evoke the noises of a mystery cult. In Glasgow, 1,600 people came to hear her talk on Attic grave stelae, or so she told the reporter from the Gazette. To many she was a living monument, to others a brilliant self-publicist.

With her Sapphic love, her fondness for William Morris wallpaper, her languor and quotability, her deployment of teddy bears - in one letter, Harrison's toy bear invites Hope Mirlees, "his young wife", to dine in Hall with Harrison, his "elder wife", and signs off with a picture of the constellation Ursa Major - Harrison fits perfectly into the history of the Decadents and Effeminates, a history in which women rarely find a place. In some ways she is what Oscar Wilde, four years younger and the most brilliant male classicist of his year, might have been had he succeeded in his ambition to become an Oxford don.

Mary Beard has spent long hours in Jane Harrison's company, digging through the archives. She is interested less in Harrison's biography than in the way her students constructed her life and her archive. How to be honest and truthful about a woman they admired and loved without giving away her "Secret"? Harrison had herself published a book of reminiscences, but she destroyed much other material. Mirlees planned a personal biography shortly after Harrison's death, but found over several decades that it was an impossible task. It was Mirlees above all who made the archive, but the archive is designed to hide as much as it reveals. In Mary Beard, however, Jane Harrison has met her match.

The star of The Invention of Jane Harrison has to share the limelight with another character who is much more obscure. Ten years younger than Harrison, Eugenie Sellers, known to posterity as Mrs Arthur Strong, seemed at one time an equally good bet for posthumous glory. A great beauty in the 19th century who modelled for the pre-Raphaelites, in the 20th she became a pioneering historian of Roman art.

According to Asquith, she was the most "distinguished woman scholar" in the world: one of the first women to become a Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries, recipient of the CBE and the gold medal of the city of Rome. She dominated the British School of Art and Archaeology for years, although not in title Director, but his Assistant.

When the director eventually married, troubles inevitably arose, ostensibly over fondness for animals. Was it true, as was alleged, that Mrs Strong had actually encouraged students to attend a bullfight? From such trivial beginnings a feud grew. When it seemed to be reaching a crisis, all three were summarily, if politely, dismissed.

Eugenie stayed on in Rome and increased her renown and her collection of calling cards. Her friends and acquaintances included Henry James, Ezra Pound, Mussolini and a whole clutch of cardinals. We know this because she saved the calling cards, as well as the correspondence over the bullfight dispute, annotating her letters. She left two rich archives, one in Cambridge and the other in Rome at the British School. Jane Harrison, on the other hand, burned her letters. Nevertheless it is Harrison and not Strong who is remembered.

Since they seem to have known almost everyone else worth knowing, Beard has a hunch that - despite the almost complete silence from their biographers - these two famous scholars must also have known each other. Mrs Strong, she notes, contributed to Harrison's memorial fund the carefully unobtrusive sum of one pound and five pence. Going much further back, she finds both as eager participants in a series of Greek tableaux put on in the spring of 1883 in the private theatre of Cromwell House, home of Sir Charles and Lady Freake, a couple not renowned for their refinements (Lady Freake, it was noted with some amusement, pronounced Homer without the aitch).

These were glittering events. Sets and poses were arranged by the great painters of the time, Alma-Tadema, Lord Leighton, Millais and Burne-Jones. Gladstone and Tennyson were to be discovered in the audience. The beautiful Eugenie was often to be found playing Helen, of course, and the costumes, poses and ladies received extravagant praise. But, as Beard discovers, the connection between Eugenie and Jane went rather deeper than sharing the same stage.

In fact, it seems likely that they shared a flat and feelings for each other. While Harrison worked up her lectures, Strong was busy booking venues and arranging publicity. At some point, however, there was a "terrific bust-up" and Harrison is later to be found angered by Strong and the "unscrupulous way she used people to get on", while in the drafts of her autobiography Strong refers darkly to the kind of woman who applied "the power of fascination... where she could, on callow youths chiefly and younger women".

Beard is too careful a scholar to draw conclusions about the precise nature of the "bust-up", and too careful a historian to out Harrison and Strong anachronistically as a lesbian couple, but she makes a cogent case for rewriting the history of Classics in a way that would make Harrison less isolated, treating the two women as partners rather than ships that passed in the night. This book does not celebrate a rare and uncomplicated feminine triumph in the still-too-butch Academy, nor does it make easy connections between Harrison's Sapphic life and work, for all its bearded snakes, powerful goddesses and transient gods.

What it does do is evoke wonderfully the kitschy Hellenic craze of the end of the 19th century, female friendship and rivalry and, above all, what it is like to be led by ghosts through an archive - careful ghosts with high expectations of the life you will produce, ghosts with a secret and endless ways to distract you from it with calling cards, precisely measured donations, wrongly labelled photographs and endless other false trails.

She is famous for being among the first to dig through the sublime surfaces of Greek civilisation to expose the stranger and more primitive culture lurking underneath. Prime ministers knew her, as did Eliots TS and George. André Gide wrote a poem, "Persephone", based on her ideas about the vegetation cycle, while Virginia Woolf was on hand to observe her "billing and cooing" with Hope Mirlees, the woman with whom she shared her later years and who became her devoted but reticent archivist. As well as being clever and important she was also, of course, a Character, full of self-belief. Indeed, she was several Characters, depending on the audience and the mood - a professionally bluff Yorkshirewoman when it suited her, at other times the chain-smoking Sappho of Colville Gardens, whose intimate seminars were the subject of an admiring article in the Pall Mall Gazette. Her lectures were full-scale theatrical events that she toured around the country. She dressed for the occasion, most famously in a shimmering beetle green, talking emphatically and always down to her audience, casting shadows over the hand-painted images of bearded serpents, sacrificial oxen and key words projected onto the screen behind her. There were sound effects, too. On one memorable occasion she had two friends whirl bull-roarers at the back of the hall to evoke the noises of a mystery cult. In Glasgow, 1,600 people came to hear her talk on Attic grave stelae, or so she told the reporter from the Gazette. To many she was a living monument, to others a brilliant self-publicist. With her Sapphic love, her fondness for William Morris wallpaper, her languor and quotability, her deployment of teddy bears - in one letter, Harrison's toy bear invites Hope Mirlees, "his young wife", to dine in Hall with Harrison, his "elder wife", and signs off with a picture of the constellation Ursa Major - Harrison fits perfectly into the history of the Decadents and Effeminates, a history in which women rarely find a place. In some ways she is what Oscar Wilde, four years younger and the most brilliant male classicist of his year, might have been had he succeeded in his ambition to become an Oxford don. Mary Beard has spent long hours in Jane Harrison's company, digging through the archives. She is interested less in Harrison's biography than in the way her students constructed her life and her archive. How to be honest and truthful about a woman they admired and loved without giving away her "Secret"? Harrison had herself published a book of reminiscences, but she destroyed much other material. Mirlees planned a personal biography shortly after Harrison's death, but found over several decades that it was an impossible task. It was Mirlees above all who made the archive, but the archive is designed to hide as much as it reveals. In Mary Beard, however, Jane Harrison has met her match. The star of The Invention of Jane Harrison has to share the limelight with another character who is much more obscure. Ten years younger than Harrison, Eugenie Sellers, known to posterity as Mrs Arthur Strong, seemed at one time an equally good bet for posthumous glory. A great beauty in the 19th century who modelled for the pre-Raphaelites, in the 20th she became a pioneering historian of Roman art. According to Asquith, she was the most "distinguished woman scholar" in the world: one of the first women to become a Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries, recipient of the CBE and the gold medal of the city of Rome. She dominated the British School of Art and Archaeology for years, although not in title Director, but his Assistant. When the director eventually married, troubles inevitably arose, ostensibly over fondness for animals. Was it true, as was alleged, that Mrs Strong had actually encouraged students to attend a bullfight? From such trivial beginnings a feud grew. When it seemed to be reaching a crisis, all three were summarily, if politely, dismissed. Eugenie stayed on in Rome and increased her renown and her collection of calling cards. Her friends and acquaintances included Henry James, Ezra Pound, Mussolini and a whole clutch of cardinals. We know this because she saved the calling cards, as well as the correspondence over the bullfight dispute, annotating her letters. She left two rich archives, one in Cambridge and the other in Rome at the British School. Jane Harrison, on the other hand, burned her letters. Nevertheless it is Harrison and not Strong who is remembered. Since they seem to have known almost everyone else worth knowing, Beard has a hunch that - despite the almost complete silence from their biographers - these two famous scholars must also have known each other. Mrs Strong, she notes, contributed to Harrison's memorial fund the carefully unobtrusive sum of one pound and five pence. Going much further back, she finds both as eager participants in a series of Greek tableaux put on in the spring of 1883 in the private theatre of Cromwell House, home of Sir Charles and Lady Freake, a couple not renowned for their refinements (Lady Freake, it was noted with some amusement, pronounced Homer without the aitch). These were glittering events. Sets and poses were arranged by the great painters of the time, Alma-Tadema, Lord Leighton, Millais and Burne-Jones. Gladstone and Tennyson were to be discovered in the audience. The beautiful Eugenie was often to be found playing Helen, of course, and the costumes, poses and ladies received extravagant praise. But, as Beard discovers, the connection between Eugenie and Jane went rather deeper than sharing the same stage. In fact, it seems likely that they shared a flat and feelings for each other. While Harrison worked up her lectures, Strong was busy booking venues and arranging publicity. At some point, however, there was a "terrific bust-up" and Harrison is later to be found angered by Strong and the "unscrupulous way she used people to get on", while in the drafts of her autobiography Strong refers darkly to the kind of woman who applied "the power of fascination... where she could, on callow youths chiefly and younger women". Beard is too careful a scholar to draw conclusions about the precise nature of the "bust-up", and too careful a historian to out Harrison and Strong anachronistically as a lesbian couple, but she makes a cogent case for rewriting the history of Classics in a way that would make Harrison less isolated, treating the two women as partners rather than ships that passed in the night. This book does not celebrate a rare and uncomplicated feminine triumph in the still-too-butch Academy, nor does it make easy connections between Harrison's Sapphic life and work, for all its bearded snakes, powerful goddesses and transient gods. What it does do is evoke wonderfully the kitschy Hellenic craze of the end of the 19th century, female friendship and rivalry and, above all, what it is like to be led by ghosts through an archive - careful ghosts with high expectations of the life you will produce, ghosts with a secret and endless ways to distract you from it with calling cards, precisely measured donations, wrongly labelled photographs and endless other false trails.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: A book to look at rather than read, and William Heath Robinson
fields.body:
The Art of the Maze
Adrian Fisher and Georg Gerster
(Seven Dials, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Scrappy, snobby text, but such entrancing aerial views we used it as a substitute for summer, tracing a finger along dark paths between hedges and turfs; it has just a few photographs taken low enough to make contact with the confusion of those lost within topiary puzzles. Thrown-away refs to the possible rites-of-passage origin of labyrinths (tenacity leading the way into sex); and amazing views of the 1980s Japanese maze craze, when moveable high wooden walls and one-way gates were re-arranged to create lab-rat conditions for visitors trying to exit within strict time limits - loudspeakers on posts enhanced the stressed scariness.

William Heath Robinson
James Hamilton
(Pavilion, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Although in his early Edwardian years as an illustrator WHR could do a fine fairyland frontisplate, his true talent was for the contraption: either a quasi-mechanical construction (tanks could not have been dreamed of without his pioneering contrivances), or a sequential process, like a silent film comedy, diagrammed in a single drawing. His sources included the rack in Foxe's Book of Martyrs and the stage machinery of Drury Lane. He was interested in the eccentricity of the humans caught up in his wheels and cogs, unlike his US equivalent Rube Goldberg, who was a mad inventor. The acme of quirkiness, and touchingly innocent.

fields.headline: Wish you were here?
fields.standfirst: Cabin fever or the Costa del Sol?   Alex Clark  tries to get away from it all with a couple of holiday novels, Leisure and Flying
fields.trailText: Cabin fever or the Costa del Sol? Alex Clark tries to get away from it all with a couple of holiday novels, Leisure and Flying
fields.body:
Leisure
Kevin Sampson
Cape, £10, 230pp
Buy it at BOL

Flying
Henry Sutton
Sceptre, £14.99, 330pp
Buy it at BOL

Two novels are released at the beginning of the summer with punchy, one-word titles and pictures of aeroplanes on their covers: any self-respecting literary critic is honour bound to look closely for the footprints of the marketing departments, who hunt in packs and are no doubt thrilled every time they hear of long delays at airports and visualise their glossy, topical titles piled up in departure-lounge bookshops. What sweaty and irritable traveller could resist the opportunity to see their own experiences translated so immediately into book form?

In the event, those wishing for fictional solace as they bake on a sun lounger or tramp around a city square might do better to stick with holiday staples - the still unread Anna Karenina or a heap of virgin John Le Carrés - than to explore the distinctly unsoothing terrains mapped out by Sampson and Sutton. Neither writer has any faith in the restorative powers of travelling hopefully or arriving. For Sampson, tackling the package holiday, and Sutton, who presents the awkward journey of the crew of a transatlantic jet to JFK and back, leaving home is a perilous business, the more so if you're not convinced you want to return.

Kevin Sampson is a novelist whose efficient progress up the bestseller lists owes much to a snappy cool characterised by those diminutive titles. We've already had Awaydays (football) and Powder (rock'n'roll); now Leisure "does" the Costa del Sol. A couple of his more up-to-the-minute characters whine plaintively for Ibiza, but good old Spain affords him a little more scope to extend his clientele. Thus we have a group of lagered-up Stockport lads on the pull, cheek by jowl with the Scanlons, an unhappily married couple jousting for predominance in the final days of their relationship.

Sampson clearly relishes the opportunity to tinker with stereotypes, although Leisure is a pretty conventional beach read. So we have Pasternak, a miserable mobile-phone millionaire whose ebullience rather obviously masks his anguish over a startling lack of success with the girls. He finally finds happiness with Viagra and Millie from Nijmegen, but more pessimistic readers will have a hard time believing that an enduring relationship is on the cards.

Elsewhere, Hilary Scanlon prefers to practise her t'ai chi than reach for the happy pills. She's browned off with husband Shaun, a former stonemason who has taken to mounting guerrilla attacks on suburban architectural monstrosities. Shaun, in Larkin's words, is "randy for antique", and likes nothing better than to drag Hilary into the hills for a quick look at an old rampart, his frantic quest for authenticity making it increasingly difficult for her to work on her tan. Needless to say, a week in the sun fails to heal the rifts, and the intervention of a soulful Adonis and a wised-up travel rep do little to help.

At least the Scanlons can head for sierra and sun lounger in different directions. The characters in Flying have no such luxury, though strict professional demarcation lines - from captain down to the new lad handing out the bread rolls and hot towels - ensure some separations. Like Sampson (who divides his book into seven days), Henry Sutton is keen on structure, with chapters referring to waypoints on the flight from LHR to JFK and back again.

Outward bound, we eavesdrop on the woes of a selection of the crew; on the return journey, their colleagues are given a turn at the controls. But the pivot to this determinedly airborne novel occurs out of sight, in the form of a wild party that takes place "down route" in New York, and results in collective boozers' gloom that, were they to know of it, would make the passengers decidedly edgy. Gradually, details of who did what with whom emerge: the sexual tension bouncing round the cabin threatens to disrupt the duty-free sales and emergency demos.

Sutton's portrayal of a profession is intriguing, if not altogether surprising: unfaithful, jaded pilots who've seen it all before; "hosties" caked in make-up, grimly determined to extract maximum glamour out of travelling the world; bossy top dogs secretly terrified of flying; uneasy homosexuals with overbearing mothers in Crawley or Worthing, meanly flirting with one another. There's also a bit of fun with ER-style technobabble ("he selects Brecon on the FMS before he activates the LNAV switch" - righto!) and handy insights into what goes on behind those little pleated curtains next to the loos.

The author may, however, slightly overplay the idea that airline staff - partly through the natural incapacity for normal life that led them to the job in the first place, partly through the effect of being sealed in a tiny space beyond countries and time zones for most of their lives - are all helpless misfits on the verge of nervous breakdowns. Although the depressives and lunatics that people this novel are more fully realised than any you might trip over in Leisure, they suffer from a kind of homogeneity, and a lack of texture eventually weakens the book. It's good, though, on capturing the slide of air travel from rarefied deluxe voyaging to cost-cutting haulage, and the effect that has had on those most closely connected with it.

In neither of these books, then, do we find that travel broadens the mind, if any of us ever suspected it. Nor are we given reason to believe that getting away from it all affords any comfort to the troubled, the weak, the unpopular or the sexually unsuccessful. The message couldn't be clearer: sort your life out, and then head for the airport.
