fields.headline: My Father's Piano
fields.trailText:
Carved from the seasoned hearts of rosewood -

  the fine grain veined black

   through the sheen of maroon -

  my father's piano

   was the centre of home...
fields.body:
Carved from the seasoned hearts of rosewood -
  the fine grain veined black
   through the sheen of maroon -
  my father's piano
   was the centre of home;

the sounding-board of thought and feeling
  ignited by
   the heartbeat, heartbeat, heartbeat
 threading through the scales
  of pitch in time.

Look at it unpacked -
  a junction box of forged connections,
   the waves of felts
 in red and green and deep sky blue,
   the interleaved shanks,

the hammers and dampers, stacked and packed in
  as close as a skeleton,
   stitched through with steel -
 the plumblines of tension -
   the strings spun around

their curved constellation of chromium pins
  scattered on a sky
   gilded Kruggerand gold.
 Always I was staggered
   by the deep bass darkness

catching at my heart, resounding around
  my lungs and bones,
   by the tinsel glissando
 housed in high ivories
   at the edge of sound -

the hammers' attack on the strings forging joy,
  then tempering tenderness.
   This is the work of love -
 the testing of harmonies
   through the risk

of dissonance, trying again as the hands fall apart,
  taking on silence
   when the afternoon fades -
 practice and grace,
  as light ebbs away before tea.
fields.bodyText: Carved from the seasoned hearts of rosewood - the fine grain veined black through the sheen of maroon - my father's piano was the centre of home; the sounding-board of thought and feeling ignited by the heartbeat, heartbeat, heartbeat threading through the scales of pitch in time. Look at it unpacked - a junction box of forged connections, the waves of felts in red and green and deep sky blue, the interleaved shanks, the hammers and dampers, stacked and packed in as close as a skeleton, stitched through with steel - the plumblines of tension - the strings spun around their curved constellation of chromium pins scattered on a sky gilded Kruggerand gold. Always I was staggered by the deep bass darkness catching at my heart, resounding around my lungs and bones, by the tinsel glissando housed in high ivories at the edge of sound - the hammers' attack on the strings forging joy, then tempering tenderness. This is the work of love - the testing of harmonies through the risk of dissonance, trying again as the hands fall apart, taking on silence when the afternoon fades - practice and grace, as light ebbs away before tea.

webTitle: Guardian review: The Call of Cthulhu by HP Lovecraft

fields.headline: Call of the weird
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  develops a taste for the strange tales of HP Lovecraft
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard develops a taste for the strange tales of HP Lovecraft
fields.body:
The Call of Cthulhu and Other Weird Stories
HP Lovecraft, ed and int ST Joshi
(Penguin, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

I had always, ignorantly, thought poorly of HP Lovecraft: probably a matter of his fanbase, people with face-studs and an unhealthy interest in the macabre. As if life isn't distressing enough. So I wondered whether Penguin was right to assert his canonical status, as inclusion in the new 20th-century classics series implies. I now know better.

Lovecraft wrote for magazines with titles like Weird Tales, mainly in the 1920s. While much genre fiction was hackwork, the standard of hackery involved was often high, especially when compared to our degraded age; at the very least, publications like Weird Tales did expect a certain minimum level of weirdness from their contributors.

Well, Lovecraft can be very weird. Whether he was inclined to horror through his youthful illnesses, ingrained morbidity, or post-war gloom (and he had written more conventional stuff earlier in his life) is up to Lovecraft academics to determine, but a couple of stories in this volume gave me the willies, so one can imagine what effect they had on people three-quarters of a century ago.

He is formulaic, but then so is Arthur Conan Doyle, or PG Wodehouse. Lovecraft's formula is this: the narrator says that he has fled the town of..., lucky to escape with his body intact, but with a mind falling apart at the horrors he has seen. (A variant on this is when the narrator meets someone who has fled the town of... etc.) The following things will crop up: a hideous but well-made artefact, with carvings both indecipherable and repulsive; a case of what seems like mass insanity in an isolated area; a cult whose secrets are so secret that only a few addled Lascars know about them; and a threat to the entire planet, the precise nature of which it would be unfair of me to reveal.

You begin to see that Lovecraft really is the big influence that any self-respecting schlock-merchant says he is; and when one considers that about 50 per cent of X-Files episodes deal with similar material, yet, pound for pound, to far lesser effect, his prescience and novelty seem more and more remarkable.

My favourite Lovecraft line comes in the story "The Shadow Over Innsmouth", in which the foolhardy narrator, investigating what at first sight seems no more than an exorbitantly inbred backwoods New England town, sees something nasty in the woodshed, as it were, and says: "It was the end, for whatever remains to me of life on the surface of this earth, of every vestige of mental peace and confidence in the integrity of Nature and the human mind."

Now, while this is unfair on the human mind (what he has seen is only human, in the sense that HP Lovecraft invented it), it does show a deeply modern horror at the universe; the effect is something like the old sense of "sublime", but here set off by anthropophagic alien deities. He often describes things as "blasphemous", but they are as likely to blaspheme against geometry as against God (whom Lovecraft didn't really believe in). In one story, someone is "swallowed up by an angle of masonry that shouldn't have been there; an angle which was acute, but behaved as if it were obtuse." Now that really is scary, and well worth a reprint.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston finds his interest in the elemental Scrabble board reawakened by Peter Atkins' tour through the periodic table
fields.body:
The Periodic Kingdom
Peter Atkins
(Orion, £9.99, 180mn)
Hear an extract

If you were bored/ baffled as a kid by that elemental Scrabble board on the chem lab wall called the periodic table, plug this in and risk rekindling your adult interest in nature's 105 building blocks. Oxford's Professor of Chemistry presents the chart poetically, not just as a range of mysterious atomic numbers, but as a series of landscapes, whose topographies vary according to the mass, size, density and behaviour of the elements. It's a meaty listen for the scientifically inert, and a copy of the periodic table on the sleeve would have been a great help. Atkins's own delivery is expressive, but the hoarse tinge could irritate, and the whole needs more refined editing.

fields.headline: Nailing quicksilver
fields.standfirst: How to catch the essence of Hollywood? It has slipped the grasp of OK You Mugs, a collection of writing about acting
fields.trailText: How to catch the essence of Hollywood? It has slipped the grasp of OK You Mugs, a collection of writing about acting
fields.body:
OK You Mugs: Writers on Movie Actors
ed Luc Sante and Melissa Holbrook Pierson
Granta, £10, 304pp

Anthologies are often lumpy affairs, and film ones even lumpier: most writing on cinema tends to be either dogged synopsis or hyperactive jargon. It misses the point, which is how such a ponderous method can produce such quicksilver results. The "magic of movies" is the tritest phrase, yet few nail its essence in words.

OK You Mugs offers appreciation as an alternative. The editors' introduction calls actors our "spectral friends", a line most clearly extended in art critic Dave Hickey's acknowledgment of a debt to Robert Mitchum regarding women. Mitchum was "jailhouse aristocracy" in Hickey's neat phrase, memorable for shrugging his sleepy-eyed way through a zillion movies while seeming not to care. In reality he thought hard about his craft; on the business of acting, he concluded in typically laconic fashion, "So that's [it]. You steal the reality of the props and control the pace of the pictures. Oh, also, you have to say these lines, but that's purely secondary." "It was like finally understanding," Hickey remarks, "that there is something to understand, that it isn't just charisma."

Movie actors, when you think about it, are required to invent very little (which is not to belittle them; they have the extremely difficult job of appearing real, as Mitchum knew). Regardless of star tantrums, acting is in the end a disciplined and obedient business, which makes it quite hard to write about. Pieces like Hickey's, that reveal the technical process, prove more stimulating than the more personal ones, with their nostalgia and reactionary sense of change for the worse.

Mugs is almost entirely about Hollywood of a period, and a valedictory tone is maintained, apart from a typically feisty piece from painter and critic Manny Farber. "The Decline of the Actor" is Farber's unsentimental account of a fascinating shift he detected at the end of the 1950s, when actors found themselves more in competition with technology, with less space in which to create their roles. One reason was an increased use of zoom lenses, which flattened actors into a foreshortened space.

For Farber, Lawrence of Arabia was not the masterpiece it is now taken for but a comedy of over-design with the cast given too little time in which to perform, resulting in "a declamatory, school-pageant bit of acting". Film acting became more like modelling, a combination of pantomimic action and photogenic skill, a trait evident in much New Wave cinema of the 1960s. By contrast, an old-fashioned star such as Joan Crawford understood the nature of a character's propulsion through a movie better than many later, more obviously talented actors. She, like Mitchum, knew what it took to get noticed.

Elsewhere there's the usual tick-box eclecticism, including cartoon characters, midgets, fat men and Marx Brothers stalwart Margaret Dumont. There's a sly bottom-drawer essay by John Updike on Doris Day, which probably says more about him than about her. But too many pieces fail to shake off an air of commission. Actors live with the knowledge that they can always be recast. Given the random element of the selection here, the contents list could just as easily have been very different.

fields.headline: All hail the new partygoers
fields.trailText: The New Puritans who haven't quite got the hang of it, plus the winner of the first Caine Prize for African Writing
fields.body:
 Keen observers of contemporary fiction will be delighted to hear of a new anthology entitled All Hail the New Puritans, in which the grooviest of writers parade their wares according to a set of draconian guidelines established by the book's editors, Nicholas Blincoe and Matt Thorne

Asceticism, though, is not what it used to be, as a handful of contributors to the book demonstrated at a dinner thrown by Zadie Smith at the ICA. Blincoe and Thorne themselves, alongside Toby Litt, Daren King and others, enjoyed proceedings so greatly that they forgot they all had to look their best the next day for a Puritans photoshoot. With an hour to go, Blincoe was still attempting to rouse King from his slumbers, having performed the same operation four times on the way home the night before. Glad to see the nation's literary flowers aren't denying themselves too many worldly pleasures for the sake of art.

 The man who has written more swingeing letters than the Loafer has had angels on horseback and Pinot Grigio - Tottenham firebrand Keith Flett - is to produce something that doesn't begin with the words Dear Sir. His subject matter remains reassuringly left of centre, though, as a dip into The Twentieth Century: A Century of Wars and Revolutions, edited with David Renton, will demonstrate.

Flett is proving himself a natural convert to the author's life, telling us of a celebratory gathering to mark publication and having a cheeky Follett-style sideswipe at Mr Blair. Those concerned for Flett's ideological purity, however, need not worry too much: we are sternly informed that the bash won't take place in Islington, but "in the environs of the Marxism 2000 summer school".

 Further material for the AA Gill dossier. The great Scottish writer (as, in all seriousness, the Loafer once heard him introduced) finds himself used as puff material for someone else's book. "Elizabeth David written by Quentin Tarantino" enthuses Gill of Anthony Bourdain's Kitchen Confidential, the blood-and-guts memoir of a hellraising chef. Give yourself a treat by trying to envisage precisely what that description means - Bunfight at the OK Corral, perhaps?

 Congratulations to Leila Aboulela, who has won the first Caine Prize for African Writing for her short story "The Museum". Ben Okri chaired the judges, and Aboulela will receive her $15,000 prize money this weekend in Harare to coincide with the Zimbabwe Book Fair.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Colm Tóibín's story of family strife was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, Come Again, Daughter of Fortune and The Memory Box
fields.body:
The Blackwater Lightship
Colm Tóibín (Picador, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

Shortlisted for the Booker Prize, this delicately realised tale of family strife captures perfectly the painful co-existence of love and antipathy, need and rejection. Declan is dying of Aids, and his mother, grandmother and sister gather to minister to him, an unhappy meeting that brings submerged resentment and bitterness to the surface. Tóibín's portrayal of a life ebbing away amid squabbles and accusations works best through its reticence and understatement, and by its subtle evocation of the generational shifts that have played a part in forming modern Ireland. And, morbid subject matter aside, it's a cracking comedy of manners.

Come Again
Josie Lloyd and Emlyn Rees
(Arrow, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

There's seductive trash and there's outright garbage, and writing duo Lloyd and Rees fall squarely into the latter category. Briefly, one pair of smug about-to-be-marrieds, and six boys and girls with screwed-up love lives dancing ineptly around one another. Plenty of booze and a bit of shagging, as we must call it, but precious little in the way of sympathetic characters, coherent plot, realistic dialogue, humour - all those little things that are kind of intrinsic to a halfway decent novel. To be fair, this pair are not appreciably worse than half-a-dozen other wannabe hip young writers: one can only hope that this unsatisfying genre, like others before it, dies on the vine before too long.

Daughter of Fortune
Isabel Allende
(Flamingo, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

You either like Allende's brand of whimsical expansiveness or you don't, and if you're not a fan, this novel will prove heavy going. Set in 19th-century Chile, it centres on Eliza, who is abandoned on the steps of a British expat household at birth. Later, she falls in love with a handsome revolutionary, gets pregnant, and follows him to California when he succumbs to goldrush fever. Her lengthy search is punctuated by meetings with prostitutes, criminals and adventurers, and by meeting the Chinese mystic - cue magic realism - who will accompany her for years to come. History on a grand scale, but liable to drag from time to time, and not as captivating as it ought to be.

The Memory Box
Margaret Forster
(Penguin, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

There's nothing quite so inhibiting as a dead parent, particularly if the common consensus is that he or she was preternaturally talented, beautiful and contented. Catherine is thus afflicted, but has never quite bought into the myth. "How can anyone but a moron be perfectly happy?" she muses, and when, at the age of 21, she is handed the Memory Box her mother prepared, that scepticism proves to be well founded. Forster is playing to her strengths, having written powerfully about mothers and memories in the past, and the result is both an intriguing detective story and a subtle exploration of the psychological effect of excavating the past.

webTitle: Guardian review: Mapping the Deep by Robert Kunzig

fields.headline: Deep waters
fields.standfirst: Robert Kunzig takes us on a journey into inner space in Mapping the Deep
fields.trailText: Robert Kunzig takes us on a journey into inner space in Mapping the Deep
fields.body:
Mapping the Deep: The Extraordinary Story of Ocean Science
Robert Kunzig
Sort Of Books, £8.99, 345pp
Buy it at BOL

We live in a divided world. The most important boundary is not political, but elemental. Water holds sway over most of the planet, while air-breathing humans cling to dry land. A scuba diver with strap-on oxygen can get down about 200ft; the deepest ocean trenches lie six-and-a-half miles below sea level.

In the first age of exploration, westerners crossed the oceans and mapped new continents. What lay beneath their keels as they skimmed across the surface remained uncharted. Over 300m cubic miles of salt water made much of the Earth as mysterious as the far side of the moon.

In the last few decades, though, our knowledge of this world has been transformed. Once the ocean floor was thought to be a dead zone of the most ancient rocks. Now we know it is where the planet's crust is remade by the Earth's inner heat, with new rock spreading out from long chains of undersea volcanoes. These volcanic ridges define one edge of the great plates on which continents float. At their far edges, old rock plunges back beneath the planet's mantle in deep ocean trenches. Thus oceans shrink or grow over millions of years.

The ocean is not just alive geographically; there are life forms down there as alien as anything in the wilder flights of science fiction. Countless worms churn up the sediment of even the deepest sea floor. Sulphur-eating bacteria flourish in superheated water blasting from volcanic vents. And a myriad living jellies float, pulsate and squirt their way around above them.

Robert Kunzig unveils this rich new panorama of the ocean and relates how it was pieced together. While men on the moon hogged the headlines, an equally intrepid bunch were exploring inner space. A few risked the crushing pressures of the deep in thick-walled submersibles, but most were using sonar detectors or looking closely at what they could dredge, scoop or hoist up onto the deck of a research ship.

Kunzig, a writer for Discover magazine, has been following ocean science for years, and is as excited by what scientists get up to back in the laboratory as by their lengthy seaborne exploits. The result is a very satisfying picture of science in the making. He also shows how our understanding is still unfolding, as the interests of the scientists' paymasters change.

At first, the main practical objectives were military. The great powers of the cold war were desperate to know where, in all that ocean, nuclear submarines could be hidden. Today, making half-way plausible models of the global climate demands, as never before, an understanding of the oceans. Are they heat sinks or heat pumps? Are their great currents stable or unstable? How do the organisms that soak up much of the carbon dioxide from our power stations and cars get their living?

Much remains to be figured out. The simplest guess about the future of Britain's climate, for instance, is that global warming will mean local warming - visions of olive groves alongside Kentish vineyards. But the history of ocean currents tells a different story. Melt too much ice into the western Atlantic and the shift in temperature and salinity can flip ocean circulation and shut off the Gulf Stream, northern Europe's convection heater. Then we shall be ice-skating on the Thames. It has happened before, even though we don't exactly understand how.

But perhaps the thousands of plankton species that swarm throughout the ocean will respond to the changing atmosphere by soaking up more carbon dioxide. Some may even react to heat by giving off other gases which help seed more clouds, thus cooling things down again. If Gaia exists, she dwells in the vastness of the seas.

Like the oceans themselves, Kunzig's book is large and contains multitudes; it is amply detailed, but never dull. It mostly lacks the finely honed style of Rachel Carson's classic The Sea Around Us, but after 50 years her great book is a piece of literary history rather than a source of reliable science. So much has changed in such a short time that ours is scarcely the same ocean. Every popular-science writer tries to bring new worlds into view; Kunzig's story is especially compelling because his new world is so strange, yet so firmly linked to our own.

 Jon Turney teaches science communication at University College London.

fields.headline: Portrait of the artist as a gorilla
fields.standfirst: Anthony Browne explains his surrealist children's style to Julia Eccleshare
fields.trailText: Anthony Browne explains his surrealist children's style to Julia Eccleshare
fields.body:
When Anthony Browne talks about the day his father died, he goes into a reverie of total recall. "I had just been promoted to the first rugby team. It was a perfect, wonderful coming of age. My brother was already in the team and my father had come to watch us. We went home and my father died in front of me. Horribly, in about half an hour. He had a heart attack."

Anthony Browne was 17 that day and he has been painting images of his father ever since, culminating in his most recent, and most direct, My Dad. Ostensibly a simple tribute to a wonderful father, it is one of Browne's sunniest books, with a string of visual surprises enriching the brief and plain text. It comes after many darker takes on fathers. In one book, Gorilla, a fantasy gorilla becomes a stand-in father for a lonely young girl. In another, King Kong's fall from the Empire State Building becomes "the image of my father falling dead in front of me".

His starting point for My Dad was the discovery of his father's old dressing-gown. "It smelt like him and, hanging on a hanger, it looked like him. It just reminded me of how he was. I'd been wanting to do a positive book about fathers for some time but hadn't found the right way. The dressing gown was my starting point."

Browne's sophisticated style, with its references to surrealism and his use of gorillas as interchangeable with humans, have made him one of the most intensely analysed and highly praised contemporary illustrators. Earlier this year he won the prestigious Hans Christian Andersen Medal - the first UK nominee to win it since Eleanor Farjeon in 1956. The competition included Dick Bruna, author of the Miffy books.

"Winning it has made me pleased that I've stuck to my guns," he says. "I certainly haven't gone for a particular age range or audience and it's reassuring that that's considered to have worked."

It seems odd to think that Browne needs reassurance, but he points out that he wasn't immediately successful. He had published seven books before winning the Kate Greenaway Medal for Gorilla in 1983. "I've always felt that I was a bit of an outsider to the British children's-book illustration scene, because I don't work in line and wash. I work in watercolour and sometimes gouache, so obviously my books look very different from the line work of Cruickshank, Ardizzone or Shirley Hughes, who are thought of as the great British tradition."

Trained at Leeds College of Art, Browne studied graphic design and originally wanted to be a painter. Needing to earn money, however, he took a job as a medical illustrator at Leeds Royal Infirmary. "I was going through a very morbid phase following the death of my father which is probably why it suited me so well. The job involved going into operations and doing illustrations for medical students. I was showing the body as meat. Things like the liver had to look real, not like people think it does. I became very obsessed by fat, the way the globules looked. Technically it was an excellent training, and I learned how to use watercolour in a very tight way."

But nobody was interested in his pictures as art, only for reference. "There wasn't any scope for my imagination," Browne explains, "so after a brief spell training as a teacher I did some work for an advertising agency - which I hated because it was all too literal."

He had spent 15 years as a designer for Gordon Fraser's greetings cards before trying a picture book. The result was Through the Magic Mirror, which was closely based on Magritte. This first, simple story, which had too little plot and too much white space around the pictures, wasn't an immediate success. Nor was his second, A Walk in the Park, though Browne is now amused by the stinging criticism of one of his publisher's reps that he was "on an ego trip because the books weren't for children, like the Mr Men".

He tried to be more "for children" in Bear Hunt, which was much brighter and more child-centred. But he still lacked confidence in his plot. "I put in a lot of background to give another layer to the story. As a child I'd always liked cowboys and Indians stories where there were two layers - gruesome in the foreground but funny in the background. I used that as my model. I now use it more self-consciously."

Both early works contain the references to the surrealist painters that are so much a part of his work, and who were a profound influence on him in adolescence. "From 17 to 21 I was obsessed by sport and art. In art, I loved the pre-Raphaelites and Rembrandt first. Then I discovered Salvador Dali and it was like finding something I already knew."

Many of these images are thought to be too sophisticated for the traditional children's-book market, which is why Browne's books have played a central role in the move towards picture books for older children. But drawing on other artists' work has also caused Browne some trouble. "I've recently been sued by the Magritte estate for my fake reproductions of his work in Willy the Dreamer," he explains. "My French publisher got a letter demanding that all the books be taken off the shelves as well as a lot of compensation. I thought that I was encouraging children to look at Magritte's pictures, but I had to take out all references to him for the new edition."

Browne will not be stopped altogether, though. His future picture books will continue to be inspired by the great artists of the past. He will just be more discreet about how he uses their work.

"I've always felt that I was a bit of an outsider to the British children's-book illustration scene, because I don't work in line and wash. I work in watercolour and sometimes gouache, so obviously my books look very different from the line work of Cruickshank, Ardizzone or Shirley Hughes, who are thought of as the great British tradition." Trained at Leeds College of Art, Browne studied graphic design and originally wanted to be a painter. Needing to earn money, however, he took a job as a medical illustrator at Leeds Royal Infirmary. "I was going through a very morbid phase following the death of my father which is probably why it suited me so well. The job involved going into operations and doing illustrations for medical students. I was showing the body as meat. Things like the liver had to look real, not like people think it does. I became very obsessed by fat, the way the globules looked. Technically it was an excellent training, and I learned how to use watercolour in a very tight way." But nobody was interested in his pictures as art, only for reference. "There wasn't any scope for my imagination," Browne explains, "so after a brief spell training as a teacher I did some work for an advertising agency - which I hated because it was all too literal." He had spent 15 years as a designer for Gordon Fraser's greetings cards before trying a picture book. The result was Through the Magic Mirror, which was closely based on Magritte. This first, simple story, which had too little plot and too much white space around the pictures, wasn't an immediate success. Nor was his second, A Walk in the Park, though Browne is now amused by the stinging criticism of one of his publisher's reps that he was "on an ego trip because the books weren't for children, like the Mr Men". He tried to be more "for children" in Bear Hunt, which was much brighter and more child-centred. But he still lacked confidence in his plot. "I put in a lot of background to give another layer to the story. As a child I'd always liked cowboys and Indians stories where there were two layers - gruesome in the foreground but funny in the background. I used that as my model. I now use it more self-consciously." Both early works contain the references to the surrealist painters that are so much a part of his work, and who were a profound influence on him in adolescence. "From 17 to 21 I was obsessed by sport and art. In art, I loved the pre-Raphaelites and Rembrandt first. Then I discovered Salvador Dali and it was like finding something I already knew." Many of these images are thought to be too sophisticated for the traditional children's-book market, which is why Browne's books have played a central role in the move towards picture books for older children. But drawing on other artists' work has also caused Browne some trouble. "I've recently been sued by the Magritte estate for my fake reproductions of his work in Willy the Dreamer," he explains. "My French publisher got a letter demanding that all the books be taken off the shelves as well as a lot of compensation. I thought that I was encouraging children to look at Magritte's pictures, but I had to take out all references to him for the new edition." Browne will not be stopped altogether, though. His future picture books will continue to be inspired by the great artists of the past. He will just be more discreet about how he uses their work.

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.trailText: Maxim Jakubowski rounds up the latest releases: Purple Cane Road, Hammerhead Ranch Motel, Thunder in the Sky and The Chelsea Girl Murders
fields.body:
My favourite gloomy poet of the bayous, James Lee Burke, revisits old haunts in Purple Cane Road (Orion, £12.99) in which his Cajun cop Dave Robicheaux returns. As ever, the troubled lawman embarks on a murky journey into the past, and this time it's deeply personal.

Attempting to stop the execution of a young woman accused of killing her child-molesting guardian, Robicheaux finds himself investigating the unsolved murder of his own mother, gunned down by two crooked cops some 30 years earlier. The quest threads its way through the pulsating underbelly of American society, in which all characters tread a grey path between horror and redemption. No crime writer in America can hold a pen to Burke's mastery of style and powers of evocation and empathy; this is prose that cuts straight to the heart, summoning a wonderful parade of damaged humanity in its wake.

The next trio of American crime offerings are all in a lighter vein, but no less entertaining for that. In Tim Dorsey's Hammerhead Ranch Motel (HarperCollins, £6.99), genial homicidal maniac Serge Storms races around Florida in pursuit of $5m hidden in the boot of the wrong car. This takes the Hiaasen formula and adds Tarantino-laced amphetamine to the mix; the ensuing mayhem is raucous, body-strewn and both sinister and hilarious.

Elizabeth Peters's Thunder in the Sky (Robinson, £6.99), the twelfth instalment of the adventures of suffragette, sleuth and archeologist Amelia Peabody, brings our doughty heroine to 1914 and a Cairo full of spies, plots, counterplots and dastardly deeds. An artifact uncovered at a Giza dig confirms to Amelia that her arch nemesis, Sethos the master criminal, is on the loose; our heroine, a cross between Miss Marple and Indiana Jones, is soon wielding a mean brolly to great effect. Endearing, exotic and tongue-in-cheek.

More contemporary, and gossamer fun, is Sparkle Hayter's heroine, TV newswoman Robin Hudson, a New York Bridget Jones with added spunk and wit. In The Chelsea Girl Murders (No Exit Press, £6.99), a fire forces her to vacate her apartment and move into the legendary Chelsea Hotel. Hayter knows all its nooks and crannies, which comes in handy: chaos soon ensues, with a plague of bodies littering the rooms and stairways. Will Robin solve the fiendish crimes? Get the bad guy? The good guy? The right dress and shade of lipstick? A fun ride with enough jokes to fill a hotel room and a splendid cast of frenetic New Yorkers, which confirms Hayter as the comic queen of all she surveys.

fields.headline: The French connection
fields.standfirst: Paul Webster  explores current crises and literary rebirths in the land of Flaubert and Voltaire
fields.trailText: Paul Webster explores current crises and literary rebirths in the land of Flaubert and Voltaire
fields.body:
The French publishing industry is well into its long summer siesta, one eye wearily open in the hope of spotting the winners among the 9,000 new releases planned for the autumn. Bookshops remain a useful air-conditioned refuge, but it is already off season for their most attractive promotional aid, the forums. All big bookstores have these theatres or lecture rooms in which authors confront passionate readers. Signing is incidental; the audience, as many as 200 or 300 people, expects a two-hour free conference, questions included, and most will have already dissected the book under discussion.

Writers prefer this intimate contact to invisible TV and radio audiences because they catch a glimpse of word-of-mouth country, that intangible zone in which books from nowhere are transformed into bestsellers. When the forum circuit gets going again, visits to Le Furet du Nord at Lille, the Montparnasse FNAC or Mollat in Bordeaux (haunted by François Mauriac) will again be more rewarding than the worn-out late-night TV discussions such as Bernard Pivot's once essential Bouillon de Culture.

In judging the literary scene there is no point in trusting media bestseller lists, which are dominated by British and US crime and thriller writers. Publishers' figures are so dishonest that they could have been drawn up by used-car vendors. An example of their unreliability struck me during a visit to the Berry, the French heartland, where seven bookshops combine to issue their own list of true sales. Not one of the five top titles figured among the Parisian media's bestsellers. I had not heard of the three most sought-after novels in la France profonde: La Péniche de Saint Nicolas by Michel Caffier, Vengeance d'Automne by Jean-Louis Magnon and Récit d'un Branleur - the wanker's story - by Samuel Benchetrit.

These books must have surfaced through the reader grapevine known as bouche-à-l'oreille. While the first two have rural settings, the Lorraine and the Cévennes, the third is about filling an empty urban day on the dole. I doubt if any of the authors will make much impact among the Left Bank literati fascinated by the lyrical Amélie Nothomb (Stupeur et Tremblements), the highly imaginative Marie Darrieussecq (Truismes) and the very commercial Michel Houellebecq (Les Particules Elémentaires), leaders in the first serious cross-Channel literary raid since the golden days of Saint-Germain-des-Prés.

Anyone who skipped the middle chapters of France's post-war literary saga could be forgiven for thinking the country has emerged from a period of writer's block. Critics prefer to compare today's young and realistic social writers with any predecessor from the 1930s to the late 1950s - Céline, Sartre, Camus, De Beauvoir or Sagan. The highly productive in-between generation that includes Philippe Sollers, Jean-Marie Le Clézio and Francois Nourissier (who has just written his autobiography) seems consigned to a quaint twilight zone - a relegation that Sollers, Mauriac's protégé, tries to escape with a plodding literary chronicle in the Journal du Dimanche.

Perhaps Nourissier, chairman of the Goncourt prize committee, was speaking for all members of the worthy cohort of reliable storytellers by titling his book A Defaut du Génie (for want of genius): touching humility from an ageing author who never escaped the shadow of predecessors in Gallimard's publishing house, whose stable of writers hoovered up Nobel and other prizes from the 1920s onwards.

Despite millions spent on flashy and often dishonest sales campaigns for a chosen elite, few writers in France today seriously claim genius status; the most recent contenders were Marguerite Duras and Nathalie Sarraute. In discovering new voices, it would be wishful thinking to expect that the Gallimard recipe or that of Jérome Lindon's Editions du Minuit (publishing Samuel Beckett and Claude Simon among others) could be easily copied.

Gallimard still profits from the work of a master Nobel-winning literary scout, André Gide, who even wrote prefaces to give newcomers a helping hand and created the best backlist in the world. Lindon, meanwhile, set a personal tradition of astuteness, patience, indulgence and risk-taking that included tolerance of the most outrageous egos in the interests of stylish literature.

Content also explains why it is impossible to repeat past glories. Take any of the writers who flourished in the golden age - Louis Aragon and Drieu la Rochelle, say, who lived on opposite sides of the ideological divide - and you will find authors absorbed by the greatest issues of the 20th century: communism, fascism, rural and religious decline, two world wars, the Holocaust, feminism, consumerism and the creeping collapse of certainties like family unity and life-long marriage.

Angrily railing against the chaos of post-1968 sexual liberation and the electronic age, Houellebecq-style, does not seem quite so grand, however shocking this type of literature might sound (crude titles include Valérie Despentes's Baise-moi, "fuck me", now a scandalous film). All the most successful current literary polemics still depend on pre-1970s history - anti-Semitism, the Algerian War, colonialism, Résistance, anarchism and François Mitterrand's dubious past.

Sharp-edged nostalgia has become a highly profitable literary business both in non-fiction and popular novels, best illustrated by former printer Didier Daeninckx's series of crime books which, like Meurtres pour Mémoires, revive buried 20th-century political and military affairs for story background. Soft-edged nostalgia has almost equal success. Persistence of things past explains the success of several bouche-à-l'oreille recommendations, including the current top of the list, an autobiography by Jean-Claude Brialy - the Beau Serge of the 1958 New Wave - whose amiable stroll through the last 40 years of cinema is called Le Ruisseau des Singes ("the monkey stream").

Apart from Christian Jacq's stories of ancient Egypt, few home-grown serious novels this year have made anything like the impact of an impressive list of regurgitated true-life stories, from Louis XVII to the Baron Haussmann - a trend that has pushed ranks of reliable storytellers, such as Goncourt winner Erik Orsenna, to forsake fiction for biography or history. Orsenna's Portrait d'un Homme Heureux marks the 300th anniversary of the death of the royal gardener André Le Nôtre. Next year, André Malraux's centenary is up for celebration, giving another chance for authors and readers alike to make further nonsense of the advice "never look back".

 Paul Webster's books include Pétain's Crime and a biography of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, both published by Papermac.

webTitle: Guardian review: From Blue to Black by Joel Lane

fields.headline: Access all areas
fields.standfirst: Phil Baker  on indie authenticity in Joel Lane's From Blue to Black
fields.trailText: Phil Baker on indie authenticity in Joel Lane's From Blue to Black
fields.body:
From Blue to Black
Joel Lane
Serpent's Tail, £10, 215pp
Buy it at BOL

"You can't explain to a metal fan why Nirvana are real and Iron Maiden aren't," says a character in Joel Lane's raw novel. "You either hear it or you don't." Set in the early 90s, From Blue to Black follows a post-punk band around pub gigs and the indie-music scene, focusing on the unpromising landscapes of Birmingham and the Black Country. Narrated by the bassist, David, it charts his relationship with the increasingly disturbed vocalist, Karl. Karl's final disintegration is followed by ugly revelations about his adolescence and some grimly abusive sex back in the bad old days of the 70s. It is a decade remembered here with no plastic nostalgia: the era of IRA pub bombings and Enoch Powell as folk hero.

Lane's writing is faultlessly immediate, with nothing too clever and no foot put wrong. There is a simple, unforced vividness and peeled-back clarity of perception, whether he is describing atmospheric effects ("You know how sometimes a gust of wind can bring the rain together so it makes a twisted shape and almost casts a shadow?"), a poky hotel in Amsterdam ("no lift or central staircase, only flights of stairs that joined up the landings at unexpected points") or the pleasures of being traumatised and stressed out. "Stress can heighten your enjoyment of things - films and music in particular. You watch and listen more closely, not sure how much is really there and how much is in your imagination."

Live music is described with a nervous authenticity. You wonder how far the book is based on experience, with familiar reference points such as the music David likes (Jesus and Mary Chain, My Bloody Valentine) and the bands he gigs with (The Family Cat, who are real enough) leading to the fictional but chunkily quoted NME and Melody Maker reviews his band receives, the lyrics they write and the death of an unstable partner. All this is underpinned by Lane's rare attention to the Black Country. Digbeth, Stourbridge, Hockley and Moseley are evoked in all their depressing variety (here "a district composed entirely of back streets", elsewhere "part Victorian, part futuristic"). Is there really a K2 Indian restaurant in Moseley? If this book's convincing texture is anything to go by, I reckon there probably is.

Hungover and broken up, the emotional landscapes are no less bleak. The hollow feeling of real life blows through the book like a chill, and we're told the music is no comfort either: "Nobody wants to leave a gig feeling cold and empty inside." But - true to the indie ethos - another character counters: "I'd rather listen to The Fall than U2. It's good to be reminded that things are complex." It is.

webTitle: Guardian review: Work Adventures Childhood Dreams by Patience Gray

fields.headline: A woman for all seasons
fields.standfirst: Vera Rule  hails the memoirs of intriguing minimalist Patience Gray, Work Adventures Childhood Dreams
fields.trailText: Vera Rule hails the memoirs of intriguing minimalist Patience Gray, Work Adventures Childhood Dreams
fields.body:
Work Adventures Childhood Dreams
Patience Gray
Prospect Books, £30, 434pp

Patience Gray's 1986 Honey From A Weed was set in Mediterranean landscapes where she smithed silver and cooked in austere local styles; it described, with recipes, an almost gone way of life - droughts, fuel dearths, fastings, feastings. It was an original work, close to John Berger documenting peasant land before the final wild asparagus is rooted out, or perhaps Norman Lewis hearing the last voices from an old Spanish sea before the Germans throw down their towels.

Honey made me speculate about Gray - there was something obliquely intriguing about this woman and her basil plants among the quarries of Carrera and Naxos, her past mentioned only in rare parentheses as she reduced the tomato crop to vats of sanguine sauce. The presence of her partner Norman, called "the sculptor" or "the man of stone", lent her sexiness - he was clearly worth the lack of plumbing in the barns on rocky outcrops where they dwelt. Gray's dishes might just about be approximated with ingredients from Waitrose, but her life was evidently savoury beyond imitation. I was very curious what she might write away from the pot of fava beans.

Well, over a decade later, here are Gray's collected fascicoli - "little bundles" or pamphlets, which are her anti-autobiography. These are not scenes arranged in any linear time. Each bundle ties together a discrete event - an encounter with a spooked TS Eliot at a Sussex cocktail party, a gate never opened into a Palladian villa garden in the Veneto - but Gray does not foreshorten her life along the usual convergent lines of narrative. Perhaps the crucial paragraph of the book is her observation aboard a bus of an Italian landscape from a crazy angle that verifies the pre-perspective conventions of Gothic art: what is important zooms up big and close, the rest falls away, small.

And that's how she treats her past. From far back, there looms a childhood scene of the 1920s: her father, a reverberatingly military man, lately arrived from Mesopotamia to set up a pig farm on heavy clay near Basingstoke, forces Gray's governess to walk a tusked boar; the swinish promenade ends with tears in a ditch. From the middle distance of 1958, there is a vignette of Gray's appointment as women's-page editor on the Observer: the phone call interrupts her ironing of a dress in which to fly to Naples, mission unspecified.

Soon a certain George Seddon arrives from the Guardian to tell her "he had discovered Observer readers to be mostly working men living in Victorian back-to-backs in the Midlands" - so the paper begins "to sing the deceptive but seductive joys of acquisition" and Gray is dismissed: much she cares.

There is an episode from 1964, set in a haunted Venice of flotsam on dazzling waters; Gray walks a roof parapet to find sanctuary after the greedy trafficking in artworks at the Biennale. After a long day on the Rialto among collectors and contessas, she remarks that "the study of what human beings can do without has hardly begun". This is her core belief: the necessary desire for less; the richness of the empty; the ultimate luxury of the minimal.

Summarising Gray can make her style sound merely anecdotal and her adventures averagely picaresque, which they never are: not even when she couriers an early package tour on the Orient Express, aided only by Mr St Leger, paragon, ex-commando and expert at petit-point. As she writes, the alarms and excursions of Dalmatia 50 years ago drop away, and Gray remembers how happiness "hummed about the pockmarked sunstruck walls of Diocletian's Palace".

She seems often surprised by happiness, which, she writes, "embraces the traveller like a cloak". Perhaps her childhood, spent on tiptoe to avoid provoking more parental reverberations, and her own solitary young motherhood (she discreetly bore and raised two children around 1940) left her unprepared for happiness, although she has a great capacity for enjoying it.

And also for reveries, those subterranean, subaquatic connections now mostly impermissible in print. This book, with sketches and snaps strewn through the text, was originally put out by an Italian house, Edizioni Leucasia, and feels almost like samizdat publishing, because Gray writes of moments unvalued in an acquisitive age.

There is a powerful undertow to all her memories: she mislays a key so archetypal it might be an icon for all locks, for the act of unlocking: she wounds her knee in the Alpes Maritimes and subsides on a clump of marestails, an ancient styptic that heals the cut in hours. And after the death of her friend Irving Davis - bibliophile, insect lover and cook, whose kitchen familiar was a bluebottle - she attends a party for the posthumous sale of his volumes; a bluebottle sips from her glass of champagne.

These are not stories of enormous changes, nor of journeys with urgent appointments to keep (and there is only a single recipe, moreover one that, in its reliance on technique impossible to learn from the page, proves the pointlessness of cookbooks). But Gray's bundles are subtly marvellous, and she gets "very close to the music of what happens".
fields.bodyText: Work Adventures Childhood Dreams Patience Gray Prospect Books, £30, 434pp Patience Gray's 1986 Honey From A Weed was set in Mediterranean landscapes where she smithed silver and cooked in austere local styles; it described, with recipes, an almost gone way of life - droughts, fuel dearths, fastings, feastings. It was an original work, close to John Berger documenting peasant land before the final wild asparagus is rooted out, or perhaps Norman Lewis hearing the last voices from an old Spanish sea before the Germans throw down their towels. Honey made me speculate about Gray - there was something obliquely intriguing about this woman and her basil plants among the quarries of Carrera and Naxos, her past mentioned only in rare parentheses as she reduced the tomato crop to vats of sanguine sauce. The presence of her partner Norman, called "the sculptor" or "the man of stone", lent her sexiness - he was clearly worth the lack of plumbing in the barns on rocky outcrops where they dwelt. Gray's dishes might just about be approximated with ingredients from Waitrose, but her life was evidently savoury beyond imitation. I was very curious what she might write away from the pot of fava beans. Well, over a decade later, here are Gray's collected fascicoli - "little bundles" or pamphlets, which are her anti-autobiography. These are not scenes arranged in any linear time. Each bundle ties together a discrete event - an encounter with a spooked TS Eliot at a Sussex cocktail party, a gate never opened into a Palladian villa garden in the Veneto - but Gray does not foreshorten her life along the usual convergent lines of narrative. Perhaps the crucial paragraph of the book is her observation aboard a bus of an Italian landscape from a crazy angle that verifies the pre-perspective conventions of Gothic art: what is important zooms up big and close, the rest falls away, small. And that's how she treats her past. From far back, there looms a childhood scene of the 1920s: her father, a reverberatingly military man, lately arrived from Mesopotamia to set up a pig farm on heavy clay near Basingstoke, forces Gray's governess to walk a tusked boar; the swinish promenade ends with tears in a ditch. From the middle distance of 1958, there is a vignette of Gray's appointment as women's-page editor on the Observer: the phone call interrupts her ironing of a dress in which to fly to Naples, mission unspecified. Soon a certain George Seddon arrives from the Guardian to tell her "he had discovered Observer readers to be mostly working men living in Victorian back-to-backs in the Midlands" - so the paper begins "to sing the deceptive but seductive joys of acquisition" and Gray is dismissed: much she cares. There is an episode from 1964, set in a haunted Venice of flotsam on dazzling waters; Gray walks a roof parapet to find sanctuary after the greedy trafficking in artworks at the Biennale. After a long day on the Rialto among collectors and contessas, she remarks that "the study of what human beings can do without has hardly begun". This is her core belief: the necessary desire for less; the richness of the empty; the ultimate luxury of the minimal. Summarising Gray can make her style sound merely anecdotal and her adventures averagely picaresque, which they never are: not even when she couriers an early package tour on the Orient Express, aided only by Mr St Leger, paragon, ex-commando and expert at petit-point. As she writes, the alarms and excursions of Dalmatia 50 years ago drop away, and Gray remembers how happiness "hummed about the pockmarked sunstruck walls of Diocletian's Palace". She seems often surprised by happiness, which, she writes, "embraces the traveller like a cloak". Perhaps her childhood, spent on tiptoe to avoid provoking more parental reverberations, and her own solitary young motherhood (she discreetly bore and raised two children around 1940) left her unprepared for happiness, although she has a great capacity for enjoying it. And also for reveries, those subterranean, subaquatic connections now mostly impermissible in print. This book, with sketches and snaps strewn through the text, was originally put out by an Italian house, Edizioni Leucasia, and feels almost like samizdat publishing, because Gray writes of moments unvalued in an acquisitive age. webTitle: Guardian review: Where The Dance Is by A Sivanandan

fields.headline: Ties that bind
fields.standfirst: John Berger  admires A Sivanandan's tangled tales in Where The Dance Is
fields.trailText: John Berger admires A Sivanandan's tangled tales in Where The Dance Is
fields.body:
Where The Dance Is
A Sivanandan
Arcadia, £10.99, 160pp

Following A Sivanandan's acclaimed novel When Memory Dies, about the suffering of his country Sri Lanka, comes this volume of 14 short stories - stories, set in London and the subcontinent, about how life ties people up in knots and about the dream of untying a knot together. Their touch is gentle, humorous; and the ends of the knotted strings are always left mysteriously loose, as in a Jim Jarmusch film.

Indeed, "Ishwar", a little masterpiece, begs to be made into a film. An English couple visit India in an attempt to save their marriage. They visit the Taj Mahal, the temple of erotic goddesses in Khajuraho, the Ganges. Their money is stolen and they end up in Calcutta dependent upon an airport tout called Ishwar, whom they had met a month earlier on arrival. What has changed in them? Perhaps nothing, or perhaps they took in what Ishwar meant when he said: "India is full of paradoxes, not contradictions." "What's the difference?" asks Ronnie. "A contradiction is capable of resolution, but a paradox... you can resolve a contradiction, but you've got to live with a paradox."

Another story is written in the form of a letter from an inmate of a hospital in Colombo. "Ah, yes, my mother how is she?... it is she and she alone who has the feel of me, for she is mad too you know and the only way she can remain that way is to pitch it against my sanity, or vice versa, does it matter? In a way, she will be lost without me, you know. She was not lost without our father. Big man, you think, all loving, all encompassing. Balls. He was a majority man, didn't understand a thing about difference. Yes, yes I know he fought all his life, but like a majority man fights, safely, for somebody, without becoming that other body..."

All the stories here raise the question of what sensuousness, "becoming that other body", can or cannot offer to the human predicament. The best of this book makes me think of Chekhov, and for an interesting reason. Sivanandan, like Chekhov, is closely engaged in his daily life with people, an engagement which has nothing directly to do with literature. Chekhov, while writing his great stories, practised as a doctor; Sivanandan, as director of the London Institute of Race Relations, listens to and defends people in difficulties at their work or on the streets. In both cases, the other activity gives a special focus to their writing. There are no heroes or villains, no judgment, no certainty; above all, no cleverness. Instead, there is what I can only call an open-air lucidity. Their stories are like passers-by on their way somewhere else. And in this lies their intense, elusive poignancy.

webTitle: Guardian review: Sick Puppy by Carl Hiaasen

fields.headline: Surfeiting USA
fields.standfirst:
Giles Foden relishes Carl Hiaasen's eco-warrior satire, Sick Puppy
Read an extract
fields.trailText: Giles Foden relishes Carl Hiaasen's eco-warrior satire, Sick Puppy
fields.body:
Sick Puppy
Carl Hiaasen
Macmillan, £16.99, 341pp
Buy it at BOL

Like all great farceurs, from Wodehouse to Orton, Carl Hiaasen tends to tread the same territory, in this case his native Florida's hasty retreat from paradise. This is far from a criticism. Hiaasen aficionados can take pleasure in how, with each new book, he shifts around the elements in what is essentially the same system of characters and situations. So in spite of Sick Puppy being his eighth solo caper (he has co-written three others with Bill Montalbano), we can be confident, as the anarchy gets under way, that we will enjoy the ride.

There is once again an ecological threat, and once again there is a crusading hero on whom the action will focus. Once more, too, Hiaasen's protagonist pales in comparison to his own alter ego, rogue ex-governor Clinton Tyree, who now lives wild ("like Grizzly Adams on PCP") in the mangroves. Tyree crops up throughout the novels, kidnapping errant tourists and taking them on brutal re-education treks.

The eco-warrior of Sick Puppy is himself well on the way to Tyree mania. Heir to a multimillion-dollar fortune, young Twilly Spree has dedicated himself to preventing further desecration of the Florida landscape: "The state was urbanising itself faster than any other place on the planet, faster than any other place in the history of man. Each day 450 acres of wild forest disappeared beneath bulldozers..."

Although he has already blown up his uncle's unethical bank and indirectly caused the death of a trucker who has been dumping chemicals in rivers, Twilly limits himself these days to disabling litterbug tourists. But in political lobbyist Palmer Stoat he meets his match. Whatever Twilly does - from filling Stoat's wife Desiderata's BMW with stinking rubbish to kidnapping their dog, the sick puppy of the title - Stoat doesn't get the message. He just will keep dropping those fast-food wrappers on the highway.

Twilly's pursuit of Stoat eventually leads him to discover the lobbyist's fixing of a property deal to build a leisure facility on unspoilt Toad Island. The property dealer, ex-drug baron Robert Clapley, aims to change this inapt name to Shearwater Island and make a mint. Both men share unpleasant or ridiculous obsessions: Stoat is crazy about cigars and hunting, while Clapley is fixated on Barbie dolls and rhino-horn aphrodisiac.

Once Twilly's interventions get too troublesome, Clapley's hitman, Mr Gash, is sent to deal with the conscience-stricken young man, who by this stage has shacked up with Desiderata in a kidnapping that isn't actually a kidnapping. Mr Gash and Desie are familiar counters on the Hiaasen playboard: we have seen both the thug and the wife/ daughter/ girlfriend of a slimeball who switches sides before. Desie, like her predecessors, fills out in character as the book progresses, gaining dignity in her own terms and pointing up the flaws even in those, like Twilly and Tyree, who are on the side of good. This is a virtue Hiaasen shares with Dickens, of all people: the types are types but at the same time they surprise us, and Hiaasen himself perhaps, by outgrowing their own typology.

Generally speaking, however, character is always secondary to plot and rhetoric in a Hiaasen story, and so it proves here. Scene tumbles upon scene, without any sense of the disjuncture one so often feels in lesser writers. The same goes for the language; the lists of habits, sins, consumer items, garbage, misdemeanours, horrors and delights are almost dizzying. Here is the core of Hiaasen's genius: to register excess and surfeit in the very texture of his writing - to effect formally what he sees happening to Florida and America in general.

Perhaps this is why the phrase "more, more" keeps cropping up throughout Sick Puppy. It suggests that this writer's project, the tireless exposure of human folly, is far from over. Alas, like the Floridian scumbags to whom he recommends greed-management courses, we will just have to temper our appetites and wait patiently for the next bout of treatment.

fields.standfirst: The book is a huge success, now there's to be a film. But in Cephalonia, where Captain Corelli's Mandolin is set,  veterans feel their campaign against the Nazis has been defamed. None more so than the real Captain Corelli
fields.trailText: Such an outburst from the writer, whose mastery of "elegant Latinate constructions" had wowed the literary world, served only to publicise the dispute and encourage his Greek critics. fields.body:
Such an outburst from the writer, whose mastery of "elegant Latinate constructions" had wowed the literary world, served only to publicise the dispute and encourage his Greek critics. By the time the shooting of the Corelli movie began in earnest in Cephalonia earlier this year, the film-makers were having to issue public assurances that they would not be re-opening the wounds of the civil war or repeating what the island's resistance veterans regard as de Bernières's defamation of their movement. Most critics on the island have accepted the undertakings that the film will be a straightforward love story and avoid the controversy surrounding the book. They have also been mollified by the fact that the scriptwriter is Shawn Slovo, daughter of Ruth First, the murdered anti-apartheid heroine, and Joe Slovo, former communist and ANC leader.

"Dr Zhivago is the movie we're making," producer Tim Bevan says. "It's a big epic romance. The war is the backdrop to the movie and politics gears things up, because it's about life and death. But the argument over the politics and the civil war is as dull as ditchwater as far as we're concerned. What this is about is maintaining an emotional through-line for 100 minutes and making them cry a lot." The script was, the film-makers say, finalised before they started shooting, but director John Madden has since moved further away from the book. Along with the civil war, they have jettisoned several other of de Bernières's most contested tales and characters, including the psychopathic partisan leader, Hector, and all the mainland partisan atrocity scenes. And, in contrast to the novel, Cephalonian andartes are indeed shown fighting side by side with the Italians against the Germans. The island authorities nevertheless remain nervous about how the movie will turn out. "If they screw us," one senior official says of the film-makers, "I don't know what we're going to do."

Meanwhile, excitement about the film on the island is being fanned in the Greek media: Robert de Niro is spotted visiting the set, Madonna is rumoured to be having dinner with Nic Cage - though it turns out she is only holidaying in nearby Ithaca. In the fishing village of Aghia Efimia, the Spanish actress Penelope Cruz, who plays Pelagia in the film, is reading El Pais in jeans in a cafe by the harbour, while John Hurt pays the bill at his regular table. Cage, who is generally surrounded by flunkies and has been busy mastering the mandolin, has not dropped in for a while. Until a couple of months ago, this was Cafe Dimitrios, but now it is Captain Corelli's Cafe, proclaimed in red-and-gold lettering above the awning. "We changed it to please the film company," explains the cafe's Peter Anastas. "The book has helped business and we hope the film does, too." But even he is sceptical about de Bernières's story. "That stuff the author wrote about the andartes and the communists is fantasy, but it doesn't matter because we know it's not true."

The problem of novels and films that play fast and loose with history - and the grey area where artistic licence predominates - is a familiar one. In earlier editions, de Bernières explained: "Much of what I have written consists of hearsay tempered with myth and hazy memory, which, of course, is what history is." It is little wonder perhaps that the Princeton university historian Mark Mazower, author of a prize-winning account of wartime Greece, should have written recently: "De Bernières has a rather jaundiced, indeed biased, attitude towards the Greek left, and his understanding of what history is is not much better." But unlike other controversial historical movies such as The Patriot or Braveheart, Captain Corelli's Mandolin deals with events that took place in living memory - and the onslaught from survivors has now forced de Bernières on to the back foot.

When first privately taken to task after the book's initial publication, according to one critic, the author explained he had obtained some of the historical background from Alexandros Rallis, then working at the Greek embassy in London and a relative of Ionnis Rallis, Greece's quisling dictator under the Nazis. But, despite offering "particular thanks" to Rallis in the book's acknowledgements, de Bernières insists that the embassy official provided only the date of a Greek Orthodox Easter during the war years and nothing else. Another of his cited sources is Helen Cosmatatos, an English-born Miss Marple character, who married a Cephalonian aristocrat and has lived in Argostoli since 1936. She stayed on the island throughout the war and is founder and guiding light of the magnificent Corgialenios cultural history museum.

Cosmatatos gave de Bernières reading lists and, according to her staff, corrected drafts of the novel. She has little love for the Greek left and her husband was arrested - though not mistreated, she says - by the resistance after the liberation. But even she now seems anxious to distance herself from the finished product. "I know a good bit of it is not true, but it's not my business to start having arguments. Allowing the book to be translated into Greek, that was asking for trouble. I even had people in here from the government, cabinet ministers from Cephalonia, waving the book around. They were furious about it."

In fact, de Bernières had already had to agree that some of his "language and opinions should be moderated", as he put it, when the Greek edition of the novel was published. The following passage, for example, was deemed too much for Greek readers to take, and was excised on the advice of his publisher: "In Cephalonia the communists began to deport awkward characters to concentration camps; from a safe distance they had watched the Nazis for years, and were well-versed in all the arts of atrocity and oppression. Hitler would have been proud of such assiduous pupils."

Last month, the novelist began a more public, if limited, climbdown over Corelli, conceding he could have been wrong about the resistance. Whether in response to the pressure of the veterans' campaign on the film-makers or not, he explained that, while he "had not actually changed my mind about what I think is the truth, I had to bear in mind the possibility that I might be wrong". He did not, he said, want to stir up bad blood and the story of the resistance was "extremely complex" - adding, for good measure, that he regarded the persecution of communists in Greece after the war as an "absolute disgrace". In an email to the Guardian last week, he said he is "no longer as sure of everything as I once was," and would be prepared to change his mind on the "production of convincing evidence".

Both de Bernières and Corelli film producer Kevin Loader like to emphasise how difficult it is to establish what really happened in Cephalonia during and after the German occupation. To this day he remains a folk hero on the island.

In any case, he says, reeling off a list of other influences, "intertextuality" is the stuff of post-modern fiction.

Nor does he recognise De Bernières's portrayal of the ELAS andartes as torturers and rapists - on the contrary, he insists, the movement's discipline was ferocious over the treatment of women, recalling a highly-valued doctor in his partisan unit who was executed after he was accused by a Greek girl of rape. The guerilla war against the Germans was brutal, he concedes. Shortly after he joined ELAS on the mainland, he was shocked to see andartes cutting the throats of captured German soldiers. I lived among them for 14 months and those months were an unforgettable experience, because of the partisans' sense of solidarity, kindness, altruism and fraternity."

Pampaloni's happiest memory of Cephalonia is his arrival at the partisan base on Mount Aenos after the massacre. "I cannot describe the warmth of the welcome I was given, or I will cry. I was at the end of my tether and all of them, men and women, embraced me, washed my face and feet, and gave me ouzo and fruit. Formally, we had been enemies a month before and now they treated me like this." In September, Pampaloni will return to the island for a commemoration of the Nazi slaughter with his fellow survivors and Greek resistance veterans. The bond between them has endured for more than half a century.

fields.headline: Greek myth
fields.standfirst: The book is a huge success, now there's to be a film. But in Cephalonia, where Captain Corelli's Mandolin is set,  veterans feel their campaign against the Nazis has been defamed. None more so than the real Captain Corelli
fields.trailText: The book is a huge success, now there's to be a film. But in Cephalonia, where Captain Corelli's Mandolin is set, veterans feel their campaign against the Nazis has been defamed. None more so than the real Captain Corelli.
fields.body:
For countless British enthusiasts, Captain Corelli's Mandolin is an enchanting literary tour de force, an epic wartime love story with the authentic flavour of Greek island life, still the ideal beach accessory for the discerning holidaymaker. Compared by AS Byatt to the work of Charles Dickens and hailed as "absolutely brilliant" by the television presenter Jeremy Paxman, the book became a publishing phenomenon of the late 90s, the New Labour politician's novel of the moment. Hugh Grant was even shown engrossed in the paperback in the final scene of Notting Hill, Britain's most successful film. To date, the book has sold 1.5 million copies, clocking up 240 weeks on the bestseller list - making its author, Louis de Bernières, a rich man and sending an electric current through the tourist industry on the island of Cephalonia, where it is set.

Now Captain Corelli is about to become a £45 million Hollywood-backed movie in its own right, starring Nicolas Cage, Penelope Cruz and John Hurt, and currently being shot in Cephalonia by the same British company that made Notting Hill. When the film goes on release some time next year, the existing de Bernières tourist boom on the island seems likely to turn into full-scale Corellimania. Already, bars and restaurants are being re-named after the novel's eponymous hero, racks of glossy guides to "Captain Corelli's Island" have gone on sale, legends proliferate about the prices the film-makers will pay for imported donkeys, and business around the port of Sami - where the main filming is taking place - has never been brisker.

Meanwhile, the Greek government has provided minesweepers, landing craft and hundreds of soldiers; half the waterfront at Sami has been requisitioned for a reconstruction of the capital, Argostoli, as it was in the 40s, and Cephalonians have been signing up in their scores to be extras in the film. De Bernières recently made a triumphal tour of the set, joshing with the actors and feasting on the fruits of his achievement. "This is a big thing for Cephalonia," declares Kevin Loader, one of the film's producers, as he suns himself outside a quayside Sami cafe, surveying a mocked-up blackened bell tower used in the previous day's shoot. "It's a big thing to happen to Greece," adds fellow producer Tim Bevan. "This is going to be Britain's biggest film next year, and it's a lot of people's favourite book in the UK. The last film on this scale to be made in Greece was the Guns Of Navarone, and I'm convinced most of that was shot in Italy, anyway."

But for all the extra income, large numbers of Cephalonians are deeply ambivalent about the Corelli phenomenon, and are far from being as grateful for their new-found celebrity as the film-makers seem to think they should be. The problem is not so much the downside of the expected tourist invasion, or the occasional traumatic flashback triggered by the sound of gunfire from the film set. For many of the older generation, who lived through the events described in de Bernières's book, his story is a slur on the record of the Greek resistance to the Nazis and a mish-mash of distortions and untruths about their island's wartime history. For the Cephalonian resistance veterans themselves, and for one uniquely-placed Italian officer and survivor of the Nazi terror on the island, Captain Corelli's Mandolin is a travesty - an inexcusable attempt to rewrite the story of their lives.

Dionisis Georgatos - the elected governor of Cephalonia who negotiated carefully-framed terms for the Corelli film to be made on the island - dismisses de Bernières's book as "reactionary and wrong". Nobody, he says, wants to benefit from the film "if it distorts our history - we had many deaths, houses were burned, people hanged in the streets. It is very sensitive. De Bernières clearly used British sources from that time and, of course, they had the role of invaders." Gerasimos Artelanis, mayor of Sami and, like Georgatos, a member of Greece's ruling socialist party, Pasok, has threatened to take the film-makers to the International Court of Justice if they include de Bernières's most controversial claims, thus breaking an undertaking not to inflame political and national sensitivities.

"We are at war with Louis de Bernières," explains Lefteris Eleftheratos, a 72-year-old former Cephalonian journalist and unofficial leader of the Greek campaign against the novel. "It is a defensive war because it is a war he declared on us." A teenage recruit to the resistance youth organisation during the Italian fascist and Nazi German occupations of the island - his father was imprisoned by the Germans after a collaborator's tip-off - Eleftheratos was forced into political exile during the ensuing civil war and spent 11 years working his way around the world, from Mao's China to Ethiopia and Australia, where he picked up the nickname Lefty Freeman. Now he is writing a book to counter de Bernières's version of the island's history and what he sees as its portrayal of Cephalonians as primitive and inhuman. "We are not against the film," he says carefully, in an Australian-Greek accent. "We know what the film means for the island as a source of income. The relationship flourishes when Pelagia's fiancé, Mandras, traumatised by the Greek-Italian war of 1940-1941, goes off to fight with the partisans on the mainland. Overwhelmed, more than 9,000 Italian soldiers on Cephalonia were either massacred on Hitler's personal orders or drowned as they were deported by ship.

Spurred on by the sacrifice of his fellow soldiers, he returns to Italy to do his bit for the war against Germany as a fireman. The lovers are not reunited until their old age, in modern-day Cephalonia.

But woven into this human drama is a one-sided account of the history of the period, and a crude and unremittingly hostile portrayal of the Greek communists in particular, who led the resistance against the Italian and German occupations and later fought British and American-backed forces in the civil war of the late 40s. In a series of jarring interludes, de Bernières offers a notably sympathetic portrait of the pre-war Greek dictator Metaxas - a man responsible for the torture, imprisonment and murder of thousands of left-wing political opponents - while Mussolini's occupation army, fresh from its genocidal sweeps through Ethiopia and Libya, is presented as a collection of harmless, fun-loving rogues.

By contrast, the main Greek resistance organisation, ELAS - which, according to the German army's own records, killed more than 8,000 German soldiers in little over a year, tied down tens of thousands more and controlled 80% of the country when Hitler withdrew - is depicted as a gang of torturers, ignorant demagogues and cowards, who spent the war "doing absolutely nothing" except stealing food from peasants and murdering guerillas from smaller rival, British-backed resistance groups. Greece was the only country liberated from the Nazis where British troops fought the resistance - second only in scale to Tito's partisan movement in Yugoslavia - to impose a pro-western authoritarian regime after the German withdrawal. In a policy that was bitterly attacked across the political spectrum in Britain, Churchill ordered General Scobie, in December 1944, to behave in Athens "as if you were in a conquered city".

And nowhere is there any reflection of the flowering of self-government in the areas liberated by the resistance, of the fact that women were given the vote for the first time in Greek history - or of the part played by ELAS in rescuing Greek Jews from transportation to the Nazi death camps.

Until the 70s, it was still a crime in Greece to have fought against the Nazis in the main wartime resistance movement, while Nazi collaborators received pensions. The role of the ELAS "andartes", or guerillas, in the liberation was formally recognised by the state only under Andreas Papandreou in the 80s. But, in case any reader might have mistaken his own view, de Bernières included an author's note in earlier editions of Captain Corelli's Mandolin to berate "disconnected intellectuals" for regarding the Greek communists as "romantic heroes", adding, "when they were not totally useless, perfidious and parasitic, they were unspeakably barbaric".

Makis Faraklos, now the 76-year-old president of the resistance veterans' association in the Cephalonian town of Lixouri, remembers witnessing the fate of some of those whom de Bernières insists spent the German occupation doing nothing.
