webTitle: Gay athletes hope games will boost Olympics bid

fields.headline: Gay athletes hope games will boost Olympics bid
fields.standfirst: London council braves critics of international gathering
fields.trailText: Britain's first international gay sports games take place this weekend, with the organisers planning a bid for the 2010 Gay Olympics if the event proves a success.
fields.body:
Britain's first international gay sports games take place this weekend, with the organisers planning a bid for the 2010 Gay Olympics if the event proves a success.

Hundreds of gay teams and athletes from around Britain, Europe and the United States are taking part in the UK Gay Sports festival in Waltham Forest, east London, the largest such event in the country.

Thousands of spectators are expected at competitions ranging from football and rugby to bridge, swimming and volleyball. The festival's size highlights the emergence of gay sports, partly as a consequence of the problems faced by some gay athletes who encounter hostility within mainstream clubs.

This festival is organised by Waltham Forest council, which plans to lead the 2010 Olympics bid along with gay sports groups, and hopes to use a new Olympic stadium at Picketts Lock, north London, as the main venue.

Since the first Gay Olympics in San Francisco in 1982, the gay event has come near to rivalling the Olympics themselves, attracting millions of pounds in sponsorship while generating a large revenue for the cities staging them.

The last Gay Olympics, in Amsterdam in 1998, attracted 15,000 participants and generated £80m for the host city; Vancouver and Los Angeles have also hosted the event. The next takes place in Sydney in 2002, using many of the venues for the Olympic games in September. Bidding for the 2006 Gay Olympics has closed, with five cities around the world hoping to win the right to stage them.

Sue Emerson of Team UK, the co-ordinating body for gay sports, said: "Lots of gay people feel excluded from mainstream sport because of locker room jokes and other hostile attitudes.

"Gay sports people have to put up with a lot of abuse.

"Many feel comfortable and more relaxed in gay sports events. The Gay Olympics have become a massive event.

"We will be writing to the sports minister [Kate Hoey] and the British Olympic Association, telling them of our plan for a 2010 London bid. There's a huge economic benefit to staging these games."

Waltham Forest council has been criticised for spending £40,000 on this weekend's event, and anticipates more criticism over bidding for the 2010 event.

A spokeswoman said: "The response has been very good across the whole of the borough, but we have been disappointed with some of the coverage.

"Bringing the Gay Olympics to London would be good for the whole of the city - we know about the strength of the pink pound, and there would be huge economic benefits.

"Gay Olympics have been staged in major cities across the world. We don't understand why people in this country are so hung up about issues like this. The time has come to move on."

The number of gay sports clubs has increased dramatically in the past few years, with gay athletes claiming that they face discrimination within mainstream sport.

Felix Zinc is a long distance runner taking part in this weekend's event, and a member of Front Runners, a gay running group.

He said: "There's a lot of gay athletes who don't feel comfortable in mainstream sport. Problems often arise over changing facilities, and there can be problems mixing socially after an event. Some of the prejudice we have encountered is overt. Gay games are friendly, fun, and just as competitive as any other event."

Richard Tremblay, a volleyball player whose team is competing in this weekend's event, said: "I think gay athletes get more out of gay sports events, because they are with like-minded people and feel more comfortable.

"The atmosphere is much nicer, but the standard of play is extremely high."

fields.headline: Concorde 'downed by burst tyre'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: As a silent procession of mourners was winding its way from Gonesse town hall to the Concorde accident site yesterday, investigators said that the catastrophic fire that downed the Air France aircraft on Tuesday appeared to have started outside the engines.
fields.body:
As a silent procession of mourners was winding its way from Gonesse town hall to the Concorde accident site yesterday, investigators said that the catastrophic fire that downed the Air France aircraft on Tuesday appeared to have started outside the engines.

With speculation among aviation experts growing that flying debris from a burst tyre may have caused the disaster, the French accident investigation bureau, the BEA, also said that at least one and possibly two of the plane's tyres had blown out before takeoff.

In a separate statement, the transport ministry said last night that "from the information available at present, it emerges that at least one tyre burst, something that could have triggered a chain of events, damage to the plane's structure, a fire and subsequent engine failure".

Air France admitted yesterday that bursting tyres had in the past damaged fuel tanks and engines on Concordes, and strenuously denied a French newspaper report that its ground crews had carried out lengthy repairs on the afterburners of the plane's two port engines, both of which burst into flame as the jet was set to take off from Charles de Gaulle airport, Paris.

Saying it "deplored the publication of incorrect information", the company did however confirm that routine maintenance was performed on the ageing supersonic plane - and all four engines tested - before the takeoff.

At the request of the captain, Christian Marty, further non-essential last-minute repairs were then carried out to a faulty reverse thruster, but Air France mechanics and many aviation experts are now convinced that this could not have been responsible for such a huge conflagration.

Spouting jets of flame almost as long as the plane itself, flight AF4590 ploughed into a hotel in the small town of Gonesse two minutes after takeoff, killing all 109 people on board and five people on the ground. The body of the latest victim, whose sex and identity has yet to be confirmed, was found late yesterday afternoon.

The BEA's latest findings appeared to support the view of many industry experts that extraneous pieces of rubber or metal could have been sucked into the plane's port engines, which then disintegrated, puncturing a fuel tank or severing the fuel lines.

Alternatively, said a former managing director of French Concorde operations, Franck Debouck, the port fuel tank may have been punctured directly by the flying debris: "Pressurised aviation fuel then poured into the two port engines, which ignited. The plane became a giant cigarette lighter."

In Gonesse, a procession of several hundred residents headed by the mayor and local dignitaries marched, their arms linked, for about a mile from the town hall to the crash site, where they laid bouquets of white roses. The silence was broken only by the roar of over-flying aircraft.

Reda Karroum, 21, a youth worker said the town had always been divided between "the bourgeois and the immigrants. But at times of tragedy like this, the people have all come together. The young people who are always on the wrong side of the law helped to dig people out of wreckage."

Henri Trento, 54, a Gonesse environmental activist, said: "We can't let this get us down. We have to learn from it. All the people here have seen death, but it's going to help us make the politicians realise that something has to be done."

Several incidents involving tyres have been reported on Concorde over the years. On June 15 1979, two tyres exploded on an Air France Concorde taking off from Washington's Dulles airport, and pieces of their magnesium rims punctured a wing and a fuel tank.

The plane returned and made a successful emergency landing, but after half a dozen similar incidents between 1979 and 1981, the National Transportation Safety Board demanded that Concorde's landing gear and tyres be inspected before every takeoff.

The BEA said in its first preliminary report late on Thursday that it had found shreds of tyre on the runway, and also revealed that Marty had told the control tower he was unable to retract the Concorde's undercarriage.

"At present, no debris from inside the engine has been identified. The fire appears to have started outside the engines, but this remains to be determined," the BEA said.

While it has decoded the plane's two black boxes, the BEA's full report on the disaster is not due until the end of August. A public prosecutor, Xavier Salvat, said the criminal investigation - which, exceptionally, is headed by three investigating magistrates - would be "as swift as humanly possible", but could still take months.

Air France again said its fleet of five Concordes would remain grounded until further notice.

Additional reporting by Amy Lodge in Gonesse

fields.headline: Tories hit at NHS 'double counting'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The Conservatives launched a counter-offensive yesterday against the government's NHS plan, accusing ministers of cynical manipulation of figures to exaggerate the growth in staff numbers and facilities that could be attributed to the recent strategic review.
fields.body:
The Conservatives launched a counter-offensive yesterday against the government's NHS plan, accusing ministers of cynical manipulation of figures to exaggerate the growth in staff numbers and facilities that could be attributed to the recent strategic review.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, cast doubt on four promises made by Tony Blair - increases in the numbers of consultants, GPs, nurses and acute beds.

A fact sheet issued by the Department of Health on Thursday to support Mr Blair's statement said: "As a result of the NHS plan, there will be between now and 2005: 7,500 more consultants (30% more than now)."

Dr Fox said this was misleading, because most of these extra consultants were already in training and would have gained these senior positions within five years, even if there had been no national plan.

The British Medical Association said it was not accusing ministers of a deliberate sleight of hand, but they had not mentioned that numbers of consultants had been growing anyway at 5% a year.

"If there had been no national plan at all, we would still have expected to see by 2005 an extra 4,500 consultants. They are already in the pipeline," a BMA spokesman said.

The DoH conceded last night that a plan, published in April, had already upgraded growth in consultant numbers over this period from 4,500 to 6,100. The increase that could be directly attributed to the national plan was 1,400, not the 7,500 indicated by the department's fact sheet.

Dr Fox said the government had similarly exaggerated the increase in numbers of GPs. The fact sheet promised 2,000 more GPs by 2005 "as a result of this NHS plan", but 1,000 of these extra posts were already in the pipeline.

The DoH said the workforce plan in April had increased the planned increase to 1,500. So the growth that could strictly be attributed to the new plan was 500. However, officials insisted there was nothing misleading in the text of the plan. "It explains how our extra investment in the NHS will be spent and sets out targets for 2004 or subsequent dates compared to now," a spokesman said.

Mr Fox said the statement on extra nurses failed to acknowledge that many would be part-time. The DoH said nurse recruitment targets were always expressed as a head count total rather than converted into the whole-time equivalent. It was too soon to say what proportion of the new nurses would be part-timers, but there was a trend to more flexible working to suit potential recruits.

 William Hague's economic policy appeared to be in disarray last night after a Treasury-backed analysis clocked up more than £5bn of new Tory spending commitments in the space of just two months, writes Nicholas Watts .

Labour accused the Tories of creating a £5bn "black hole" in their spending plans which raised fresh doubts about Mr Hague's ability to cut taxes.

The Tory leadership has promised to spend less than Labour in order to leave room for tax cuts.

The new hole identified in the Tory's spending plans showed that Mr Hague would struggle to cut costs.

Christopher Leslie, a Labour ministerial aide, said last night that he was astonished at the "profligacy" of the Tories. "At the rate the Tories are going there will be nothing left in the exchequer if they take over," he said.

fields.headline: Supermarkets cut pump prices
fields.trailText: The supermarket price war stepped up a gear yesterday when two major chains announced they were cutting the cost of petrol, days before the start of a boycott of the pumps.
fields.body:
The supermarket price war stepped up a gear yesterday when two major chains announced they were cutting the cost of petrol, days before the start of a boycott of the pumps.

Morrison's was the first to announce the price cut yesterday, followed by Sainsbury's several hours later.

Both reduced the price of unleaded petrol and diesel to 79.9p a litre from an average of 81.9p and 83.9p respectively from midnight yesterday.

Their decision has been encouraged by the falling cost-price of unleaded petrol -down by more than a quarter in the last three weeks - and the prospect of a road users' campaign for a one day boycott of petrol stations on Tuesday, August 1, aimed at forcing the government to reduce fuel duty.

The Dump the Pump campaigners, supported by the Road Haulage Association and tabloid newspapers, have said that, if their protest is a success, it will be repeated on subsequent Mondays.

Mark Hooper, Sainsbury's senior manager for petrol, said: "We want to ensure that our motorists benefit from the falling market costs as soon as possible, and hope that other national retailers follow suit."

Simon Davies, of Morrison's, said: "When the price of crude oil rises, petrol prices usually follow. In this instance, the cost of oil is falling, and we are acting decisively to ensure our customers receive the full benefit of the lower price -passing on much needed savings as soon as possible."

A spokesman for Tesco, which charges an average of 82.9p per litre for petrol, refused to say if the supermarket would reduce its prices. He said: "We have a price guarantee that we will match the price of petrol if it is found to be cheaper within a three-mile radius."

Another supermarket chain, Asda, said that some of its petrol stations had been selling unleaded petrol for 79.5p a litre for several weeks.

Edmund King, executive director of the RAC Foundation, a charity that is part of the motoring organisation and conducts research on its behalf, said it had been inundated with calls from motorists complaining about the high cost of petrol - particularly, he claimed, from elderly and disabled people, and those in rural areas who were dependent on their cars.

"If supermarkets are taking the lead in bringing the prices down, then hopefully it will be reflected in petrol pumps across the country. Normally other companies follow suit days later," he said.

"For many families, fuel is now their number one expenditure ahead of food and rent costs."

webTitle: Husband cleared of ordering contract killing

fields.headline: Husband cleared of ordering contract killing
fields.standfirst: Book dealer not guilty of offering best friend £20,000 to murder wife found dead in swimming pool
fields.trailText: A book dealer was yesterday cleared of contracting his best friend to murder his wife and dump her body in the couple's swimming pool.
fields.body:
A book dealer was yesterday cleared of contracting his best friend to murder his wife and dump her body in the couple's swimming pool.

Colin Harrold, 35, had been charged with murder and conspiring to murder Diane Harrold, 36, by offering Darren Lake, his best man from his first marriage, £20,000 to knock her unconscious then dump her in a pool in Uffington, Lincolnshire, last October.

The jury at Nottingham crown court unanimously rejected the prosecution's case that Harrold paid Lake to murder his wife because he was bored with her and did not want to pay for a divorce.

Lake, a former nightclub doorman nicknamed He-Man, had earlier admitted bludgeoning Mrs Harrold with a wooden post and drowning her. Lake claimed Harrold blackmailed him to do it, by producing a photo showing him being raped by two men in Tenerife 10 years before.

Lake, 31, from Peterborough, was yesterday given two life sentences at Nottingham crown court - one for murder and one for conspiracy to murder.

Sentencing him, Mr Justice Morland said he was guilty of a "cold blooded and merciless" planned murder. But he also said he believed Lake's evidence was "essentially truthful".

Mr Justice Morland told Lake: "I am satisfied whatever your reasons may have been for committing this terrible crime that your primary motive was financial reward."

In mitigation, Lake's barrister, Guy Boney QC, asked why Lake would have murdered Mrs Harrold if her husband had not put him up to it. Mr Boney said there was no truth in the suggestion made in Harrold's trial that Lake was having an affair with Mrs Harrold.

Mrs Harrold's body was found face down in the deep end of the pool at the £335,000 converted barn house.

Lake told the jury that Harrold asked him to kill his wife in September last year. He alleged that Harrold took him to the pool area and said: "I have a proposition for you - 20 grand to knock off Diane."

Lake had debts and needed money. He said if he did not agree to the murder, Harrold would send a picture of Lake being raped to his father, girlfriend, and the mother of his seven-year-old child.

Lake told the court he did not protest because "Colin doesn't know the meaning of the word, 'no'."

He said Harrold code-named the murder plot "Cleo" after his wife's cat. The idea was to drown the cat and make it look like Mrs Harrold had tripped on a pool slab and drowned while looking for the cat.

Harrold was on a trip to the red light district of Amsterdam at the time of the murder and Lake said this was an arranged alibi.

Lake claimed Harrold suggested he kill Diane with a concrete pool slab. Lake feared he could not lift the slab, so he bought a three-foot wooden post from Texas Homebase. He went to the Harrolds' house for coffee, stunned Mrs Harrold with the post and carried her body to the pool.

But the staged accident went wrong when blood splattered the kitchen walls and floor. After the murder, Lake went to Tesco to buy cleaning products, returning to scrub the house. But he left bloody footprints in the kitchen and his fingerprints on a Tesco bag full of cash.

Harrold was arrested after police searched Lake's flat and found two letters hidden behind the sink in which Lake said Harrold paid for the murder because he wanted a playboy lifestyle and that he would now kill Lake.

Harrold denied he had blackmailed Lake and said the supposed photo of Lake being raped did not exist.

Harrold had told the jury he met Diane Emerson-Hawley, a former nurse from Scunthorpe, in 1994, after she answered a lonely hearts ad he had placed in a local paper. They married in 1997.

Harrold admitted he had been seeing another woman behind Mrs Harrold's back, but told the jury his wife was his "soul mate".

Speaking after Lake had been sentenced, Chief Superintendent Chris Cook said Lincolnshire police would not be looking for anyone else in connection with the murder.

"As far as Harrold is concerned the jury has made its decision - as for Lake he is a cold-blooded killer," he said.

"As far as we are concerned this has been a success, a crime has been solved and Diane's killer has been convicted."

Outside the court, Harrold's lawyer, Robert Starr, said Harrold was going straight back to the Uffington house where Diane was killed. Mr Starr said: "He has had his living taken away from him for the last nine months and that has been very difficult, but now he is a very happy man."

Mr Starr said Harrold had turned down an offer of £35,000 from a national newspaper for his story.

Stephen Lowne, prosecuting, earlier told the court police intelligence led them to believe Harrold had taken out a contract on the heads of Darren Lake and John Bond, the former prisoner who testified that Harrold had confessed his role in the murder. Police had stepped up security around the court, with six armed officers with MP5 semi-automatic rifles and 9mm revolvers.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
No decision in Straw case

Police investigating a speeding incident involving the home secretary's official car denied reports that a decision had been taken not to prosecute Jack Straw's driver for allegedly travelling at 103mph on the M5 in Somerset this month because he was on official duty.

Bomber's father 'suicide risk'

The shotgun licence held by the father of the Soho nail-bomber David Copeland was withdrawn after his son's arrest because police feared he would kill himself, Winchester crown court heard yesterday. Police feared Stephen Copeland, 51, could be a danger to himself and the public because of the pressure. Mr Copeland, of Yateley, Hampshire, is appealing against the decision. He said the police claim was outrageous.

Pollution kills 36,000 fish

Environmental experts were yesterday trying to trace the source of pollution that killed 36,000 fish in the River Irwell near Rawtenstall, Lancashire.

Figures reveal scale of bugging

Police and customs officers were authorised to plant nearly 2,500 bugs, including 50 in hotel bedrooms, over the year to April, it was disclosed yesterday. The figure is given for the first time by a chief surveillance commissioner, appointed under the 1997 Police Act. More than 200 bugs were placed in private dwellings and 67 in offices, reports Sir Andrew Leggatt, a retired judge.

Move to cut food poisoning

Tough new targets to cut food poisoning cases by a fifth in five years were announced by the Food Standards Agency yesterday. They include action to reduce the risk of infection in small businesses, better training for people handling food, and campaigns to improve home hygiene.

They include action to reduce the risk of infection in small businesses, better training for people handling food, and campaigns to improve home hygiene.

webTitle: Prison officers face jail for assault

fields.headline: Prison officers face jail for assault
fields.trailText: Three Wormwood Scrubs prison officers were warned they faced jail yesterday after being convicted of a planned attack on an inmate.
fields.body:
Three Wormwood Scrubs prison officers were warned they faced jail yesterday after being convicted of a planned attack on an inmate.

For up to five minutes the officers subjected their victim to a barrage of kicks and punches on the floor of his cell. One stood on his face to prevent him escaping, Blackfriars crown court in London heard.

Finally, after being hauled to his feet bruised and bleeding, Timothy Donovan, a convicted murderer, was handcuffed and later spent 14 days in solitary confinement for allegedly assaulting one of his attackers.

All three officers, none of whom can be named for legal reasons, were convicted of one count of assault occasioning actual bodily harm in July 1998.

A fourth warder, who also pleaded not guilty to the charge, may face a retrial after the jury failed to reach a verdict in his case. He cannot be identified either.

Adjourning the case to September 4 for pre-sentence reports, judge Charles Byres said: "This type of case is extremely serious and is likely to result in a custodial sentence. The only thing that is exercising my mind is how long that should be," he said.

The month-long trial heard that Donovan, 33, from Liverpool, was serving a life sentence in the west London prison's E wing when he was subjected to a "concerted" attack.

Mark Hayward, prosecuting, said his problems began after a search was made for a missing fish slicer and snooker ball.

"It was a matter of concern that they find them," he said. When the officer who faces a retrial searched the prisoner's cell with the help of a colleague an extra mattress, some wood and a rug were confiscated because they were believed to contravene prison rules.

"[Donovan] was aggrieved that the rug had been removed because it had been in his cell for some time and it had come from his mother. He thought he was entitled to have it," Mr Hayward said. So, in a "fit of pique" he snatched it back and threw it over a balcony.

Fifteen minutes later the first officer returned to the cell with the rug under his arm as part of what the crown insisted was a plan to explain the violence that was to follow.

Donovan said "He was aggressive. He dropped the carpet and punched me on the nose with considerable force."

He added: "My nose was bleeding. He grabbed my head and pushed me down towards the floor." Donovan said he then became aware of other officers joining in the attack.

All four officers were arrested but denied any wrongdoing.

webTitle: Ministers urge ban on job gene tests

fields.headline: Ministers urge ban on job gene tests
fields.trailText: The government is proposing to prevent employers being given access to results of genetic tests on staff or potential recruits, according to a joint letter from the public health minister, Yvette Cooper, and the science minister, Lord Sainsbury.
fields.body:
The government is proposing to prevent employers being given access to results of genetic tests on staff or potential recruits, according to a joint letter from the public health minister, Yvette Cooper, and the science minister, Lord Sainsbury.

The letter puts the government's view on the issue to the human genetics commission, chaired by Lady Kennedy QC, which is reviewing the law on genetics testing in employment.

In their letter, Lord Sainsbury and Ms Cooper accept that the use of genetic testing is growing, particularly in health care.

But they suggest "that it would not be acceptable for employers to use the information arising from genetic tests to predict future poor health of potential or existing employees, or to exclude people from employment or advancement".

Department of Health sources said ministers would back a legal ban if they believed it was necessary. They accepted that the science of genetic testing was moving at breathtaking speed, and it was increasingly difficult for the law to keep pace.

However, Ms Cooper and Lord Sainsbury tell the commission that very specific "genetic tests might provide valuable information, if appropriately used, to detect a condition that may put the employee or others at risk in the workplace".

The implication - not explicitly stated in the letter - is that tests might be passed on if they showed a propensity to infectious or mental illnesses. It also suggests that evidence might be passed to employers if the tests indicated that someone was unsuitable to operate specific machinery.

But the ministers suggest that in even these circumstances the onus would legally remain on the employers to make sure the workplace was as safe as possible for the employee.

They recommend the health and safety commission to involve geneticists, employers and trade union representatives in monitoring developments in genetic screening as they apply to health and safety at work.

The ministers say the data protection commissioner should develop a code of practice on the use of personal data in relations between employers and employees. The code is likely to be published in the autumn.

The human genetics commission is also examining guidelines to prevent the use of genetic testing in insurance. Some insurers are keen to extend its use to increase premiums for individuals prone to disease.

The government is likely to support a ban on job applicants being required to take genetic tests, believing that an individual's right not to know his or her genetic constitution should be upheld.

Only in very specific circumstance should an employer be permitted to refuse a job: where public safety issues arise and the individual refuses to take a test.

However, the two ministers, drawing on work from the disability rights task force, recommend that at present genetic predispositions to impairments should not be classified as a disability under the Disability Discrimination Act.

Overall they argue: "The government wishes to ensure that, once genetic testing has advanced to the stage where the use of test results by employers becomes a realistic proposition, it has in place proper safeguards to prevent such information being used unfairly."

webTitle: The general, the diva and the soul star

fields.headline: The general, the diva and the soul star
fields.trailText: General Sir Charles Guthrie, Britain's top military officer and a former SAS soldier, will tomorrow reveal a sentimental side to his nature by choosing Stevie Wonder and Maria Callas as his desert island companions.
fields.body:
General Sir Charles Guthrie, Britain's top military officer and a former SAS soldier, will tomorrow reveal a sentimental side to his nature by choosing Stevie Wonder and Maria Callas as his desert island companions.

He would take Wonder's I Just Called to Say I Love You to remind him of the days when he was allowed only two minutes a week to speak to his fiancee, Catherine, he told the presenter of the BBC's Desert Island Discs, Sue Lawley.

His company radio officer would listen in, but that did not stop him from proposing to his future wife when on duty at his Belfast command post, he said.

Callas singing Puccini's Tosca brought back memories of the late 1960s, when the future chief of defence staff spent a season at the Royal Opera House as an extra. Many walk-on parts were played by guardsmen based at Chelsea barracks.

"The highlight of my opera career was appearing in the royal command performance with Maria Callas," said Sir Charles. "I'll never forget the first time that Callas came off _ She had given everything _ She used to collapse on a sofa in the wings and be flapped with a towel, rather like a boxer. I remember a soldier who was going on rather nervously with me said: 'I hope you're not going to be like that when you come off'."

Sir Charles, 61 and retiring next year, avoided marching music and sidestepped a question on reports that he had killed with his bare hands. He described his period in the SAS as a happy one.

However, he was clearly less than happy about the spate of books written by former SAS soldiers, prompted in part by revelations by General Sir Peter de la Billiere, commander of British troops in the Gulf war.

Some had written for money, others for their egos, Sir Charles said, "but very few people do it... because they think they're improving the history of the British army".

Opposition in military circles to books by former special forces soldiers prompted a furious attack by David Lyon, colonel commandant of the SAS, on the decision by Dame Stella Rimington, former head of MI5, to write her memoirs. "All members of the security forces should keep silent about their work, for life," he said in a letter to the Times in May. "When there is a requirement to publish, it is the government alone who should do so."

Sir Charles admitted that the army had a funding problem: "I'm not saying that I wouldn't want more, and I'm not saying that I didn't say that to the chancellor."

 Desert Island Discs, BBC Radio 4, July 30, 11.15am .

fields.headline: Coastline rescued from man-made horror
fields.standfirst: Nature returns to Co Durham's 'Get Carter' lunar landscape
fields.trailText: Nature returns to Co Durham's 'Get Carter' lunar landscape
fields.body:
On the limestone cliffs high above the rocky shoreline a rare butterfly flutters in the July sunshine.

Skylarks swoop overhead while a variety of seabirds - purple sandpipers, little terns, oystercatchers - wheel above a reclaimed beach or waddle on the sand.

Walking along a newly-created cliff-top footpath, weaving between high grasses and a profusion of harebells, speedwell, sea sandwort and other wild flowers, John Goodfellow swore that the landscape could easily match Dorset, Cornwall or nearby North Yorkshire.

"Would you believe that, until very recently, everyone turned their back on this area," he said. "It just wasn't a nice place to be."

Five years ago, only the brave and foolhardy ventured onto the badly-scarred cliffs and the blackened beaches of County Durham. After 100 years of mining it had the most heavily polluted coastline in Britain, and probably western Europe.

A series of huge overhead mechanical conveyors had dumped at least 100m tonnes of colliery waste onto the cliffs and into the sea. Scores of pipelines pumped black liquid across once sandy beaches. Parents warned children to keep away.

The lunar coastline was the backdrop to the final grim scene in the 1960s film Get Carter, as Michael Caine struggled with a mobster on the conveyors preparing to tip waste high above the North Sea.

The film graphically illustrated the man-made horror below: years of indiscriminate tipping meant that the Durham coastline had the distinction of being the only part of Britain that had extended into the sea - by about 100 yards in 50 years, according to Ordnance Survey maps.

When the last of the six big coastal collieries at Easington closed in 1993 local councils faced a choice: write off the coastline or attempt to bring it back to life.

As the collieries were demolished the councils opted for a massive reclamation scheme in the hope of restoring the area to its former glory. A partnership with national agencies and conservation groups was launched, boldly titled Turning the Tide.

With funding from the Millennium Commission and other sources running to £10m, the four-year scheme is due to be completed next spring, and has exceeded the wildest expectations of a small project team. John Goodfellow, one of its senior officers, lists a string of achievements, not least the return of the Durham Argus butterfly (brown, with orange-spotted wings), which has been attracted by rock roses on the reclaimed magnesian limestone cliffs, along with many varieties of wild flowers. Partly as a result, the coast has become a national nature reserve.

It has been a monumental task.

For a start, 1.3m tonnes of waste, sometimes 30 feet deep, has been removed, although some slag has been retained because it is considered necessary to stabilise the cliffs. Footpaths, including a spectacular 12 mile coastal route, and cycle ways have been created, and a string of sculptures erected. More public art is planned.

To improve access and encourage flora and wildlife, around 500 acres of farmland has been bought from local farmers and converted to limestone grassland.

"On a summer weekend, you can't move for people on the beach," said David Smith, a former miner, as he walked his dog towards Easington sea front.

"It's now clean and lovely - but you've got to watch, because the tide now comes in further with all the muck gone."

Ambling along the coastal path with her daughter Amy, Tracy Kirkup, whose father was a miner, vividly recalled the "horrible beaches" of her childhood.

"You'd go onto them and come back all black. I grew up with it, and it was awful.

"I remember that at school our old head teacher once showed us some photographs of sandy beaches and we couldn't believe it. Now it's getting to be lovely once again."

At Seaham, the northern point of the path, Alan Willis licked an ice cream on his mountain bike, and recalled how most people boycotted the beaches during his youth. "You turned your back on them and went somewhere else. Now they've been cleaned up, you can clearly see rocks through the water. Before it was all black."

Now that millions are being spent improving hotels in the area, some brave souls are even predicting the emergence of a holiday trade.

"Maybe that's going a bit far," said Tracy Kirkup. "It's still nice to go abroad. It can be cold and wet here."

webTitle: Kurds fear Saddam is poised to strike

fields.headline: Kurds fear Saddam is poised to strike
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The leader of one of the two main Kurdish factions controlling northern Iraq has warned that Saddam Hussein could make another military move against the region in the next few months.
fields.body:
The leader of one of the two main Kurdish factions controlling northern Iraq has warned that Saddam Hussein could make another military move against the region in the next few months.

Jalal Talabani, the leader of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK), was at pains to play down the extent of the threat, but he admitted privately that nothing could be ruled out.

Reports of an Iraqi military build-up on the borders of the Kurdish enclave have circulated for several weeks, since an Iraqi defector revealed plans for a military operation to recapture the city of Sulaymaniyah, which serves as Mr Talabani's headquarters.

The operation - called Fair Retribution - would also involve the seizure of two dams which supply water to central Iraq, where a severe drought is well into its second year.

Northern Iraq has been ruled by two rival Kurdish factions since shortly after the end of the Gulf war in 1991, but Baghdad wants to bring the region back under its control. Mr Talabani said that up to 50,000 Iraqi troops were stationed close to the Kurdish enclave, and three army corps, backed up by units of the republican guard, were facing the area administered by the PUK.

Iraq's leaked military plans involve three infantry divisions, accompanied by hundreds of tanks, moving swiftly to surround Sulaymaniyah.

Turkish officials believe the reports are exaggerated, and western diplomats argue that the proposed military operation described in Fair Retribution is more of a contingency plan than a blueprint for definite action.

"We've seen no mass movement of troops or heavy military equipment towards the north," one official said. If there was a sudden burst of military activity, western spy satellites would quickly spot it.

But there is an element of uncertainty, based on the unpredictability of President Saddam. The west has misjudged his intentions spectacularly in the past, not least 10 years ago this week, when Iraq launched its invasion of Kuwait.

American and British aircraft still patrol the skies over northern Iraq. But the no-fly zone which the allies have declared over the north extends only as far as the 36th parallel. Sulaymaniyah is below that line, and therefore more vulnerable to attack.

The US has promised to respond to any Iraqi attack on the Kurds "in a manner and at a time of our own choosing". That may not translate as the immediate military response the Kurds seem to expect.

The last time President Saddam intervened in northern Iraq was in August 1996, at the start of the US presidential election campaign, and there is a fear that he may try to test American will againwhen he believes the coming election will be a massive distraction.

Some analysts argue that the Iraqi government would be reluctant to take military action when its campaign to have UN sanctions eased is gradually gaining international sympathy. But there is an alternative theory: that President Saddam knows that the US will never allow sanctions to be lifted, and he may feel he has little to lose by again throwing down a challenge to the west.

webTitle: Snail mail - postcard is delivered after 40 years

fields.headline: Snail mail - postcard is delivered after 40 years
fields.trailText: Patrick Renshaw had his whole academic future before him when his Oxford college sent an urgent postcard to his digs half a mile away.
fields.body:
Patrick Renshaw had his whole academic future before him when his Oxford college sent an urgent postcard to his digs half a mile away.

Yesterday, four years after he retired as a senior don with an international reputation, he heard that the card had finally arrived. It came 40 years late, unstamped, with an excess postage demand for four pre-decimal pennies (just over 1p).

Postmarked May 11, 1960, the card asked him to fill in a form sent at the beginning of term "and return it as soon as possible".

Mr Renshaw, until recently reader in American politics at Sheffield University, was, at the time the card was sent, a postgraduate scholar at Queen's College, Oxford, who was applying for scholarships to study in the US.

The Royal Mail persisted in its attempts to find him. A second postmark on the card shows that it was recently sent to the Sheffield sorting office, which failed to trace his local address.

So earlier this week, the Sheffield office sent it to Mr Renshaw's old digs in Oxford. Its arrival amazed John Crabtree, the don who lives there now. Told yesterday by the Guardian where Mr Renshaw currently lives, Mr Crabtree said he would forward it to him.

A Royal Mail spokeswoman said: "We occasionally get mishaps like this."

webTitle: EC threatens to take Britain to court over dirty beaches

fields.headline: EC threatens to take Britain to court over dirty beaches
fields.trailText: Brussels cast a long cloud over carefree summer holidays yesterday when it said it would take Britain to court for failing to clean up some of the country's most popular beaches.
fields.body:
Brussels cast a long cloud over carefree summer holidays yesterday when it said it would take Britain to court for failing to clean up some of the country's most popular beaches.

As thousands packed buckets and spades for possibly rather cloudy seaside breaks, the European commission told the government to ensure that 46 of 541 British beaches complied with minimum pollution standards.

Sweden was informed that it too would have to answer to the European court of justice in Luxembourg, where fines can be imposed. Spain got off with a warning.

According to an EU report issued in May, three out of four Blackpool beaches and both in neighbouring St Anne's remain below par for testing under the EU's bathing water quality directive.

Britain had already received an official warning from Brussels about sub-standard beaches, including Exmouth, Instow and Westward Ho, Bembridge, Southsea, Cleethorpes, Southport and South Shields.

Margot Wallstrom, the environment commissioner, said: "As the commission has indicated on numerous occasions, we are serious about ensuring bathing water quality compliance in all member states."

The Conservative's environment spokesman, Damian Green, said: "John Prescott has been fingered as the dirty man of Europe. Labour must take responsibility for not acting to clean up Britain."

Britain in Europe, the pro-EU campaigning group, said: "Europe is right to take action to clean up beaches in Britain. British beachgoers should be able to enjoy clean beaches wherever they go in Europe and will be delighted that high European standards are being enforced here."

Under the directive, the 15 member states have to ensure that water at designated coastal and inland bathing areas is safe to swim in.

The directive aims to ensure that bathing waters meet minimum quality criteria by establishing a set of binding standards for a range of key parameters, including the presence of faecal bacteria in sea water.

But a spokeswoman for the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions said: "The commission's decision is disappointing. The government believes that the commission has not given full consideration to the considerable steps being taken to improve bathing water quality."

The number of beaches that failed the EU's cleanliness test last year was down to 46, from 56 in 1998.

webTitle: Comment: Jeremy Hardy on the crisis in the health service

fields.headline: Bedpan humour
fields.standfirst:
The health service is in crisis - so the government gives lots of help to the private sector

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The health service is in crisis - so the government gives lots of help to the private sector
fields.body:
Today might be our last chance to save the pound, that beloved currency which has done so much to promote monarchs and beards as symbols of our national life. For today is a national day of protest against the inhumanity of a new currency circulating in this country: the asylum voucher.

The French multinational Sodexho has been busily converting our pounds into vouchers. It is also one of the companies converting our health service into a major provider of public money to the private sector, although under that scheme, the private finance initiative, they just take the pounds and don't have to exchange them for vouchers.

But one shouldn't assume that asylum vouchers are simply a way of throwing money into the private purse. One could be forgiven for making that mistake, since so much of government spending seems to go that way. For example, what is the working families tax credit other than an incentive for employers to pay poverty wages? And why is the government helping the private health sector out? When the health service was founded, the state confiscated private assets in order to provide a service on the basis of need. But the independent sector has grown and grown, assisted by charitable status, tax relief on medical insurance, a supply of trained staff and an under-resourced NHS.

Now the private sector is faced with massive over-capacity because of a crippling disadvantage: it is driven entirely by greed. Greed is a terrible problem if you are in the business of helping the sick, many of whom are bloody useless when it comes to shelling out the readies for carpeted wards and wine lists. Try as they might to tout for custom, private hospitals just can't seem to get bums on bedpans. Enticing menus of treatments, promising drips that are salty but unpretentious and breasts that are beautifully re-upholstered, are not enough to pull in the crowds. Moreover, medical insurers set their sights rather low, being under-confident about selling cover to anyone who might conceivably become ill. Again, these business people don't seem to know their own market.

But our government, keen to help businesses large and small, has decided to tempt the private sector to moonlight in the health service. Of course, this will in some ways be a bitter pill to swallow. Common people with cheap pyjamas, ordering lager and wanting operations that are necessary, will soon be burdening private hospitals. But this will in no way undermine the lack of values upon which the private sector was built. These will remain private hospitals even though they treat NHS patients. No principles will be sacrificed in the independent health sector because there aren't any.

There are a variety of corporate welfare schemes in operation. All are dressed up as partnership, the private sector being the abusive partner whom the government can't leave. "You don't know capitalism like I do," the state protests, "it's not like that when it's with me." But it would be wrong to see the asylum voucher purely as a scam to give our money to Sodexho. British supermarkets will also benefit. In the words of Sodexho, "Don't miss this revenue-making opportunity. Vouchers will be the only method of buying essential living products. No change given, but you receive the full value of the voucher." Perhaps the government will be given a reward card. But the primary motive for this costly scheme is not simply to subsidise corporate profit. It is to victimise refugees.

There are other ways in which the government lines private pockets with the asylum budget. Local authorities pay enormous housing benefit to landlords, especially as the remaining stock of social housing is being disposed of. Kentish seaside towns might protest that, because of refugees, Victorian bathers can't get a room, or that private landlords who have waited years for the council to install one-parent families now see their vacancies filled with the displaced and tortured. But there is nothing sinister in government housing policy other than a callous indifference and cowardice in the face of landlordism.

No, the asylum vouchers, like the dispersal scheme, involve something else. Britain will become a much more miserable place for those who seek shelter here. It will not only be harder for refugees to cope, more humiliating and disorienting, it is also a signal to the rest of us. The refugees will be the foreign-looking ones holding up the queue, getting free stuff. Scattered all over the UK, they are cut off from mutual support and more easily noticed and targeted. They are being attacked. The message will go back that Britain is a heartless and dangerous place. People such as the Roma of eastern Europe, who now see this as a multicultural place where it is not a crime to be dark-skinned, will learn differently. But, as Tony Blair might say, tough.

Anyway, I shan't keep you. You must get down to Tesco to protest. See you there.

fields.headline: Police ignore freemason survey
fields.trailText: Police officers may be required to reveal whether they are freemasons after almost two-thirds refused to cooperate with an official study of membership of the secretive society, the government announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Police officers may be required to reveal whether they are freemasons after almost two-thirds refused to cooperate with an official study of membership of the secretive society, the government announced yesterday.

Ministers had hoped that a request for voluntary declaration of membership would allay public anxiety about the existence of masonic networks in the criminal justice system. But the proportion of officers in England and Wales responding to the survey amounted to only 36%, compared with 96% of judges and 87% of magistrates.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, said that he would consult police representatives to see how to obtain a "satisfactory" response from officers.

Responding to a critical home affairs select committee report published yesterday, Mr Straw said that the judiciary and magistrates had demonstrated that registration could be adequately achieved "on a voluntary basis and without legislation".

"However, this has not so far been the case in police forces," said Mr Straw's statement, "and the Home Office will therefore be consulting the police service about how to achieve a satisfactory response rate, whether through changing the way in which voluntary registration is conducted, or through legislating to require registration."

Mr Straw acknowledged the committee's conclusion that there was "a widespread public perception" that freemasonry could have an unhealthy influence on the courts.

"The government is committed to ensuring public confidence in their police service," he said.

"It is important that the police service now work with us to develop arrangements which will deliver this confidence."

The Home Office said that among judges, 5% declared they were masons; 89% declared non-membership; and 1% declined to say. Among magistrates, 5% declared as masons, 80% non-masons, and 2% refused to say.

The voluntary system was operated by 32 of the 43 police forces in England and Wales. Of the 36% of police and civil ian support staff who did respond, 1% declared as masons; 89% declared non-membership; and 9% refused to say.

Sussex chief constable Paul Whitehouse, spokesman of the Association of Chief Police Officers, said that the association welcomed further consultation with the government on the issue of registration of freemasonry.

John Hamill, director of communications at the United Grand Lodge of England, said that freemasons would oppose any move to force police officers to declare membership. "We see that as singling out freemasons for discrimination based on a false perception," he said.

The consultation will seek responses by the end of December.

fields.headline: Venezuelans muster to re-elect Chavez
fields.trailText: Venezuela's charismatic leader, President Hugo Chavez, is expected to be re-elected tomorrow in the county's sixth election in the past 18 months - despite flagging military support for him that threatens to destabilise the country's "peaceful revolution".
fields.body:
Venezuela's charismatic leader, President Hugo Chavez, is expected to be re-elected tomorrow in the county's sixth election in the past 18 months - despite flagging military support for him that threatens to destabilise the country's "peaceful revolution".

Since he came to power in February last year, Mr Chavez has overhauled Venezuelan politics by tearing down virtually every institution and rebuilding them to his liking.

Tomorrow's election seems certain to hand the former army paratrooper six more years in charge - he leads his challenger by 20% in the opinion polls.

But despite the almost religious devotion he inspires among the 80% of Venezuelans who live below the poverty line, Mr Chavez's transformation of the political landscape has failed to improve their livelihoods.

The ranks of the country's unemployed grew by 500,000 in 1999, its economy declined by 7% and foreign investors withdrew more than £5bn from the oil-rich country.

Mr Chavez, 46, who was jailed in 1992 after launching a botched coup attempt, claims that tomorrow's election will be the final piece in the political jigsaw that will allow him to plough ahead with his left-leaning social reforms.

"After the elections, the political confrontation will be left behind," he vowed during his final campaign rally this week. "We will devote our hearts to the social and economic recovery of Venezuela."

While many people in Latin America see in Mr Chavez a nationalist saviour along the lines of the independence hero, Simon Bolivar, there are those to whom he reawakens memories of another icon of the continent's political heritage, the military caudillo (strongman).

As was perhaps inevitable from a career soldier, Mr Chavez has increased the role of the military by appointing officers to important civilian positions, giving service personnel the right to vote, increasing spending on arms and mobilising thousands of troops for non-military duties, such as painting schools, repairing hospitals and running food markets.

But instead of forging a powerful ally, insiders say, he has upset many within the armed forces by meddling in their affairs.

Concern with the Chavez administration is not restricted to the military; the president's challenger, Francisco Arias Cardenas, once a colleague in the 1992 coup attempt, broke away from Mr Chavez this year, accusing him of betraying the goals of the rebellion.

Mr Cardenas and other opposition candidates have been trying to capitalise on the acute economic slump that has hounded Mr Chavez's reign, despite a surge in the international price of oil, Venezuela's main export.

Mr Chavez blames the downturn on decades of corruption in the previous governments, but international analysts are sceptical about his ability to pull the economy out of crisis.

webTitle: Big Corsican vote likely for autonomy plan

fields.headline: Big Corsican vote likely for autonomy plan
fields.trailText: The Corsican assembly was yesterday expected to approve by a large majority revolutionary proposals by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, to give the turbulent Mediterranean island limited powers to run its own affairs for the first time since the 18th century.
fields.body:
The Corsican assembly was yesterday expected to approve by a large majority revolutionary proposals by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, to give the turbulent Mediterranean island limited powers to run its own affairs for the first time since the 18th century.

Denounced by the opposition and some members of Mr Jospin's cabinet, including the radical republican interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, who could resign over the issue, the plan marks a huge departure from France's cherished notion of national integrity and has sparked fears that other regions like Brittany, Alsace, the Basque country and Languedoc may demand similar treatment.

Corsican leaders agree. "I believe France is beginning a major decentralising reform on the threshold of the 21st century," said the president of the Corsican assembly, José Rossi. "Constitutional reform is no longer a dream." Specific conditions would be taken into account, he said. "France will no longer be administered in exactly the same way from Dunkirk to Bonifacio".

The scheme, put forward after six months of talks, aims to end more than 20 years of almost daily separatist bombings, machine-gun attacks and other violence on the island. It foresees Paris temporarily transferring the administration of issues like regional development, culture, education and infrastructure to the assembly, which would also have the power to modify laws passed in Paris.

Satisfying a key demand of the nationalists, the plan also requires the Corsican language to be taught in all primary and junior schools "within normal school hours".

If the package proves successful - and Mr Jospin has said any further reform will hinge on law and order being restored - a future French government will revise the constitution in 2003 or 2004, introducing proportional representation and creating a single political and administrative body for Corsica with formal, though limited, law-making powers.

The possibility of constitutional reform has sparked outrage among the Gaullist opposition, champions of the unity of the 200-year-old republic.

"It is essential to recall that the republic is indivisible. There should be no question of transgressing this principle," Michèle Alliot-Marie, president of the RPR party, said.

Mr Chevènement's MDC party, a member of the governing socialist-led coalition, is also bitterly opposed. The minister, who has resigned twice before from cabinet posts on questions of principle, has let it be known that he will refuse to present the bill as it stands to the national assembly for ratification later this year.

His close adviser, Georges Sarre, said yesterday: "A Pandora's box has been opened that will lead inevitably to the dislocation of the republican state and the full independence of Corsica."

In the regions, the plan has been welcomed by many activists who have long campaigned for greater autonomy - along the lines of that now enjoyed by Scotland, Wales or the German states - from the traditionally monolithic government of Paris.

"This is a big step forward," Jean-Yves Cozan, a leading figure in the Breton devolution movement, said.

"I'm not saying we would want exactly the same regime, but it is at least a first recognition that parts of France that are different must be governed differently."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.body:
UN forces move in to Lebanon

UN peacekeepers took up positions on the Lebanese-Israeli border yesterday to extend their authority over the area occupied by Israel until two months ago.

Lebanon, still disputing that Israel has fully withdrawn, played down the significance of the move.

The UN interim force in Lebanon went to the areas of Yaroun and Manara in the central sector of the former occupation zone.

Kremlin talks to Chechen leader

President Vladimir Putin's new envoy to the Caucasus, Viktor Kazantsev, revealed yesterday that negotiations were under way with the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, and a rebel commander - the first official confirmation that the Kremlin has abandoned its refusal to talk with rebels.

Until now the Kremlin has publicly insisted that Mr Maskhadov would have to guarantee an end to all hostilities before any kind of talks could begin.

Katyn massacre remembered

Russian and Polish officials gathered at Katyn, the scene of one of the Soviet Union's most brutal massacres yesterday, to dedicate a memorial to more than 4,000 Polish army officers murdered there by Stalin's secret police.

The officers were shot and dumped in mass graves in April and May 1940 - an act the communist authorities denied for decades.

Farm incest pair charged

A brother and sister suspected of killing their children appeared in court to be charged with incest, as South African police searched for seven missing children on a farm 60 miles east of Johannesburg.

Heibrecht and Robert Fedder, 32 and 40, were remanded in custody. Their parents were ordered to be detained for aiding and abetting incest.

Mugabe faces national strike

A three-day national strike to protest against President Robert Mugabe's government is expected to close down Zimbabwe next week.

The Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions voted yesterday to call the strike. Other industrial and commercial workers are expected to join in.

Seven die in heatwave

A heatwave sweeping south-eastern Europe has triggered forest fires in Greece and Bulgaria and caused the deaths of at least seven people in Romania during the past three days, officials said yesterday.

fields.headline: Wrong stop for bus thief
fields.trailText: A harried Brazilian thief could not have picked a worse place to get off a Rio de Janeiro bus after robbing its passengers at gunpoint.
fields.body:
A harried Brazilian thief could not have picked a worse place to get off a Rio de Janeiro bus after robbing its passengers at gunpoint.

After snatching more than $800 (£530), Jose Roberto Rocha jumped off the bus - right in front of 410 police gathered for an official ceremony with Rio's governor.

The commanding general of the military police himself abandoned the podium to pursue him. Dozens of officers chased and captured the thief after a gun battle and an attempt to hijack another bus.

"It was certainly bad luck," a police spokesman said. The city is notorious for its soaring crime rates, with robbers often preying on bus passengers.

fields.headline: Germans split on language reform
fields.trailText: Germans faced a new threat to their unity yesterday after two of the country's most prestigious institutions signalled that they had given up on the latest rules imposed on the German language.
fields.body:
Germans faced a new threat to their unity yesterday after two of the country's most prestigious institutions signalled that they had given up on the latest rules imposed on the German language.

Four years ago the culture ministers of Germany's 16 regional administrations agreed to the most radical overhaul of German since 1901. The reforms, which were gradually adopted, brought in thousands of changes including many new spellings.

But the new German has remained intensely controversial, and this week the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, the weightiest of the country's heavyweight newspapers, decided that the time had come to say genug - enough.

"For a year, since August 1 1999, we have done everything in our power to stick to the official new rules. But it has not worked," the conservative daily said.

The paper's stand - taken in a front-page article given precedence over news of the Concorde disaster - isolated it from the rest of the German press. But it won support from the authoritative German Academy of Language and Poetry, which issued a statement agreeing that it was time for a rethink.

"We earnestly request that this text should be reproduced in the style in which it is drafted," said the statement, written in pre-reform German. The tabloid Bild Zeitung yesterday quoted rightwing politicians adding their voices to the chorus of dissent.

The spelling reform is a political issue: it was intended to simplify the language and save less educated people from making mistakes that show up their class origins.

It brought order into the chaos surrounding the use of "ss" rather than the uniquely German letter ß. But it also introduced practices which have not caught on, such as the space changing "aufwiedersehen" into "auf wiedersehen".

The new rules are taught in all German schools, so if the revolt gathers momentum school-leavers could find that the language used in the workplace differs from what they were taught in the classroom. There is also a risk that German regions could go in different directions - petitions have already been started in three of the 16 regions to ask for a referendum on the issue.

But the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung claims that German is already split."Of all the many dictionaries written since the reform, not one is identical to another," it said.

The paper continued in apocalyptic tones: "Gripped by uncertainty about what is right and what is wrong, people have begun avoiding terms and phrases that might conceivably be subject to the new spelling rules. A new language, a language of avoidance, has been created and it is not a pretty one."

webTitle: Far-right link sought after bomb blast

fields.headline: Far-right link sought after bomb blast
fields.trailText: Suspicions grew yesterday that rightwing extremists had planted the bomb which maimed and terrorised travellers outside a Düsseldorf railway station on Thursday.
fields.body:
Suspicions grew yesterday that rightwing extremists had planted the bomb which maimed and terrorised travellers outside a Düsseldorf railway station on Thursday.

It emerged that all nine casualties were immigrants, six of whom were Jews; the other three victims were related by marriage to the six.

Germany's interior minister, Otto Schily, said it was reasonable to suspect that the attack was a racist one. "One can suspect that it could have such a background," he said.

The bombing will cause deep concern within the German government - only last month ministers received a warning from the security services that the far right was developing "terrorist" structures.

The attack will also spread dismay among the tens of thousands of Jews who hope to enter Germany under a scheme which accords them preferential treatment over other immigrants. In recent years, some 60,000 Jews have flocked to Germany from eastern Europe and Russia, lured by special entry permits and resettlement facilities.

The victims came from Russia, Ukraine and Azerbaijan. They had just left a daily German-language class paid for by the government and were on their way to catch a train to the nearby town of Solingen when they were caught by the blast. The bomb, packed with shrapnel, had been placed on a footbridge leading to the station.

A spokesman for the prosecutor's office in Düsseldorf said: "We can't rule out any motive, including an anti-foreigner motive."

Police experts were yesterday trying to reconstruct the explosive device to establish whether it was detonated remotely or by means of a timer. This is crucial to gauge whether the victims were the intended targets: a timed explosion would be less discriminate than a remotely detonated one.

"We can't rule out that someone placed this bomb to hit this group or one member of it - or it could be simple coincidence," the prosecutor's spokesman said.

A reward of DM10,000 (£3,150) has been offered for information leading to the arrest of the bombers.

A 26-year-old woman lost her unborn child when shrapnel tore into her belly. She was five months pregnant. However, doctors at the Düsseldorf's university hospital managed to reattach her leg, which was almost severed by the explosion.

The woman's husband, a 28-year-old economist, was the most seriously injured of the victims. He received wounds to the abdomen and was last night still on the critical list.

Michael Szentei-Heife, the director of the Jewish community in Düsseldorf, said the couple had arrived in Germany last November from Simferopol in central Ukraine. The other victims - five women and two men - suffered shrapnel wounds.

Jewish leaders were careful, however, not to predict the outcome of police inquiries.

"We are horrified by this attack on innocent people," said Paul Spiegel, the head of Germany's Jewish community. But he said he did not want to comment further until more was known about the reasons for the bombing.

Mr Szentei-Heife said it would be difficult to show that anti-semitism, rather than xenophobia, lay behind the maiming of the victims. "The fact that six out of nine are Jewish puts that into your mind. But, on the other hand, they were not recognisable as Jews," he said.

Large numbers of eastern Europeans have arrived in Germany since the collapse of communism. But the hostility towards them has been most pronounced in the formerly communist east of the country, where unemployment is high and the presence of cheap labour is deeply resented.

Düsseldorf, by contrast, is one of the most prosperous cities in the west.

"We are shocked that this could occur in Düsseldorf, a place where these things so far have seemed impossible," Mr Szentei-Heife said. "We are not in the east, the south or the north, where xenophobia is stronger than in the Rhineland, so the shock is that much greater."

webTitle: Newspapers still a recruiter's best bet

fields.headline: Newspapers still a recruiter's best bet
fields.standfirst: Online recruitment is in the news, but despite its speed and economy, newspapers remain a far more user-friendly option, writes Jerry Wright
fields.trailText: Online recruitment is in the news, but despite its speed and economy, newspapers remain a far more user-friendly option, writes Jerry Wright
fields.body:
Recruitment over the web is here to stay - it's official. The rush to develop web-based services has had a significant impact on the recruitment industry, and both established agencies and their new-entrant rivals are claiming to offer a broader choice of opportunities. Not surprisingly, it is among IT staff, both permanent and contract, where acceptance of this new method is greatest.

In the upper echelons of the executive recruitment market, the internet is unlikely to revolutionise current practices, at least for the foreseeable future.

Putting the current market into context, a recent report by market analysts Forrester confirmed that, while online advertising more than doubled from 1998 to 1999, at £54m, it still represents less than 0.5% of the total UK advertising spend.

Time, access, confidentiality and established practices all continue to guide senior managers towards the traditional method - advertising in the printed press.

The evidence of this is already there, with many internet start-ups and ebusiness companies abandoning their own medium and advertising for chief executive officers, chief financial officers and chief technical officers in the quality national press.

The reasons are many. Few senior executives have internet access outside the office, and a lack of inclination to visit online job sites in the office, for obvious reasons, means that the majority of executives still favour newspapers when seeking new career opportunities.

Browsing through the appointments section of the newspaper is also about as user-friendly as you can get - completely portable, no power supply needed, and easy to access over breakfast, on the train, or in bed on a Sunday morning.

Then there is the key difference between push and pull recruitment. Surfing the net for job sites is a conscious decision, requiring a candidate to deliberately visit a site. A casual browsing of a newspaper displays a selection of jobs, pushing the information to a passive reader.

So it is far more likely that a recruitment advertisement in the press will attract "inactive" job changers and, as many recruiters will tell you, casual browsers make the best candidates because they are satisfied by their current role and company, and are well motivated.

This last year has seen a major increase in the activities of web-based recruitment companies, such as Futurestep and StepStone, offering senior executives the chance to register online and enter a gateway to a range of new opportunities. But registration can be time-consuming and it is questionable whether senior executives have the time or the desire to spend up to two hours going through the registration process.

Finally, there are the concerns about data security and the final destination of your personal details. Recent press reports about cyber-bandits lifting CVs from rival recruitment companies' sites and other cowboy practices does nothing to inspire confidence, and official acknowledgement that a problem exists was shown recently in a DTI announcement about stricter legislation.

Despite this, the attractions of web-based recruitment for an employer is obvious. When under pressure to fill a key appointment, the speed of the internet is highly attractive. An advertisement can be online very quickly, whereas a press advertisement in a quality national newspaper may have to be prepared a week or more in advance.

But there is a catch with online advertising - respondents can come from all over the world. One of Prism Executive Recruitment's recent online advertisements for a position in West London attracted applicants from the Philippines and Peru.

There are also problems with the skills level and experience of online applicants; unlike newspapers and trade magazines, which tend to have a well-defined readership, the internet is not restricted to any specific target audience.

For those recruiters with a modest budget, the internet appeals as a relatively inexpensive advertising medium. But focusing on web recruitment alone may be tipping that balance too far.

The answer, of course, is to mix and match. The web and the newspaper are not mutually exclusive and, as we enter a transitional phase in the history of recruitment advertising, forward-thinking recruiters will be advertising both online and offline.

It has taken two to three years for senior executives in the UK to catch up with their counterparts in the US in terms of responding to advertisements by email; it is likely that it will take at least the same amount of time for usage of recruitment via the internet to catch on.

Online recruitment may well make the front pages, but it is still the back pages and supplements that candidates go to for their job search.

 Jerry Wright is MD of Prism Executive Recruitment

fields.headline: Working week
fields.standfirst: There's no place like home for 7% of workforce
fields.trailText: There's no place like home for 7% of workforce
fields.body:
Around a quarter of a million people last year shunted the vagaries of daily commuting to work from home. This is one of the key findings from the Institute for Employment Studies'(IES) analysis of the latest Labour Force Survey. In spring 1999, approximately 1.2m people worked from home in the UK for at least one day per week, using a computer and a telephone link to their employer or client. One year later, this had increased to 1.5m, an increase of 19% and representing 5.5% of the British workforce. The definition used here covers only people who are dependent on a computer and telecommunications link to work from home. Using a broader definition, those who use the technology but could work from home without it, brings the total up to more than 1.8m, or 7% of the UK workforce.

The IES study also discovered that more than a quarter of all teleworkers (27%) work in the business and financial services sector with another 25% in the public and voluntary sectors.

Most teleworkers are in senior jobs - 28% are managers, 22% are professionals and 18% are in associate professional or technical occupations.

www.employment-studies.co.uk

 The revelations that emerged from an analysis of calls made to the TUC's "root out racism" telephone hotline will come as no surprise to a majority of black and Asian workers. The service, an initiative by the TUC's Stephen Lawrence Taskforce Group, ran for five days and received around 450 calls exposing widespread discrimination and racist abuse leading to many minority ethnic workers having to take time off suffering from stress, depression and anxiety. Alarmingly one in five calls was made by abused professionals where the employing organisations are committed to equal opportunities.

 Don't put your daughter on the stage Mrs Worthington, but do put her in overalls and ask her to be an engineer. The shortage of professional engineers is being reflected in the sharp rise in their salaries. According to The Engineering Council average salaries for incorporated engineers rose by 11% in the last year to £36,000, with chartered engineers drawing around £44,803 on average.

 The Maternity Alliance has updated its guide to negotiating flexible working patterns for women returning to work after childbirth. Child-friendly Working Hours - Your Rights is £2; for a copy, tel: 020-7588-8583.
