webTitle: The view from the top, with John Elkington chairman of strategy consultants Sustain Ability

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Successful communication is not just a matter of what is said but also of who says it. Consider: in 1978, I wrote a report for the Hudson Institute predicting that ozone depletion and global warming would be two of the biggest issues of the 90s.
fields.body:
Successful communication is not just a matter of what is said but also of who says it. Consider: in 1978, I wrote a report for the Hudson Institute predicting that ozone depletion and global warming would be two of the biggest issues of the 90s.

More recently, we have been among the voices warning major corporations that climate change is emerging as a major commercial challenge. Most top executives, however, responded with polite disinterest. But now the boardroom climate is changing.

One reason: the message is coming through new channels, some plugging directly into boardrooms. The authoritative Harvard Business Review, for example, has just published an article entitled What Every Executive Needs to Know About Global Warming' - and top executive reactions have been instructive.

Co-authored by a McKinsey consultant, the article accepts that climate change is dogged by uncertainties, but cautions "uncertainty is no excuse for inaction". Some executives, it concludes, are meeting the challenge head-on. But, it warns: "Those who are not should wonder why they aren't - and so should their shareholders."

Instead of fighting the climate change agenda, the authors advise, "executives should encourage a regulatory climate that will be stable and predictable - and therefore friendly to investment - over the long term."

Some major companies have begun to bite the bullet by reviewing their public policy positions on climate. So, for instance, we have seen BP Amoco, Shell, Ford and DaimlerChrysler resigning from the Global Climate Coalition (GCC), a lobbying group which pressures gov ernments to soft-pedal on global warming. Ironically, climate change also surfaced as the top emerging issue at this year's World Economic Forum, the summit for movers and shakers in global business. And, whatever the GCC may say, markets are already gearing up.

One place to look for clues to the future is the world of derivatives, the risk management tools we heard so much about in the 90s. Worried about the increasing volatility of world weather, some companies are protecting their businesses against weather-related risks by buying derivatives.

Since the first weather derivatives deal was struck in 1997, the market has grown reasonably fast, with some $3.5bn of derivatives now traded, according to the magazine Environmental Finance.

All of which sounds impressive, but it's small beer compared with the overall size of the potential exposures. The US Department of Energy estimates that some $1tn of the US economy is now exposed to weather risk, suggesting a huge amount of headroom for future growth in this sector.

Remember, though, that insurance doesn't solve environmental problems; it simply spreads the risks. So while it's exciting that insurance and reinsurance companies like AIG and Swiss Re are piling into this area, the spotlight should really be on corporate initiatives to shrink carbon emissions.

BP Amoco and Shell are de veloping internal carbon trading schemes, making emission reductions cheaper.

And the pressure is building on other carbon-heavies: in Australia, Greenpeace just submitted the world's first-ever complaint to a stock exchange about carbon risks. They claim that undisclosed carbon credits could cost Southern Pacific Petroleum and Central Pacific Minerals a thumping 42% of the revenues they expect from a major oil shale project. The game has begun.

 John Elkington is chairman of strategy consultants SustainAbility (www.sustain ability.co.uk) and author of Cannibals With Forks: The Triple Bottom Line of 21st Century Business (Capstone, £12.99).

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Mike Pounsford Chief executive of Banner McBride, the management consultancy arm of WPP
fields.trailText: Mike Pounsford Chief executive of Banner McBride, the management consultancy arm of WPP
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

When I was 24 with AMPR, a PR Agency, which later became Ampercord.

What has been your best moment in management?

I think coming to Banner McBride. I love it here. I have never worked with a better bunch of people.

What was your greatest mistake?

Not going to Canada when I was 19 or 20. I was offered a scholarship to do an MA at McMaster University.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

The Bill Gates deal with IBM.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

They don't annoy me. I find them intelligent and stimulating.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

No, not at all.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

Scientific management from the 30s which said that, basically, all you needed to do was time people and set them piece rates to do their work.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

Brand engagement, without a doubt. More and more organisations are realising that their employees are their single greatest asset and that their people have a role to play as brand ambassadors.

What one single lesson would you pass on to trainee managers?

Always look for the positive in your colleagues, and try to be fair with them.

Which management guru do you believe in?

Charles Handy. I also like David Meister, who specialises in professional services.

Who is your management hero?

Dave Packard and Gordon Hewlett who built Hewlett Packard by putting people at the centre of the business.

Who is your favourite politician?

Mo Mowlam, because of the work she's done in Northern Ireland.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?

"So what's the next step?"

What annoys you most?

People who are late, or being late myself.

How do you relax?

By playing the guitar and listening to music - all types.

What was your last cultural experience?

De La Guarda at The Roundhouse in Camden about three months ago. They are a group of Argentinean acrobats and high wire artistes.

What is your favourite city?

London, because of its cultural diversity and cosmopolitan flavour.

What is your greatest regret?

That I didn't have the knowledge I now have when I was younger and that I didn't have more belief in myself when I was younger.

Do you have a favourite website?

CDNow which is a music site. Also, OLGA which stood for on line guitar archive. I don't think it exists now, but it was for people who want tablature.

What would you really like to have been?

A Buddhist monk.

fields.headline: Putting new life into cycles
fields.standfirst: Collectors are showing a great and growing interest in classic bicycles writes Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Collectors are showing a great and growing interest in classic bicycles writes Stewart Dalby
fields.body:
Last year at Phillips' fourth annual sale of bicycles and cycling memorabilia, an 1891 English Diamond Frame Safety bicycle sold for an amazing £105,750. The pre-sale estimate was only £1,300.

Nicholas Oddy, the specialist at Phillips says: "That was quite bizarre. It was not even a classic bicycle. There was rival bidding between an American collector and a Middle East enthusiast who was ultimately successful."

That kind of thing can happen at auctions. When a rich collector decides he or she must have something, reason goes out the window.

It appears unlikely to happen again. There is, however, great and growing interest in modern racing bicycles and antique ones, as well as ephemera. Prices at the fifth Phillips sale of bicycles and cycling memorabilia on August 19, start at £100 and range up to £20,000, but these are estimates and could easily be exceeded. There is, for example, demand for Dursley Pedersens, a superior roadster of the Edwardian era if they are in working order. Prices here are rising. There are a number of these at the Phillips auction and velocipedes, tandems, trikes and roadsters as well as two rare cycling amusement games harking back to the heyday of pier amusements at British seaside resorts.

One, a World Sprint game, dating from 1900, is expected to fetch £5,000 to £8,000, while the Marathon Cycle Race from the 30s (pictured below) is estimated at £3,000 to £4,000.

The sale does not include any Draisiennes or hobbyhorses. These are considered to be the first bicycles. They date from 1817 when they were first patented and were the brainchild of Carl Von Drais. One was brought to England by Denis Johnson and, adapted, they became known as hobbyhorses. These days they would cost some £20,000 £30,000.

The next development of the bicycle came in the 1860s with velocipedes, also known as bone shakers. These were wooden wheeled front-wheel driven bicycles. They are fairly common today and sell for £1,000 to £3,000.

In 1876 Eugene Meyer developed the spider wired high-wheeled bicycle. The period between 1870 and 1890 became known as the era of the penny-farthing. There are still a lot of them around and they cost anything from £160 to £3,000 for a model by a well-known manufacturer.

The problem was they required trousers, for anyone but the most forward of Victorian women. So some variants of the penny-farthing were invented. One was the trike, with two wheels aft and one forward. At the Phillips sale there are some Salvio models which have front-wheel steering and some rear steer types. Again they are rare and estimates range from £10,000 to £14,000.

The age of the modern bicycle came in 1885 when JK Starley, a nephew of J Starley, a pioneering cycle engineer, came up with the chain driven back wheel, together with gears.

This ushered in the era of the roadster aided by the invention of pneumatic tyres. The original roadster was made for hard wear but it had many clones and was manufactured in huge numbers. You can get a good 30s roadster for £60 to £70, but original items sell for more. A mint 1920 Raleigh roadster would cost £200.

Dursely Pedersens tend to cost a little more. These were thought of as a grander version of the original roadster. They were popular in Edwardian times and they are popular now. Nicholas Oddy says: "Even then, they were considered superior. They are recognisable by their triangulated frames tensioned by wire and sprung woven seats."

At the Phillips sale a rare 19th-century Pedersen preceding its mass production is available at £2,000 to £4,000 while an early 20th-century maroon Dursely made by R.A. Lister & Co is estimated at £1,500 to £2,500. David Higman, curator of the National Cycle Collection, says a few years back they would have cost £800 to £1,200.

 Phillips, Bayswater, London tel: 020-7229-9090.

 The National Cycle Collection, Llandrindod Wells, Powys, tel: 01597-825-531.

webTitle: Why not put yourself through the hoops?

fields.headline: Why not put yourself through the hoops?
fields.standfirst: It seems more like Hurlingham and vicarage lawns, but croquet can be just as good in back gardens. Richard Nelsson reports
fields.trailText: It seems more like Hurlingham and vicarage lawns, but croquet can be just as good in back gardens. Richard Nelsson reports
fields.body:
It may be associated with vicarage garden parties, drinking Pimm's and Alice in Wonderland, but croquet is a sport in which Britain leads the world. Earlier this month, while all eyes were on the Wimbledon finals, a few miles away at the Hurlingham Club in West London, Stephen Mulliner took the crown at the British Open championships. And Britain has won the last four annual world team events.

Croquet enthusiasts say the game is growing in popularity. There are around 130 dedicated clubs dotted across the UK with 4,000 members. Many more people of all ages enjoy playing the occasional game in public parks or their gardens, finding it the perfect way to pass a lazy summer afternoon.

Nigel Graves, secretary of the Croquet Association, says:"What goes on at Hurlingham isn't a fair image of the game. Lots of croquet is played in municipally owned spaces. The top players tend to be younger, around the age of 30, although a lot of people take up the game when their knees become too rocky for other things."

Whether you play once a year or regularly take part in tournaments, croquet is a relatively cheap game to take up. A set containing everything you need - mallets, balls, hoops and winning peg - can be bought for around £200, while membership of a club costs £50 to £100.

Before rushing out to the nearest lawn though, it is worth being aware that there are two main variations of the game; golf croquet and association croquet. Both are played with two sides, each playing a pair of balls - yellow and red together and black and blue.

However with golf croquet, each side takes single alternate shots with their own balls so the game is fast moving and more sociable. The association variation, which is played at most competitions, is tactically more akin to snooker with many shots making a break. A game can take much longer to play, but it is said to be more interesting.

Although there is some debate as to the origins of the game, it is generally accepted that John Jaques II introduced modern day croquet into Britain at the Great Exhibition of 1851. One hundred and fifty years later, a firm called Jaques is still making croquet equipment. A good quality set such as the Oxford (£399) comes in a natural pine box and includes four ash mallets with brass rings which add weight and protect against damage. Thankfully, a set of rules is also included.

A more basic set, ideal for playing in the garden, is the Richmond at £160. For those who like to swing their mallets in only the finest style, there is the eight-player Sandringham set (£2,495). Everything you need is contained in the mahogany box, including a "smasher" to knock the hoops and peg into the grass.

Townsend Croquet also produces a wide range of sets. Its basic garden set costs £99, while the tournament standard Championship set is £595.

Serious players, though, may want to select a mallet that suits their particular style of playing. This could either be made from the traditional hardwood lignum vitae or a modern one with a fibreglass shaft and cast aluminium heads.

The Croquet Association naturally sells a wide range, including the respected Jaques Hurlingham mallet (£85 approx) or, for the same price, their speciality the Hogan, which is imported from New Zealand.

Customised mallets are also available. There are a number of bespoke mallet makers who will construct and adapt to suit your playing idiosyncrasies. John Hobbs, which made the mallet for the winner in last year's Open, for example, offers a whole range of variations from weight, stiffness and length to a handle that can be rotated in the head to improve accuracy. Prices start at £125.

If the whole point of the game for you is to conjure up the spirit of croquet's Victorian heyday, think about investing in an antique set with round-headed mallets rather than the modern day square heads. A shop such as Sean Arnold, which specialises in antique sports equipment, sells them, although they are very much in demand and go quickly. For example, it recently sold a 100-year-old set with its original antique pine box for £750 - the value very much depending on having the original box with the manufacturer's name on it.

Another garden game, although lacking the social cachet of croquet, is quoits. It was rumoured that Queen Elizabeth I was banned from playing because the game was deemed too vulgar. The traditional event, which is often played in pubs, uses heavy steel rings (2.4kg) that are thrown at a stake buried in the ground.

Masters Games sells blacksmith forged rings for £57 a pair, as well as a garden-friendly sets made from rubber. Jacques also has a set for £17 that uses rope quoits and a frame with five hardwood pegs.

One of the simplest games to play in the garden is boules. All you do is throw larger balls at the smaller jack. Cheap versions of the game can be found in supermarkets, but it is best to buy a French-made set such as those sold by Brighton shop A Lot of Gaul, which has sets ranging from £15 to £75.

If you want to participate in something a touch more intellectual in the garden, look out for an outdoor chess set. Garden chess produces setzs that fit into the space of four flagstones on a patio, or all-weather sets for the lawn for £250.

Rules and the kit as you take to the lawns

A standard croquet court measures 53 yards by 28 yards. A wooden peg stands in the centre of the court. Six iron hoops are at designated places on the court.

These are 12 inches high and must be no more than 4 inches wide. Each player has a long-handled mallet around three feet in length.

The basic idea is to get your side's two balls - black and blue or red and yellow - twice around the six-hoop course to finish off against the middle peg. This last bit is known as "pegging out" - a term that has of course passed into common usage. The variations of the game are:

Association croquet

Each side takes alternate turns (in a specified order) but each turn may consist of many shots. Every time the ball runs through a hoop in the correct order or hits another ball (called roquet) on the lawn, they earn additional shots, much the same as a snooker player does.

Skilful play can lead to scoring several hoops in one turn. The winner is the side who manages to score all the hoops and hit the peg first.

Golf croquet

Each side takes alternate shots with the aim of running their ball through the hoops in a specified order. Once one player has scored a particular hoop, all players proceed to the next one. The winner is the one that scores the most hoops.

 Detailed rules are available from the Croquet Association.

Who to call

Croquet Association, tel: 020-7736-3148, www.croquet.org.uk

Jaques, tel: 020-8684-4242; also available from www.simplysports.co.uk

John Hobbs: aol.com/hobbsmall

Townsend Croquet, tel: 01255-424247

Sean Arnold, tel: 020-7221-2267

Garden Chess: cableinet.co.uk/miketasker

Masters Games: 020-8288-2604, www.mastersgames.com

A Lot of Gaul: www.gaul.co.uk

fields.headline: Organise the  organic dream
fields.standfirst: An eco-friendly career would do wonders for your self-esteem, but is the salary up to scratch? And does a green job mean a complete change in the way you work? Sandra Deeble reports
fields.trailText: An eco-friendly career would do wonders for your self-esteem, but is the salary up to scratch? And does a green job mean a complete change in the way you work? Sandra Deeble reports
fields.body:
You buy the unpolished vegetables, your child will only eat Baby Organix bread sticks, your dog's developed a taste for Yarrah's organic chicken chunks and you are seriously considering switching your mortgage to an ethical lender. So why not complete the holistic dream and develop an organic career?

As the demand for organic products increases, so do the job opportunities. But does it mean embracing an organic, salary? Or, like the organic fruit and veg that is sold at a premium, does it follow that an eco career could deliver premium rewards?

"The basic salary is exactly the same, but the annual profit share is not," says Susan Cooper, a loan manager at Triodos, the Bristol-based bank which invests exclusively in organisations and businesses with social and environmental objectives.

Ms Cooper worked at Barclays for more than 20 years so she's in a good position to compare traditional with green. "The pressures are different. I'm probably working harder here, but as we don't have sales targets, there's more time for customers."

The job interview methods differ, too. Whereas Barclays went in for lengthy form filling and relied heavily on psychometric testing, her new employer's emphasis was on whether she would fit in with "the Triodos way of working".

Which is? "Instead of being told what to do, you're asked your opinion," she explains. And what of the working environment? "We're not in a whizzy eco-building, although they've got one in our Dutch office, in Zeist; we're in a Georgian Merchants House, overlooking the Downs. And there's no fluorescent lighting," she says.

Everyone at Triodos is, unsurprisingly, known as a "co-worker" and, according to Susan Cooper, the opportunities are less about motoring towards the end of year bonus, and more about "being able to marry the finance side with positive activities". These can range from lending money to businesses such as Cafedirect and the Organic Milk Suppliers Co-operative, and a host of other green, urban regeneration and community projects.

But does an organic career mean wearing Birkenstocks full-time, reprinting your CV on hemp and moving lock, stock, and barrel to Totnes?

The Totnes part helps. William and Gabriela Lana moved to Devon three years ago to set up the Green- fibreshop, in addition to their mail order business, which sells clothes made from organic cotton. "I'm sure in myself that this is the way to go forward," says Mr Lana, whose business recently turned the corner from the red into the black. "Although it's still very new. It's a bit like organic food was 10 years ago. And you have to give people an explanation as to why there's a 20% premium."

What of the clothes? "Our products do not look like anything other than mainstream products," says Mr Lana. "We've got a men's button-down shirt with coconut shell buttons which looks as if it could have come from Next."

And just as organic food used to be found only in health food shops but is now stocked by all supermarkets, Mr Lana believes that once the high street clothing retailers start to stock products made from organic cotton, consumers will start to make different choices about what they wear. He says: "M&S started selling an organic cotton line." Organic knickers? "But they didn't really go very well and they withdrew the line with no explanation."

Perhaps it's still early days. And Mr Lana is not without his competitors. Linda Row studied fashion at St Martin's and knew she wanted to do business "in a different way" which motivated her to set up Clothworks three years ago.

"The way that cotton is produced, using large amounts of chemicals isn't really sustainable as, after a while, the pests become immune to the pesticides," she explains. Mixing hemp with wool and silk, Ms Row gets lots of interest from students who, she believes, will create "a new generation of designers".

Soon to be stocking Clothworks clothes is the Organic Cafe Natural Home Store, opening in Notting Hill, London, later this year. Other products on offer will be organic paint, wooden toys, and eco-furniture. Farewell Ikea? "I hope so," says Carol Charlton Jones, who is behind the new shop. "It's a made-to-last concept. And I think the future lies in people having to change their view of how and where they purchase."

As organic suppliers step up their production to meet the demands from the supermarkets, some of the homespun businesses are having to change - and recruit differently.

Rachel's Dairy, in Aberystwyth, may sound like two people pottering about in a cowshed, but is in fact a family business which has just been bought by Horizon. And that isn't a holiday company, but a US business set up by health food specialists.

The newest recruit is Anahita Belanger, who has defected from Procter &Gamble where she managed the Sainsbury's account: selling Pampers and Wash & Go. As she was brought up on an organic farm herself, she sees Rachel's as a "good ethical fit". She's now national account manager, selling organic wholemilk yoghurt with maple syrup to the likes of Waitrose, Safeway and or ganic supermarkets Fresh and Wild. "Before I joined, no one person was dealing with the multiples," she explains. Although she has only been with Rachel's Dairy for a couple of weeks, she believes the working culture to be "less competitive" than P&G.

Yet as the demand for organic food increases, won't competition impact on the working culture within the individual organisations? And as the organisations grow, how can you maintain a green and friendly working environment?

Two years ago, the Soil Association employed 40 people. They now have 130 people in their Bristol offices.

"We're developing new systems to deal with growth," says Mike Collins, who adds that there is a huge demand for people with marketing, campaigning and IT skills combined with an understanding of the aims of the Soil Association.

Inevitably, too, the organic market is opening up opportunities for savvy, green consultants. And it's a long term thing - which, for consultancy fees is even better.

Robert Weston set up Groundswell, "a communications and culture change consultancy around sustainability" in Bath. A graduate of the MSc in Responsibility & Business Practice at the University of Bath (in partnership with the New Academy of Business), Robert Weston sees more and more green consultancy opportunities opening up.

"The name Groundswell seems to be living up to its name," he says, explaining that many of his former clients from his days as a mainstream consultant: the likes of Ford and Wrangler, are now becoming clients again as he works in collaboration with their sustainability departments.

Other agencies which are growing include the Soho-based Good Business, which helps mainstream clients such as Nike, Coca-Cola and NatWest to tackle their marketing through addressing social issues; and C21, also in London, which specialises in ethical, environmental and educational communication.

Indeed, if all organisations are beginning to take steps to deal with social and green issues and are finding ways of integrating them into their businesses does it mean that if you just stay put and hang around long enough, your mainstream employer will start to feel as clean as a whistle?

"Instead of the niche being made up of the goodies, it'll be the baddies," agrees Alex MacGillivray, deputy director of the New Economics Foundation.

"And there'll be lots of career opportunities for brokers: the kind of people who are doing the Bristol Breakfast (an ethical breakfast made up of locally sourced products and fairly traded coffee and bananas). And there's bound to be an 'Ask Ethical Jeeves' website," he predicts.

So you know what to do. Either sit tight and wait for things to change or, if you're what Alex MacGillivray describes as an "early adopter" you can hit the organic fast track. Move to the West Country. Do the MSc at Bath University. Wear a hemp shirt. And eat plenty of yoghurt. You'll be well on your way to an organic career.

fields.headline: Mixed motives hamper postal delivery
fields.standfirst: Notebook: Ministers bungle exclusion remedy
fields.trailText: There is something quite silly about asking Britain's leading banks to contribute to a piece of social infrastructure in the form of a post office-based "universal bank" and then turning around and saying that if they don't like the idea they can just set up their own socially responsible divisions and forget the post offices.
fields.body:
There is something quite silly about asking Britain's leading banks to contribute to a piece of social infrastructure in the form of a post office-based "universal bank" and then turning around and saying that if they don't like the idea they can just set up their own socially responsible divisions and forget the post offices.

Banks are like other businesses in that they try to avoid funding competitors. They see the government's request for them to pay the bulk of the universal bank's annual costs as no more than a subsidy to the Post Office, which is keen to move into the personal finance field - albeit at the low end of the market.

They now have a way out which will prove much cheaper - by simply devising appropriate basic accounts for those who have fought shy of the banking system and then advertising them widely.

We can expect the take-up to be limited because bank branches tend to be thin on the ground in those areas where the "unbanked" live and work - rural areas or rough parts of town.

The beauty of the post office-based scheme shows through in one statistic: there are post offices in 60% of villages and banks in only 5%.

This whole fiasco seems to have arisen because of in-fighting between the Treasury and the department of trade and industry. The former simply wants to end financial exclusion and get benefits paid out in a more efficient manner. The latter is seeking ways of replacing the earnings the post offices will lose through the decision to pay benefits directly into bank accounts by 2003.

This is a fine example of unjoined-up government.

Green with envy

It could almost be read as an act of spite: Lord Hollick turning on his fair weather friend, deciding that if he was not going to be able to play at being a meeja baron then he would do his damnedest to make sure that that Michael Green will lose his title as well.

There were rumours, of course, before Stephen Byers' regulatory nail bomb a month ago, killing the proposed merger of Lord Hollick's United News & Media and Mr Green's Carlton Communications, that tensions between the two men were rising fast.

The chatter was denied at the time and was probably misguided in any case. But the effect of yesterday's deal to sell United's choice TV bits to Charles Allen's Granada Media is to leave Mr Green in the weakest possible position.

If Granada had been forced to pursue a risky hostile takeover of United, even victory might have left it weaker, burning cash and management time.

Instead, Mr Allen has been able to pay for the three franchise assets substantially with Granada paper, leaving a group that will be capitalised at something just north of £10bn. It will also have more than £1.5bn of cash in the bank to put down as a deposit on the next acquisition or strategic partnership - which we must presume will be in mainland Europe.

Of course, Carlton is not history. Mr Green can look forward to all sorts of fun swapping assets with Mr Allen: stakes in Scottish Media Group and Meridian are all in play as well as the HTV and GMTV assets. But his apparently passive behaviour in recent weeks seems strange, especially when set against the vibrancy and vision this man displayed throughout the 1990s.

Maybe Mr Green has just been a bit under the weather at an irritating time. If so, he should try some of the rocket fuel which Mr Allen has clearly been pouring on his breakfast over the past three months.

Late opening

After a rare period on the back foot, Lloyds TSB is once again setting an example for its peers. Unlike the corporate governance disasters at the likes of Barclays - which spent much of last year without a chief executive - and Alliance & Leicester - which dumped its chief after a boardroom row, Lloyds showed us yesterday how boardroom successions should be planned. True, the bank was unable to find a chairman from the ranks of its own board, and has recently lost a number of senior executives such as Gordon Pell to NatWest.

But while there had been mutterings in the City that finding a successor for the veteran Sir Brian Pitman was becoming an issue, it had not yet caused enough anxiety to become an agenda-setting issue. The bank put the headhunters on to the task of finding a new chairman a year ago. The fact it has taken this long to find a replacement shows just how tight the market is in top flight candidates.

With the handover now set, the only reason to be nervous might be that the new man, Maarten van den Bergh from Royal Dutch Shell, was being hailed yesterday not as a banker but a businessman. Then again, Lloyds has always been a little different.

fields.headline: Golden Wonder is £156m morsel
fields.trailText: Crisps manufacterer Golden Wonder is to be gobbled up by private equity firm Bridgepoint Capital for £156m - and will set out on an acquisition trail of its own.
fields.body:
Crisps manufacterer Golden Wonder is to be gobbled up by private equity firm Bridgepoint Capital for £156m - and will set out on an acquisition trail of its own.

Bridgepoint, bought out from NatWest earlier this year, is thought to have seen off competition from PepsiCo, the American drinks group which also owns Walkers Crisps, and fellow private equity group Phildrew Ventures.

The total value of the deal, taking into account Golden Wonder's debt, is around £150m and represents a large profit for L&G Ventures which backed the original management buyout from Dalgety in 1995 for £54.6m.

Its former guise of NatWest Equity Partners, Bridgepoint also had a stake in the business during the first buyout.

PepsiCo dominates the British crisps and snacks market but Golden Wonder's label Munchies, along with brands such as Wotsits, Weetcrunches and Nik Naks, have built up a 13% share of the market.

KP, owner of the Brannigans brand, is the other leading player in the sector. It is owned by Finalrealm, a consortium which owns United Biscuits.

Golden Wonder has been on the market since April, having abandoned plans for a flotation. Last year it made pre-tax profits of £12m on sales of some £162m.

Clive Sharpe, the chief executive of Golden Wonder who led the original buyout five years ago, is now ready to embark on his own acquisitions in the sector.

He said yesterday that he was looking at "a number of potential acquisitions" to help develop Golden Wonder's business in the future.

The heartland of its business is in Scunthorpe and Corby, where it employs 1,600 people.

Golden Wonder was founded in 1947 by a Scottish baker, William Alexander.

Among its culinary claims to fame are the introduction of the ready salted and cheese and onion flavours of potato crisps.

Its snack services division is the largest national van supplier of crisps, snacks, nuts and other savoury products to British pubs, schools and leisure venues.

webTitle: £41m payout for Chase de Vere staff

fields.headline: £41m payout for Chase de Vere staff
fields.standfirst: Receptionists and secretaries to cash in after bank's acquisition
fields.trailText: Receptionists and secretaries are among almost 200 members of staff at an independent financial adviser firm who will share a £41m payout as a result of its planned acquisition by Bank of Ireland, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Receptionists and secretaries are among almost 200 members of staff at an independent financial adviser firm who will share a £41m payout as a result of its planned acquisition by Bank of Ireland, it was announced yesterday.

Mike Edge, co-founder and chairman of Chase de Vere Investments, will collect £50m. Bath-based Chase de Vere, one of Britain's most high-profile IFAs, is being bought by Bank of Ireland for up to £132.5m, and will be run as part of its UK subsidiary Bristol & West, the former building society.

The bank has agreed to buy the 55% stake in Chase de Vere owned by Mr Edge and co-founder Michael Chadwick for £69m, and has made a proposal to buy the remaining 45% owned by 196 employees for a cash payment of £41m.

Nigel Mitchell, managing director of Chase de Vere, would not be drawn on how much he will be pocketing. While £41m between 196 people works out at £209,000 each, in reality the payouts will vary from a few thousand pounds to several million pounds.

Employees have varying numbers of shares depending on length of service and how well they have performed. A secretary with the company 10 or 15 years might expect to collect around £30,000, said Mr Mitchell. This would indicate that some senior staff will be picking up £1m or more each.

The deal is conditional on all the option holders accepting - they have a week to make their decision.

The deal also provides for performance-related payments of up to £22.5m to be made to eligible shareholders in 2003, "depending on the actual results achieved".

Mr Edge and Mr Chadwick founded the firm in 1983 and it became unquoted, public and limited five years later. It has offices in Bath, London and Leeds, employs 300 and specialises in financial advice on investment products.

Bank of Ireland said the acquisition supports its strategy of building up Bristol & West's presence in "selected profitable market segments" such as specialist mortgage products and investments, and allows it to expand into providing independent financial advice.

The firm will retain its name. Jeff Warren, the chief executive of Bristol & West, said: "Chase de Vere is a strong brand name with very good customer recognition.

"For Bristol & West customers this offers us potential to give customers with more complex needs access to independent financial advice through Chase de Vere."

Mr Edge is staying on as a non-executive director while Mr Chadwick, who has been a non-executive director for the past few years, will resign. The deal excludes London & Country Mortgages, Chase de Vere's mortgage advice business.

fields.headline: New home for Axa's orphan
fields.standfirst: Patrick Collinson unravels some of the puzzles attached to the latest windfall payments
fields.trailText: Patrick Collinson unravels some of the puzzles attached to the latest windfall payments
fields.body:
A new type of windfall is promised after French insurer Axa reached a deal with regulators to pay out the surplus cash built up in the company over many decades.

The Axa deal is relatively small - it is unlocking £1.7bn in its "orphan estate" - compared with the £8bn Prudential has in its surplus cash kitty. Some estimates put potential payouts at thousands of pounds per head.

But don't expect the cash soon. Prudential has been in negotiations with the authorities for six years and a conclusion is probably some way off. The negotiations involve both financial and philosophical considerations about who "owns" the surplus; the policyholders or the shareholders?

In a proprietary company (one owned by shareholders) the rule of thumb is that surpluses belong 10% to shareholders, 90% to policyholders. But that is only a starting point in negotiations, with many shareholders pressing for more.

For policyholders, judging whether your payout is a fair representation of your rights is something that would defeat most actuaries. As one observer quipped this week: "Axa is making you an offer you can't understand." Below we attempt to identify some of the main questions policyholders will be asking.

How much will I get?

It depends on the size of your policy. Axa cites an average of £400, with one lucky policyholder picking up £90,000. Someone who put £10,000 into a personal pension in 1980 will receive £2,142. But that's just the initial bonus for giving up your rights to future distributions from the £1.7bn orphan estate. A further reorganisation bonus, typically worth 3% of the value of a policy, will be added when the policy matures.

Why are they giving me this money?

It is the only way shareholders can also unlock the value of the orphan estate. They will receive a minimum of 10% of the estate, although some observers believe that in reality they are getting hold of 45%.

Who qualifies?

Anybody with a with-profits policy in force on July 24, 2000. It numbers 660,000 people with 750,000 policies, including Axa Sun Life as well as Axa Equity & Law policies, but not Sun Life Assurance Society policies.

Our policy matured last year. Do we get a windfall?

No. But if your policy matures between now and next February, you will receive an ex gratia payment equal to the payments to other policyholders.

When will I get the money?

Assuming the plan is approved (it needs a 35% yes vote), payments will be made at the end of February 2001.

How will I receive it?

In cash; this is not a shares distribution. Holders of free-standing additional voluntary contribution pension policies will not receive cash but an additional bonus instead.

Will it be taxed?

No. However, policies bought through the second-hand market may incur a capital gains tax charge.

Is the offer reasonable?

The plan has been overseen by the Financial Services Authority (it says "the proposals Axa are making are reasonable") and won the approval of independent actuaries Hymans Robertson. But not the Consumers' Association. Its director, Sheila McKechnie says: "We are staggered the FSA has allowed Axa to give so much money to shareholders. This deal is scandalous."

Must I accept this deal?

No. If you vote "no" you will retain your rights over the orphan estate until your policy matures. You'll lose the cash windfall, but keep your entitlement to future distributions from the estate - even if 99.9% of other policyholders have voted for jam today rather than tomorrow. But Axa says there can be no distributions until 2006 at least, so, under the terms of this deal, anybody with a plan maturing before then should vote for the cash.

Will the payout weaken the company?

No, says Axa. Its existing financial strength will be maintained, with the initial £300m bonus financed from shareholders', not policyholders', funds.

I'm not with Axa but my life company has an orphan estate. Will I get a windfall?

There's lots of speculation about £20bn locked in orphan estates, about to produce another cascade of payouts. But expectations were dashed when it was made clear that the Axa deal is not a blueprint for other distributions. Each one has to be separately negotiated, and the negotiations can take many years.

Who are the other companies with orphan estates?

Prudential is the biggest, with £8bn in orphan assets. CGNU has £5bn, L&G £2.3bn, Britannic £2bn, Clerical Medical £1.9bn and Pearl £1.5bn.

fields.headline: Granada targets Europe
fields.trailText: Granada Media yesterday promised to use a £1.5bn cash pile to expand the business in Europe after agreeing a deal which will leave it the prime force behind Britain's biggest commercial channel, ITV.
fields.body:
Granada Media yesterday promised to use a £1.5bn cash pile to expand the business in Europe after agreeing a deal which will leave it the prime force behind Britain's biggest commercial channel, ITV.

The deal to acquire the Meridian, Anglia and HTV franchises from Lord Hollick's United News & Media was confirmed yesterday after week-long negotiations.

The agreement has been structured as £1.25bn in shares and £500m in cash, leaving Granada Media with an ample war chest with which to turn its focus overseas.

Granada Media chief Charles Allen said: "Leading companies in each European country will be looking at how they can play a larger role and I'm hopeful we'll agree alliances and partners. We have the firepower to move forward."

Granada Media was left debt free and with £2bn in the bank after being spun off from its hospitality business last month. Mr Allen also disclosed plans to develop a family of ITV-branded channels for digital services which would be grouped around particular genres or type of viewer.

The Granada paper will be distributed to United shareholders, which Lord Hollick said would allow investors at least to benefit from the consolidation of ITV. He shrugged off suggestions that he had in anyway lost out. The franchises were put up for sale after fellow ITV group Carlton Communications pulled out of a proposed merger with United a week ago.

"If people characterise getting the highest ever value from the sale of ITV assets and allowing your shareholders to play a role in the consolidation of ITV as losing then they are missing the point," he said.

A memo sent to staff yesterday though admitted that "in many ways this [was] a sad day." Lord Hollick played down suggestions that he had put the Daily and Sunday Express newspapers up for sale and said he was keen to rebuild United around business to business publishing and new media.

United maintained that it had held talks with a number of different parties interested in acquiring its ITV assets before agreeing a deal - although Granada advisers remained sceptical that there were any other serious buyers. United had been open to an offer for the entire company but Mr Allen said he had no interest in the other properties including the Daily Express.

Granada will have to sell a series of assets to keep itself below the 15% limit of national audience imposed on any sin gle broadcast company. The most significant disposal will be HTV, which it has been given six months to sell on to another buyer.

Mr Allen said he had already put a call in to Michael Green, chairman of Carlton Communications, which is the natural buyer of the Wales and west of England franchise. Granada will also need to sell down its stake in breakfast televison group GMTV to below 20%.

Border, over which Granada has a call option for the next three years, would tip the company over the limit by 0.1% but the natural erosion of ITV's share as new channels emerge will probably bring it below the limit before then.

fields.headline: At this price? BAA
fields.trailText: BAA, Britain's largest airport operator, has a simple problem. More passengers are passing through its airports but the cash it is extracting from each is falling.
fields.body:
BAA, Britain's largest airport operator, has a simple problem. More passengers are passing through its airports but the cash it is extracting from each is falling.

The group has been struggling to recover from the blow of abolition last July of the duty free concession within the European Union.

Its shares went into free fall last October when it forecast that the scrapping would wipe out £80m of profits. More than £1bn was wiped off its market value. The price has been creeping back up after bottoming at 358.25p in March but more than half of lost ground has to be made up.

The group's first quarter results, published yesterday, gave the shares a small boost, lifting them 8.5p to 528p. Profits before tax, exceptionals and joint ventures, rose 3.6% to £144m, and chief executive Mike Hodgkinson reported that the group's retail business had performed "ahead of plan".

But although results of the retail operation had been "satisfactory" so far this month, it was too early to draw real conclusions, he said. The group, whose operations include London's Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted airports, saw 32.1m people travel through its UK airports during the quarter, an increase of 7.5% over the same period last year. However, net retail income per passenger fell 17.3%.

Since the duty free changes, BAA has decided to concentrate on its core businesses. It is closing its world duty free in-flight service and has made a number of property disposals. It is also returning up to £400m to shareholders through share buy-backs and has acquired 9.8m shares at a cost of £48.7m.

After an operating profit of £4.1m all last year, its Heathrow Express service made a £2.4m profit over the first quarter this year.

However, analyst Andrew Darke of Williams de Broe expects that the early start to the Civil Aviation Authority's regulatory review will cast "a shadow of uncertainty" over BAA's shares for two years.

fields.headline: North Pembrokeshire
fields.body:
Walking by Carnedd Meibion Owen we have on our left Carn Ingli, covered in heather and bracken, its shape changing throughout the walk. On the right there are a range of fields, woods and farmhouses. Most of the fields are the quiet fawn colour of cut hay. One is still in stripes, cut but not gathered. Others are green and some contain cattle. Woods are thickly in leaf. Old farms tuck into the ground, only new sheds look uneasy on the land.

We walked through a quiet Tycanol wood, birds keeping their July modesty. Leaving the trees we picked up the path to Newport along the river Clydach. We were going to visit friends at Brithdir Mawr.

This farm has been in the news with the sobriquet "lost tribe of Pembrokeshire". So much for the government's cry for diversification and sustainable development. Practise it and you are tracked down by journalists as oddities. You are different, but traditional. Here the hay has been cut and gathered with horses. It is stored in a barn whose round wooden structure and turf roof make it look as if it is growing from the earth.

Farmers are allowed barns for hay, but farm workers here are not allowed houses of a similar natural, sustainable pattern. They have missed all the categories and muddled the bureaucrats: how can farm workers be accomplished musicians, makers of wooden bowls and spoons, historians, writers? By skipping a century and returning to the 18th. They've also missed the rules, so they're in trouble. But their land isn't. Good husbandary takes time to flower. This once derelict farm and farm house are steadily improving.

We walked past the horses. They stood in the shade, whisking and snorting. Then we moved on through the curious cattle to some of the clear streams running down from Carn Ingli.

We heard them before we saw them: the defiant clanking of golden-ringed dragonflies exchanging views. These ancient insects have long outlived man's attempts at farming, housing and social organisation. Their freedom is short, but glorious.

fields.headline: Oil company looks beyond petroleum
fields.standfirst: Brand values: BP
fields.trailText: Warnings by former Saudi energy minister Sheik Yamani that the world is nearing the end of the oil era had few rushing out to buy electric cars. But a more potent symbol of pending decline for the industry appeared this week
fields.body:
Warnings by former Saudi energy minister Sheik Yamani that the world is nearing the end of the oil era had few rushing out to buy electric cars. But a more potent symbol of pending decline for the industry appeared this week: BP, the company which started the Middle East oil boom early this century, said its name in future would signify "beyond petroleum" rather than British Petroleum.

Chief executive Sir John Browne plans to spend £100m over the next 12 months reinforcing this image with a new logo, a makeover for its petrol stations and a media advertising blitz.

So what is wrong with being an oil company? Quite a lot, it would seem from the adverse reaction to BP daring to spend a lot of money on a marketing makeover.

The road lobby has been up in arms, complaining that the cash should have been used for lowering petrol station prices. The green lobby has been up in arms complaining its all a cynical ploy.

Environmentalists say BP is rooted in the hydrocarbon field - and no amount of rebranding can hide that. The fact that BP has chosen a new logo which looks like a sunflower just adds insult to injury for the eco-warriors.

So why did BP do it? The official version from its headquarters at Britannic House is that it reflects the growing interest in cleaner, more environmentally friendly fuels such as natural gas and solar power.

It is certainly true that since the recent takeover of Amoco, BP has become a major gas producer. It is also true that BP has become a world leader in the development of solar power, even though the amount of money being spent is insignificant compared to its oil exploration.

But Sir John also has ambitions outside of the energy field, and the logo could as much be used to front an office cleaning company or a supermarket chain as it could a hydrocarbon group.

In fact a supermarket chain is on the way because the oil major has plans to open up retail outlets at all its major petrol stations as part of ambitions to increase retail revenues by 10%.

But underneath all the hype is thought to be an acceptance that the traditional image of the oil company has become a negative one in the hearts and minds of the consumer.

Its not just the high petrol prices that are the problem. There is also a growing demand throughout the business sector for a social and ethical dimension in all that is done.

On a more mundane level, the oil companies are aware that one petrol is the same as any other, making it nearly impossible to build brand loyalty. Then there is the fact that BP was 58th in a recent survey by consultant Interbrand on globally recognised product names.

But is the makeover a grossly cynical exercise to pull the wool over its environmental critics and retail customers alike? No, it is good business practice, and is being done by every truly successful brand around the world, says Robert Jones, a director at consultant Wolff Olins.

Think of Starbucks, Disney or Virgin. These brands are despised by a few but liked by millions. In a market filled with coffee bars, Starbucks stands for sociability as well as beverages.

Disney stands for much more than cartoons and theme parks. It stands for fun - while Sir Richard Branson's Virgin is nothing if not youthful and iconoclastic. It can sell anything its founder comes up with - records, airlines, financial services, mobile phones and even energy.

So BP is not mistaken in spending all that cash on rebranding, but it does raise the question of whether the message is correct. Saying BP stands for "beyond petroleum" points people in an interesting direction but does not explain what they will find there - or even exactly what BP now stands for, says Mr Jones.

The challenge over the next few years will be to fine tune the message so that consumers understand what idea they are buying into - and having set a new standard delivering on that.

Consumers do not like to be let down. Nike is seen as a brand that represents more than shoes; it represents winning. Allegations that it was using low-cost labour from poor countries nearly damaged the company's name.

BP is engaged in some of the most politically sensitive countries in the world, such as Colombia, where it has been accused by charities of not doing enough to halt human rights abuses.

Plans to drill in environmentally sensitive areas such as the Arctic have also led to its annual general meetings being logjammed by protests from green-fingered shareholders.

But BP has so far managed to walk the tightrope between making spectacular financial gains and being seen by the wider community as a company that cares for both customers and employees.

Although it has made large numbers of redundancies after taking over first Amoco, then Arco and then Burmah Castrol, it has done so by awarding generous financial packages.

Sir John stresses that the bright new green and yellow logo is as much geared to inspiring people inside the organisation as outside. He has raised expectations that must be met.

The fax

BP's roots go back to a concession to explore for oil in Persia granted to a syndicate led by wealthy Englishman, William Knox D'Arcy, in 1901

The syndicate , later to be known as the Anglo-Persian Oil Company, ran short of money and was rescued by the Burmah Oil Company

Burmah gave up its BP shares as part of a Bank of England rescue deal in the 1970s. BP made a successful takeover bid for its former saviour earlier this year

webTitle: Northern Ireland is not like West Sussex

fields.headline: Why they had to be freed
fields.standfirst:
Northern Ireland is not like West Sussex
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Few of the many repulsive scenes played out in Northern Ireland over the last three decades will have turned stomachs quite so sharply as yesterday's little tableau outside the Maze jail.
fields.body:
Few of the many repulsive scenes played out in Northern Ireland over the last three decades will have turned stomachs quite so sharply as yesterday's little tableau outside the Maze jail.

The stars of the show were men like Torrens Knight, the loyalist gunmen who walked into the Rising Sun bar in 1993 shouting "trick or treat" before firing randomly, killing eight people. Or James McArdle, the Canary Wharf bomber whose handiwork killed two men in February 1996. The sight of these people walking to freedom yesterday after serving such brief punishments - less than four years for double murder in McArdle's case - is enough to make the blood run cold.

The disgust at these early releases has been compounded this week by an intense debate about crimes so heinous, it is said that their punishment should never end. The murder of Sarah Payne has prompted the demand for some killers to serve life with no prospect of release: yet here outside the Maze are hardened multiple murderers walking free. It is hard not to agree with Ishan Bashir, whose brother Inam was killed by that Docklands bomb: "Terrorism has triumphed today," he said, "and made a mockery of our rule of law."

We can empathise with Mr Bashir and share the revulsion so many feel at this trampling on normal standards of justice. We can feel all that - and still defend the prisoner releases which all but wound up yesterday. We can do that by admitting a painful truth: that the tragedy of Northern Ireland is that it has not been a "normal" society and that the normal rules have not applied.

The argument against the early release scheme - in our view, a much more agonising aspect of the Good Friday agreement than the more publicly vexed issue of decommissioning - is that it is at odds with the normal rule of law in a democratic society. As Michael Gove, the Times columnist and author of a new pamphlet on the peace process, argued this week, we would not let Sarah Payne's killer walk free after four years, so why James McArdle? His error is to pretend that Northern Ireland is West Sussex: it is not.

Whether it was the shoot-to-kill policy of the 1980s, Diplock courts or internment, Northern Ireland has not enjoyed the same rule of law as the rest of the United Kingdom. That is because a war has been fought there. The Daily Telegraph may like to pretend there was no such conflict - hence its policy of putting "peace process" in quotation marks - and that the province just had an unusually high crime rate, but the rest of us know that Northern Ireland's tragedy was to be a 30-year-long exception to the rule of law.

The consequence of that fact is that when it comes to making peace, the normal rules cannot always apply either. We know that from South Africa, where amnesty had to be extended to confessed killers, and from the Middle East where Israel has had to release thousands of convicted murderers for the sake of a series of peace accords. The painful fact is that when wars are ending, justice sometimes has to take second place to ensuring peace.

British rightwingers know this argument well: after all, they made it themselves in the case of Augusto Pinochet. Even if the Chilean former dictator is guilty, they said, he should not be tried if that would upset the delicate settlement Chile has reached for itself. At least with Northern Ireland, in contrast with Chile, these killers have been called to account for their crimes. That they enjoy freedom too early is a function of Northern Ireland's past as an abnormal society - and we hope a step on the way to its future as a normal one.
fields.bodyText: Few of the many repulsive scenes played out in Northern Ireland over the last three decades will have turned stomachs quite so sharply as yesterday's little tableau outside the Maze jail. The stars of the show were men like Torrens Knight, the loyalist gunmen who walked into the Rising Sun bar in 1993 shouting "trick or treat" before firing randomly, killing eight people. Or James McArdle, the Canary Wharf bomber whose handiwork killed two men in February 1996. The sight of these people walking to freedom yesterday after serving such brief punishments - less than four years for double murder in McArdle's case - is enough to make the blood run cold. The disgust at these early releases has been compounded this week by an intense debate about crimes so heinous, it is said that their punishment should never end. The murder of Sarah Payne has prompted the demand for some killers to serve life with no prospect of release: yet here outside the Maze are hardened multiple murderers walking free. It is hard not to agree with Ishan Bashir, whose brother Inam was killed by that Docklands bomb: "Terrorism has triumphed today," he said, "and made a mockery of our rule of law." We can empathise with Mr Bashir and share the revulsion so many feel at this trampling on normal standards of justice. We can feel all that - and still defend the prisoner releases which all but wound up yesterday. We can do that by admitting a painful truth: that the tragedy of Northern Ireland is that it has not been a "normal" society and that the normal rules have not applied. The argument against the early release scheme - in our view, a much more agonising aspect of the Good Friday agreement than the more publicly vexed issue of decommissioning - is that it is at odds with the normal rule of law in a democratic society. As Michael Gove, the Times columnist and author of a new pamphlet on the peace process, argued this week, we would not let Sarah Payne's killer walk free after four years, so why James McArdle? His error is to pretend that Northern Ireland is West Sussex: it is not. Whether it was the shoot-to-kill policy of the 1980s, Diplock courts or internment, Northern Ireland has not enjoyed the same rule of law as the rest of the United Kingdom. That is because a war has been fought there. The Daily Telegraph may like to pretend there was no such conflict - hence its policy of putting "peace process" in quotation marks - and that the province just had an unusually high crime rate, but the rest of us know that Northern Ireland's tragedy was to be a 30-year-long exception to the rule of law. The consequence of that fact is that when it comes to making peace, the normal rules cannot always apply either. We know that from South Africa, where amnesty had to be extended to confessed killers, and from the Middle East where Israel has had to release thousands of convicted murderers for the sake of a series of peace accords. The painful fact is that when wars are ending, justice sometimes has to take second place to ensuring peace. British rightwingers know this argument well: after all, they made it themselves in the case of Augusto Pinochet. Even if the Chilean former dictator is guilty, they said, he should not be tried if that would upset the delicate settlement Chile has reached for itself. At least with Northern Ireland, in contrast with Chile, these killers have been called to account for their crimes. That they enjoy freedom too early is a function of Northern Ireland's past as an abnormal society - and we hope a step on the way to its future as a normal one.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Stephen Pollard, an apology. There were a number of significant errors in a report by David Hencke on page 9, yesterday, headed Chance chat over dinner led Blair to order u-turn on beds.
fields.body:
Stephen Pollard, an apology. There were a number of significant errors in a report by David Hencke on page 9, yesterday, headed Chance chat over dinner led Blair to order u-turn on beds.

The report depended substantially on the assertion that Tony Blair had had an animated conversation on the NHS beds crisis with Stephen Pollard, described as an associate editor of the Daily Express, whom he was said to have met by chance while the latter was dining in the River Cafe with his girlfriend.

Mr Pollard is not an associate editor of the Daily Express; he is a columnist. He has never eaten in the River Cafe, let alone with Tony and Cherie Blair. While it is true that he has strong views on the NHS and the private sector, he has never discussed them "animatedly" with Tony or Cherie Blair.

Mr Hencke did not check any of this with Mr Pollard. Profuse apologies.

We ended our report about the Dome, page 3, yesterday, by saying that people would be able to get in free after 4pm provided they were prepared to take part in a fire drill. Unfortunately we neglected to say on which day this offer applied. It is just tomorrow, Sunday, and not on any other day.

A heading, ITN in news times legal challenge, page 11, yesterday, should have referred to ITV. It is ITV, the commercial operator, that is challenging a directive of the Independent Television Commission and seeking a judicial review, not ITN.

We were wrong in several of our references to the Battle of Bannockburn in a piece headed Battlefield falls with out a fight, page 9, G2, July 27. A subsidiary headline referred to "William Wallace's victory over the English". The Battle of Bannockburn was in 1314. Wallace died in 1305. The Scots were led by Robert the Bruce (as it said in the article). He defeated the army of Edward II, not Edward I (who died in 1307).

The readers' editor writes about the editor's new guidelines, page 7 of today's Saturday Review. It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. fields.headline: Bravo Benji
fields.trailText: Benji the Binman may or may not be: a strange individual, a grubby mercenary, an idealist (Muckraker who feeds from rubbish bins, July 27).
fields.body:
Benji the Binman may or may not be: a strange individual, a grubby mercenary, an idealist (Muckraker who feeds from rubbish bins, July 27). Stealing household waste may or may not be: illegal, a squalid occupation, the least glamorous branch of espionage. But when the government proposes to read not just my emails but the encryption software protecting my privacy, then I am extremely grateful for the corrective and democratic light he is shining into these murky corners of government.

John Souray
London

webTitle: Leader - Mrs Evans has been chastised too much

fields.headline: Too heavy a hand
fields.standfirst: Mrs Evans has been chastised too much
fields.trailText: As Marjorie Evans left Abergavenny magistrates court yesterday after receiving a suspended jail sentence for slapping a pupil, she was greeted by around 50 supporters with placards which said: "We support you, Marge." The headteacher's one comment was to thank the public for the hundreds of cards and messages she had received.
fields.body:
As Marjorie Evans left Abergavenny magistrates court yesterday after receiving a suspended jail sentence for slapping a pupil, she was greeted by around 50 supporters with placards which said: "We support you, Marge." The headteacher's one comment was to thank the public for the hundreds of cards and messages she had received.

In the next few weeks, she is likely to have a huge mailbag full of such sympathy. Yet that will be of little comfort to Mrs Evans, who is said to be "shattered" and faces a ruined career and losing her job.

The principle of banning corporal punishment in schools is a good one. But should it have been applied so rigorously? In court, Mrs Evans's 35 years of experience and good character counted for nothing. Her "glowing" reputation amongst parents and the governors was regarded as irrelevant compared to that minute when Mrs Evans temporarily lost her self-control when faced with an unruly 10-year-old child.

This flies in the face of any commonsense understanding of justice. Even the boy's mother describes him as a "little monster at times". Millions of parents can recognise that awful, usually brief, moment when exasperation with a child is capable of overwhelming our better instincts. To make such human failing a crime is absurd.

There is a wider policy issue for the government to consider. At a time when its ambitions for raising educational standards crucially depend on recruiting teachers and keeping them, the message from Abergavenny is damaging.

Public support for Mrs Evans springs in part from the understanding that teachers have an increasingly difficult job to do in dealing with unruly pupils. The boy in question pushed Mrs Evans and attempted to head-butt and punch her. More than one in six of British teachers have been assaulted or threatened with assault. Given such pressure on the teaching profession, justice should be tempered with mercy.

fields.headline: Images that make no sense
fields.trailText: Your report on our study (TV shows panned for third world coverage, July 28), does not do justice to its contents. It does not conclude that "holiday programmes concentrate on holidays"
fields.body:
Your report on our study (TV shows panned for third world coverage, July 28), does not do justice to its contents. It does not conclude that "holiday programmes concentrate on holidays". In the largest study of its kind ever attempted, we showed the impact of images of the developing world on the beliefs and understanding of viewers. This had crucial implications not just for public attitudes to development, aid, and the debt crisis but also for domestic issues such as race and migration.

The study showed a profound level of unease amongst many viewers that they simply did not understand the world in which they lived and that TV and press coverage were the source of much of the confusion: a ratings-driven media focused increasingly on disasters, celebrities and eye-catching events, without explanation or context. The study has led to a series of initiatives with journalists and researchers working together to find new ways to give more informed coverage of the developing world.

Dr Greg Philo
Glasgow University media unit

 Minority and indigenous peoples have even less chance of escaping poverty because education is rarely offered in their own languages. Experience has shown that when people have the chance to become literate in their own language, the transition to regional and/or national language is not hard to bridge. Can more consideration be given to this by G8 policy-makers?

Dr Clinton Robinson
High Wycombe, Bucks

fields.headline: We're not news ghouls
fields.trailText: While reading reports of the Concorde crash on Wednesday, I thought very soon there will be a follow-up article about the media coverage. And on Thursday there was Madeleine Bunting telling us all how voyeuristic we are and how we like to be emotionally stimulated by a disaster like this
fields.body:
While reading reports of the Concorde crash on Wednesday, I thought very soon there will be a follow-up article about the media coverage. And on Thursday there was Madeleine Bunting telling us all how voyeuristic we are and how we like to be emotionally stimulated by a disaster like this (The ghoulish crowds, July 27). She seems to be criticising every other newspaper, television and radio organisation for giving saturation coverage of Concorde. But the Guardian on Wednesday had plenty of excitable phrases - "like an atomic bomb", "the last moments", "seconds from disaster".

The rolling coverage on television is not available to everyone; different systems deliver news to our homes and gives us a choice. The coverage was very fair; it gave us the facts, the experts and we could share in the tragedy of the families. Just let us judge the news for ourselves.

Chris Myatt
Lewes, E Sussex

 Your correspondent Spiros Papaglimis asks, "don't third world plane crashes count?" (Letters, July 27). We cannot care about everyone equally. The Concorde crash provokes more interest in the UK and Europe because it is closer to us and thus means more - many will have used Charles de Gaulle airport and seen Concorde in the sky. While the death of people in distant lands is equally tragic objectively speaking, we cannot always be objective about everything. If we grieved for the death of all equally, we would be overwhelmed. It is not a cause for guilt if we feel more deeply as a result of a tragedy closer to home. We may think globally, but we still feel locally.

Jonathan Bratt
London
jj@moseley1.demon.co.uk

 There are plane crashes, train crashes, car crashes all over the world, but the Concorde crash is more than just another crash for it involved one of the most beautiful and interesting planes ever designed. I have lived here for 32 years, but still go to my kitchen window to watch it flying into Heathrow. It is just so special.

Lois Hockey
Richmond, Surrey

 Commentators have not dwelt on the flawed political decision to make the aeroplane. Concorde was built to preserve the employment of the makers of the TSR2 supersonic military plane when it was cancelled and to assuage both the French and many people in this country who objected to our consequential dependence on US-built aircraft. Concorde went ahead despite objections that the dangers and inefficiency which may be tolerable in a military aircraft were not acceptable for a civil airplane broadly based on the same technology.

Supersonic aircraft with small wing areas are potentially vulnerable because they require high take-off speeds which make aborting very difficult. Military aircraft are provided with ejector seats. Civil aircraft are not.

Andrew Horton
Hemel Hempstead, Herts

 Is it not about time we take a lesson from the rules regarding flights over a highly populated city? Paris prohibits commercial airliners from flying over the city centre. London surely must take heed, before a fully laden airliner crashes with a resultant massive death toll.

Jeremy Brown
London
JB@ronaldbrown.com

 Once again it seems that the only available video of an airliner crash is amateur in origin and exists only by chance. Surely, in these days of inexpensive high-quality Hi-8 and camcorders, it should be routine to video every airliner take-off and landing, providing invaluable evidence if an accident occurs. The cost would be minute compared with other costs involved in flying.

O Nikolaus
Northampton

fields.headline: Freud and Metroland
fields.trailText: Some words of Freud I came across (written soon after fleeing Austria in 1938) reminded me of a greater generosity of spirit towards asylum-seeking than recent debate has had room for
fields.body:
Some words of Freud I came across (written soon after fleeing Austria in 1938) reminded me of a greater generosity of spirit towards asylum-seeking than recent debate has had room for (Europe 'should accept' 75m new migrants, July 28): "I met with the friendliest reception in lovely, free magnanimous England. Here I now live, a welcome guest; I can breathe a sigh of relief now that the weight has been taken off me and that I am once more able to speak and write - I had almost said 'and think' - as I wish or as I must."

Martin Treacy
Bletchley, Bucks

 I wish people like Baroness Young would stop saying they "speak for Britain" (Politics, July 25). Now Lord Shore says "the ordinary people of Britain are against the single currency" (Letters, July 28). I'm British and I'm ordinary and I don't agree with either of them.

Jane Hamilton
Bexhill on Sea, E Sussex

 To appease the children among us, couldn't we join the euro and call it a pound?

Andrew Moss
Greiveldange, Luxembourg

 To the marketing department responsible for the Dome sheep advert (Dome given new £53m subsidy, July 28): the British public will not be cowed into wasting any more of our money on this pig's ear. We will stay away in herds. Cheeky monkeys.

Matthew Conway
London

 For some time I have been wondering what happened to all the monkey puzzle trees. A few years ago they used to be a feature of all English gardens, especially in places like John Betjeman's lovely Metroland, but no longer. They are so uncommon that we have taken to shouting "monkey puzzle!" when out in the car so everyone can have the pleasure of the rare sighting of these marvellous trees.

Judy Martin
Judy Martin Literary Agency

fields.headline: Blind to genocide
fields.trailText: I read with anguish Maggie O'Kane's admirable article on the tragedy of Burma (The generals, G2, July 27) for a very personal reason: my dear son, James, is almost one year into a savage 17-year sentence to be served in solitary confinement and foul conditions.
fields.body:
I read with anguish Maggie O'Kane's admirable article on the tragedy of Burma (The generals, G2, July 27) for a very personal reason: my dear son, James, is almost one year into a savage 17-year sentence to be served in solitary confinement and foul conditions.

His "crime" was to peacefully express his concern for the suffering of the Burmese people.

James saw at first hand the result of the junta's atrocities. He lived for months in a camp for the internally displaced before it was torched by the Burmese army. Burma remains a signatory to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, yet tolerates no dissent and practises genocide. It remains a member of the International Labour Organisation and practises the brutality of slavery. Mr Jamieson of Premier Oil denies any accountability for the ethnic cleansing required to keep the oil pipeline. James met him last year and received the same answer as your newspaper - "he is unaware of any abuse". There are none so blind as those who will not see.

Diana Mawdsley
Brancepeth, Co Durham

Maggie O'Kane's article on the genocide against the Karen people brings much-needed publicity to the plight of this suffering minority. I secured a debate in parliament in April on this subject and urged the British government to ban all new investment in Burma by UK companies, as the US has done. Sadly, the British government continues to hesitate. The fact that Premier Oil has ignored the Foreign Office's calls for disinvestment proves that nothing short of a ban will stop their involvement.

The Karen people were our faithful allies during the second world war when the Japanese invaded Burma. Many were brutally tortured and killed for their loyalty to the British. How have we repaid them? By allowing British companies to get rich on their backs.

Edward Leigh MP
