webTitle: Racism strikes no chord at Womad

fields.headline: Racism strikes no chord at Womad
fields.trailText: Yes, do go back to Womad next year, Dea Birkett (Role reversal, G2, July 26). Try and arrive a little earlier, as the vast sea of tents is less daunting, and do camp.
fields.body:
Yes, do go back to Womad next year, Dea Birkett (Role reversal, G2, July 26). Try and arrive a little earlier, as the vast sea of tents is less daunting, and do camp. I took my daughter, Alice, then four, to her first Womad in Cornwall in 1988, having been to a few without her. She was furious to discover what she had missed and refused to be left with Granny ever again. Camping with children is wonderful because they are small ambassadors and soon get to know all the neighbours. Womad is not the same without the camaraderie of the campsite and it is the perfect place to learn to grow up.

My timid daughter took on another persona and was allowed the freedom I dared not allow at home. She could go shopping for the first time, alone among the stalls, clutching money saved all year. She experienced the independence I had in the 50s.

Over the years she learnt of many injustices from Kurdish singers, aborigines and the Cambodian dancers allowed abroad for the first time since the Vietnam war. I'm afraid I never managed the excellent children's workshops, but selfishly insisted that she watched the music. "You might not like this like you do Kylie," I whispered to a six-year-old Alice, as we listened to Mongolian throat singers, "but you're very privileged to see them." Coming from a very white, rural county, Womad was her introduction to a mixed-race society and she relished the friends she made, with wonderful heritages - some still friends 10 years later. I thought of this as I read, on site, about asylum seekers. There is no trace of xenophobia or racism there.

Illness forced her to stay at home this year and yes, I missed her company. I found myself eyeing up the gorgeous babies and toddlers and planning bringing future grandchildren - if she'll let me ...

Celia Bouquet
Exeter
celiabouquet@eurobell.co.uk

Camping with children is wonderful because they are small ambassadors and soon get to know all the neighbours. Womad is not the same without the camaraderie of the campsite and it is the perfect place to learn to grow up. My timid daughter took on another persona and was allowed the freedom I dared not allow at home. She could go shopping for the first time, alone among the stalls, clutching money saved all year. She experienced the independence I had in the 50s. Over the years she learnt of many injustices from Kurdish singers, aborigines and the Cambodian dancers allowed abroad for the first time since the Vietnam war. I'm afraid I never managed the excellent children's workshops, but selfishly insisted that she watched the music. "You might not like this like you do Kylie," I whispered to a six-year-old Alice, as we listened to Mongolian throat singers, "but you're very privileged to see them." Coming from a very white, rural county, Womad was her introduction to a mixed-race society and she relished the friends she made, with wonderful heritages - some still friends 10 years later. I thought of this as I read, on site, about asylum seekers. There is no trace of xenophobia or racism there. Illness forced her to stay at home this year and yes, I missed her company. I found myself eyeing up the gorgeous babies and toddlers and planning bringing future grandchildren - if she'll let me ... Celia Bouquet Exeter celiabouquet@eurobell.co.uk

webTitle: Government breaches own ban on gas-fired power stations

fields.headline: Government breaches own ban on gas-fired power stations
fields.trailText: The government has breached its own moratorium on new gas-fired power stations by giving the go-ahead for a combined heat and power plant on Anglesey - paving the way for an official lifting of the ban later this year.
fields.body:
The government has breached its own moratorium on new gas-fired power stations by giving the go-ahead for a combined heat and power plant on Anglesey - paving the way for an official lifting of the ban later this year.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has bowed to pressure from the national assembly for Wales in allowing Burlington Resources to build a 560MW gas-fired station at Rhosgoch. Mr Byers turned down its application last November because it would have broken the moratorium.

Welcoming the decision, Rhodri Morgan, the Welsh first secretary, said it would save 600 jobs at Anglesey Aluminium and Great Lakes Chemicals, two of the biggest employers on an island hit by unemployment.

The DTI insisted that the Rhosgoch decision was exceptional and had been made on economic and environmental grounds. The station is to be powered by gas brought in from Liverpool Bay which is said to be ecologically friendly.

But the move is likely to lead to renewals of the around two dozen applications for gas-fired stations held up by the moratorium imposed in late 1997 to protect the British coal industry, which was then undergoing a periodic crisis.

The moratorium is scheduled to be formally lifted on November 21, when the new electricity trading arrangements for the wholesale market should come into force, although there is scepticism in the industry that the IT systems will be ready.

Callum McCarthy, the energy regulator, said last week he saw no reason why the target date could not be met, and that the IT systems were expected to go live on August 14.

According to the government's annual energy statistics, published yesterday, gas accounted for 38.5% of Britain's power generation last year, compared with 15% in 1994. Coal's share sank to 28% from 48% five years before. Renewables accounted for 2.8% compared with 1.5% in 1994 and Helen Liddell, the energy minister, said the industry was on course to meet targets of 5% by 2003 and 10% by 2010.

A former National Power station in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire - now up for sale - could be converted to "renewable" energy. The station was closed in 1998 after National Power abandoned a £500m plan to convert the oil-fired plant to orimulsion, the so-called dirty fuel, in the face of environmental objections.

Separately, Texaco is to invest £44m in its Pembroke oil refinery to bring ultra-low sulphur petrol on stream. The first green fuel of its kind in Europe, the petrol should flow from the end of 2001 - four years ahead of an EU deadline.

webTitle: Sir Brian Pitman leaves Lloyds TSB

fields.headline: Sir Brian bows out after 50 years
fields.trailText: After a career of almost 50 years with Lloyds TSB, Sir Brian Pitman was in a jovial mood yesterday when he described the process of finding his successor as chairman as akin to choosing a wife.
fields.body:
After a career of almost 50 years with Lloyds TSB, Sir Brian Pitman was in a jovial mood yesterday when he described the process of finding his successor as chairman as akin to choosing a wife.

The elder statesman of the industry, who has been struggling with his bank's weak share price over recent months, is to bow out at the annual general meeting next April.

"It's been enormous fun," said Sir Brian, whose presentations to the City have often become lectures on the entire banking industry since his appointment as chief executive in 1983 and elevation to chairman in 1997.

Sir Brian, who will be 69 when he retires, has won plaudits in the City for his mantra about shareholder value, a holy grail which his successor Maarten van den Bergh, until recently president of Royal Dutch Petroleum, repeated yesterday.

Sir Brian has also become the City's arch-dealmaker, gobbling up building society Cheltenham & Gloucester, the TSB, and more recently mutual insurance company Scottish Widows.

Sir Brian has had his share of difficulties, too, failing with a hostile bid for Standard Chartered and having to face up the problems of the bank's poor lending decisions in Latin America in the 1980s.

He still carries a trace of his Gloucestershire accent, having grown up in Cheltenham, where he says his enjoyments were team sports and the trombone.

Recounting a tale yesterday about his friend "Spider" who went on to become a professional trombonist, Sir Brian said that whether playing in an orchestra, on the sports field or in the boardroom it was team spirit that he had enjoyed most.

He has a clutch of non-executive positions already in the bag: chairman of Next and on the board of Carlton Communications and Tomkins. Tantalisingly, Sir Brian promises that in "due course" he will be announcing more "interesting things".

fields.headline: City Centre's dish
fields.trailText: Shares in beleaguered City Centre Restaurants experienced a rare rally yesterday after an overhang of stock from an institution keen to reduce its holding was finally swallowed up.
fields.body:
Shares in beleaguered City Centre Restaurants experienced a rare rally yesterday after an overhang of stock from an institution keen to reduce its holding was finally swallowed up.

The shares rose by 11% to 53.5p, with more than 9m shares being traded. At the start of the year the shares traded at 80p.

Does yesterday's rise signal a return to favour for the group that owns the Cafe Uno, Deep Pan Pizza and Garfunkels franchises? The whispers are that Deep Pan is performing better now it has been spruced up and staff morale has improved.

But the quoted restaurant sector has a bitter taste to it at the moment, with the shares of several operators struggling.

City Centres' market valuation is down to around £100m, and yet it has a portfolio of around 300 restaurants. It may be worth buying one share - a shareholder offer entitles you to 25% off the bill at Garfunkels.

fields.headline: No defence
fields.trailText: David Burnside (Letters, July 28) challenges the evidence I established of his career in the Ulster Defence Regiment (Unsavoury loyalist, July 27).
fields.body:
David Burnside (Letters, July 28) challenges the evidence I established of his career in the Ulster Defence Regiment (Unsavoury loyalist, July 27). He was pictured and quoted in the UDA's August 1975 Ulster Defender, warning that "the people will have to take steps to defend themselves" against the "communist threat". Such pronouncements were judged by the British army to be incompatible with his role as a part-time member of the UDR, and led to his departure. If, as he claims, he "resigned", why did Belfast newspapers report his subsequent appeal which made the matter public? As he seeks to resurrect his career at Westminster, voters of South Antrim would be wise to treat his version of his history in the UDR with scepticism.

Martyn Gregory
London

webTitle: Market forces: Mood is downwardly mobile

fields.headline: Mood is downwardly mobile
fields.trailText: Cautious words from mobile company Nokia on Thursday were causing real pain in London yesterday, spoiling most brokers' chances of deciding it was too hot and sticky to do any work and therefore slipping off for a long lunch before the weekend.
fields.body:
Cautious words from mobile company Nokia on Thursday were causing real pain in London yesterday, spoiling most brokers' chances of deciding it was too hot and sticky to do any work and therefore slipping off for a long lunch before the weekend.

Almost anything with a telecoms feel was given a thumping, wiping some 151p off Colt Telecom , for example, to £21.90 and slicing 11.5p from market heavyweight Vodafone to 280p.

Vodafone has changed its name, having dropped "AirTouch" after shareholders voted on the matter at this week's annual meeting.

There was a similar levels of angst in parts of the banking sector, where almost every trading session since the beginning of the interim reporting season a little over a week ago has seen waves of selling. Yesterday, the bears were picking on HSBC , which shed 18p to 885p, Standard Chartered , which closed 24p lower at 920p, and Bank of Scotland , off 10p at 533p.

The net effect of all this was an unstable FTSE 100, which rapidly lost an early 40-point advance to close 16.4 points lower at 6335.7.

There was increasing nervousness later in the day as the latest economic data from the United States revived fears of further interest rate rises on the other side of the Atlantic, causing a particularly heavy sell-off on the Nasdaq high-technology exchange.

This quickly fed through in to Britain's hi-tech sector. Among the leaders the pure software companies were strangely mixed. While Logica and Sema were following the downward trend set by the US Nasdaq, quickly falling more than 3% apiece, Misys - which specialises in financial software - made good early progress after this week's figures, adding 24p to 684p at one stage before a 660.5p close.

The results came in a little below expectations, but a strong accompanying trading statement, indicating that the slowdown caused by the Y2K bug debacle is coming to an end, has helped sentiment. Meanwhile Logica closed at £17.60, down 55p, and Sema shed 36p to £10.49.

Against this, the big drug companies led what support there was for the main index, with merger partners Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline gaining 45p to £19.55 and 23p to 875p respectively. An 11.5p advance by BP Amoco - which is due to lose the "Amoco" part of its name - to 593.5p also helped the Footsie.

Engineering group Babcock International announced at its annual meeting yesterday that, in order to focus on its support and defence services, a number of disposals are in the pipeline and part of the cash raised, around £30m, will be returned to shareholders. The shares added 5.5p to 98p.

The Nokia effect could be seen on Filtronic , which makes parts for mobile telephone networks. The firm's shares shed 72.5p to 862.5p.

A few late bid speculators in pumps and valves specialist Weir Group had their fingers burned. A couple of newspaper tips saw the stock surge to 225p. But the supposed suitor, a Swiss technology firm named Sulzer, issued a denial and the price reversed to 212p - still up 13.5p on balance.

Utilitec , which supplies electronic equipment to water and gas companies, put its corporate hands up and declared the best way of returning value to shareholders was to take the £13m group private.The management is offering 18p a share. The market price, which trades on a ridiculously wide buy-sell spread of 14p-17p, added 2p to 15.5p in the middle of trade.

The ceramic bathroom accessories group Longmead dropped 4p to 19.5p after warning that second half results would not match first half trading. Similarly, a profits warning from the IT staff consultant Higham Systems saw 7p sliced from its shares, leaving them at 36.5p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
Nortel busy net traffic firm Canada's Nortel Networks said yesterday it is paying $7.8bn (£5.2bn) in stock to acquire Alteon WebSystems, a maker of equipment and software that directs the flow of internet traffic. Alteon reported revenues of $51.5m for the three months ending on June 30, a rise of 82% on the previous quarter. Customers include Yahoo! and ExciteAtHome. Nortel said the purchase would help it integrate net data centres with its optical and wireless network equipment.

The announcement came a day after the collapse of talks for the sale of Nortel's optical components business to Corning in a deal potentially worth $100bn.

Redstone in £18m deal

Business telecom provider Redstone Network Services has bought Touchbase Network for up to £18m in cash, parent company Redstone Telecom said yesterday.

It added that the purchase would increase traffic volumes, provide a home counties presence and build its customer base and sales force.

An initial payment of £6m will be made on completion of the purchase from Touchbase Group and other shareholders, while two further payments will depend on future revenues.

Marconi moves into Europe

British electronics company Marconi said yesterday it was buying Albany Partnership, a Europe-wide provider of wireless network services, for £71.4m in shares, loan notes and cash.

Albany Partnership's customers include all Britain's mobile operators, and its services include construction of aerial masts and acquisition of suitable sites for them. The company made pre-tax profits of £2.4m on revenue of £19.4m in the year to April 30, 2000.

Hong Kong ISP lays off 80

Tom.com, a net portal firm whose initial public offering generated such excitement in February that it nearly triggered riots, yesterday confirmed that it fired 80 Hong Kong-based employees to boost its competitiveness.

The move was the latest of a string of layoffs made by local internet firms after the sector's aggressive expansion, and came on the heels of City Telecom's decision on Thursday to cut 200 jobs at its broadband internet branch.

Aventis reports surge in sales

Franco-German life sciences firm Aventis reported better than expected first-half 2000 sales and a surge in its Aventis Pharma drug division's US sales yesterday. Aventis, formed last December from the merger of Germany's Hoechst and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer of France, posted an 11.6% rise in first half sales to €10.245bn (£6.3bn) from €9.179bn in 1999's first half. This was made up of 17.6% sales growth at Aventis Pharma to €7.794bn and a 4.4% slide in sales at Aventis Agriculture to €2.49bn in the period.

fields.headline: Lloyds aims for overseas expansion
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB is to embark on major overseas expansion following the announcement yesterday of a new chairman, who is not a banker.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB is to embark on major overseas expansion following the announcement yesterday of a new chairman, who is not a banker.

Maarten van den Bergh, a former president of Royal Dutch Petroleum, will join Lloyds TSB's board in October before becoming chairman next year. He is expected to help the bank deliver the prime acquisition or merger in the US or Europe that it has been seeking for the past several months.

Lloyds TSB, which has already built its presence in Britain through a series of acquisitions - the most recent being Scottish Widows - has not ruled out further deals in Britain to boost its presence in the sectors where it has not already large enough to attract the attention of the regulators.

This suggests the bank might look to pounce in the area of mortgages, life and pensions and credit cards.

The bank, whose shares have slumped in recent months over concerns that it has lost its appetite for further expansion, insisted that its lower stock market valuation would not prevent it pulling off an agreed deal. It has generated its profits in the past by squeezing out costs through the acquisitions.

Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, said: "Maarten has led a lot of change [in the oil industry] and has great international experience. If you look at this organisation in the next five to 10 years, its expansion is inevitably going to be focused overseas for the big deal."

He insisted, though, that the bank would not be rushed into making acquisitions and would not drop its criteria to make deals work.

His comments came as the bank reported a 12% rise in pre-tax profits in the first six months of the year to £2bn and revealed that sales of life and pensions products had slowed at its new acquisition Scottish Widows.

The bank committed itself, however, to a growth in sales of 15% in the coming month when sales of Scottish Widows products started to flow through from its branches.

Independent financial advisers, the bank said, were continuing to support the brand even though there had been speculation that they would be reluctant to sell products which were also being sold in branches. Its shares, which have halved in a year, gained 14p to close at £6 yesterday.

Mr Ellwood predicted a move towards offering customers "value-based accounts" which provided insurance, for instance, as well as basic banking services.

He also said that he would be "quite surprised" if the competition commission inquiry into small and medium sized business banking led to any major regulatory changes when it is completed in a year.

The bank, which is developing a new internet bank called Evolve for launch in Spain later this year, will pay an interim dividend of 9.3p.

fields.headline: Amstrad to make mobiles
fields.standfirst: Sugar will supply Virgin with handsets as Branson loses control of internet venture
fields.trailText: Sir Alan Sugar's Amstrad consumer electronics firm is to start making mobile phones and is understood to be in negotiations with Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Mobile about becoming its first major customer.
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar's Amstrad consumer electronics firm is to start making mobile phones and is understood to be in negotiations with Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Mobile about becoming its first major customer.

The first handsets are likely to go on sale in time for the Christmas buying season. Amstrad hopes that their low price, small size, innovative design and ease of use will differentiate them from products offered by multinational competitors such as Nokia and Ericsson.

Virgin is likely to put its own brand on the new phones, while Sir Alan is thought to be discussing similar deals with overseas mobile operators. It is thought that a range of phones will be made available, some with internet access.

Amstrad will be a relatively late entrant into an already crowded market but is confident that its product will differentiate itself enough to enable it to sign contracts with several domestic and overseas operators.

Sir Alan has been looking for a mass-market consumer electronics product for some time and he is thought to have first approached Sir Richard about making phones for Virgin Mobile earlier this year.

At the end of March Sir Alan introduced the e-m@iler, a fixed-line telephone with email capabilities targeted at people who are unable to cope with computers.

He bullishly predicted sales of 1m units within two years and dismissed the threat of internet-enabled mobile phones as a rival delivery mechanism for email.

Shares in Amstrad had climbed sharply before the e-m@iler launch, trading at around 600p. They have fallen sharply since, last night closing down 4.5p at 206.5p.

Analysts predicted the £79.99 e-m@iler would face stiff competition from developments in mobile phones and digital televisions which are likely to offer broader access to the net.

It is unclear whether the new mobile phones will rival the e-m@iler or target an entirely different market niche. Dixons has since paid £15m for a 20% stake in the new business.

Amstrad has had an internal development team working on the phones since the start of this year. The team is made up of seasoned mobile phone developers from some of the industry's largest manufacturers.

Separately, Virgin yesterday confirmed that its partnership with NTL over Virgin Net, the internet service provider, is coming to an end. The parting of ways comes at a time of rapid consolidation and strong competition in the internet access market.

NTL will take the customer base, with Virgin taking control of the entertainment and leisure content side of the business. NTL is paying an estimated £100m for the ISP's 400,000 subscribers. The payment will comprise 10% cash with the remainder in NTL stock. The deal makes NTL's dial-up internet customer base the third-largest in Britain, after Freeserve and AOL.

Virgin Net is valued at around £240m and Virgin had been keen to roll the entire business into its Virgin.com portal, in which NTL would have been given shares. NTL vetoed that but will give Virgin.com a presence on the interactive digital television service it is rolling out to customers.

The corporate structure of Virgin.com is proving tricky to resolve. Several of Virgin's partners saw flotation as the preferred exit route for their investments. But Virgin would prefer that companies exchange their stakes for shares in Virgin.com which could be floated as a multi-billion pound stand-alone enterprise over the next 18 months.

webTitle: Sales driven:  VW profits increase by half

fields.headline: Sales driven:  VW profits increase by half
fields.trailText: Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker yesterday reported a rise in net profits of 48% for the first half year at DM1.25bn (£403m), compared with analysts' forecasts of DM1bn. Revenue also rose by 12% to DM83.3bn, sending shares higher.
fields.body:
Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker yesterday reported a rise in net profits of 48% for the first half year at DM1.25bn (£403m), compared with analysts' forecasts of DM1bn. Revenue also rose by 12% to DM83.3bn, sending shares higher.

The company gave an optimistic assessment for the remainder of the year, in sharp contrast to DaimlerChrysler, which earlier this week said it expected profits to come under pressure.

"The first-half profit met our expectations. We reaffirm our assessment that that we will be able to achieve significant earnings growth for the full year 2000," VW said.

The company's shares have underperformed the broader market this year, however, falling around 12.5% since January before yesterday's rise.

Analysts said the first-half results were unlikely to trigger a lasting turnaround for the share.

Merck Finck analyst Pia-Christine Schulze said: "I don't see any fundamental reason to buy the shares. From registration figures, VW has been losing market share to Renault and Peugeot."

Figures from the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association showed that VW's European market share fell to 18.2% in the first six months of the year from 19% a year earlier.

Some analysts have felt that feel Volkswagen's pallet of brands, which include the Audi, Seat and Skoda marques as well as its own VW models, have eaten into each other's markets.

Photograph: Fabian Bimmer

fields.headline: The last word on   moralising
fields.standfirst: A man who moralises is usually a hypocrite -   Oscar Wilde
fields.trailText: A man who moralises is usually a hypocrite - Oscar Wilde
fields.body:
Much moralising accompanied the House of Lords' refusal to repeal section 28 this week. Lady Young claimed that to oppose repeal was to "speak up for parents and children". Lady Blatch saw repeal as a wedge's thin end: trans-sexual marriages and adoptions, lowering the gay age of consent, and in general "relaxing the laws", as she said with a shudder, "as they relate to gays and lesbians and for people cruising on our public roads for sex". She thereby illustrated how section 28's supporters think: it is their Vietnam, the place where the rot must be stopped.

Section 28 outlaws the "promotion" of homosexuality in schools by local authorities. No prosecution has even been initiated under its terms, and local authorities no longer run schools. Supporters of section 28 are therefore making a purely symbolic gesture in retaining it. It is their way of manifesting hostility to lifestyles they personally dislike, and of trying to impose instead a traditionalist fantasy of "family morality" to which they cling for equally personal reasons. They claim to represent the majority of public opinion - an unreliable beast that few of them would wish to represent on other questions - but that is a dishonest manoeuvre. Their true motives are explained by the fact that they are nothing more or less than a highly questionable form of mallophage which infests the body politic: viz moralisers.

When the body politic is immune to moralisers they merely appear comical - as prigs and curmudgeons, who complain and blame, stamping their feet and waving umbrellas in outrage at whatever is different from themselves - or whatever comes too close to their own guilty desires. When the body politic is not immune to them they are a menace, causing not just general inflammation and irritation in society, but downright misery to the people whose ways of life are different from their own.

A moraliser is a person who seeks to impose upon others his view of how they should live and behave. Everyone is entitled to a view about what counts as acceptable behaviour, and everyone is entitled to put it forward as eloquently and forcefully as he can. But moralisers go much further. They want others to conform to their views, and they seek to bring this about by coercion - employing means that range from social disapproval to legal control, this latter being their preferred option.

In forcing others to comply with their preferences, they show at least several of the following: insensitivity, intolerance, unkindness, lack of imagination, failure of sympathy, absence of understanding, ignorance of alternative interests and needs in human experience, and arrogance in believing that theirs is the only acceptable way. They defend their actions by saying that they are trying to protect others from harm, thereby claiming not only a monopoly on moral judgment, but the right to decide on others' behalf what is good for them.

There are two key nodes in the moralising defence of section 28. One is its defence of the "traditional family" and the other is its status as the place where the line has to be drawn.

The folly and pretension of the latter speak for them selves. The former is more complex. To defend that historical recent arrival, the "traditional family", is to impugn all those who do not live in traditional families. It is to pass judgment on single-parent families, whose problem is not how many parents live in the household, but how few resources such households typically have. It is to pass judgment on households where two loving adults care for children, if those adults are not of different sexes. It is to pass judgment on households where three or more adults live together as spouses, with or without children, and irrespective of whether they are happy and flourishing people. "Family" is also a code for sexual control, denoting hostility to anything other than the kind of sex that arch-moralisers like Lady Young and Lady Blatch are prepared to tolerate - if anything so jejune merits the name.

They and their beloved section 28 put one in mind of Clarence Day's dictum that "too many moralists begin with a dislike of reality". But the reality after this week's vote is that the moralisers are on top. Let us hope that the situation is temporary.

fields.headline: Oscar Shumsky
fields.standfirst: American violinist held in awe for his technical virtuosity, lyrical playing and musical memory
fields.trailText: The American violinist Oscar Shumsky, who has died aged 83, was regarded by many musicians as one of the greatest 20th-century exponents of his instrument.
fields.body:
The American violinist Oscar Shumsky, who has died aged 83, was regarded by many musicians as one of the greatest 20th-century exponents of his instrument.

His intensely communicative yet refined playing combined the grand romantic tradition of Russian-Jewish violinists with the same dash of eloquence that characterised the playing of his idol, Fritz Kreisler. His immaculate technical command was legendary, and his lyrical playing was distinguished by a luscious warmth and highly expressive intonation. His musical memory was staggering; he could play entire passages of an orchestral score on the violin.

Born to Russian immigrant parents in Philadelphia, Shumsky began studying the violin at the age of three. His outstanding talent was recognised early, and, in an era of such remarkable prodigies as Yehudi Menuhin, Ruggiero Ricci and Guila Bustabo, he held his own.

After playing to Leopold Stokowski, the conductor pronounced the young violinist "the most astounding genius I have ever heard", and, in 1925, invited Shumsky to appear as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Mozart's Violin Concerto No 5 in A major. Later that year, Shumsky began studying privately in New York with the renowned violin pedagogue Leopold Auer, who had taught Heifetz, Elman, Milstein and Efrem Zimbalist, father of the film star.

As a child, Shumsky performed several hundred concerts, often appearing with the pianist and conductor Ernest Schelling, the founder of a series of young people's symphony concerts. On one occasion, Schelling arranged for Shumsky to play to Fritz Kreisler. After performing several pieces, he gave the great Austrian violinist a surprise by playing Kreisler's then unpublished solo cadenza for the first movement of the Beethoven Violin Concerto. Shumsky had heard Kreisler perform the concerto twice in concert, and had reconstructed the cadenza from memory. Deeply impressed, Kreisler predicted that the young prodigy would become one of the finest violinists of the century.

In the autumn of 1925, Shumsky enrolled at the prestigious Curtis Institute of Music in his home town, where he joined Auer's violin class. After Auer's death in 1930, he continued his studies at Curtis with Zimbalist In 1939, Shumsky was personally invited by Arturo Toscanini to join the newly-formed NBC Symphony, where he remained for two years.

At the same time, the great viola-player William Primrose asked him to lead the Primrose Quartet as first violin (with Josef Gingold as second violin and Harvey Shapiro on the cello). To this day, the quartet's commercial recordings of Haydn, Schumann, Brahms and Smetana are prized by connoisseurs of chamber music.

After serving in the US navy during the second world war, Shumsky resumed his concert career as a soloist. He was also in great demand for studio work, and often led the RCA Victor Symphony and Columbia Symphony orchestras. Later, he was appointed as solo violinist for the NBC network in New York. During this golden age of American radio, he was featured weekly as soloist in radio broadcasts, often accompanied by Earl Wild at the piano.

In 1959, he became co-director, with the pianist Glenn Gould, of the Stratford festival in Canada. They performed frequently in duo sonatas, and were often joined by the cellist Leonard Rose in trios. During these years, Shumsky began performing on the viola as well, and began to conduct. He also established himself as a superb teacher at the Curtis, Juilliard and Peabody conservatoires, as well as at Yale University. His students included Steven Staryk, Elliot Chapo, Ida Kavafian, Eugene Drucker and Philip Setzer, the last two members of the Emerson Quartet.

Shumsky's primary instrument was the 1715 "Rode, ex-Duke of Cambridge" Stradivarius, but he also used a modern Italian violin by Enrico Rocca. His recorded legacy includes the unaccompanied sonatas by Bach and Ysaÿe, concertos by Bach, Mozart, Beethoven and Glazunov, the complete Mozart violin sonatas (with Artur Balsam) and sonatas by Brahms, Grieg, Dohnanyi and Leo Weiner. He also made several discs of short pieces by Kreisler and the complete Brahms Hungarian Dances. Apart from music, he had a keen interest in woodworking and a passion for photography.

As a musician, Shumsky was intensely focused. He was intolerant of showmanship; for him, music was not entertainment, and he abhorred the showbiz antics that characterised many musical performances in the late 20th century. His artistic demands could sometimes intimidate colleagues and students, and his uncompromising attitude would occasionally work to his disadvantage.

Fortunately, in the autumn of his career, Shumsky was rewarded by a renewed interest in his artistry. In the early 1980s, he resumed giving concerts after an absence of over 45 years. His appearances throughout Britain and continental Europe were an overwhelming success, prompting the London-based critic Dominic Gill to proclaim the most memorable musical events of 1982 as appearances by "Horowitz, Michelangeli and Shumsky".

Although he never became a household name like Heifetz or Perlman, Oscar Shumsky was the quintessential "violinist's violinist". As Eugene Drucker remarked: "I will never forget his uncompromising personal integrity, his continual quest for musical substance rather than surface gesture, his encyclopaedic knowledge of the violin repertoire and his magnificent command of the instrument. There will never be another like him."

Shumsky is survived by two sons, Noel and Eric, the latter a distinguished viola-player.

Oscar Shumsky, violinist, born March 23 1917; died July 24 2000

fields.headline: Brave words
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... our new guidelines on unattributed quotes
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... our new guidelines on unattributed quotes
fields.body:
The editor of the Guardian has now formulated his guidelines on attribution in reporting Downing Street briefings, on the use of anonymous pejorative quotes, and on other unattributable quotes.

The guidelines express an attempt to blow away some of the fog. Too often we ask you to listen to people speaking without telling you who they are, precisely where they are or with what authority they speak. Worse than that, we sometimes collude with these unidentified individuals, granting them anonymity and at the same time providing the platform from which they make nasty and perhaps damaging remarks about someone else.

I will cram into this column as full an account of the guidelines as I can. They should be posted in full on our website early next week. I repeat what I said in my last column, that we know that they make us vulnerable to criticism for the lapses from them that will undoubtedly occur. The editor recognises this at the end of his draft when he says, "This is a counsel of perfection." He adds, "We will sometimes, for any number of reasons, slip below these standards. That doesn't mean we shouldn't aspire to them_ Over time, the more careful and watchful we are, the more we will be trusted - by both readers and sources."

On Downing Street briefings, Guardian staff are now told unequivocally: "We will name the official briefer when he/she is speaking on the record to the collected lobby." The editor points out that this is simply taking the next logical step beyond the position recently arrived at, where we have either named the speaker at lobby briefings or referred to him in such terms as "the prime minister's official spokesman".

He makes the point that not naming the briefer would be to foster the pretence that Alastair Campbell, "an intensely committed New Labour partisan", is the same sort of animal as his deputy Godric Smith. Mr Smith, he reminds Guardian journalists, is a member of the Government Information Service (GIS), which requires his statements to be "objective and explanatory, not tendentious or polemical_ or liable to misrepresentation as being party political".

He says the paper will keep an open mind on whether or not to extend the policy to other areas of political reporting.

I believe that most of you will welcome the restrictions placed on the use of anonymous pejorative quotes, about which I have written a couple of times in this column, in response to complaints from readers. If I had to sum up the reasons why they are so disliked I would say it is because they attack our sense of fair play.

The editor now says that they will be allowed in future only in exceptional and rare circumstances, and then only after consultation with the senior editor of the day.

He says, "In taking the decision whether to allow the quote, the editor might consider such factors as: is the source a respected person who is well placed to pass judgment on the subject in question? Does he/she have direct or indirect knowledge? Is it authoritative? In so far as one can judge, what are his or her motives in a) speaking pejoratively of someone and b) demanding anonymity? Can a public-interest case be made for including the information in direct quotes?"

In the absence of specific approval, he says, journalists should paraphrase anonymous pejorative quotes. He quotes from the New York Times manual of style and usage, to which I referred last week: "The vivid language of direct quotation confers an unfair advantage on a speaker or writer who hides behind the newspaper, and turns of phrase are valueless to a reader who cannot assess the source."

In his guidelines on the use of unattributed quotes in general, the editor recognises that there are circumstances in which people will speak more honestly if allowed to do so anonymously. "But if used lazily or indiscriminately, anonymous quotes become a menace," he says. "Readers - with an increasingly sophisticated understanding of spin - distrust them. The more they are used, the more readers discount them. This becomes an obstacle between us and our readers. For this, if for no other reason, we should be careful about our use of anonymous quotes. The most obvious requirement of a story is that it is true. But it is also important that it is believed."

He emphasises the importance of honesty in describing anonymous sources. "It is best to be as specific as possible. 'One MP', or 'a government colleague' is so weak as to be meaningless. 'Senior minister' is an advance. 'Cabinet minister with direct knowledge of the negotiations' is better still. By now the reader can genuinely evaluate the worth of the remark."

At another point he says, "Think of the poor reader and try to give him/her some help."

 Your views are welcome. You may email the editor directly: alan.rusbridger@ theguardian.com, or contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. The editor recognises this at the end of his draft when he says, "This is a counsel of perfection." He adds, "We will sometimes, for any number of reasons, slip below these standards. That doesn't mean we shouldn't aspire to them_ Over time, the more careful and watchful we are, the more we will be trusted - by both readers and sources." On Downing Street briefings, Guardian staff are now told unequivocally: "We will name the official briefer when he/she is speaking on the record to the collected lobby." The editor points out that this is simply taking the next logical step beyond the position recently arrived at, where we have either named the speaker at lobby briefings or referred to him in such terms as "the prime minister's official spokesman". He makes the point that not naming the briefer would be to foster the pretence that Alastair Campbell, "an intensely committed New Labour partisan", is the same sort of animal as his deputy Godric Smith. Mr Smith, he reminds Guardian journalists, is a member of the Government Information Service (GIS), which requires his statements to be "objective and explanatory, not tendentious or polemical_ or liable to misrepresentation as being party political". He says the paper will keep an open mind on whether or not to extend the policy to other areas of political reporting. I believe that most of you will welcome the restrictions placed on the use of anonymous pejorative quotes, about which I have written a couple of times in this column, in response to complaints from readers. If I had to sum up the reasons why they are so disliked I would say it is because they attack our sense of fair play. The editor now says that they will be allowed in future only in exceptional and rare circumstances, and then only after consultation with the senior editor of the day. He says, "In taking the decision whether to allow the quote, the editor might consider such factors as: is the source a respected person who is well placed to pass judgment on the subject in question? Does he/she have direct or indirect knowledge? Is it authoritative? In so far as one can judge, what are his or her motives in a) speaking pejoratively of someone and b) demanding anonymity? Can a public-interest case be made for including the information in direct quotes?" In the absence of specific approval, he says, journalists should paraphrase anonymous pejorative quotes. He quotes from the New York Times manual of style and usage, to which I referred last week: "The vivid language of direct quotation confers an unfair advantage on a speaker or writer who hides behind the newspaper, and turns of phrase are valueless to a reader who cannot assess the source." In his guidelines on the use of unattributed quotes in general, the editor recognises that there are circumstances in which people will speak more honestly if allowed to do so anonymously. "But if used lazily or indiscriminately, anonymous quotes become a menace," he says. "Readers - with an increasingly sophisticated understanding of spin - distrust them. The more they are used, the more readers discount them. This becomes an obstacle between us and our readers. For this, if for no other reason, we should be careful about our use of anonymous quotes. The most obvious requirement of a story is that it is true. But it is also important that it is believed." He emphasises the importance of honesty in describing anonymous sources. "It is best to be as specific as possible. 'One MP', or 'a government colleague' is so weak as to be meaningless. 'Senior minister' is an advance. 'Cabinet minister with direct knowledge of the negotiations' is better still. By now the reader can genuinely evaluate the worth of the remark." At another point he says, "Think of the poor reader and try to give him/her some help."  Your views are welcome. webTitle: Darling, you were divine, superb, wonderful...

fields.headline: Darling, you were divine, superb, wonderful...
fields.standfirst: Simon Hoggart's Diary
fields.trailText: More letters from Wigan | Bye, bye Betty
fields.body:
News from the US, where folk are buying a new book , You're Too Kind - a Brief History Of Flattery, by Richard Stengel. I've made a bit of a study of the subject myself. There are two things you need to know: first, lay it on thick, because people will always believe half of what you tell them. If you say to someone, "You know, you're the most fascinating person I've ever met," they will naturally think, "Well, that's nonsense - but I must be in the top 10." "I have never heard a more brilliant speech" translates in people's heads as "That was pretty good, at least for you."

The most successful flatterer I know of this type is Sir David Frost ("super stuff, really super") - and of course I've told him so many times. Gyles Brandreth is also absolutely marvellous.

The other trick is to be very specific. Mr Stengel says that if you meet Tom Hanks, you shouldn't tell him you liked Forrest Gump, but that you adored one particular tracking shot in another film. So don't just say, "Your Hamlet was quite, quite dazzling"; add, "You know, my friend Jed normally hates Shakespeare, but I persuaded him to come anyway, and the Yorick scene - I shouldn't tell you this, I suppose, but it made him cry." Don't tell a writer that you loved his or her book; say instead, "That extended metaphor in chapter seven - I don't know how you did it!"

 Normally, the news that a married father of three had been caught by police in a gay sting operation would call for nothing but sympathy for him and his family. This feeling is tempered when the victim turns out to be Barry Hinkley, known as "the corporate rottweiler" at Stagecoach, the predatory transport company, which among its sins runs our dismal local train service. Mr Hinkley was in Houston, Texas, when he answered an ad covertly placed by the cops, and asked for a black male prostitute to be sent round to his hotel room.

Mr Hinkley, whose business philosophy includes the line "You can't afford to pay people for an hour's tea break or a meal break", asked for full sex, whereupon his visitor revealed himself to be a police officer. (It is heartening to know that the crime rate in Houston is now so low that the police can spend time setting up elaborate traps for visiting gay businessmen.)

He resigned after being suspended by Brian Souter, the multi-millionaire head of Stagecoach, who, by a wonderful, glorious irony, is the man who spent £1m of his own money (it used to be our money, before he got his hands on all those massive taxpayer subsidies) on trying to prevent the Scottish parliament from repealing clause 28 - which, thank heavens, they did anyway.

Mr Hinkley must be feeling dreadful now. But his feelings will be as nothing to the combined misery he has inflicted on travellers and on sacked employees. As a card-carrying, paid-up, tolerant, Guardian-reading, Guardian-writing, soggy liberal, I fear that the only reasonable reaction to his plight is a great big raspberry and a belly laugh.

 Letters keep arriving from Wigan, the Périgord of the north. I really must make a point of going there during the parliamentary recess, and would be grateful for advice on any gourmet establishments where I might savour the local cuisine. Writing in the Manchester Evening News, Andrew Grimes enquires: "What does a Wiganer expect in a mixed grill? A meat pie, a meat-and-potato pie, and a pasty."

This week I found myself taking the ring road round Andover, a pleasant market town in Hampshire. I was delighted to see that the town's many roundabouts had been elaborately decorated with plantings of flowers. It was just like the old days, when members of the parks department would spend weeks making the most elaborate displays as a matter of civic pride, and a fine example of public spending for communal pleasure.

Then I noticed that this wasn't the case at all. All the lovingly assembled floral tributes were, in fact, set up by local firms as advertisements for themselves; the petals spelled out "Twining", "Meritire", "Papst" and "AJT". It was such a perversion of this nice old British tradition that I drove on with a heavy heart. Nothing, nothing at all in our national life, is now free from the admen.

 I watched Mo Mowlam's appearance on You Only Live Once on BBC1 this week. She was smart, funny and astute. Nick Hancock, with the usual Hat Trick Productions bundle of pre-scripted jokes, kept trying to trip her up, but on each occasion she either capped him or ignored him. It was an impressively poised performance on what must be a terribly difficult show.

In the same week we learned that Peter Mandelson is refusing to repay the £11,000 he received when he resigned from his job as industry secretary because of his extremely unwise financial dealings. This is in spite of the fact that he got another cabinet place only 10 months later. The contrast between the dignity of the last Ulster secretary and the whiff of sleaze that clings like camphor to the present one could hardly be more marked.

 Have you noticed how the royals are becoming irredeemably naff? It was the embarrassing barbecue scene in the TV film Royal Family which, I suspect, started us on to the long slide to supermarkets full of Quik-Lite charcoal briquettes, Insta-Grills and packets of bones coated thinly with fluorescent orange meat substance. This week we learned that the Queen now sends out to the Pr t à Manger chain for sandwiches for the staff, freeing them to spend more time cooking delectable meals for her (I recommend a Wigan chip pie with added gravy).

I read this news as I morosely munched a rather dull Pr t a Manger beef sandwich for which I had been charged £3.49. "It's because you're eating it here," said the grumpy assistant, though "here" meant a rickety table on the pavement outside as the wind howled down the Tottenham Court Road, dumping a glop of mustard-flavoured mayonnaise in my lap. Once the royal crest signified quality; now it seems to say, "About to become a down-market brand".

webTitle: Obituary: Walter Ingham, skier and entrepreneur

fields.headline: Walter Ingham
fields.standfirst: Skiing enthusiast in at the start of the winter sports holiday boom
fields.trailText: Walter Ingham, who has died aged 86, was a pioneer of skiing as a leisure activity, and of the postwar mass travel phenomenon. He was among a handful of entrepreneurs who spotted early the new demand for organised foreign holidays. Though he had retired before the explosion in package travel really began, he helped change winter sports from a pursuit enjoyed almost exclusively by the upper middle classes to a passion which ran throughout the social spectrum.
fields.body:
Walter Ingham, who has died aged 86, was a pioneer of skiing as a leisure activity, and of the postwar mass travel phenomenon. He was among a handful of entrepreneurs who spotted early the new demand for organised foreign holidays. Though he had retired before the explosion in package travel really began, he helped change winter sports from a pursuit enjoyed almost exclusively by the upper middle classes to a passion which ran throughout the social spectrum.

Ingham was born in Vienna, where his parents had moved after eloping. His father worked as south-east European manager for the Remington typewriter company, and it was at school in Austria that his love of skiing, climbing and sailing was born. His parents, who had hoped he would apply himself more rigorously to academic studies, were less than delighted. In 1932, Walter returned to England to work as a salesman, also for Remington. "Very soon," he wrote later, "I found that selling typewriters gave no job satisfaction and no skiing."

He discovered that if he took a party of 15 people to the Alps, he could get a free rail ticket and hotel room into the bargain. In 1934, then living in a Kensington bedsitter, he left Remington with £25 in capital and placed small ads in newspapers. That Christmas he took his first group to the Tyrol; by the end of the season, he had organised another five parties, and had £80 in the bank.

He started offering walking trips and holidays to the French mountains and seaside, as well as to Austria. The move served him well when Germany annexed Austria in 1938, for he was able to concentrate his business there. When his father retired, the two worked together as F&W Ingham.

Henry Lunn was already taking groups of public school and university educated skiers to Switzerland, but Walter's enduring and friendly rivalry was with Erna Low, who as Erna Löwwe, had thrown the javelin for Austria, come to England and, in 1932, similarly advertised for clients to take skiing.

Walter was in France when war broke out, "wishfully trying to organise our winter's operations". He headed home by car. Later that year, he was back in France as a lance corporal, and married his wife Barbara in Le Mans. The wedding was on April 20. Thereafter, they never referred to their anniversary, calling it "Hitler's birthday" instead. Walter later served in north Africa, and after the Nazi defeat - he spoke fluent German with a Viennese accent - was sent to Austria to work with the control commission.

When he emerged from the army with the rank of major in 1948, he set up in a Bond Street office with ex-War Department trestle tables covered with military blankets. During the following 14 years, Inghams grew steadily, eventually employing 80 full-time staff and 30 overseas representatives, and carrying some 14,000 people abroad each year.

He operated snow trains to the Alps, sharing space with Erna Low, and introduced dancing cars in which customers would rock the night away as they rattled across the continent. By the early 1950s, Inghams was flying customers to the Alps in propellor-driven DC-3 aircraft.

When he sold out to Hotelplan, part of the Swiss grocery wholesaling and retail organisation, Migros, in 1962, customers were still skiing in lace-up boots and using skis with finger-scraping cable bindings. He retired to Elba, to sail. A lover of classical music, he became a friend of the conductor Charles Mackerras, who also had a house on the island.

The company Walter Ingham founded continues to operate, not as one of the giants of the travel business but, principally, as a leading winter sports specialist - and with one of the industry's longest surviving brand names.

Ingham's wife died two years ago. He leaves two sons and a daughter.

Walter Ingham, travel operator, born May 29 1914; died July 18 2000

fields.headline: Crisis, what crisis?
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
It's raining men, hallelujah, was not my first thought at this week's radio offerings. The blighters were all over the schedules like a rash: Bull Epic ("a city lad's experiences", Radio 4); Kings of the Ring (5 Live's history of boxing); How Tickled Am I? (Mark Radcliffe's Radio 4 tribute to north of England comedians - no girls there, I guess) and There'll Never Be Another (a Radio 4 tribute to_er_ Britain's top comic acts of the past. Overlap and overkill, yes. Dames, nope).

As if all this wasn't enough, men were also in crisis this week under the tenacious scrutiny of Professor Anthony Clare and his team of merry helpers. These mainly consist of psychiatrists, regularly and cheerfully saying things like "We are already impotent, already castrated", "It's men who suffer from penis envy" and "Ahhh, this is where we get back to the penis." We never actually leave it for long in Men in Crisis (Radio 4).

Still, for all the cynical harridans - me for one - out there who might think men in crisis (yawn) is just sooo 1990s, or that chaps should sort themselves out like women have had to over the centuries, there were some startling stats, enough to make me put my Cosmopolitan down. Twice. Men are eight times more likely to commit GBH than women, 27 times more likely to murder. No surprises there, you might be thinking. But howzabout the fact that domestic violence makes up a quarter of all violent crime in the UK and that each week in this country, two women are murdered by their male partners?

OK, so I only got into the programme because of what men in crisis might mean for women (and because I could listen to Anthony Clare talk about grouting and still be in heaven); but once in, I gave it unconditional love, which is more than Frank has ever had from anyone, including his girlfriend. "I can only remember little bits," he says, edgily, "like when I spat in her face." He never, he swears to Clare, caused "any real damage" - bruises but not hospitalisation.

Listening to Frank and the other messed-up men in the programme's focus group was like watching a woodlouse on its back - all legs going wildly in the effort to turn over and just not being able to do it. The solution might not be a palatable one to the modern woman (men just need to "be looked after and brought up with even greater sensitivity"), but the problem isn't one we can just make Sex and the City-style jibes about. Even if it is fun and a cheap night out.

Despite Jamie Theakston's best pleading, the sun refused to shine in Irvine on One Big Sunday (Radio 1). After a sultry, tropical week, the weather made its own small protest at the demise of the Radio 1 Roadshow this year. You remember: instead of DJs going out on the road to play in front of crowds, often at the seaside (too passé), we have... well... DJs going out on the road to play in front of crowds at the seaside. These are called mini-festivals, though, just so there's no confusion.

The roadshows used to feature cheesy bands miming. One Big Sunday had Ronan Keating and The Corrs. As soon as it ended, the sun came out, roastingly hot, pleased that it had made a stand against the shock of the new.

Andy Williams (Radio 2), by way of contrast, was assured and reassuring. Playing Top of the Pops aged 70 with Music to Watch Girls By was, he assured us, "better than Viagra." Hallelujah.

webTitle: It's that old devil called love again

fields.headline: It's that old devil called love again
fields.standfirst: The Magnetic Fields' sublime and witty songs about the peculiarities of passion leave  Betty Clarke  weak at the knees
fields.trailText: The Magnetic Fields' sublime and witty songs about the peculiarities of passion leave Betty Clarke weak at the knees
fields.body:
When New York cool meets London reserve an odd atmosphere of curiosity and deference results. So it was with no fanfare and more than a little awkwardness that the Magnetic Fields made their appearance at London's Queen Elizabeth Hall.

Their opus, the magnificent 69 Love Songs, has had critics foaming at the mouth and has found a place in the heart of everyone who likes their lyrics witty and their melodies sublime. The vision of songwriter-producer Stephin Merritt (he of The 6ths and Future Bible Heroes), 69 Love Songs has taken a genre normally appropriated by the Celine Dions and Barry Whites of this world and made it credible and beautiful.

Shuffling into view, dressed in black like Johnny Cash, to whom his distinctive vocals owe so much, Merritt looks crumpled and small, barely acknowledging the audi ence as he sits impishly on his stool. But as he begins A Pretty Girl Is Like, he appears to increase in stature as the warmth and depth of his chocolatey-brown voice fills the air.

Merrit - aided by other Fields members Claudia Gonson on keyboards, Sam Davol on the cello and John Woo (no, not that one) on the guitar - sounds like a world-weary traveller singing into his Bud in some two-bit town in the Deep South. He sings of the peculiarities of love, a wry smile in his voice, though his face remains deadpan. It's Scott Walker singing songs about Prozac and sailors. "The only stars there really are were shining in your eyes/ There is no sun except the one that never shone on other guys," sings Merritt, and a thousand hearts sigh.

The Fields' songs may be about one subject but they've discovered a diversity that keeps them interesting. From Fido, Your Leash Is Too Long (an ode to loving your dog sung straight-faced) to Time Enough For Rocking When You're Dead (extolling the virtues of dancing now and sleeping later) love in all its forms is revealed, each smothered in humour and heartbreak, the delivery simple but affecting.

Merritt's bleak vocals are balanced by Gonson's lilting voice. She sings Merritt's lyrics with care, sharing his vision without stealing the glory. Reno Dakota has the desperation of a woman whose lover won't call her but it never detracts from the sense of calm the Fields create.

As Merritt finally relaxes and manages a "Bless you" in thanks for the wild applause each song is awarded, he climbs down off his stool for a bit of a wander. Microphone in one hand, wine glass and cigarette in the other, he inspects the black curtains at the back of the stage and sways a little, in iconic Dean Martin pose, enjoying the opportunity to show off a little. But when a heckler keeps shouting "Cheer up!", it's down to Gonson to tell him it isn't funny.

Merritt lets the music speak for itself, which makes it even harder to take your eyes off him. He's as mesmerising as the sounds he makes, by virtue of doing very little at all. He's here to sing his songs and that's enough.
fields.bodyText: When New York cool meets London reserve an odd atmosphere of curiosity and deference results. So it was with no fanfare and more than a little awkwardness that the Magnetic Fields made their appearance at London's Queen Elizabeth Hall. Their opus, the magnificent 69 Love Songs, has had critics foaming at the mouth and has found a place in the heart of everyone who likes their lyrics witty and their melodies sublime. The vision of songwriter-producer Stephin Merritt (he of The 6ths and Future Bible Heroes), 69 Love Songs has taken a genre normally appropriated by the Celine Dions and Barry Whites of this world and made it credible and beautiful. Shuffling into view, dressed in black like Johnny Cash, to whom his distinctive vocals owe so much, Merritt looks crumpled and small, barely acknowledging the audi ence as he sits impishly on his stool. But as he begins A Pretty Girl Is Like, he appears to increase in stature as the warmth and depth of his chocolatey-brown voice fills the air. Merrit - aided by other Fields members Claudia Gonson on keyboards, Sam Davol on the cello and John Woo (no, not that one) on the guitar - sounds like a world-weary traveller singing into his Bud in some two-bit town in the Deep South. He sings of the peculiarities of love, a wry smile in his voice, though his face remains deadpan. It's Scott Walker singing songs about Prozac and sailors. fields.headline: Spider - the clean crusty
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
What does a girl do when her boyfriend wants to go to India to find himself? In Toyah Battersby's case, she repairs to the Rover's Return for a bacardi and coke and some avuncular advice from Ken Barlow, which is enough to take the bloom off almost anything. Thus fortified, she returned to face Spider with the news that, after all, she'd rather stay in Weatherfield and wait for exam results than swan off to Goa on a one-way ticket. This, we can be sure, is a decision that she will live to regret sooner rather than later, especially when you take a look at her family.

All the colour seemed to drain from the screen as Toyah (Georgia Taylor) and Spider (Martin Hancock) said their final goodbyes in Coronation Street (ITV). "I'm going to stay but I think you should go," blurted Toyah, who only minutes earlier had been ranting on about "small-minded prejudice" and looking forward to flying the nest. Spider, who had already undergone one tearful farewell from Aunt Emily, wrung every last drop out of the scene. "I might be a crusty," he said forlornly, "but I'm a clean crusty." And so he shook the dust of Weatherfield from his shoes, a broken man. Mind you, after a couple of weeks in the sun, the loss of Toyah and the rest of his friends on the Street might not seem quite so hard to bear.

God never closes a door without somewhere opening a window, and it was heartening to see a possible romance blooming among the senior cast members. Rita (Barbara Knox, whose performance becomes camper by the day) found love in a bookshop, where she was following up her new-found interest in genealogy. "I'm a widow," she told the posh, bowtie-wearing proprietor, who promptly offered to initiate her into the mysteries of the internet. Time was when a proposition of this nature would have earned him a sock on the jaw, but Rita has mellowed in recent years, and instead rolled her eyes in unspoken invitation. Now that she's shot of Norris the deadly dull lodger, her couch may not remain chaste for much longer.

A little later ITV's Crimefighters reached a zen level with an episode in which practically nothing happened for an entire half-hour. We were out on the streets of south-west London with the Territorial Support Group, who cruised around in enormous vans looking for trouble, but never really found it. Called to an address in Streatham, where "a mentally unstable female" had "abused drugs" and was threatening to cut herself with a knife, the 20-strong force donned full riot gear and then_ sat around and waited. Nothing happened. The negotiators came and went, the TSG went and sat in the van, and were finally relieved by a different squad. Apparently they carted the woman off the following day when the cameras weren't there. Result!

The "youths" of Romford don't stay in on a Friday night watching such fly-on-the-wall crime shows; they take to the streets, neck a few alcopops and go to clubs with names like Vivid and Elite.PC Andy endured the pissed ravings of a young man, while PC Eunice stepped in between two brawling clubbers at 2am. Her helmet went flying, but she got the cuffs on. The miscreant spent a night in the cells, but was released the next day after "the police decided to take no further action", a fittingly downbeat ending to an agonisingly uneventful piece of TV.

fields.headline: Deadly wonders
fields.standfirst: Spirit guidedogs, forks for eating human flesh, corpse-locks to foil grave-robbers_ an exhibition exploring death ceremonies and the afterlife gives  Tanya Wilson  a thrill and a chill
fields.trailText: Spirit guidedogs, forks for eating human flesh, corpse-locks to foil grave-robbers_ an exhibition exploring death ceremonies and the afterlife gives Tanya Wilson a thrill and a chill
fields.body:
In the first empty room of the Heaven and Hell exhibition at the Royal Museum in Edinburgh, all is serene and white, with billowy white folds of fabric. It's our first and last moments all at once: a new, bewilderingly strange realm, the setting for a near-death experience, perhaps, or even the backdrop to The Obituary Show. In the next, a flood of colour and, ironically, the stuff of life; a mass of beliefs, rituals and traditions - 6,000 years of global perspectives on death - are laid out before us. Like the Royal Museum's history of souvenirs last year, this is an impressive exhibition that doesn't stint on design. That empty first room, all purgatorial uncertainty, lingers longer than you might think.

Given the universality of its theme, there are plenty of deadly wonders in this show, especially around the question of transition from earthly to heavenly realms. Companions for the dead were popular with the Incas, mostly in the form of jewellery and pottery figures. Deceased local bigwigs, though, would apparently be accompanied by women and servants, who were buried alive (well, what use is a dead one?) alongside the corpse. Mexicans included spirit guidedogs for the journey and, if someone had been unkind to dogs in their lifetime, some tortillas were included to pacify the spirit dog.

The Chinese have Hell Passports and tickets for Hell airlines; a remote cannibalistic tribe had dainty sacred forks for eating the flesh of dead enemies. The Batak people of Sumatra gave childless people an especially touching send-off: a life-size puppet would dance a death song to boogie away the curse of childlessness, as they saw it, and then embrace the mourners. The puppet, the display label quietly notes, would then be thrown away or destroyed. No ceremony, nothing to mark its passing.

All is not lost after death, of course, if you are from Singapore (where paper versions of everything you could possibly need - cigarettes, shoes, hats, mobile phones - are burned so they reach you) or Mexico, with its Day of the Dead festival each year. There's a mocked-up stall of merchandise bought last year, a hugely colourful, wildly naff array next to a frankly wimpy little straggle of Hallowe'en tat. It may be because we know it so well that the curators hardly bothered, but as our annual collective brush with the ghoulish side of death for fun, it demands more attention - as do other popular cultural reflections on heaven and hell. Horror films, comedies (Heaven Can Wait), disco tunes (all together now: "Heaven, must be missin' an angel"), death bed scenes from Victorian novels - all of these and more could have mixed rather than simply lightened the tone of a show, which relies a little too heavily on the brightly lit museum display case approach to curating. Heaven and Hell also looks at other cultures more insightfully than it looks at our own and there are too many "oh silly them" moments in this global survey.

When the deadly stare is turned back on us, though, we don't look quite so smug. The brutal corpse collars, scary contraptions like modern-day bike locks, used to protect corpses from body- snatching, sit starkly alongside tales of Burke and Hare. Standard-issue shrouds, all clinically white, non-toxic and fully-combustible (gulp) are the sartorial equivalent of cancelling out life, especially when placed next to the glorious colour of a bridal burial sari from a Hindu ceremony. There are ecologically-friendly cardboard and wicker basket coffins - mmm, shuffle off this mortal coil in a giant picnic hamper - and a nod, only a nod mind, to the modern cult of the celebrity death (Elvis, Monroe, James Dean, Diana).

In the end, this macabre, funny, touching material simply underlines the fact that all we have, when we really think of death, is that blank, empty whiteness we began with. "To die will be an awfully big adventure," JM Barrie wrote in Peter Pan, but for most of us, it's still a shiver-me-timbers prospect.

When I visited the exhibition, two janitors were talking about George Best. "Aye, he'll drink himself to death one of these days right enough." They shook their heads, as much in shock at the death of his talent as the idea that someone might propel themselves along that final road. To them, to us, that thought is as scary as hell.

 Till February 11 (0131 247 4219)

fields.headline: Back with a bang
fields.standfirst: These are tense times for Keith Jarrett, laid low by chronic fatigue syndrome. But, says  John Fordham, he was soon back to his leg-flapping, pyrotechnic ways
fields.trailText: These are tense times for Keith Jarrett, laid low by chronic fatigue syndrome. But, says John Fordham, he was soon back to his leg-flapping, pyrotechnic ways
fields.body:
Keith Jarrett stopped his comeback show on Wednesday barely before the cheers for his return, after years of absence from London, had died down. There was a hum from the piano's amplification, disturbing his equilibrium, and the full house at the Royal Festival Hall collectively held its breath as the legendarily raw-nerved virtuoso got up and ominously called to his sound engineer. It brought back distant memories of the solo concert at the same venue that Jarrett stopped in its tracks because he suspected somebody in the audience was recording him. Would he vanish as soon as he'd reappeared - like a genie retreating into the bottle - before he'd even begun to weave the old spell?

The glitch was fixed and Jarrett sat down again in the church-like silence. Then he turned to the audience. "For our second selection, we'd like to play_" he began, and the breath was let out, the audience laughing and applauding, grateful for Jarrett's evident desire to break the ice. These are tense times for Jarrett. Off the scene for three years with chronic fatigue syndrome, the pianist has said that every show he does now is a gamble with his constitution.

Would the old impassioned spontaneity be gone? Would Jarrett play as he did on The Melody At Night, With You, the one disc he recorded in mid-illness - exquisitely - but distilling the music to such delicate nuances that it was like witnessing a blazing fire burned down to embers?

In the event, the 17-year-old Standards Trio (Jarrett plus Gary Peacock on bass and Jack DeJohnette on drums) certainly played differently - but although there was plenty of hushed rumination, there was also plenty of flat-out jamming and animated, one-touch conversation. Far from handling himself like fine china, Jarrett was soon off into his celebrated onstage ballet - standing to play, flapping his legs like a man trying to shake water out of his shoes, crouching, weaving, grimacing, emitting exultant shouts as if encouraging particularly eager phrases on their way.

The Standards Trio, though historically dedicated to the jazz-standards repertoire, has certainly thrown away the maps and flown by the seat of its pants before, and even recorded its looser outings. This was just such a performance of startling fluency of movement between orthodox and free- improvising, familiar tunes sometimes appearing like wraiths at the edges of rich ensemble tapestries painted entirely on the fly.

This was a real trio performance, and it may be that Jarrett's softer, more glancing sound, and inclination to bounce short but pregnant motifs at his partners, keeping his famously long, swerving runs on tighter rein, has made it an even more equal partnership. Jack DeJohnette, overloud at the start but sublimely intelligent later, quickly indicated the conversational style in the opening moments.

Jarrett had begun with a mixture of melancholy chords and short, inquisitive phrases. DeJohnette echoed them with flat, clapping snare-drum sounds and cymbal flurries. Gradually, a typical Jarrett momentum developed. A brilliant motivic improvisor, Jarrett develops his solos out of his encyclopaedically-informed love of melody, the secret of his success however freely he plays. A driving mid-tempo improvisation that frequently hinted at the security of a recurring tonal centre gave way to a whisper in which the bass and drums dropped out, then a repeating, boogie-like left-hand figure appeared, against which Jarrett dropped miniscule right-hand notes as if flicking drops of water.

The first set resolved on a long and increasingly majestic exploration of bluesy improvisation on gospel forms, that had grown out of soft, spacious chords as evocative as a hymn. The second half began as open improvising, too, kicked in by DeJohnette's chattering hi-hat patterns, punctuated by the hiss of the cymbals snapping together.

Gary Peacock's ease of movement between quick, cello-like high sounds and resonant low ones was accentuated by the naturalness of the barely-perceptible amplification, and DeJohnette's astonishing rhythmic and tonal variety with the clipped sounds of the rims, the woodwork and the hi-hat eventually brought Jarrett to a halt, simply opening and shutting the piano lid in percussive sympathy.

You Don't Know What Love Is mingled the free-improv with achingly suspended chords, and the fast bebop classic Doxy brought in the long-delayed arrival of straight-ahead jazz to an ecstatic reaction. It seemed to help the more ensemble-oriented Jarrett of most of the show recover some former swaggering exuberance, which marked a solo of devastating long lines and mischievous turnarounds in the first of his encores. The pianist was flapping his hands as if surprised they were still with him when he took his bows. But if the relationship between them and wherever he keeps his genius is nowadays a little different, it's undoubtedly in its own kind of newly radiant health.

 The Standards Trio's Whisper Not will be released on ECM in October.
