fields.headline: Consuming passion
fields.standfirst: Alan Ayckbourn's indictment of 1980s values has been revived at Chichester - and it's all horribly topical, says  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: Alan Ayckbourn's indictment of 1980s values has been revived at Chichester - and it's all horribly topical, says Michael Billington
fields.body:
Which British play best sums up the mood of the 1980s? You could make a case for Churchill's Serious Money or Hare's The Secret Rapture. But Ayckbourn's A Small Family Business, first seen at the National in 1987, encapsulates the greed, amorality and conspicuous consumption that characterised that dismal decade as well as any work I know; this may be why Chichester greeted Rachel Kavanaugh's lively revival with distinctly chilly enthusiasm.

Ayckbourn is writing about the difficulty of being good in an imperfect world. Jack McCracken takes over his father-in-law's furniture business and makes an idealistic speech about the need for trust. No sooner has he done so than he is faced with a moral dilemma: a private investigator offers to drop shoplifting charges against Jack's daughter in return for a job with the firm. Indignation gives way to surrender; from then on it is downhill.

Some critics objected to what they saw as Ayckbourn's attenuated characterisation. But that is to miss the point. He has written a morality play in which a plausible hero is confronted by moral choices. It harpoons Thatcherite attitudes and is still horribly topical.

Though there are scenes that Kavanaugh could have pushed to greater extremes, this is nevertheless an excellent revival in which Nigel Planer's Jack has just the right sense of suburban idealism reduced to panic. He is well supported by John Nettleton as his aphasic father-in-law, Vicki Pepperdine as his deranged sister-in-law, and Christopher Luscombe as the creepy private investigator.

What shocks is the enduring relevance of Ayckbourn's point that we place consumer durables above the heart's affections. Jack's brother says he loves his Porsche, boat and computer more than he loves his wife: a current TV advert endorses the same attitude. The cookery-mad brother-in-law who sacrifices everything to his dream of opening a restaurant in Minorca eerily anticipates the foodie pornography that engulfs us today.

 At Chichester Festival Theatre (01243 781312) till September 30.

No sooner has he done so than he is faced with a moral dilemma: a private investigator offers to drop shoplifting charges against Jack's daughter in return for a job with the firm. Indignation gives way to surrender; from then on it is downhill. Some critics objected to what they saw as Ayckbourn's attenuated characterisation. But that is to miss the point. He has written a morality play in which a plausible hero is confronted by moral choices. It harpoons Thatcherite attitudes and is still horribly topical. Though there are scenes that Kavanaugh could have pushed to greater extremes, this is nevertheless an excellent revival in which Nigel Planer's Jack has just the right sense of suburban idealism reduced to panic. He is well supported by John Nettleton as his aphasic father-in-law, Vicki Pepperdine as his deranged sister-in-law, and Christopher Luscombe as the creepy private investigator. What shocks is the enduring relevance of Ayckbourn's point that we place consumer durables above the heart's affections. Jack's brother says he loves his Porsche, boat and computer more than he loves his wife: a current TV advert endorses the same attitude. The cookery-mad brother-in-law who sacrifices everything to his dream of opening a restaurant in Minorca eerily anticipates the foodie pornography that engulfs us today.  At Chichester Festival Theatre (01243 781312) till September 30.

fields.headline: Signs of the times
fields.standfirst: As the UN is criticised for allowing corporations to use its logo,  Jonathan Glancey  wonders how distinct distinguishing marks can be in a world awash with symbols
fields.trailText: As the UN is criticised for allowing corporations to use its logo, Jonathan Glancey wonders how distinct distinguishing marks can be in a world awash with symbols
fields.body:
Logorrhoea is an ugly word that describes excessive, uncontrollable or incoherent talkativeness. But it might be hijacked to describe the excessive, seemingly uncontrollable and increasingly incoherent use and abuse of logos.

You know the sort of thing: the flash on the side of a pair of trainers that signifies Nike, the double golden arches that herald McDonald's, the apple with a bite taken out of it imprinted above my computer screen. So powerful is the corporate logo, so seductive, that millions of people are willing to pay to wear T-shirts that advertise a company's corporate presence for nothing. If these people were less enthralled by logos and their promise of belonging to a stylish club, they would demand to be paid for acting as walking adverts for fizzy drinks, burgers and pumped-up plimsolls.

This week, the United Nations secretary-general, Kofi Annan, came under attack from 20 non-governmental agencies including Greenpeace for offering global corporations such as Nike, Shell and Rio Tinto the right to use the UN logo as some sort of proof that they are happy to meet and promote a list of nine human-rights principles drawn up by Mr Annan and his colleagues.

The outcry was provoked by the fact that these multinationals have all been accused of various forms of human-rights abuse over the years. Twinning the UN logo (a view of the world through what appears to be the gunsight of a B-52 bomber with an imperial Roman laurel leaf wrapped around it) with the Nike flash is viewed by Annan's critics as offer ing the shoe company a powerful marketing tool that it neither particularly needs nor deserves.

If the UN secretary-general had simply written a letter encouraging these multinationals to pursue their business as ethically as possible, it is unlikely that Greenpeace and co would have kicked up such a fuss. It's the use of the logo that has raised hackles. For a logo is indeed a powerful symbol, a visual rallying cry for ideas, cultures and values. Think of Hitler's swastika, an ancient religious symbol that is hard to look at now without thinking of Stuka bombers and Nuremberg rallies.

The logo is a longstanding device and, when used sparingly, can be memorable, even stirring. One of the earliest "universal" logos was the fish symbolising Christianity. This was used among early Christians facing Roman persecution. The Romans themselves made powerful use of logos -the legend SPQR (senatus populusque romanus) was emblazoned across civic buildings and the standards of military legions - as did the warlords of later ages. Emperors had their double-headed eagles, Napoleon his bees, Lancastrian knights their red roses, Yorkshire horsemen white.

These emblems were highly distinctive, standing out over fields of battle and from the pediments of cities yet to face the commercial revolution that has given us Coca-Cola, Nike and their ubiquitous insignia. Even in the age of burgeoning mass transport, the logo was highly distinctive because there was little visual competition. When Frank Pick, then commercial manager of London Underground, commissioned the distinguished calligrapher Edward Johnston to design a logo, he created one of the most distinctive of all, the London Transport "bullseye" (or, in today's slightly modified form, "roundel"). Johnston's logo, with its brilliant red, white and blue, worked superbly. As elegant as the encircled three-pointed star on the radiator grille of a Mercedes or the entwined Roman Rs of Rolls-Royce.

But today even such a clear-cut logo as Pick and Johnston's has to work hard to make its mark. Since the 1960s every self-respecting commercial outfit has felt the need for a natty logo, an instant way of gaining attention in our post-literate age, when image (the logo) is all and the word (logos) is often not understood.

Design studios are paid small fortunes for devising logos. Each nugatory change in the design of a corporate logo is accompanied by a PR extravaganza, as if we were witnessing the second coming. Yet, when there are so many logos being waved about in our streets, our homes (often unwittingly in the goods and foodstuffs we buy) and across all media, each logo is debased by the simple fact of there being so many others. And so each must be redesigned, then redesigned again until its original effect is all but lost, planed to a banal image signifying little. Greenpeace and other critics of the UN can perhaps relax. In the crush, logos may be losing some of their insuperable, sempiternal might.

fields.headline: The Kosovo of Africa
fields.standfirst: Eritrea's capital, Asmara, seems a sophisticated city - yet it is just a morning's drive from the Ethiopian troops who may soon overrun it.  Thomas Keneally  reports from a place he has come to love
fields.trailText: Eritrea's capital, Asmara, seems a sophisticated city - yet it is just a morning's drive from the Ethiopian troops who may soon overrun it. Thomas Keneally reports from a place he has come to love
fields.body:
Asmara, capital of Eritrea, lies 8,000 feet up in the highlands of east Africa. Its style is Italian, with palm tree'd avenues. It takes coffee seriously, inheriting different coffee traditions - Italian espresso and capuccino, and the wonderful ginger-spiced ceremonial coffee which is the climax of all formal meals. In Asmara, people try to dress well, and have their shoes cleaned outside the old Italian opera house. Around the Catholic cathedral, which evokes the long-gone years of the Italian colony of Eritrea, cafes and pastry-shops do good trade in the mornings and evenings. On the cathedral walls Benito Mussolini is mentioned among the donors, but the Eritrean people who have inherited the centre of the town are Coptic Christian and Muslim, and of East African demeanour. Apart from that, the absence of street crime and an exceptional lack of beggars, one might think the place was somewhere in southern Italy.

But Asmara is a city under considerable threat. Eritrea has been invaded, and the Ethiopian lines are a morning's drive away. Though a peace treaty was signed in late June, the Ethiopians remain in place, and nearly everybody in the city fears that they might seek to break the cease-fire before the UN and Organisation of African Unity peacekeepers can be put in place 25 kilometres inside Eritrea.

The Ethiopians do not primarily want Asmara. Their army might lunge towards the port of Asab, on the Red Sea, which Ethiopia seems to covet. Even so, given that the world is not too much concerned for the future of Eritrea, the citizens of Asmara know that, with a little bad luck, their city could lie in ruins, its sophistication gutted. So, trying to guess at Ethiopian intentions is a chief sport in Eritrea's coffee shops, particularly engaged in by the many people whom I met on previous visits to Eritrea, the rebels who fought the war of independence, which ended in 1991.

One of those is Askalu Menkarios, now Minister for Labour. I first met her 13 years past, one morning during the long "struggle" when the truck I had been a passenger in during the night broke down. The Eritreans covered it with branches to protect it from detection by Ethiopian Mig fighters and I set off meek as a child in the care of my Eritrean escort to seek shelter. Seeing another camouflaged truck in front of a hole in a mountain, we entered a bunker and discovered a young Eritrean woman, a member of the rebel Congress, Askalu, suckling her child.

A few weeks ago in Asmara, Askalu brought to see me the 14-year-old whom I had first met as an infant near She'b. That angular child is a characteristic middle-class kid from an urbane city, and Askalu must ask herself will her daughter need, and could she face, living in holes in the mountain like her mother before her? Askalu also reiterates the bemusement of many former Eritrean rebels. Since Ethiopia has, in the June peace talks, refused to state its claims, and will define them only when the peace process advances to the discussion of border demarcation, what did they really want from this renewed war?

On my first two visits, I came to rebel-held Eritrea by truck from the Sudan, so it was not until my third visit that I saw Asmara. The Eritreans had not captured their capital until 1991, and I first came to it in 1993. It was an ecstatic city then, awaiting the UN-supervised referendum on independence. The men and women I had known as rebel soldiers in the mountains now wore suits. The world had turned benign. The Ethiopian dictator, Menghistu, had fled to Zimbabwe. The northern Ethiopian rebels, the Tigreans, allies of Eritrea, were in power in Ethiopia. To see the referendum, the new prime minister of Ethiopia, Meles Zenawi, was staying at the same hotel as my wife and I. In the villages of Serai Province, which has now been reinvaded by the Ethiopian army, people decorated our truck with wheels of bread, threw celebratory popcorn, chanted and danced before the polling booths. Not only would independence be achieved through a UN-supervised referendum, but the time of dying was over.

There is no joy in those towns now. A few weeks ago around Deborwa, just 40 kilometres from the city, 100,000 people who escaped the invading Ethiopian army were living 15 to a tent, their little mattresses slotted tight under canvas. Many were living under trees in the open. More than one and a half million were displaced through the country - half the population.

"Tell the world!" an adolescent Eritrean boy from the Ethiopian-held town of Senafe instructed me in English. For, although the Eritreans go to a great deal of trouble to ensure they do not fit the archetype of African refugee, it has begun raining on the camps in the hinterland, and mosquito hatchlings fill the evening air and visit malaria on a populace scraping by on short rations of lentils and flour. Since there has not been time to establish proper sanitation, gastric illness is everywhere. Children puke and are overcome close to family quarters by uncontrollable diarrhoea, compounding infection.

In the past few weeks the Ethiopians have shortened their lines for logistical reasons, and some refugees have gone home. But it is to roofless and gutted towns and farmhouses, to plundered granaries and livestock pens, to fields littered with corpses and sown with mines. It is too late in the year now to plant a crop. This manufactured hunger will occupy the coming year. In eight months, said an aid expert, it will take 130 trucks to bring food up from the Red Sea port of Massawa to feed the Eritreans.

The conflict between the two nations began as a border dispute nearly three years ago and moved on to become a full-scale invasion. Over their chief luxury, their coffee, the old rebels of the capital argue that what has befallen Eritrea is the equivalent of what befell Belgium in 1914 and Kuwait in 1991. And yet it is the invaded who are being punished, perhaps more acutely than the invaders.

The UN Security Council has placed sanctions on both parties, but one sees unfeigned bemusement in the president Isaias Afwerki. I first met him, as I met Askalu, in the highlands 13 years ago. He told me that, as a student in Beijing at the time of Mao, he had concluded that the cult of personality was a destructive element in all politics. After independence, he remained reserved in his public appearances, and lived plainly. Yet his frankness, his forthrightness, may have contributed to some of Eritrea's problems. He was always a passionate advocate of African self-sufficiency. He cooperated with the late visionary Australian eye doctor, Fred Hollows, who wanted to put in place the technological means for Eritreans to manufacture their own intra- ocular lenses at an African price, for export to the poorer nations of the world at $7, instead of the western price of over $100. But it seems that the west does not like this stroppy attitude.

Eritrea had achieved food self-sufficiency by the late 1990s, and aid organisations were kissed off - as they saw it, not always diplomatically. Now they are needed back, and help is not as forthcoming. With the war, and the destruction of cotton crops in western Eritrea, and even of a cotton pro duction plant at Tessenai, Isaias says: "Dependence has suddenly become the condition of the whole population." Why, the people in Asmara's cafes ask, has there been so little international outcry over the invasion? Why has the US State Department been so late to react, and, with its ally, Canada, been so content to deal harshly with the Eritreans? Seventy-five per cent of what is coming in, to help the displaced clustering in the valleys and hillsides around Asmara, comes from Europe.

The situation has not been helped by the two Badmes. There is a Badme in Tigre, Ethiopia, and one just over the border in Eritrea. The Ethiopian Badme is more heavily populated and appears on maps, so that many outsiders wrongly thought the Eritreans were attacking Tigrean Badme, when, in reality, they were defending Eritrean Badme.

For a more forthright statement of how wrong the world community is, one needs to go to a person as vigorous as Lea Brilmayer, who holds a chair in international law at Yale and spends half the year in Eritrea working as adviser to Isaias. "This war is a fraud," she says. It's a fraud, she argues, because there were no grounds for a border dispute - the border of Eritrea was fixed by a treaty in 1908 between Italy and the then Abyssinia, and appeared on Ethiopian maps until a few years ago. It's a fraud because the world believes that the Eritreans reacted aggressively, whereas she knows of the long and acutely polite protests president Isaias sent off to his friend Meles. It's a fraud because the world gave implicit permission for invasion, by ignoring the deportation of Eritreans from Ethiopia over the past two or more years.

Where the Eritreans adopt an air of wistful bemusement, Brilmayer is full of pithiness. Eritrea is becoming Kosovo, she says, with the difference that "people in Kosovo hold credit cards, so they're worth saving". She says about the large ethnic Eritrean population now registered and under the gun in Ethiopia, that in five years: "People could say this is Rwanda all over again. Why did we do nothing?"

And so Asmara waits as a weary world gathers together yet another peace-keeping exercise. It is clear that, unless there is vigorous international influence, a pretext may be found by the Ethiopian regime to renew the war and to lunge at Asab before the peacekeepers arrive. On past evidence, I would not be surprised if Eritrea, although it has no self-interest in any further aggression, were blamed. Should that happen, of course, a remarkable society will be destroyed and a number of us will write wise books on how the disaster was achieved - in the normal way, through an impotence of reaction.

 Thomas Keneally is the author of Schindler's Ark and Towards Asmara: A Story Of Africa.

fields.headline: Take the long way home
fields.standfirst: 'If you are 'busy, busy, busy', you're really thick, thick, thick, because you haven't the wit to skive, skive, skive or delegate, delegate, delegate'
fields.trailText: 'If you are 'busy, busy, busy', you're really thick, thick, thick, because you haven't the wit to skive, skive, skive or delegate, delegate, delegate'.
fields.body:
Isn't science wonderful? They put a man on the moon and now they've put caffeine in a lipstick. Hard Candy, for the hefty sum of £13.50, will flog you slugabeds LipAchino, Latte Lip or Café O Lip. Not just caffeine, but St John's Wort, the "herbal Prozac", too, which you'll find in Tony & Tina's Mood Balance Lipstick. Hmm... call me an unreconstructed, killjoy feminist if you like, but I must say it strikes me as distinctly sad and suspect that women are striding into the 21st century eating cosmetics. Bread and circuses are off indefinitely, but let them eat lipstick.

The perfect lipstick has always been presented as the final frontier for female-friendly science; you would think we didn't ever die of cancers, the way all those hundreds of thousands of scientists are slaving away torturing animals day and night, supposedly to answer the insistent demand of the Eternal Woman for a perfect red with no blue in it, or for the ultimate beige that doesn't make you look as if you've got a blood disease. Who can forget the parties in the streets, the rejoicing worldwide, when in the 90s those friendly men in white coats finally presented a waiting world with a lipstick that stayed on all day and never needed retouching? Thereby enabling women to save, oh, at least two minutes a day - that's 14 minutes a week! Lovely: an extra 14 minutes in which to wait for buses, give up on trains and get stuck at airports.

Phrases such as "saving time" and "time-saving" have always puzzled me. You can't "save" time as you could pennies in a jar - five minutes here, a quarter-of-an-hour there, and stick them all together until you've got enough for a week in the Bahamas. You can't store time; like vitamin C or orgasms, it needs replenishing each new day. If you are eight minutes idle, they'll find something else for you to do.

Fifty years ago, the mass availability of time - and labour-saving appliances in the household - was meant to herald an age when women, in particular, would trip-trop languidly around from coffee morning to bistro luncheon to dinner-dance. But now, even women who don't work (and, yes, I am going to stick to the old definition of "work" meaning paid employment, because if we did not make that differentiation then anyone, man or woman, with children who was sacked from their job could not be described as out of work, and the government could do all sorts of crafty tricks with unemployment figures and benefits) are rushing around like mad things, stopping only to find the time, mysteriously, to fill in long magazine surveys about how they're so stressed and overworked that they feel like topping themselves.

The obvious answer to this dilemma, which no one ever seems to consider, is to simply STOP DOING SO MUCH - get your existing children adopted, have your womb taken out, start reading books instead of filling in those magazine surveys, and a year from now you will be totally on top of your game.

People simply do too much, except for those who do too little. Every time you do too much, you're taking that away from someone with very little to do already, so, in fact, you're not being good and clever, you're being nasty. Not to mention sucking up to the boss-man, who, of course, will dump you without a moment's thought when you become surplus to his requirements. There's something really creepy about people who "love" their work, and really class-traitorous, too.

How many of you oldsters out there remember the autobiographical Patti Smith single Piss Factory ('scuse French), in which our young-blood heroine went to work in said factory and worked a bit too hard, in fact, until the union representative on the factory floor had to take her to one side and ask her to slow down as it was showing the rest of them up. Naturally, Patti, being a rebel, didn't listen and carried on churning it out, until the other women cornered her one lunchtime and stuck her head down a toilet. At the time, of course, I thought this was the most tragic and unfair thing I had ever heard. Now, I think the little sneak totally deserved it.

For years, I was the busiest bee in town, until I realised that this merely made every booby I married feel that he could coast by on writing one shopping list and one thank-you letter a week, while Baby here churned it out and brought home the Baco-Bits. Now I take it easy - and I make no bones about it, either. Whenever I am commissioned to write a piece, I never play eager, but ask immediately what is "the least possible words by the latest possible time" I can do. At first, people laughed, thinking I was mucking about, but they soon realised that I was serious and, let me tell you, they know who's boss now. And, if I should somehow finish my work before time, I'll sit on it until the last possible minute. Because I know for a fact that the more work you do, the more you'll get dropped on to you.

There is something hideously unsexy about busy, efficient or "driven" people. As for "thrusting", as used in the context of work, well, what are they trying to overcompensate for? (Just think of poor Ian Beale in EastEnders.) Imagine how bad in bed those men who are always in a hurry must be; those mobile drones with their phones on the train, wanting everything done last week.

And the sort of strange woman who finds such men attractive! They obviously looked a bit too long at Adam Chance in Crossroads and never got over it. Chances are that, if you are "busy, busy, busy" (and, obviously, I'm talking here about white-collar workers, not nurses or people looking after their old parents), you are actually thick, thick, thick, because you haven't got the wit to skive, skive, skive or delegate, delegate, delegate.

Busy people often act like martyrs, but the fact is that they are tremendous egoists; they believe - or at least they want the onlooker to believe - that if they let up for one minute the world will end. I don't for a moment believe that about myself or anybody, and indeed the fact is that most people would do their jobs better if they did them less, not more. Don't make that deadline; take the long way home. When you see two queues, stand in the longer one and daydream. And look, Chicken Licken, the sky still won't fall down.

fields.headline: Farmed out
fields.standfirst: 'Tony Martin was never likely to be popular with his fellow prisoners, since he considers it his right to shoot them if necessary'
fields.trailText: 'Tony Martin was never likely to be popular with his fellow prisoners, since he considers it his right to shoot them if necessary'.
fields.body:
Tony Martin, the farmer serving a life sentence for shooting a teenage burglar at his home in Norfolk, has been having a terrifying time in prison. According to the Mail On Sunday last weekend, he has been attacked so often by fellow prisoners at Bullingdon jail in Oxfordshire that he has been moved to another prison in Leicestershire. The worst incident was when a group of prisoners tried to burn him alive. They forced him to the ground and set fire to him. Fortunately, he did not catch light. It's not altogether surprising that Martin has been having a bad time in jail: he was never likely to be popular with fellow criminals, since he considers it his right to shoot them, if necessary; and there were fears that friends and relatives of his murder victim, 16-year-old Fred Barras, might be planning revenge.

But Martin's sufferings have been worse than anyone anticipated, and not, it seems, for the obvious reasons. A "prison source", quoted by the newspaper, had the following extraordinary thing to say: "During the Euro 2000 football championships, emotions were running high, and this made things worse for Martin. When England lost against Romania, all the paedophiles on a nearby wing were chanting, 'Hang the farmer'. It really shook him up."

I bet it did: whatever Martin may be responsible for, it is not for Romania's victory at football. And he may well have wondered why the paedophiles had it in for him in particular. They may have been patriotic paedophiles, as distressed as all other proud Englishmen by their country's Euro 2000 humiliation, but why should their chosen scapegoat be this wretched 55-year-old farmer? Martin has never shown any pro-Romanian tendencies, and he has no unique record of hostility to paedophiles. And he probably minded just as much as they did when England lost the match.

Whatever he was frightened of when he entered prison, I doubt if it was paedophiles. But then in tense, angry modern Britain, you never know where the dangers lurk. Road rage, trolley rage, and all the other forms of rage, including football hooliganism, are equally mysterious. Jack Straw thinks they may have something to do with the legacy of the British Empire, however fanciful that sounds. One possible reason why the paedophiles picked on Martin is simply that he is a farmer, for there is a tremendous gut hostility to farmers in England.

Despite the efforts of Prince Charles, who made a speech this week pointing out that farmers are going through "desperately difficult" times (which indeed they are) and praying that "the farming community and all that it stands for is supported, protected and cherished", farmer-bashing continues unabated. In the same Mail On Sunday that sympathised with Martin, Geoffrey Wheatcroft wrote a vigorous attack on all farmers for their "greedy whingeing". "They are always whining," he wrote, "and they are always holding their hands out. They expect - and they get - money to grow crops, and money not to grow crops. All in all, the way in which farming is subsidised has become the greatest single affront to British democracy. What makes it worse is the astonishing ingratitude of our farmers."

There is much wrong with Europe's system of agricultural subsidies, not least that it fails to keep many of our farmers afloat. They may be subsidised, but many of them are also facing ruin - under these circumstances, their ingratitude is less than "astonishing".

Wheatcroft's outburst was prompted by the claim of Sussex farmer Paul Langmead for £10,000 in compensation after his crops were damaged by police investigating the death of eight-year-old Sarah Payne. Amid a storm of tabloid fury over his "heartlessness", Langmead coolly explained that, despite his distress over the murder, he could not "afford to ignore the fact that - through no fault of their own - many thousands of pounds worth of damage has been done to our crops during the course of the searches". He added that it was "proper" for police to be notified promptly of his "quantified claim", so that their insurers could be informed.

The police clearly leaked the story to the newspapers, knowing they could be relied upon to kick up such a fuss that Langmead would be driven to drop his claim, which may have been too high, which may have appeared insensitive to the public, but which was far from wicked. To claim for damage to crops caused by the police does not suggest indifference to the fate of Sarah Payne, nor any kind of sympathy towards paedophiles. It is a perfectly normal course of action.

Nevertheless, Langmead has been "named and shamed" in the tabloids, just as much as paedophiles were in the News Of The World last Sunday. To judge from the tone of the newspapers, you would hardly guess they were more wicked than him.

fields.headline: How to be suave
fields.trailText: There's an important difference between being suave and being cool, principally that being suave isn't cool.
fields.body:
There's an important difference between being suave and being cool, principally that being suave isn't cool. The basis of suavity is streamlining in personal grooming, social interaction and transportation. Suave cars never have four doors and should preferably be convertible sports cars - it's impossible to be suave in a people-carrier.

Suave footwear mirrors the choice of car, in that streamlining is also important. Slip-ons are, therefore, the shoes of choice for the suave among us. There is another option, and that is suede. It's no coincidence that the word suede is much like suave, because suede is the natural covering of the suave. A suave man wearing a lot of suede is elevated to the condition of being svelte, to which all suave people aspire.

Suave haircuts, too, tend towards the aerodynamic. It's difficult to have big, curly hair and pass yourself off as suave. Instead, you need a slicked-back look that sweeps over the head and ends in a rococo flourish on, or very near, the collar. Hair gel/glue should be applied in quantities sufficient to maintain maximum suavity when the hood of your sports car is down.

Suavity tends to focus around the neck. At one end of the spectrum is the medallion or tasteful St Christopher medal. On the other is the holy grail of suavity, the cravat. Both are difficult to carry off these days, and are often substituted by the polo-neck sweater, preferably under a suede jacket. It's the little touches that mark out the terminally suave: after-shave that would have been subtle, if only 15 times less of it been applied; large cufflinks on casual shirts; driving gloves; briefcases so slim they don't have an inside.

Body language for the suave is dictated by the necessity of appearing to make very little effort to move. Suave men tend to lean on things a lot and walk in a gliding sort of way (much of this is because they're trying desperately to keep their suede slip-ons on their feet). Journeys that cannot be made on lounge carpets must be made in sports cars. Suave men generally consider themselves to be enormously attractive to the opposite sex, which might be true, if only anyone could work out exactly what the opposite sex to them was. Nevertheless, suave men still act as if they're sex on toast, and as if their entire existence is enormously subtle and skilful foreplay of which all women are acutely aware. They stop thinking this in their late 50s, when they discover that their only regular female companion is a suave-looking collie.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Nick Hancock
fields.trailText: Nick Hancock
fields.body:
Nick Hancock was born in Stoke in 1962. Educated at Cambridge, he performed in the Footlights. He bought media space for an ad agency before breaking into stand-up comedy in 1985. He presented the cult TV show Room 101, and went on to host the sports quiz show, They Think It's All Over. He is currently presenting a new chat-show, You Only Live Once, for BBC1. He is married, has a daughter, and lives in London.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
If you have nothing to look forward to, you are not perfectly happy. If you have something to look forward to, then you are, as yet, unfulfilled.

What is your greatest fear?
Being perfectly happy.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Canute, he was trying to be humble but people found it more convenient to believe he was not.

Which living person do you most admire?
Jack Ashley, a politician of integrity, loyalty and wisdom.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
I'm easily discouraged.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Earnestness.

Where would you like to live?
The past.

What is your most unappealing habit?
My early-morning coughing fit.

What is your favourite word?
Secular.

What is your favourite fantasy?
Having dinner with Arnold Bennett.

For what cause would you die?
None of us can know until it's too late.

Which living person do you most despise?
I don't believe you should despise anyone, unless it's yourself.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Yes.

What is your greatest regret?
That my time at college was spent exercising everything but my mind.

When and where were you happiest?
On my wedding day. No, honestly.

How do you relax?
I fish.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
My own baggage handlers.

What would your motto be?
Vis unita fortior [unity is strength].

How would you like to be remembered?
By people who know me - not people who think they do.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Nearly everyone you know well will disappoint you at some stage, but not half as much as you'll disappoint yourself.

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: Co-Op Organic Premium Ale
fields.trailText: Co-Op Organic Premium Ale
fields.body: Well done, the Co-Op, for joining the small rush to offer organic beer to drinkers. Brewed by Caledonian of Edinburgh, revered for Golden Promise organic beer, Co-Op's 5% beer is available on draught and in bottle (£1.59 for 500ml). It has the same Chariot malt as Golden Promise, but the bittering hops come from New Zealand in the form of Hallertauer, a German variety that flourishes in the Kiwi climate without the need for chemical sprays. Brewer Dougal Sharp also uses a touch of English organic Target hops, from Kent, for aroma. The beer has a brilliant russet-brown colour, with a rich, biscuity malt, a spicy-hops aroma and a hint of sulphur from Edinburgh's salty water. The palate is a superb balance of juicy malt and tart hops, with an underpinning of citrus fruit. The finish is long yet delicate, with biscuity malt, tart hops and a lingering flavour reminiscent of Lucozade. Dougal uses, most unusually, a lager yeast at ale temperature, which explains its quenching nature.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: The acid test: ceviche
fields.trailText: The acid test: ceviche
fields.body:
The subject
Pieces of fish that have been given a long soak in a high-acid solution. Sounds like a chemistry experiment, but it's merely a mega-trendy menu item of the moment. And one of the world's great ultra-simple dishes. Pronounced seh-VEE-chay in Mexican Spanish, whence it comes; spelled seviche in some sources. Probably acquired by Mexico through trading with Polynesian islanders.

The basics
Applying acid to animal protein denatures it, making the fibres contract and express water. When the animals in question are fish, and when they're cut up into small pieces, and when the acid bath lasts long enough, the effect is similar to that of cooking: the flesh becomes opaque and very firm. That's why recipes for ceviche often describe the process as 'cooking' the fish in the liquid. It ain't so, but what the hell.

The details
First, select your fish. Mexicans traditionally use sierra - aka, kingfish - which is similar to mackerel. You can use mackerel, too. Or any good white fish. Or scallops, if you want to push the boat out. Salmon doesn't look so good after the acid's had a go. But, whatever you use, it must be splendidly fresh. Next, choose your acid. If it is, you can now add the flavourings, mix and leave for another hour or so.

The best fish is not found in supermarkets.

The easy way out
Pickled herring?

And one of the world's great ultra-simple dishes. Pronounced seh-VEE-chay in Mexican Spanish, whence it comes; spelled seviche in some sources. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck puts a cork in it
fields.body:
A few weeks back, there were two letters in the Saturday correspondence columns concerned with cork taint and plastic stoppers. They were in response to an article that promulgated the notion (an idea originating from the cork producers PR outfit) that an ecological disaster will occur if wine retailers insist upon plastic closures and so make redundant the cork from the oak forests - the farming of which ensures that the trees are the basis of an important habitat for certain flora and fauna. Only the final words of that last sentence are indisputably correct. Cork has many uses beyond wine bottles. The drinks industry is just one market. Cork producers must expand their other markets rather than exploit the happy existence of rare fauna in order to maintain the commercial status quo for a dodgy product.

Mr Campbell, the correspondent whose letter suggested that one use of plastic cork might be to shut my mouth on the subject, is a misinformed bird lover. (I direct him to the Somerfield Argentine Sangiovese below - it'd be marvellous with a roast bird.) Cork is a pain in the neck. It not only contaminates a significant percentage of wine (industry estimates are between 5% and 8%) but causes bottles to vary in performance, dramatically so in wine designed to be cellared for years. For Mr Lindo, the second correspondent and a Cornish wine grower, to write that he has tasted corked wine 'on less than a dozen occasions' is to invite the riposte that either he has drunk only a few hundred bottles of wine in his life hitherto, or that he has consumed many bottles of corked wine without knowing it.

Subject now closed, I hope. We can now turn to the real business of the day: opening bottles. Let us go first to Somerfield, which has some marvellous new reds. Pietroasa Young Vatted Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16 points, out of 20, £3.99), from Romania, is what beaujolais would love to be. It has similar cheeky freshness, but more character, bite and tannins, and a rich finish. Somerfield Chilean Merlot 1999 (17 points, £4.49) explodes in the mouth like a spicy cherry/blackcurrant grenade. Hugely impressive depth and leatheriness here. Hardy s Nottage Hill Cabernet Sauvignon/Shiraz 1999 (16.5 points, £5.79) is one of Aussie's sassiest red-wine bargains under six quid in this vintage. It has thrilling tannins and subtle spiciness. Somerfield Cabernet Sauvignon/Merlot Vina La Rosa 1999 (16.5 points, £3.99) is a marvel of a blend, offering spice, blackcurrants, leather, plums, all rolled up into a powerful knot of intense flavour. Last at Somerfield, there is that Argentine Sangiovese 1999. The texture is lush and ripe, the 17-point fruit is complex and savoury, the finish is enough to turn a Chianti farmer green, especially at £4.29 the bottle. It is one of most quaffable reds I've encountered all year.

So is Santa Julia Tempranillo Oak Reserve 1998. Incredibly well and warmly textured, and gently spicy, it offers outstanding tannins and complex fruit, rating 17 points and costing £5.99. This wine, like those that follow, can be found at Unwins, the homely, almost quaintly southern chain that recently gobbled up Fullers. Vinas del Vero Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16.5 points, £5.49), from Spain, flaunts decent tannins, too, and the fruit, in perfect harmony, progresses in stately yet vividelegance over the tastebuds. Vina Porta Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16 points, £4.99), from Chile, also has some urgent tannic richness and solid, meaty fruit, as does Penta Cabernet Sauvignon/Malbec 1999 (16 points, £3.99), also from Chile. There is compelling richness and controlled tannicity with the Penta wine, along with beautiful texture and ripeness.

The tannins in Chapelle St Marie Syrah 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99) are more savoury, and they are allied to marvellously earthy fruit. With Domaine de l'Arneillaud Cairanne Ctes du Rhne Villages 1999, we move into herbier pastures. There is sensational potency of texture here and compelling depth. It has intense, world-class tannins, and costs only £5.99. Will you uncork the same wine as I did, and rate it 18 points, as I do, if you buy a bottle? With natural cork, there s always a chance you will be disappointed. I do not want disappointed readers.

fields.headline: House of collection
fields.standfirst: Collecting is a passion shared by many, but what happens when it takes over your life? No one better to ask, says Graham Langley, than Katie Thompson and John Keen
fields.trailText: Collecting is a passion shared by many, but what happens when it takes over your life? No one better to ask, says Graham Langley, than Katie Thompson and John Keen.
fields.body:
Once it was bird's eggs, cigarette cards and train numbers. Now, people collect Beanie Babies and TG Green Cornishware, buy specialist magazines, join clubs, go to fairs and surf a galaxy of websites. For some, though, even this level of dedication is not enough. To Kent couple Katie Thompson and John Keen, it is minor-league stuff. They play in the Premier Division: they collect collections.

Every corner of their three- bedroom town-centre semi is stacked with collectibles. The whole house is a visual feast so sumptuous that the eye barely settles on one area before it is drawn to some other corner or shelf. Even talking to Thompson is hard. Eye contact is near impossible. I find myself drifting out of conversation and staring over her shoulder at something that has momentarily captured my attention. She is used to it: "It happens all the time. Even regular visitors find something new each time they call."

Coca-Cola memorabilia is piled against Thunderbirds toys, Avon cosmetics products are displayed in a cabinet beside 30s women's dress gloves. On the floor, baskets holding shoe-trees sit next to ceramic hot-water bottles. The bed is stacked with teddies: no space is wasted when a collection could fill it.

Keen, a station commander in the Kent Fire Service, and Thompson, an administrator for an insurance company, spend all their spare time hunting for collectibles. "We can't pass a secondhand shop, a charity fair or a bric-a-brac seller without paying them a visit," says Thompson with a smile. "We've never bought anything new. Even the house is Edwardian."

The two of them already had some small collections, but the house inspired them and the collecting really took off. "We bought the house from an elderly couple," explains Thompson. "We were attracted by the fact that it hadn't been 'improved'. There was no central heating, the pantry was still in use and the previous owners even left some period furniture, a 30s bedroom suite. We decorated and bought accessories to suit the house."

That was six years ago. Now the collections and the house have become intertwined - one feeding off the other. The kitchen is a museum of early 20th-century cooking, all the items beautifully arranged and echoing the cosy family life of a bygone age. If Listen With Mother played on the radio, it would seem in perfect keeping. There are jelly moulds, a rack of rolling pins arranged as a ladder, blue-and-white Cornishware, pie funnels, lemon squeezers, egg timers and rows of G-clamp mincers (a must for recycling leftovers in austerity-rationing Britain, but still in use in their home).

But while some collectors would keep their possessions strictly for show, Thompson and Keen have a lifestyle to match: "What makes us different from other collectors is that we use our kitchenalia every day," says Thompson. "We have carpet beaters, steam and flat irons and a mangle for wringing out clothes. We don't have heating in the house. In winter, we put on another layer and carry a hot water bottle."

When they bought the house, the kitchen had a 1935 New World gas cooker. Thompson refused to replace it with a modern unit. "I love the authenticity. I use the original cookbook the manufacturers produced, and last year my relatives marvelled when I produced Christmas dinner for 10 from an antique."

The back parlour, or dining room, is dominated by a square table, perfect for playing rummy to the sound of ticking and chimes from the collection of clocks on the mantelpiece. Below the window are a treadle-operated sewing machine, wool winders and a tapestry frame, to help while away those winter evenings. Beside them, in a jardinière, is that staple plant of every Edwardian lounge, the aspidistra. Against one wall, a glass cabinet is packed with the 270 pieces of 50s Royal Doulton Coppice Ware that they use as a dinner service.

Finding authentic wallpaper was probably the most difficult challenge facing the couple. With patterns and styles changing so rapidly, 50s wall coverings are hard to come by. As all good collectors are blessed with patience and serendipity, they persevered. Finally, they struck gold. Keen found rolls of heavily patterned paper in a bargain bin.

By now, the room was almost complete. All that was needed was a trio of mallard ducks to fly up the wall - easy things to acquire.

A recent departure for Keen, and one that gives him considerable satisfaction, are his school visits. Taking a mixed box of kitchen paraphernalia, he will explain how life used to be. He always includes a few "mystery" items to tax the children: they will try to discover the use for strange objects that were designed for long-forgotten chores such as grating a coconut from inside the shell.

This year, the couple has moved into the 21st century by going online. Far from destroying the period culture, it has enhanced it: "I know computers are modern, but they help me access like-minded collectors around the world," says Keen. "Last week, I sold a Quaker Oats figurine to a man in Puerto Rico who I will never meet. I now have contacts on five continents without leaving my home."

Surprisingly, despite the sheer scale of their collections, there is no sense of clutter. Everything has its place, everything, you can well believe, gets individual attention. "It's a duster's nightmare, of course," says Thompson, "but I often look at a piece or a display and think, 'Isn't that lovely?'"

Thompson's sister, Karen, says she thinks the couple's passion amounts to obsession, but is nevertheless prepared to indulge it. There is even, she says, a plus side. "At least they are the easiest relatives in the world to buy Christmas presents for. You can get almost anything and it adds to one of their collections."

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: seized-up machinery
fields.standfirst: 'He climbs ladder, gazes up my chimneys and admires my monstrous cardoons'
fields.trailText: 'He climbs ladder, gazes up my chimneys and admires my monstrous cardoons'.
fields.body:
Old fax machine seized up. Whenever a fax arrives, it should be chopped off by a pair of blades. But the blades are buckled and now instead of chopping, they engage each other in a rusty embrace and will not be separated. Not sure how to deter machinery behaving badly. Vaguely associate coupling dogs and buckets of water. But not sure if it's the answer for (presumably) hermaphroditic fax machine.

"Dulcie? Therre's something stuck up my chimney, dearr! " Aged aunt whispers in tone of voice reserved for indelicate ailments. "It keeps squawking and flapping!" Aunt has been eccentric recently. Perhaps she has secretly laid clutch of phoenix eggs in her fireplace. It would certainly have been so in Greek myth. Life in small town near Swindon falls lamentably short of such excitement. Go to aunt's room to investigate.

As we arrive, startled black bird falls into hearth in tumble of disordered feathers. "It's a black bird!" I cry foolishly. "No, dearr - it's a young jackdaw!" insists Aunt. Always pulling rank when it comes to ornithology. I'm a member of the RSPB, too, and I once bought The Book Of Indian Birds in Hay-on-Wye. One day I shall go to the Himalayan foothills and spot the Haircrested Drongo. That'll put her nose out of joint.

Jackdaw flies madly around the room. Duck, but do not panic. I'm at my best with frantic animals. After 20 years of family life, who isn't? Give me a strange rash in the armpit and I'll rush off and weep tragically in the garden shed. Give me a recipe for lasagne and I'll produce a scale model of Wicken Fen. But give me a maddened jackdaw and, for a moment, I'm adequate. Open window with ostentatious sang-froid.

It said "Believe in yourself!" on my internet horoscope. "Stop all this self-criticism! Release your talents! Take control!" This encouragement comes from Nuga, by the way. Most internet astrologers are Canadian. I'm half-tempted to have an online psychic chat with Nuga. I'm beginning to wonder if Saturn has gone retrograde again. I certainly have. Life seems a bit of a cul-de-sac at the moment.

The jackdaw flitters to the window and escapes. For a moment, as in Remains Of The Day, I long to follow. Cul-de-sac - what on earth does it mean? Cul de sac?

Ransack ancient archives of A-level French, and all I can come up with is, "Does my bum look big in this?"

"I think we need a bird-cowl on the chimney, dearr ." Aunt frets and tuts over her soot-stained tartan blanket. At least it was Black Watch. Wonder if the old fax machine could be recycled as a bird cowl.

I am halfway through dialling the chimney specialists when ex-Spouse emerges scowling from TV room, scratching his arse in unpleasant manner. "I'm going mad with this bloody formication," he snaps. Aunt blushes and runs off. "Like insects crawling all over my skin." Remind him that it is due to too many analgesics, because of too many headaches, the result of too much TV.

Proceed with phone call. Once I have made appointment for chimney man to visit, ex-Spouse embarks on tirade. Anyone would think that my conscientious maintenance of the fabric of our home was some kind of twee feminine piece of self-indulgence. "Dulcie! My deah! What a sweet hat! Where did you get it, darling?" "Oh a frightfully clever little man behind the Brompton Oratory made it for me out of an old fax machine and a bird-cowl. After Ascot I'm sending it to Africa to have it made into an artesian well."

Next day, chimney man calls, climbs ladder, gazes up chimneys from below, and incidentally (quite a gardener, it seems) admires my monstrous cardoons. However, the bad news is, my chimney stack's only held together with jackdaw shit and the lining is disintegrating. He does not mention my chimney breast, for which I am profoundly grateful.

Wonder aloud how on earth we are going to afford the necessary repairs. "Well, you can kiss your beloved Umbria goodbye, for a start," growls ex-Spouse, scratching his thighs quite nastily. Wonder why he is so hard on me and Umbria. Is it because he was my beloved, once? Strange how people who were once lovers, gazing into each other's eyes beneath the willows, eventually turn into a seized-up piece of old machinery.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: An important benefit of insecticide-treated bed nets (Once Bitten, July 22) is that they can be made and distributed by Africans. Most other potential solutions outlined in your article may not be ready for widespread use for some years. fields.body:
An important benefit of insecticide-treated bed nets (Once Bitten, July 22) is that they can be made and distributed by Africans. Most other potential solutions outlined in your article may not be ready for widespread use for some years. The African Medical and Research Foundation has found that nets do more than prevent malaria; their manufacture by local tailors also contributes to the local economy.

Furthermore, AMREF is also working on ways to involve local businesses. Labour-intensive industries supply the insecticide, so that nets can be re-dipped every six months. This keeps the nets effective and gives the companies the benefit of a fit workforce. This exciting partnership between governments, aid agencies and local people makes more bed nets available to the people who need them in their fight against malaria.
Alexander Héroys
Director, AMREF UK
London SW1

Like Alexander Chancellor, and much of the rest of the country, I, too, have to travel to work in the mornings (July 22). The roads are fairly clear and, when I have to use them, the trains are regular, punctual and inwardly clean. I have never suffered the misfortune of having my train cancelled, and my notion of overcrowding is not having a double seat to myself. Of course, I do suffer the misfortune of living in the north.
Adam Stauder
Accrington, Lancs

Tina Arena is seriously overprotected if she thinks that, just because this is the 21st century, there are no causes worth dying for (Questionnaire, July 22). Perhaps she has no sense of justice burning in her? Or takes the sacrifices of previous generations for granted? Or just soulless?
Richard Cussons
richard.cussons@virgin.net

The Prime Minister's understanding of 'touchstone issues', as interpreted by Alexander Chancellor (July 22), throws us into some confusion at the Touchstone project in Bradford. Hitherto, we have unpacked the image in two ways: a) we are about identifying 'gold' from 'dross' in the city, like the old alloy testers; and b) we identify ourselves with Touchstone the fool in As You Like It, remembering St Paul's notion of the fool as an agent of Christian mission. Now we are told that touchstone issues require 'urgent, eye-catching initiatives'. Our problem is that we see issues of inner-city regeneration and inter-faith understanding as urgent, but requiring unspectacular, sustained, costly responses that are rarely eye-catching.
Rev Geoff Reid
Methodist Touchstone Centre, Bradford

Christopher Lloyd obviously hasn't spent enough 'fresh-air' time on his annual visit to Scotland to appreciate the benefits of shelter screening and a short run for cover (Garden, July 22). Presumably, the weather at Great Dixter isn't taxing him enough throughout the rest of the year.
L Moffat
London SE23

John Rostron (Dear Weekend, July 22) challenges my letter of the previous week, and says that co-operation is 'incompatible with natural selection'. Co-operation is a major means of survival, and not only in human societies, although it would be inconceivable for it to occur at the initial stage of life. Sperm will not be observed holding back politely from the egg and murmuring, 'After you', 'No, no, dear boy, after you'.
Joy Wood
London E16

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya is stripped of her qualifications
fields.body:
I work impossible hours, I check the sales at www.whatsonsale.com, I exercise until I'm bone-tired, but nonetheless the tension of remaining asexual has been driving me crazy. One evening, I screamed in frustration. When I stopped, the door bell was ringing. It was Mum (now that I stay in most evenings, she drops off her dog, Redwood, before she goes out).

'You must take singing lessons, dear, you'll ruin your voice like that,' she said. Why not? I checked the Net and found Anyone Can Sing! at www.singtome.com, a CD/cassette programme for $25. However, Mark Baxter at www.voicelesson.com, who has coached Steven Tyler of Aerosmith and other celebs, offers The Singer's Toolbox, 'a video jam-packed with essential information, exercises and tips for EVERY singer' at only $14.95, and he looks good in the picture.

Next time Redwood came, I practised Four Steps To Keep Your Voice Strong. The wretched dog howled, then he began to bark. A moment later, someone was banging at the door. I opened it in a rage - and found myself staring at a vision: smooth, olive skin, slicked-back hair as lustruously black as his eyes, cheekbones you could sharpen a knife on.

'Are you all right?' he asked in a voice as heady as the aroma of jasmine by moonlight. 'Who are you?' I managed to whisper.

'Diego del Fuego, your downstairs neighbour.' My God! I'd seen the posters! The best tango dancer in London! He stepped in, as silent as a panther. A disc bulged in his shirt pocket. He slipped it into my player and took me in his arms. We began to dance...

So, here I am practising steps, following the diagrams at www.cyber-tango.com, waiting and dreaming. Sorry, but I don't think I qualify as celibate any more.

 tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk
 www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk

webTitle: Gays tell of mutilation by apartheid army

fields.headline: Gays tell of mutilation by apartheid army
fields.standfirst: A report detailing castration and electric shocks adds weight to calls for doctors to be held to account over abuses
fields.trailText: A report detailing castration and electric shocks adds weight to calls for doctors to be held to account over abuses
fields.body:
The part-man, part-woman who still calls himself Harold is trying to gather the courage to finally fight back against South Africa's military. It was the army, after all, which abandoned him more than a decade ago, part way through "treatment" to turn him from a male to a female under a discredited policy of trying to "cure" homosexual conscripts.

"I now know that in one sense I was just unlucky. The army had whole gay battalions who they just shunted aside and let be. But if things went wrong and you ended up in the hands of the psychologists then it could get very bad. In my case it began with the electric shocks and only ended after they'd already given me breasts, and then the army said it had abandoned the whole policy," he said.

He is not alone. Thousands of other gays were subjected to electric shock therapy, hormone treatment and chemical castration through the 1970s and 80s, when national service was compulsory for white males and homosexuality was a crime.

Some lesbians were also given "cures".

An as-yet unpublished report, called the Aversion Project, commissioned by gay rights groups and South Africa's medical research council, details the extent of the abuses and is expected to form the basis of demands for corrective treatment, and demands that the doctors behind the "treatments" be held accountable by the medical authorities.

The attempts to "cure" homosexuals began after the creation of the infamous ward 22 at the Voortrekkerhoogte military hospital near Pretoria in 1969. The ward, which ostensibly catered for servicemen with psychological problems, was under the command of an army colonel and psychologist, Aubrey Levin.

Aversion therapy

Dr Levin treated genuinely disturbed patients, but was also keen to take in other soldiers to "cure". His focus was homosexuals and drug users. Commanding officers and chaplains were encouraged to refer "deviants" for "treatment".

At first Dr Levin was convinced he could make heterosexuals out of gay patients, using electroconvulsive aversion therapy. Michael Smith, now a 46-year-old marketing manager in Johannesburg, was sent to ward 22 after Dr Levin forced him to admit he was homosexual in front of his parents. He was then an 18-year-old conscript.

"It was the first time they realised I was homosexual and they were horrified. Dr Levin told them he had a therapy that would 'reorientate' me, so I agreed to the treatment," he said.

The treatment consisted of strapping electrodes to the upper arm with wires running to a dial calibrated from one to 10. Homosexual soldiers were shown pictures of a naked man and encouraged to fantasise, then the power was ratcheted up until the patient could take no more.

The subject was then shown an image of a naked woman.

"When you kind of reached the maximum point and then you'd say 'No, no, no, I couldn't stand it any more', then he would say: 'Now you must think about your girlfriend', and all that sort of off-the-wall statements," said Mr Smith.

"I was actually just completely freaked out and confused. It certainly didn't do much for my impulses of attraction for other boys."

Trudie Grobler, an intern psychologist on ward 22, saw a lesbian subjected to such severe shocks that her shoes flew off.

"It was traumatic. I could not believe her body could handle it," she said.

Dr Levin believed the same treatment could also cure "drug addicts", mostly men caught smoking marijuana. There were also those who simply did not want to serve in the apartheid military. They were tagged as "disturbed".

On arrival at ward 22, "patients" were stripped of their clothes and shoes and given brown pyjamas. The army said that would help to prevent escapes. Every new patient was put on Valium. The ward orderlies carried pistols.

Dr Levin also subjected his patients to narco-analysis or a "truth drug", involving the slow injection of a barbiturate before the questioning began. Dr Levin does not deny its use.

Hard labour

"Narco-analysis was used, I give you that, but it was used in very isolated cases and only to help treat post-traumatic stress. Narco-analysis was used to help get victims to talk about the trauma they suffered," he said.

But former patients say that gays and "drug addicts" were subjected to the treatment to see if they were really "cured". Drug users considered habitual addicts were sent to a hard-labour farm.

Dr Levin, who became chief psychiatrist for the whole South African military, eventually concluded that aversion therapy was a failure and abandoned it in favour of other methods.

One gay soldier, Jean Erasmus, was chemically castrated by Dr Levin at Bloemfontein psychiatric hospital in 1980.

Before he committed suicide last year, Erasmus recorded a tape detailing the broader abuse of homosexuals in the army, including how he was forced by his officers to participate in the gang rape of Angolan women, and how other gay soldiers were given hormone drugs.

"I am quite convinced that quite a few murders of gay people took place which we will never know of, and it was covered up. When people got trigger happy, gays were often the brunt of the bullet."

In practice, the army's treatment of gays was confused. Many found themselves in de facto "gay battalions", according to Mikki van Zyl, a researcher on the Aversion Project report.

"In Uppington, virtually the whole battalion was queer until some general decided this should be broken up. There was one in Grahamstown. There was another in Pretoria. For some of them, these were supportive environments," she said.

Some men joined the army specifically to get a sex change operation. But others were pressured into surgery by military psychologists after other methods failed. The army carried out as many as 50 sex change operations a year.

Lesbians were also offered surgery - one woman is among those left partially altered after the programme was shut down.

The Aversion Project report argues that the doctors concerned broke international law.

"Health workers in the [military] were expected to be loyal first to the state and its ideologies. It meant that some doctors flagrantly ignored terms from the Geneva convention and Tokyo declaration, and certainly showed no accountability to the national professional councils, nor best current practices. The stage was set for human rights abuses of patients under the care of such doctors."

Ms van Zyl says that while the army as an institution should be held accountable, Dr Levin has particular responsibility.

"He left a trail of experiments. He worked in environments where he had captive subjects and he abused them," she said.

Dr Levin emigrated to Canada at about the time he was warned by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in South Africa that he would be named as an abuser of human rights.

Speaking to the Guardian from Canada, where he works at a teaching hospital, he said he left South Africa only because of the high crime rate, and denied the accusations against him.

"Nobody was given electric shock treatment by me. What we practised was aversion therapy. We caused slight, very slight, pain in the arm by contracting the muscles, using an electronic device," he said.

"Nobody was held against his or her will. We did not keep human guinea pigs, like Russian communists; we only had patients who wanted to be cured and were there voluntarily."

webTitle: Suspended jail term for head who hit pupil

fields.headline: Suspended jail term for head who hit pupil
fields.standfirst:
NUT backs appeal as colleagues condemn court

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The National Union of Teachers has pledged to fund an immediate appeal for a south Wales primary school head with 35 years experience in the teaching profession after she was given a three month suspended sentence for slapping an unruly 10-year-old boy across the face.
fields.body:
The National Union of Teachers has pledged to fund an immediate appeal for a south Wales primary school head with 35 years experience in the teaching profession after she was given a three month suspended sentence for slapping an unruly 10-year-old boy across the face.

Marjorie Evans, 56, denied hitting the pupil, but was convicted of common assault earlier this month following a five day trial.

The case has provoked fear and anger among fellow teachers, dozens of whom appeared at Abergavenny magistrates court yesterday to provide support when Mrs Evans appeared for sentencing.

Stipendiary magistrate Vivian Manning-Davies, who had indicated that a prison sentence was among the options he would consider, told the headteacher her actions were "a gross breach of trust" against a child in her care. As headteacher she was charged with setting an example. She had failed the boy, she had failed the school and she had failed her "honourable profession" and the community.

The sentence and the magistrate's words left some supporters in tears. One teacher was ordered from the court for contempt after calling the magistrate's ruling "disgusting".

Mrs Evans, who has been suspended since the incident in September last year, left the court without comment after being ordered to pay prosecution costs of £2,200. The three month sentence is suspended for one year. Governors at the Monmouthshire school, which cannot be named for legal reasons, will meet to consider her position on Monday.

Mrs Evans, described at the earlier hearing as a teacher with a glowing reputation, was found guilty of hitting the boy, who has behavioural difficulties, when he started struggling after being told he could not go to a swimming lesson with classmates.

In evidence, the headteacher said she had restrained the boy after he tried to push, punch and head-butt her, but she denied hitting him. The prosecution argued that she used her open palm to slap the "sullen" child after momentarily losing her self-control. A member of staff claimed the head had later admitted hitting the boy.

The court heard that on the day of the incident the school was facing a staffing crisis and that Mrs Evans had had to leave her office to fill in. The boy, now 11, wanted to go swimming, but had been banned because of earlier bad behaviour.

He told magistrates that Mrs Evans grabbed him and took him outside after an argument over work in the classroom. "She picked my trays up and pushed them against my chest. I pushed her and she fell backwards on to the bench. I was trying to run away and then she slapped me across the face."

Dyfan Jones, a spokesman for NUT Cymru, said Mrs Evans' case highlighted the difficult conditions in which teachers were being forced to work and would hit morale and recruitment in the profession. He said violence was a daily occurrence in schools across Britain.

Teachers were becoming increasingly unhappy about intervening in violent situations unless another adult was present because of the rise in the number of false allegations against them. He said the NUT in Wales had been dealing with allegations against teachers at the rate of one a week since the start of this year. All had been proved either false or malicious.

"The pendulum has swung too far," Mr Jones warned outside court. "Teachers now feel they are treated as if they are guilty unless they can prove their innocence."

The union hopes an appeal hearing could take place by early September.

Deidre Davies, one of those protesting outside the court, said the conviction and sentence was a verdict on the whole teaching profession.

"Teachers in our staff room are absolutely outraged about this. It was the word of a child against the word of a professional. If you can't restrain a pupil without being threatened with a loss of your liberty then what can you do? "

Kim Denning, a maths and special needs teacher at King Henry VIII comprehensive school in Abergavenny, said the case would hit recruitment and could persuade some teachers to consider leaving the profession altogether. "Who wants to put themselves in a position where they can lose their jobs, lose their pension and actually go to prison? It's appalling."

Graham Powell, chairman of governors at Mrs Evans' school, said he was astounded at the outcome and made it clear the head continued to have his personal support. He said he could not reconcile what he knew of the situation with the way it had been dealt with in court.

Gwent police are meanwhile continuing to investigate other allegations that have been made about "inappropriate physical and emotional handling of pupils" at the school.
